The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.

div.head: To His GRACE THE Duke of Beauford, &c.
div.p:
AS I have long had an Ambition of preenting ome Eay to Your Grace's Patronage, I was likewie enible that no Performance (which was entirely my own) could, without Preumption, apire to that Honour: But this Addres comes Arm'd with a double Apology; not only the fix'd Reputation of the
Work in the Original, but on account of the Tranlation it elf, being half perform'd by a Peron of Quality and Judgement. By whoe untimely Death we were deny'd the Happines of his farther Progres, and I was prevail'd with to think that the World would rather dipene with my coure finihing of the Piece, than loe the part which he had o well begun. Beide the Tetimonies of the Learned for my Author, it is yet to be added, That he was not only the Firt who attempted this way of Writing, but the Bet. The Caandra and Cleopatra of the French were Scions from this Stock, nor hall we envy them the Reputation which thoe Authors
eem'd chiefly to deign, the diverion of the Ladies. Heliodorus has as well contriv'd for their favour, yet o as to make the Amour ubordinate to Intruction, and every where an occaion of dipening that Learning and Experience, with which he was o wonderfully furnihed. The Philoophy and Politicks deliver'd in the Romance of Barclay have render'd it worthy the perual of the greatet Stratemen; yet, on the firt view, we hall find the Argenis to be but a Copy of Chariclea. But after all his maxims of Conduct, and Examples of Vertue, methinks I ee the Authors Genius tremble to come under your Graces Inpection, who have in
Practice o far excell'd the mot perfect Images that he could feign. Of what Importance your unhaken Loyalty, Indutry, and Prudent Management, has always been towards the Happines of this Nation, is bet known to perons of your own high Sphere, where your Grace is placed a Star of the firt Magnitude. But Your more immediate Influence for the publick Safety, in the late eaon of our Extremity, was o manifet, that thouands were Spectators of its Operation. The proud Invader himelf acknowledg'd his meaures to be broken in their Foundation, by your preence in Britol, the main Fortres of his Hopes; from which he was obtructed
by Your Grace's matchles Interet and Conduct. For a Parallel to this Service, we mut run up to your own great Ancetor, whoe Name hall be Sacred to Poterity as long asMarques of Worceter's Seat, lat Garrion held out for King Charles I. Ragland Catle hall have one Stone left upon another.

I have too jut a ene of Your Grace's Character to attempt your Panegyrick; yet, in Gratitude, I am obliged to ay, That while Your Grace is blet with Qualifications to adorn the Noblet Court, it is Your peculiar Glory to have Magnificence and Condecenion to charm all Mankind. That Clemency I mut make my Sanctuary for this Addres, and
leave Your Encomium to ome more able Genius, while the height of my Ambition is to ubcribe my lef.

closer.signed: Your Grace's Mot Devoted Humble Servant, N. TATE.

div.head: Tetimonies of Eminent Perons, Ancient and Modern, concerning the following Work.

q.p: HEliodorus the Author of that Ingenious Piece, call'd The Aethiopick Hitory, which he o prized, that he choe rather to loe his Bihoprick, than conent to the Burning of his Book, which a Provincial Synod had adjudged to the Fire. A piece indeed of rare contexture and neat contrivance, without any touch of looe or lacivious Language, honest and chat affection being the ubject of it, not uch as Old or Modern Poets hew us in the Comedies or other Poems: for here we have no Incetious mixtures of Fathers and Daughters: no Pandorim of Old Nures: no uneemly action pecified, where heat of Blood and opportunity do meet: nor indeed any one paage unworthy of the chatet Ear.

THE Stile is Florid without Affection; the Variety of Councils, Accidents and Events contained therein is wonderful; exhibiting mot Images of humane Life, o that it may be read by all with equal Profit and Pleaure.

THE reaon why Learned Men have thought The Aethiopian Hitory of Heliodorus, worthy the perual of Poterity, is very evident, the deign being equally accommodated to the Instruction and Diverion of the Reader. In which, beides the Elegance of Stile, not only changes of Fortune, but examples of Vertue are et forth.

I Recommend The Aethiopian Hitory of Heliodorus, as the mot abolute Image of all humane Affections; a perfect Example of Conjugal Love, Truth and Contancy being wonderfully drawn in the Characters of Theagenes and Chariclea. I pas over the Beauty, Contrivance, and Artifice in the expreion. Of all Greek Authors that ever came into my hands, I mut
affirm him to be the mot pleaant and will venture to ay the mot Learned. For the Truth of his Tale I leave it to himelf, but for the probability it may compare with any Hitory. For the Argument which is various, I can aver it to be compleat; foramuch as it is, beides the continued pleaantnes of the Tale, full of admirable turns and urpries; he has mot skilfully given the Comography of many places; laid open the ecret caues of Nature in many Intances; learnedly decribed the Rites and Cutoms of many Nations; the nature of divers Mountains, Rivers, Stones, Herbs, and Regions of Aegypt and Aethiopia epecially, Countrys the leat known; mingling all with uch beautiful digreions, that in the whole Work he hath left nothing imperfect or what might give offence to the mot Critical Reader.

THis Work is o furnihed with widom in Councils and Government of humane Affections, uch Dicipline and knowledge in all circumtances of War; uch Inconstances of Fortune and variety of humane affections, that it eems wholly derived from the puret Fountains of Eloquence.
HEliodorus the Phoenician, the most Eloquent and chat Writer of Loves; mot Delightful and Artificial in the management of his Story.

HEliodorus the mot Elegant Author, in whoe Volumn are many Sentences, Grave, Solid, Ethick, Political, Oeconomick. How many things therein ubervient to antiquity no where ele delivered. This is atteted by divers amongt the Ancients, viz. in the Melia of Antony, and the Centuries of Maximus: to instance in modern Authors would be endles. I will mention Barnabas Brionius intead of all: Whooever reads his Treatie concerning the Perian Principality, will eaily find how much he was obliged to this Author.

div.p: LICENSED, RO. L'ESTRANGE.

div.head: THE AETHIOPIAN HISTORY.
The Firt Book.
div.p:
THE break of day had now dipered the darknes, and the Sun with earliet beams, guilded the ummits of the Mountains; when a Troop of Men that had no Living but by Robberies, and Rapine, appeared upon the Promontory that elevates it elf over one of the Mouths of Nilus, named the Heracliotick: Being aembled, they made a tand to take view of the Sea, that lay like a vat Valley underneath them; but when they aw nothing that preented hope of Prey (all the Ships they dicovered, ayling off to the Main) they cat their Eyes towards
the neighbour Shoar, and encountered this Object.

A Ship at Anchor, no men in her, yet heavy laden, as might eaily be judged afar off, for he was of that burthen, as he drew Water to the third Deck. The Shoar was covered with a Maacre of men, ome dead, others were but half dead, and the parts of their Bodies that yet panted, gave aurance to the beholders, it was no long time ince the Fight was ended; nor were thee the Marks of a jut Quarrel, they were the aid Relicks of an unfortunate Feat. There were Tables that tood yet full furnihed, and ome that were overturned betwixt the Arms of thoe that ate at them; others lay like Tomb-tones over the Dead that had (as it is probable) hid themelves under them: Many Bowls and Pots were cat down, and many yet held in their hands that had taken them either to drink, or to cat at their Enemies heads; for the uddennes of the Mutiny, and the neceity, had taught them a new way, and (intead of Darts and other offenive Weapons) armed them with the Cups they drank in. They lay, one cloven with an Axe, another his Brains beat out with Shells that lay ready on the Sands, ome bruied to pieces with Leavers, many burnt with Coals of Fire, and divers others, diverly Murthered; but the mot were Shot to Death with Arrows. In um, Fortune in a little time had produced trange variations, contaminating the Wine with Blood, changing the chearfulnes
of a Feat into the horrors of a Battle, promicuouly mixing their Meat with Wounds, and Drinking Healths with Death; preparing uch a Stage for the Aegyptian Thieves to be Spectators; but from thoe heights they could not undertand the Play; for they plainly aw a defeat, but no Maters of the Field; an abolute Victory, but no Spoils taken; a Ship unmann'd, but ele untouched; hulling in that dangerous Road, as if in full peace, and in the midt of the greatet ecurity in the world.

But though ignorant of the Caue, they were greedy of the Prey; and reolved to make themelves the Conquerors: So they marched forward to the pillage; and when they were not far from the Ship, and near to the dead Bodies, there was preented to their ene, a ight of greater atonihment than the former.

It was a young Lady, itting upon a Rock, of o rare and perfect a Beauty, as one would have taken her for a Goddes, and though her preent miery oppret her with extreamet grief, yet in the greatnes of her affliction, they might eaily perceive the greatnes of her Courage: A Laurel crown'd her Head, and a Quiver in a Scarf hanged at her back; he reted her left Arm upon her Bow, and let her Hand carelely hang down upon her right Thigh; he leaned on her other Arm, laying her Cheek upon her hand, and fixing her eyes upon a young Gentleman that lay not far ditant from her; he was covered in his wounds, and
now began to raie himelf a little, as if awaking out of a deep leep, almot of Death if elf; yet uch a tock of Beauty hined in his Face, and the Blood that rained down o etoff the whitenes of his Skin, as made him hew mot lovely; the pain he felt, eemed to weigh down his Eye-lids, and the Beauty of the Lady, to attract and open them.
He had no ooner recollected his Spirits, and carce breath'd, but with a languihing voice he pronounced thee words.

p.hi: Sweetet, Is it true that I yet behold you Living, or (perihing in the execution) have you encreaed the number of the dead? can you not, not even in Death be ravihed from me, but will your hadow be yet a loooker on, and harer in my Fortunes?

div.p: It is from you reply'd the Maid that I expect my Fortune, Life or Death; this you here ee (hewing him a Steeletto in her lap) hath yet not done its office, hindered by the happy igns of your recovery.

This aid, he leaped from the Rock, and the Thieves upon the Mountains urprized with fear and atonihment ran to hide themelves behind the Buhes: For he appeared more Divine when he was upon her Feet; her Arrows in her Quiver clahing as he tepped, her Robe (that was Cloth of Gold) glittering in the Sun, and her Hair that lowedunder her Coronet (like the Prietees of Bacchus) reaching almot to the ground. One aid he was a Goddes, and ure the Goddes Diana, or Iis the Patrones of their Country;
others conceived her to be a Votares to ome God, that inpired with divine fury had made o great a laughter.
This while the Maid running to the Gentleman, cat herelf upon his Body, wept, kit him, wiped his wounds, and imbraced him o cloely as if he could hardly be aured he had him in her Arms.

The Aegyptians oberving this, preently altered their Opinions; What, aid they, are thee the actions of a Goddes? do Goddees kis dead Men? and with o much commieration! So encouraging one another, they marched on, and found the Lady dreing the young mans wounds, and coming cloe behind her, did not dare to attempt any thing, not o much as to peak to her; but the noie they had made, and their hadows cat before her Eyes, moved her to turn her Head; and when he had een them, he again declined her Face; and applyed her elf to bind up her friends wounds, not o much as the leat daunted with the unuual Apect, and colour of thee armed Aegyptians: So powerful is incere affection, as it depies all other pleaing or dipleaing things, and tranports our whole care and thoughts to the object we love dearet: But when the Thieves paed on, and tood in front before her, and eemed as if they would attempt omething, he lifted up her Eyes again, and eeing them o black and ugly.

If you be (he aid) thee dead mens Spirits, you
do us wrong to trouble us, ince mot of you with your own hands lew one another; if any of you fell by ours, it was but in our jut revenge, to repell the violence you offered to my Chatity; but if ye be living men, I hould take you to be Thieves; if o, you come mot opportanely: Free us, I beeech you, from thee evils that oppres us, kill us, and put and end to all our miery: Thee paionate wodrs he pake with as ad an Accent.

But they (neither undertanding her words nor meaning) left her with the wounded Gentleman, not putting any urer guard upon them then their own weaknes; and hating to the Ship, they unladed her, every man carrying out as much Gold, Silver, Precious Stones and Silks, as they were able to bear, neglecting other Commodities (tho' rich and various) and when they had every one as much as atisfied their Avarice, they lay'd it down upon the hoar, making it up into packs, and dividing it, not by reaon, or after the jut value of the things, but equalling them by weight, reerving for the lat, to reolve what to do with the young Gentleman and the Lady.

Mean while there appears upon the Mountains a econd Company, two riding before them as their Captains; thee were no ooner perceived by the former, but without preparing for the fight, or daring to take with them any part of of the poil, let it might give occaion to the Enemy to purue; the fear that trook their hearts, made them take their heels with the greatet agility
that was poible, for they were but Ten, and thoe they aw coming were twice that number. Thus the Lady was twice taken, and yet not Prioner. Now thee others, though they had an extream longing to be at the pillage, and had already devoured it in their hopes, yet the Apprehenion, that troubled their Spirits, not knowing the caue of thee events, retained them for a while; for they imagined the firt Thieves had made that horrible Slaughter; and oberving the Lady in all the dangers that threatned her, to be no more afraid than if there had been no uch thing, careful only of the young man's wounds, that eemed to pain her more, than if they had been her own; they remained mightily amazed, as well at the generoity of her courage, and rarenes of her Beauty, as at the delicate hape and exact tature of the wounded young man; who began to reume his natural Colour: After they had long conidered, their Captain tept forth, and took her by the hand, commanding her to rie and go with him; but he that undertood not his Language, and yet doubted what he meant, drew the young Gentleman along (nor would he part with her) and etting her Steeletto to her Breat, threatned to kill her elf, if they might not go together: The Captain undertanding her more by action and igns, than by her words, and hoping if the young Gentleman recovered, he would erve him in deigns of higher Nature; made his Page alight, and he alo
dimounting, caued the two Captives to be mounted on his Hores, and himelf etting forward on foot, whilt his men trued up the Pillage, went with the Prioners to help them, if happily their weaknes hould not uffer them to help themelves, nor did their Captivity want a Glory, to ee the Conqueror humbled to the Conquered, and to be waited on by him that had them in his power: So great is the Appearance of Nobility, and Magick of a Beauty, as to ubdue the inhumane Nature of Thieves, and to mollifie the hearts of the mot Barbarous. When they had now paed along the Sea Shoar, about half a quarter of a Mile, leaving the left hand-way, they turned uphill, and climbing over, doubled their paces, to arrive by day-light, at a Lake on the other ide the Mountain.

This part of the Country is by the Aegyptians named the Bucolia, or Pature, in which there is a Valley that receives the Innundations and diburdenings of Nilus, growing into a Lake of an infinite deepnes in the midt, but near the ides it is but hallow and marih: Here the Aegyptian Thieves live together with a kind of policy, and oberving a certain form of a Republick: Some dwell in Cabbins or Huts, builded upon little pots of Earth, that rie above the water in divers places of the Lake; others live in Boats, that they ue both for ferrying over, and habitations for themelves and wives, who are there brought a-Bed;
their Infants firt uck the Mothers-milk, and within a while are weaned, and ue to eat Fih, got in the Lake, and broyled in the Sun; when a little one deires to go, his Mother tyes a Cord to his Foot, that reacheth no farther than the Boat, committing him to this new guide.

Thus all that are born within the Lake, account it for their Nure and Country, and hold it as a trong protection to their Robberies, and to that end uch kind of people flock hither from all parts; for the water erves them for a wall, and the great quantity of Reed and Cane that grows about the borders, tands before them as their Bulwark, and therein they have cut out o many ways, intermazed one within another (which their practice makes eaie to them) and cuts off all hope of incurion from the Enemy.

The Sun now declining to the Wet, the Captain and the ret of his company arrived at this Lake, and dimounting the two Prioners, carried the Prey aboard their little Boats; preently all their Fellows that had tayed at home, ome from one ide of the Fenns, and ome from the other, came running to meet their Captain, and received him as their King, doing him all humble reverence; but when they had viewed the riches of the Prize, and the divine form of the Maid, they conceived their companions had robbed ome Temple, and taken away the Prietes, or the living Image of ome Goddes; o with a thouand glorious Praies, elevating their Captains Valour
to the Heavens, they all conducted him to his place of reidence, which was a little Iland cut off from theirs, and reerved only for him, and ome few appointed to be always near his Peron: Being landed here, he commanded the multitude hould retire home, and not fail to attend him the next morning: Himelf with ome few of his Friends made a hort Supper, then committed the two Prioners to the cutody of a young Grecian (taken by the ame Thieves not long before) to the end he might erve for their interpreter; and giving him order they hould be lodged in a Tent joyned to his own; charged him to dres the Gentlemans wounds, and ee that none hould do injury to the Lady, whilt he wearied with the labour of his Journey, and the care of preent buines went to ret.

But when ilence reigned in all the Iland, about the firt watch of the Night, the Maid being alone, ued her olitude, and abence of her keeper, as an occaion given her to eae her Spirits with complaining, the calm of the Night exciting her ad thoughts, and being able to ee nothing that might divert her mind; when he had deeply ighed to her elf (for he was eparated by command of the Captain, Theagenes lying with Knemon, and he reting on a poor low Palate) weeping as if her heart would break.

Oh Apollo (he aid) how much greater is our punihment than our offence! cannot all our pat mieries extinguih thy revenge? We are deprived of the
weet preence of our Friends and Parents, we have been taken by Pyrates, we have been toed at Sea by Tempets, and a thouand times in danger of our lives, we are now at Land a prey to Thieves: Alas are we yet reerved to be more tormented? Where at lat wilt thou end the Progres of our Mieries? To dye with a noble Fame, were a weet death; but if any Villain hall offer to force me, which my Theagenes never yet attempted, with my own Hands I will prevent him, and trangle this betraying Beauty, keeping my Virtue to adorn my Epitaph, whilt thou Apollo halt be called the mot cruel Judge.

She would have proceeded, but Theagenes thus interupted her; Ceae my dearet, my Soul Cariclea: tis true you have reaon to complain, but you provoke the God more than you do believe; we ought not to contradict the will of Heaven; by Prayers not Injuries, that which is greater than our elves, mut be appeaed. Tou ay true, replyed Cariclea, but pray how do you? Better he aid, ince Evening; I thank this Gentleman, he hath applyed that to my wounds, hath much awaged their inflammation. You hall find your elf more eaie to Morrow Morning (added their Kepper) For I will gather you uch an Herb, as hall heal your wounds at the third dreing; I have tryed the properties of it by many experiments, ince my elf was taken Prioner here; for none of my Captains men have ever come home wounded, but in a little time I have effected their cure by the ame means; and do not you wonder I take
uch particular care of you, for your Fortune repreents my own; I mut need pity a Grecians miery, that am my elf a Grecian. A Grecian, (Oh Immortal Gods! cryed the two Prioners for joy) I am both by Language and Birth. This yet (aid Theagenes) gives us ome breathing pace from our afflictions; but how may we call you? my Name is Knemon. Of what part of Greece? Of Athens. Do us the Favour I beeech you, to let us know your Fortune: Forbear (aid Knemon) do not make my woes to bleed afreh, nor let not me with abundance of my Evils increae yours; neither would the whole Night uffice for the Narration; and you after your many Labours had need of ret and leep: But they initing, and telling him that it would not be a little comfort to them, to hear of chances like their own: Knemon begins thus;

This good Son (he aid) o full of Piety towards me; our common Child, whom I have loved (I call the Gods to witnes) more than your elf, upecting me by ome ignes to be with Child, which I have concealed from you till I hould be better aured of it my elf, took the occaion of your abence, and when
I advertied him of his duty, and perwaded him to Temperance, and to abtain from Drinking and wanton Coures, for I knew his irregularities in that kind, though I would not tell you o much, fearing to incur the upicion of a Step-mother: Whilt I was thus dicouring with him alone, leat be hould be too much ahamed; I bluh to tell you the ret, he purned me with his Foot, and hath made me in this cae as you now ee.

My Father hearing this, without peaking to me, or giving me leiure to defend my elf, not believing he that had witneed o tender an affection to me, would now bely me; having found me in my Chamber, he et upon me, beating me with his own hands, and cauing his Servants to to courge me with rods in his preence: I being not able to imagine for what caue they thus abued me; but when the firt motion of his choller was pat, Father (aid I) yet now at leat (ince before you would not uffer me) let me know the reaon of your dipleaure, and what offence I have committed to deerve this cruel Punihment. Diembling Traytor, he replyed, wouldt thou have me to be the Hitorian of thy Villanies? and turning away from me, hatned to Damoeneta; but he (for he had not yet atisfied her Cruelty) lay'd a new train for me.

She had a Maid called Thisbe that played excellently well upon the Lute, a handom Maid; her he commands to love me, and preently he
obeys her, and he that had oftentimes before rejected my uit to her, began now to tempt me with her looks and getures, in uch ort that my Vanity believed I was grown Beautiful on the uddain: To conclude, I admitted her to my Bed, which he continued to viit often; and when I warned her he hould take heed let her Mitres hould perceive her: Lord (aid he) how imple you are! if you think it uch danger for me, a Slave, and bought with Money, to be taken thus; what punihment do you judg my Mitres deerves, who boating her elf nobly Born, and having a Bed-fellow by the Laws of Matrimony; Latly, knowing Death to be the reward propoed for her in, yet fears not to commit Adultry. Oh! ay not o (I reply'd) for I can by no means believe it. Yes if you pleae (aid Thisbe) I will bring you where you may take the Adulterer with her: I having told her he hould with all my Heart; I will, he anwered, both for your ake, that have been extreamly injured by her, and for my own, that dayly uffer under her vain Jealouie. Therefore (if you have courage) prepare your elf to take him: I having promied her I would not fail, he preently retired her elf. The third night after, he came and waked me from my leep, telling me the Adulterer was within, and my Father by a uddain neceity called into the Country, which he knowing before, had made him this appointment, and that it was now time for my revenge, and wihed
me to take my Sword let the Villain hould ecape me; I did o, and carrying it naked in my hand, Thesbe going before me with a Light, I came to the Chamber Door, which I found locked, and aw through the crevies, the glympe of a Lamp that burned within: Tranported with impatience, I broke open the Door, and running in, cryed out aloud, Where is this Villain, the Gallant, Inamorato of this Illutrious Lady, that is famed to be o Virtuous? And then approaching with a full intent to Nayl them both to the Bed; I aw my Father (Oh good Gods!) who had leapt out in his Shirt, and now was upon his knees before me; And oh Son (aid he) retrain a little your paion; take pity of your Father; pare thee gray Hairs, that have given you your breeding: We have done you wrong, 'tis true, but it is not of that Nature, you hould purue us to the Death; uffer not your Fury to tranport you, nor tain your Hands in your Fathers Blood: In thee, and other lamentable Words, he pleaded; whilt I (as if trook with a Clap of Thunder) tood ilenced, and atonihed; looking round about the Bed and Chamber, not knowing either what to ay or do, wondring what became of Thesbe, that I know not how, had lided away from me. In this amaze my Sword fell out of my Hand, and Damoeneta, ran preently and catched it up: My Father now eeing he had ecaped the danger he apprehended, laid Hands upon me, and commanded I hould be bound.
Damoeneta periting to exaperate him againt me; Did not I tell you this? that you hould take heed of this Youth, that when occaion was offered he would have ome deign; I knew it by his Face, I aw into his Heart: Indeed you told me o (he aid) but I could not believe you: Then pinnion'd (as I was) he commanded me to be taken away, and would not give me liberty to peak: Next day in the morning, he produced me to the People in my Bonds, and cating dut upon his head,

It was not to this Hope Athenians, that I bred this Child (aid he) but promiing to my elf he would one day, be a upport and tay to my feeble Age; willing out of uch Fortunes as the Gods betowed upon me, to render him accompliht in all orts of Virtues I provided able Maters to intruct him in the Liberal Arts; and when he had tated the Elements of Letters, caued his Name to be inrolled in the Regiter of my Family, made him a Free-man of your Town, that Living under your Laws, he might enjoy your Priviledges; and o much I have loved him, that I have made my whole Life a trouble for his ake; but he forgetful of all thee Benefits, firt did me injury in his cruel uage of this my Lawful Wife; and latly entred my Chamber in the night, Armed with his Sword, and was only o far from being a Paracide, as Fortune tood between us, a uddain Terror making his Sword fall out of his hand. I now fly to your Jutice, and have here brought him before you; for though by the Laws, with my own hands
I might have killed him, yet I would not; eteeming it better that be hould receive his punihment from you, than an unfortunate Father pot his hands in the Blood of his own Son.

Speaking thee words, he wept; and Damoeneta eemed to take on extreamly, calling me mierable, that hould die thus; jutly indeed, but yet before my time, and that ure ome Devil had poet me, and put it into my Mind, to attempt my Fathers Life; her Tears bearing fale Witnes of her Sorrow, and confirming my accuation as Truth: And when I beeeched they would permit me to peak, a Notary tepping in, put this trict quetion to me; Whether I had not entered my Fathers Chamber in the Night, with my Sword naked? I did enter (I reply'd;) but hear me, and I will tell you how; preently the People clamoured out, and aid, I ought not to be uffered to peak more; ome cryed tone him; others bid the Hangman hould take me, and throw me down headlong from the Precipice: During this time of their Ditractions in Opinion, I cryed, oh Step-mother! alas I dye for my Step-mother, my Step-mother condemns me without a hearing! Thee words touched the Hearts of many, and made them upect the Truth; but yet I could not be heard; for the People were in that tumult and trouble, as it was not poible to appeae them: When they came to numbring of the Votes, they found about One Thouand Seven Hundred that condemned me to Death, one
half whereof adjugded me to be toned, and the other, to be cat headlong from the Rock; there remained yet about another Thouand, that lacking omething of their Severity, out of the Supicion they had conceived of my Mother-in-Law, condemned me to perpetual Banihment; and it was concluded according to their Sentence; for notwithtanding they were the minor part, both the others being joyned, yet take the firt everally, and a Thouand made the greatet number: Thus was I exiled from my Country, and my Fathers Houe.

But the wicked Damoeneta did not long ecape unpunihed by the Gods, that hate Impieties; how it was you hall know hereafter: Now it is time you hould ret, for the night is far pent, and you had need of a great deal of leep: Oh now you will add to our miery, reply'd Theagenes, if you leave this wicked Woman thus: Hear then (aid Knemon) ince your will is o;

After my Judgment was pronounced, I went down to the Port we call Pyreum, and lighted on a Ship that was bound for the Iland of Egina, knowing I had ome Friends by my Mothers ide, that lived there: When I was landed, and had found out thoe I enquired for, I paed my time there a while, with indifferent good content: I had not tayed there pat Twenty Days, but walking as my cutom was upon the Haven, I perceived a Bark making in; therefore taying a little to ee from whence it was, the Planks were carce
laid down, but a Paenger came running to me, and imbraced me; it was Charias, one of my old Acquaintance: Oh Knemon (aid he) I bring you joyful News! you are revenged of your Enemy, Damoeneta is dead: You are welcom dear Friend Charias (I reply'd) but why do you pas over your good News o lightly, as if it were ome ill accident? Relate the manner I beeech you, for I fear he dyed by ome unuual way, and ecaped the Death and Shame he deerved: Jutice aid Charias, hath not altogether foraken us, as Heiod thought; but though ometimes it conniveth at the wickednes of men, and eems as if it lept upon their Sins, and for a time deferring to punih them, yet at length it overtakes them; as it hath done the wicked Damoeneta: The Particulars whereof, came to my knowledge, out of the Familiarity that had pat betwixt my Self and Thesbe, who concealed nothing from me; for when the decree of unjut Banihment had pat againt me, your Father Penitent for his act, withdrew himelf from the company of men, and retired to his Grange Houe in the Country, there eating his own Heart, as the (Poet ays) he reolved to pend the remainder of his Days; but uddainly all the Furies of Hell began to torment your Mother-in-Law; he loved you now in your abence, more than ever, and did nothing but complain inceantly, deploring your Fortune, but indeed lamenting for her own: No word paed from her mouth but Knemon, her Sweetet, her
Soul Knemon? In fine, her affliction grew to that exces, all the Town took notice of it, and the Neighbours, and Noble Ladies her Friends, that came to viit her wondered exceedingly to ee a Mother-in-Law, witnes uch a Motherly affection, much commending her, and endeavouring to comfort her the bet they could; but he told them her evil was greater than to be cured by perwaions, that they knew not the caue of her orrows, not what tings were in her Heart: And ever as he came to her elf, he complained of Thesbe; that he knew not how to erve her purpoe; How nimble he was (aid Damoeneta) to enterprize and execute a malice! he knew not how to make me enjoy the pleaure of my Love, but he knew how to deprive me of my Joy; in an intant, e'er I could think, e'er he would give me time to change my Mind. By thee, and other words and actions, he accidently hewed the dipleaure he conceived againt Thesbe, and that he meant her no good: But Thesbe (finding her indignation, and eeing he was lot in paion; dipoed by her ill Nature, to lay ome train for her, and mad both with Love and Anger) reolved to anticipate her, and by laying a Plot for her, to preerve her elf; and coming to her, Mitres (aid he) What Detiny, Enemy to your Contentment, and my Fidelity, makes you accue your Servant? I have always, and even in this lat Act, obeyed your will; if any thing ucceeds not to your wih, you mut blame Fortune, not me; yet if you
pleae to command me, I hall tetifie a great deal of affection, and no little indutry, to find out a way to your content.

(Alas he reply'd) How is that poible, ince he that only can content me is o far ditant, and o much Sea and Land is interpoed betwixt us? the unexpected Lenity of his Judg was my death, for had they covered him in a Monument of Stones, they had with him buried and extinguihed my Flame; for when there is no more hope, there is no more care, or ence of pain: Now methinks I till ee him, methinks I till hear him object againt me my unjut deceits, and upbraid me with them, and I bluh to think my elf in his preence; ometimes I think I may yet enjoy him, and reolve to go my elf and find him, in what part of the World oever he remains; this ets me all on Fire, this makes me Mad; and jutly, Oh you Gods I uffer! For why did I plot againt him, and rather not ue him kindly? Why was I an Enemy, and not rather a Suppliant at his Feet? had he not reaon to give me one refual? I was a Stranger to him; he was afraid to tain his Fathers Bed; it might be time, acquaintance, and my expreions to him, might have won him: But I, crueller than a wild Beat, not as if I had been a Suiter, but a Mitres, that had the abolute Empire of his Will, thought trange he hould not obey me; and in my unhappy rigour perecuted him for depiing Damoeneta, that had
not Beauty equal to his merit: But my Thesbe, what content was that you pake of?

Madam (he reply'd) the World believes that Knemon hath obeyed his Sentence, and hath left the Town and Territory of Athens; but I know (that ever ince that time I have been thoughtful to procure your quiet) he lyeth concealed at a Friends Houe here in Town: You have heard of Arinoe, the Flutenit, and her Familiarity with him; he after his diater, received him into her Houe, promiing to go along with him; and till he can furnih her elf with Necearies for the Voyage, he keeps him in ecret at her Houe. But Demoeneta could not now refrain to interrupt her, aying, Oh bleed Arinoe! both in the former Felicity thou hat tated, and that occaion offers thee the preent happines to exile thy elf with him: But what doth this concern me?

Oh greatly Mitres (reply'd Thesbe) for I will fain to be deperately in Love with him, and pray Arinoe, that is my old Acquaintance, and my fellow Muician, to give me one nights lodging with him in her place; this being obtained, I will make over my right to you; you hall peronate Arinoe, and he hall take you for her; for I will look he hall have a Cup more than ordinary in his Head, and the Chamber hall be dark; and then I hope when your Deires are obtained, your Torments will ceae, for the end of Love is enjoying: But if your Fire hould kindle again, as I hope it will not, we mut make a econd Navigation (as they ay) and it again in
Council; mean time let us have a care of our preent Buines.

Demoeneta approving, and praiing Thesbe, conjured her to be ecret, and expeditious; he (deiring but one day to dipatch it in) went preently to Arinoe, and asked her if he knew not Teledemus? he aid yes; pray thee (aid Thesbe) make me beholding to thee, to receive us this night into thy Houe; for I have promied him a nights Lodging; he will come firt, and I will follow aoon as ever I have got my Mitres to Bed. Arinoe conenting, Thesbe ran preently to meet her Mater, walking olitary in his Grounds, and thus pake to him.
div.q:
Sir, I come to you the Accuer of my elf, and to receive uch punihment as you hall pleae to inflict upon me: I have deprived you of your Son, not as a Principal, yet as an Acceary; for when I found that my Mitres lived not as he ought, but wronged your Bed, fearing if it hould be dicovered by any other but my elf, I hould incur the Supition of being her Bawd; and epecially pitying you, that o much loved and doted on her, yet had no better recompence; not daring to peak freely to you, I reolved to unfold the truth to my young Mater; and coming to him in the night that none might ee me, I told him my Mitres abued your Honour, and did receive an Adulterer to your Bed; but your Son (being then as you know incened againt her) undertanding me that I aid the Adulterer was with her in your Bed, carried away with rage, catcht up his Sword, and though
I cryed to him to tay, yet he regarded me not, but thinking I had repented me of my Dicovery, ran like a mad man to your Chamber; the ret you know: And now you may, if you pleae, purge your elf before your Son, though abent; and revenge your elf of her that hath done injury to you both: For I will this Night hew you Damoeneta, lying with her Adulterous Friend, in the Houe of a Stranger in the Suburbs.
div.p: If you do it, aid Aritippus, I will reward you with your Liberty, and it may be, when I ee my Enemy punihed, I may again take Comfort, and chae away the orrow, that in depair of my Sons repeal, hath tormented my Old Age. I have doubted this a long time, and had ever ome hadow of it in my apprehenion; yet becaue I wanted manifet Proofs, I reted quiet; But what is to be done?
You know (aid he) the Monument of the Epicureans; there do you tay for me in the Evening: Having thus poken, he returned to Damoeneta.
Madam (aid he) dres your elf preently, curl your Hair, and put on your bet Jewels; for now your deires approach to their effect.

She intantly made her elf ready, and Thesbe leading her the way, when they came near to Arinoes Houe, he prayed her to tay there a little, and running in to Arinoe, intreated her to go over the way, and let them have the Houe to themelves, for her Friend was bahful, newly
initiated in the Rites of Venus, and would bluh if he did ee any but her elf: Arinoe conented, and Thesbe preently returning to her Mitres, brought her in, and having got her to Bed, took away the Light, for fear (he aid) Knemon hould know of her coming to the Iland of Egina (for there he is uppoed to remain) and wihing her to content her Deires, without peaking a word, told her he would bring the young Gentleman to her, that was but drinking with a Neighbour hard by: Then he made hat to meet her Mater Aritippus, in the appointed place; and as he came along with him, warned him to be ure to take the Adulterer.

Aritippus followed her in, and by the Light of the Moon, that hined a little into her Chamber, with much ado he found the Bed: And have I taken thee (he aid) thou Enemy of the Gods? Whilt he was peaking, Thesbe ran to the Chamber Door, and making a noie, cryed out, Oh wretched! What ill luck have we? the Adulterer is ecaped, and therefore Mater take heed; you know what former mitake was made by your Son: Fear not me, reply'd Aritippus, I have the wicked Woman fat; I deire no more, and o drew her with him towards the City; but he conidering (as it is probable) the evils that encompaed her, the frutrating of her expectation, the ignominy of her Fault, and the punihment ordained by the Laws, for hame to be urprized, and in pight to be deluded; when he
came right againt the Pit, in the Academy (where you know our Captains (according to the cutom of the Country) ue to acrifice to the Hero's, or Demy-Gods, for the properity of the Town) She brake from him with uch a fury; as the Old Man feeling his trength unable to reit, was forced to let her go; and no ooner out of his hands, but he leapt into the Pit, and brake her Neck: A mierable end of an Impious Woman! I am revenged, aid Aritippus, without employing the uccours of the Law to punih thee. The next day your father recounted the whole matter to the People, and made all the Friends he could to get your Banihment repealed: I know not what is yet done in it; for before any thing was reolved, the particular neceity of my Affairs, preed me as you ee to come into thee parts: Yet you may hope the people will conent to your return; and that your Father will imbark himelf to find you out, and bring you back.

This was the Relation Charias made me; what ince befel'me, how I came hither, and the Fortunes I have had, would be too long to tell you; with that he wept, and his two Prioners bare him company in Tears, as compaionating his miery, and the more becaue his diaters made them have a livelier remembrance of their own: Nor had they ceaed from Weeping, if Sleep, delighting, as it were, to Bath it elf in Tears, had not cloed up their Fountains.

But Thyamis (o was the Captain of thee Robbers named) having reted quietly the firt part of the Night, was afterwards troubled with a trange Dream, and waking upon it, pent the ret of the Night in tudying out the Meaning of it; for about the Hour that the Cocks Crowing (whether it be as ome think out of a Natural feeling and knowledge of the Suns return to our Horizon, that moves them by intinct to alute that Divine Light, or by a certain heat proper to them, or by a deire to tir and eek new Nourihment) do ummon Mortals to their cutomary Works, about that time the Gods ent Thyamis this Apparition in his leep.

It eemed to his Imagination, that he was in the City of Memphis, were he was born; and that entering the Temple of the Goddes Iis, he aw it all on Fire; uch a great number of lighted Torches were within it, and the Altars were full of all manner of Beats for Sacrifice, their Blood flowing upon the Pavement, and Entries and Galleries were o fill'd with People, as their noie and tumult much amazed him; when he was come into the inner part of the Temple, he thought the Goddes met him with Chariclea in her hand; and aid thee words,

Thyamis, I charge thy Fidelity with this Virgin; yet having of her, thou halt not have her; but thou halt be wicked, and kill this Stranger; yet he hall not dye. Thee Ambiguities exceedingly troubled his Spirit; and often canvaing
the meaning. At length he expounded it thus; thou halt have her, and thou halt not; that is, poeing her for thy Wife, thou halt have her a Maid no longer; thou halt Murder her; that is her Virginity; but o killed, he hall not dye: Thus Thyamis interpreted his Dream, flattering his wihes.

When it was Morning, and the principal Thieves, according to his commandment were aembled; he bade that the Spoils hould be brought forth (for by that pecious name they call'd the Booty) and ending for Knemon to him, charged him to bring thither his two Prioners: As he was carrying them to his Captain (Oh Gods) aid they one to another, what Fortune now attends us? and conjured Knemon, he would be favourable to them to his power; which he promied, and bade them animate themelves, and not uffer fear to eize upon their Courages; for his Captain was not a Barbarian, but Noble and full of Courteie; and that he well expret by his Humanity, the Illutrious Blood of his decent; that is was meer neceity contrained him to take uch a coure of Life: When they were come into Thyamis's Iland, which he had deigned for that Aembly, he acended to a higher Ground, and commanded Knemon, who tood below with the Prioners to interpret to them; for Knemon had now learned the Aegyptian Language; and Thyamis did not yet well undertand the Greek.

My Fellow Souldiers (aid Thyamis) you well know my Spirit and Affection to you, and in what ort I have ever managed your Affairs; for being (as you know) Son to the Chief Priet of Memphis; and unjutly deprived of the Dignity of the Priethood, after my Fathers Death, by the Means of my younger Brother, in this Extremity, I fled into your Arms, and craved your Succours, to revenge my Wrong, and recover my Honour; and you favoured me o much, as by your general Suffrage to elect me your Captain; ince which time I have lived amongt you, without entrenching upon your Priviledges, or challenging to my elf any greater part of the Prize, than the meanet of you; but if Money were to be ditributed, I only deired my hare; if Prioners to be old, I caued the Prize to be laid down in common, knowing he that will dicharge the office of a good Captain, mut be above his Men in pains, and but their equal in Profit: When I took Prioners in the Field, that were Men likely to do us Service, I have received them into the number of our Souldiers; others les erviceable, I have made Money of: I never offered violence to any Woman; but if they were Noble, I have put them to their Ranom, or retored them to their Liberty, pitying their Misfortune; others of meaner Condition, and uch as the Chance of War made Captives, and were by their own natural Baenes inclined to erve, I have given you for Slaves: But now I have a
Suit to you, that for my part of the Prey, you will pleae to give me this Fair Stranger; and though by my own Authority I might retain her, yet I hold it more honourable to take her with your Conent; for I hould do very imprudently, if for gaining of one Prioner a Stranger, I hould loe or offend my Friends and Companions; yet the Favour you do me hall not be without a Recompence; for I will leave the Spoyls to your Dipoe: And foramuch as we of the Prophetick Race didain to mix our Blood with any Women that are not of our Quality, I am reolved to take this Virgin, not for the pleaure I hall receive in the equal enjoying of her, but for the propagation of an Iue to ucceed me in my Sacred Charge; and I will give you the Reaons that induce me: When I firt aw her, I eteem'd her to be nobly born, as well for the Riches he had about her, as that her Spirits failed not in the midt of her Calamities, but that he contantly tood the Aaults of Fortune; her Form, Modety and Breeding were great Arguments to me of her Quality; for her Beauty exceeds all of our Times, and her Modety is uch as invites her Beholders to a Continency: why therefore hould not I honour her, and judge highly of her? But what yet is more coniderable, he eems to me to be a Religious Votares of ome Goddes, ince in all the Dangers that befel her, (believing it to be an intolerable in (he never would pull off her Crown of Lawrel, nor her
Sacred Robe; what Marriage then can be more equal, my brave Aitants, than the Son of a Prophet to match with a Maid conecrated to the Gods.

They all approved the Match, and wihed him Joy. Thyamis catching the Words, I thank you, worthy Friends, he aid, but we hall do well firt to ask the Maids conent; for if I would have ued the Law of Empire, to Will had been enough for all: but my Demands being only a lawful Marriage, the conent of two is neceary; and turning to her, Tell us (he aid) you Fair One, what you do reolve upon our Propoitions, and declare to us who, and of whence your Parents are: But he, after he had fix'd her Eyes a good while upon the ground, as meditating what he would ay, at length he raied her Head, and looking upon Thyamis, with more Beauty than before, for her tudy to contrive her Speech, had painted her Cheeks with a becoming Bluh, and her Eyes with the vehemency of her Thoughts parkled with more than ordinary lutre; Knemon interpreting, he aid,

Sir, it would better have become my Brother Theagenes to have anwered you than I, ilence being as commendable in Maids, as the Grace of Replying is in Men; but ince you give me liberty to peak, and that you have expret your Noblenes in eeking to compas jut things by perwaion, not force, and in regard your Speech is principally directed to me, I am contrained to exceed the Bounds I have
precribed to my elf, and are proper to my Sex, and to anwer the Demands of my Conqueror in the Eyes and Hearing of o many Men;

Know then, our Countrey is Ionia, and we are born of one of the bet Families of Epheus: when we were come to the Age wherein the Noble mens Children of our Countrey are accutomed to do Service to the Gods, I was choen Prietles to Diana, and my Brother Priet to Apollo. This being an Annual Honour, when the Tear was run out, we were to make a Voyage to Delos, in our Sacred Robes, and there to exhibit publick Games, for exercie of Letters, Muick and the Body; and o according to the manner of our Ancetors, to reign but Priethood: To this end a Ship was made ready for us, laden with Gold, Silver, Silks, and other Necearies both for etting forth of the Games, and feating of the People: Thus we looed out of the Haven, leaving our Father and Mother in their Houe, who in regard of the feeblenes of their old Age, and the dangers of the Sea, did not dare to embark with us: many of the Citizens went the Voyage, ome in our Ship, ome in Veels of their own; and having ayled the greater part of our way, with all favour of the Heavens, on a udden the Clouds thickned, and a fearful Tempet aroe, accompanied with Lightning and Thunder, that o masked the Skies, and plowed up the Seas, as we lot the benefit of our Compas, and our Pilot overcome with the greatnes of the Evil, was forced to give way to the violence of the Tempet, and abandon the Government and Helm to the dicretion
of Fortune. In fine, the Storm having (even days and nights together) pent the fury of its tronget guts upon our Veel, we were cat upon the Shore where you took us, and beheld o great a Maacre of men, for amuch as we there making a Feat of Joy, and a Sacrifice to the Gods of Thanksgiving for our Deliverance, the Saylors (with impious deire to poes our Riches) et upon us, and reolved to put us to the Sword; but we made uch reitance, as after the los of our Enemies and our Friends, we two, as you aw, remained the Conquerors; and would it had pleaed the Gods we had ended our days among them, and not been the only mierable Relicks of that Battel; but ince it o falls out, yet we are happy in this one repect, that ome favourable Deity hath made us fall into your hands, and gives us, that late expected nothing but Death, the liberty now to treat of a Marriage, which I were indicreet if I hould refue: For what Felicity can be imagined greater, than for a poor Captive to be though worthy of her Generals Bed; add to this, that a Maid dedicated to the Gods, hall be taken to wife by the Son of a Prophet, that in a little while hall himelf be a Prophet, which ure is not without ome ecret Mytery of Providence. I only beeech one favour, that before you marry me, I may be permitted to go to the next great Town, or any nearer place where there is an Altar or Temple of Apollo, that I may render up the Charge of my Priethood, and put off the Marks and Enigns of the God; it would do bet at Memphis, when you have recovered the Dignity
of Chief Priet; for a Marriage joyn'd to Victory would be celebrated with more joy, and be as a Trophy of your glorious Actions; but whether before or after, I leave it to your pleaure, o as you vouchafe to let me accomplih the Ceremonies uual in my Countrey; whereto I know you will condecend, ince (as you ay) you have been bred from a Child in the Myteries of Religion, and are full of Reverence towards the Gods.

Thus he ceaed to peak, and began to weep: All that were preent did greatly approve her Anwer, and by a general Cry aured her they were ready to ee her Deires performed; and Thyamis conented half voluntary, and half by contraint; for his ardent longing to enjoy Chariclea, made him think an hour of delay an Eternity; withal he found himelf o charm'd with her Speech, as if it had been a Syrens Song, that it forced him to allow of her Demands, having alo a relation to his Dream, flattering his Deires with a belief their Nuptials hould be held in Memphis: Then he broke up the Meeting, (having firt divided the Booty, whereof his Companions freely gave him the richer and the greater part) and commanded them within ten days to be ready to it down before Memphis, and beiege his Brother. To the Prioners he aigned their old Tent, and Knemon to attend them, not now as a Keeper, but a Companion, and many times ent for Theagenes to his Table for his Siters ake, whom he reolved not to viit often, for
fear her ight hould increae his impatient wihes to enjoy her, and let it hould make him attempt any thing againt what was publickly conented to, and privately figured in his Dream. For thee Reaons Thyamis forbare to ee her, thinking it impoible he hould behold her and contain his longings; but Knemon, after every one was retired to their Lodgings, paed the Lake, and went a great way by Land to eek the Herb he had promied Theagenes the day before.

In the mean time, Theagenes taking the advantage of his Abence wept and lamented to himelf, without peaking a word to Chariclea, but inceantly calling upon the Gods; and he demanding whether he did igh for their common Miery, or that ome new Diater was befallen? Alas (aid Theagenes) is there any thing more new, or more unjut, than to falifie Faith, and violate Oaths, and that Chariclea, without memory of me, or of my Services, hould treat of a Marriage with another?

Oh ay not o (replied Chariclea) be not you more cruel to me than my Detiny: you have proved my Affection by many Arguments, and can you now ditrut me only for words accommodated to the time, and for the interet of our Affairs? No, no, your elf may ooner change your Mind, than I. I can uffer all the Calamities of the World, but know there is no violence o great, that can eparate me and Modety; nor am I concious of a fault that way, but in loving you too much, yet with an honet
and a lawful Love; for from the firt entitling of you to my Heart, it was as to my Husband, not as to a Lover that could not moderate his Deires, having to this hour preerv'd the outmot Purity, often repelling your Impatience to conummate the Marriage which with Vows we had contracted; think how little reaon you have to conceive I would prefer a Barbarian before a Greek, and a Thief before a man of all men the dearet?

But what was the meaning then (replied Theagenes) of your Speech in that famous Aembly, when you called me your Brother, methought it was a fine invention, putting Thyamis out of jealouie of our Love, and making way that we might freely be together, I approved your Story of the Countrey of Ionia, and of a Voyage to Delos for they were things like Truths, and led the Hearers in a pleaing Error; but to accord o freely to a Marriage, to article, and et down the time before uch multitudes of People, I neither could nor would conjecture what it meant, but wihed the Earth would open and devour me, ere I hould ee my hopes and ervices repaid with uch Ingratitude.

At thee Words, Chariclea imbracing Theagenes, and weeping, How well I take thee Fears, (aid he) that torment you for my ake, ince they make me know in the extremity of our Adverities your Affection is the ame it was: but aure your elf, Theagenes, if I had not carried it thus, we hould not at this time have had the freedom to confer
together; for to be wilful, and to run a contrary coure to the deires of one more powerful than our elves, begets but a tronger oppoition, whilt yielding words, applied to the motion of the Will, preently appeaeth the firt heat, and by the weetnes of a Promie lays the Appetite to leep; foramuch as they that love after a gros rutick way, if at the firt eay they get conent, they think they have done enough, and making ure they hall enjoy the content they wih, their Spirit is in more repoe, and goes floating in their hope. This Conideration made me yield to Thyamis, in words only, commending the Sequel to the Gods, and the Genius that from the beginning hath taken our chate Love into his Patronage; oftentimes a day or two put off, hath been greatly advantageous to the mierable, and brought means of afety, when no humane Prudence could work it; therefore for the preent I deferred him, avoiding a Certainty for an ncertainty; but we mut do this artificially, and conceal it, as a light at the Weapon, from our Enemies, even from Knemon; for though he be full of Courteie, and hath done many Favours for us, and is as we are, a Grecian, yet he is, as we are, a Captive; and therefore if occaion hould be offered, more likely to gratifie his Conqueror, than us the Conquered; for neither the time of his Acquaintance, nor his being our Countreyman, are ufficient Pledges to us of his Fidelity, and therefore, if at any time he touches at our Affairs, you mut deny the Truth, for the Lye is not evil that does good to the Author, and no hurt to the Hearer.

As Chariclea was dicouring thus, Knemon entred all in a weat, and manifeting a great perturbation by his countenance; Here Theagenes, take this Herb (he aid) and apply it to your Wounds, we mut prepare our elves for greater hurts; Theagenes praying him to peak plain, The conideration of the time (aid he) will not let you hear me out; for it is to be feared the effect will prevent my Words: but follow me you and Chariclea; and o led them both to Thyamis, whom he found buied in furbihing an Armour, and harpning the point of a Javelin: This is to the purpoe, aid Knemon, that you have your Arms o near you; put them on preently, and command every one to do the like, for I have dicovered uch a cloud of enemies coming as I never aw before; they are not far off; for having decried them from the top of the Hill where I was gathering Herbs, I have brought you the News with all the peed I could, and in travering the Lake, I have given warning to your Men to be in a readines for their defence.

Thyamis hearing this, uddenly tarted up, and demanded where Chariclea was, as fearing more for her than for himelf, and Knemon having hewed her tanding at the Door, Go (aid Thyamis in his ear) take her with thee into the Cave where we conceal our Treaure, and when thou hat conveyed her down, and covered the mouth of the Cave with the Stone that ueth to lie upon it, pr'ythee Friend return with all celerity;
mean time we will give order for the Fight: then he commanded his Page to eek him a fat Beat; that having acrificed to the Gods Protectors of the Place, they might joyn Battel. This while, Knemon doing his Commands, led away Chariclea, that ighed and lamented, and at every tep he went, turned back her eyes towards Theagenes; at length they came to the Cave, where Knemon immediatly carried her down.

The Place was not a work of Nature, as we ee many both above and under the ground; but it was a Vault wrought out of the Rock by the indutry of the Aegyptian Thieves, and imitating Nature, artificially hollowed, to contain their Spoyls; the Entry was narrow and obcure, and conveyed into a little Cell, the Threhold Stone whereof was a Door that opened and hut eaily, and gave another paage for decent into the Cave when neceity required; within it were cut many Trenches and Meanders, that went turning of either ide, ometimes alone, ometimes mixing together like the Roots of Trees, till they came to the bottom, and there they end in a large and pacious Plain, whereinto enters a little Light, by certain clefts and crannies in the Earth above: Knemon, that by practice knew the turnings, having brought Chariclea to the bottom, endeavoured to comfort her the bet he could, auring her, he and Theagenes would come and ee her oon at Night, and that he would not uffer him to fight, nor come within
the danger; and o he left her not able to peak one Word; but fainting, as if he had been truck to death, and deprived of her Soul in her Theagenes: and cloing up the Cave, could not himelf refrain from weeping, both that he hould be forced to execute o hard a Command, and in compaion of her Fortune, whom he had almot buried alive, and ealed up in Night and Darknes, the perfectet Workmanhip of Nature: then he made hate to Thyamis, whom he found compleatly armed, and with his Oration exciting thoe that were about him; for tanding in the midt of them, he aid,

My Companions in Arms, I do not think it needful to trouble you with many Words; you need no admonition, War is your Trade, and now the Enemy is o near us, he cuts off Dicoure, he comes upon us to force our Trenches with his Sword, and we mut anwer him in his own Language: I have nothing ele to ay, but that now, you are not only to defend your Wives and Children (which hath been Motive ufficient for others to fight to the lat man; though if we be Conquerors, uch mall things, and many of greater moment wil be in our power) but your Lives are now at take, for the War among Thieves was never ended by Treaty, nor ecured by League, but the Survivors mut be Conquerors, and the Conquered mut die; therefore let us go to't, and let him that dies his Weapon deepet in our Enemies Blood, be thought the bravet Man.

Having thus aid, Thyamis looked about him for his Page, and-often called him by his Name Thermutis, and not eeing him appear, curing and threatning him, he hatned to the Boat: The Battel was now begun, and he might ee the Enemy make himelf Mater of the Borders of the Lake; for he had et fire upon their Cabbins and their Boats, and o made them tranport the Flame about the Fens, that, devouring the great quantity of the Reed, dazzled the Eyes of the Inhabitants with inufferable Light: whilt the Noie and Tumult deafned their Ears, all Cruelties of War were een and heard, the Lakits triving to make good the Place, but the others falling upon them unawares, and oppreing them with Multitudes, lew eaily thoe they found on Land, and overwhelmed thoe within the Lake in their Boats and Cabbins, whence the Air was filled with horrible Cries, both of thoe that defended themelves upon the Water, and thoe that fought by Land, and the Lake was tain'd all over in the Blood of dying perons that fell at one time, both by Fire and Water.

When Thyamis aw and heard this, he remembred his Dream, how he had een the Goddes Iis, and her Temple all on fire, and full of Sacrifices; and oberving his Viion was thus far brought to pas, he began to make another explication of the ret: Having, thou halt not have her; foramuch as he hall be ravih'd from thee by the fury of this War; and that he hould kill
her, yet he hould not hurt her; that is, he hould detroy her with his Sword, and not by Rape. To conclude, rating the Goddes as fraudulent and injurious, charging her that he had abus'd and mockt him, and not being able to endure with patience that any other hould enjoy Chariclea, he commanded his men to retire a little, and to hold the Enemy in play a while, only with skirmihing, and ome few Sallies, which as they were intrenched, might reit the forces of greater multitudes, whilt he would go and find Thermutis, and offer Vows and Sacrifices to their preidiary Gods; and o forbidding any man to follow him, he departed as towards his Tent, but took his way to the Cave: Oh how hard it is to turn a Barbarian from that he hath once reolved in his Soul; for aoon as they fall to depair of their own afety, it is their cutom preently to kill their dearet Friends; either believing they hall live together after death, or deiring to take them out of their enemies power, and to free them from all injuries; for thee Reaons Thyamis forgetting all his own Affairs, and though he was at that preent encompat with Enemy-Troops that had taken him as in Nets, furiouly tranported with Love and Jealouie, he entred the Cave, where calling as loud as he could, and peaking ome Words in the Aegyptian Tongue, he heard a Woman anwer him in Greek; and the ound of her Voyce leading him to the place where he was, he put his left hand about her
Neck, and with his right drawing his Sword, ran her through the Body under the left Breat, wherewith the poor Woman fell down dead, breathing but one igh, that brake her Heart-trings.

Preently Thyamis went out, letting fall the Stone upon the Entry of the Cave, and for her Epitaph eeming to write upon it with his tears, adding thee Words, Alas poor Maid, thee are the Nuptial Gifts I preent thee: And o returning to his Men, he found their Battel quite diordered, and ready to fly, frighted with the Enemies Approach; and on the other ide, eeing Thermutis, that brought him a Beat to imolate, he chid him, and told him he had already offered the fairet Sacrifice of the world; and o entred into his Bark with him, & only one more to row; for the Boats they have here can carry no more, being wrought out of the Body but of one thick Tree, by their rude Shipwrights; Theagenes and Knemon imbarked together in another, and the ret in the like manner; and when they had coated the Iland a great way, they ceaed rowing, and dipoed their Boats in front of their Battalion, as attending the hock of their Enemies; but aoon as they approached, the Herdmen of the Iland were o far from the courage to utain the firt Aault upon the Water, that they preently cat about and fled, not daring to endure the very ound of the Alarum. Theagenes and Knemon retired themelves oftly after the ret; but Fear did
not make them turn their backs; only Thyamis held it unworthy to give ground, and not deiring to urvive Chariclea, he pret into the midt of his Enemies, and as he was fighting amongt them, one cried out, This is Thyamis, every man now look to his Charge, o immediately wheeling in a Ring about him, they incloed him with their Boats; but he toutly holding out, wounded ome with his Javelin, and killed others: The Fight was worthy of admiration, in all the multitude of his Foes no man appoed or drew a Sword againt him, but every one did his bet to take him alive, he reited a great while, but at lat his Javelin was beaten out of his hand, and them his Foes preed in upon him, being alo at that intant deprived of the uccour of his Page, that had tood to him bravely, but at that time had newly received (as was thought) a mortal Wound, and cating himelf into the Lake, wimming with much difficulty, had recovered Land, no one taking the pains to follow him; for having Thyamis in their power, they eteemed it to be an abolute Victory.

Yet not withtanding the los of many of their Fellows, they more rejoyced to have him alive that lew them, than they orrowed for their Friends and Kinmens Deaths; o inatiable are the covetous hearts of Thieves, preferring Gain before their Lives, and having no end in the holy Name of Friendhip and Conanguinity, but to get by them; it was the cae of thee Thieves,
for they were the ame that before out of their ear of Thyamis and his Men, had fled from the Heracliotick Arm of Nilus, who tomacking to be deprived of other mens Goods as if they were their own, had gathered together their Companions, and called in the Neighbour Villages, offering them equal hares, and chuing them for their Captains to conduct the Expedition.

But the Caue of their taking Thyamis, was this, he had at Memphis a Brother named Petoiris, who having by his plots dipoeed his Brother of the Dignity of Chief Priet, againt the Laws and Intitutions of the Countrey, (for he was his younger Brother) and hearing that he was the Captain of thee Thieves, he feared Thyamis would take time to chae him out of his uurped Honour, and dicover his perfidiounes: alo he deired to take away the ill opinion that many had conceived of him, that he had killed his Brother, becaue it appeared not where he was; therefore ending Meengers to the Villages of the Thieves, he propoed a great Sum of Money, and o many Catles to any one that would take him alive; o as thee Thieves charmed with the hope of uch a Profit, even in the heat of Blood and War, did not forget their Promie, but after he was dicovered, took him alive, though many died for it: Being thus eized of Thyamis, they rowed to Land, putting him in Irons, and appointing half of their Troops to guard him, who vexing at his Fortune, upbraided them of
Cowardie, for not daring to take him with their Swords, bearing his imprionment with more indignation and les patience than if it had been Death it elf; the ret of them returned into the Iland, in hope to find the Riches for which they had been tempted to run this hazard. But after they had paed over all the Iland, without leaving one corner unearched, and finding nothing, or very little of the Prize, unles it were ome Trifles that they had neglected to put up in the Cave, they et fire upon the Cabbins, and the Evening now approaching, and putting them in a fear to tay longer in the Iland, let they hould fall into the Trains of ome of thoe that fled from the Battel, and might now perhaps lie in Ambucado for them, they returned to their Companies.

div.head: THE AETHIOPIAN HISTORY.
The Second Book.
div.p: THus the Iland was all on fire; but Theagenes and Knemon did not perceive that Misfortune o long as the Sun hined upon the Earth, becaue his Beams leened the appearance of Fire by Day; but after Sun-et, when it grew dark, the Flame having then no Light greater than its own, dicovered it elf in the full horror, whilt they truting to the Nights obcurity, came out of the Reeds of the Marih, and aw clearly the whole Iland almot burnt to Ahes; and then Theagenes beating his Head, and tearing off his Hair,

Farewel to Life, (he aid) This day hall make an end of all Fears, Dangers, Cares, Hope and Love, Chariclea is dead, Theagenes is lot; in vain then, nfortunate that I am, have I fled from the Battel, an Action unworthy of a man, only reerving my elf, my Dearet, for your ake; but I will live no longer, ince you are deprived of your Life; and which heightens my Affliction, not after the common coure of Nature, nor have you rendred your Spirit in his Arms where you did wih to breath it. Alas, are you conumed by Fire, and has your Detiny prepared thee Flames to be our Nuptial Torches? Mut that Beauty without a Second in the World, be thus defaced, as not to leave o much Remains as a dead Body, or any Relicks of her unadulterate Charms. Oh, unexampled Cruelty! the mot bitter Spite of Fortune, I am denied the favour of a lat Embrace, and a poor parting Kis.
At thee Words, drawing his Sword, to run himelf upon it, Knemon caught hold of him, and asked what he meant? why do ye mourn for her as dead that lives? Chariclea is in perfect health I do aure you.

This is for Children and Mad-men to believe (replied Theagenes) but Knemon, you have done me wrong to come betwixt me and a pleaing Death: But he confirming the truth of his News with Oaths, told him all the Commands of Thyamis, the Cave, and Nature of the Cave where he had put her, that he need not fear the Fire
could penetrate to the bottom, the violence of it being repell'd and broke with a thouand everal Turnings. At this Theagenes began to breath a little, and thought long till he hould come to the Iland, which he had already preented to his Thoughts, and taken up his Marriage-chamber in the Cave, not imagining the Complaints he hould make, nor the Tears he hould there hed.

Thus they rowed towards the Iland, themelves playing the Watermen; for he that rowed them the day before, at the firt Alarum and Cry of the Enemy, had fallen overboard. Now they being unpractied at the Oar, were a long time carried up and down, haying alo the Wind againt them, yet their impatient deire of Landing overcame their unskilfulnes.

When therefore with difficulty and much labour they were arrived, they hated with all poible peed to the Cave, where they found all wated by the Fire, and only knew it by the Stone that covered the Entry of the Pit; for the Wind blowing the Flame upon the Shades, that were only made of Canes and Sedges, matted one within another, had burnt them down, and levell'd all into a Plain, elevating the Ahes in the Air, and carrying them away; the little that remain'd being o well cool'd, that they might pas over them without fear of burning; and gathering together ome Reeds that were half burnt, making them into a Torch, Knemon
went before Theagenes, to light him down; and after they were entred a little way, on the udden Knemon cried out, O Jove! what have we here? We are undone, Chariclea is lain: Then cating his Torch againt the Earth, he extinguihed it, and fell upon his knees, weeping for her untimely Death; but Theagenes, as if ome Enemy had truck him down, fell upon her Body, and held her in his Arms, as if they had been incorporated together: Knemon knowing him to be lot in orrow, and fearing let he hould kill himelf, drew his Sword out of the Scabbard, and o leaving him, ran to light his Torch again.

Mean while, Theagenes fetching deep Sighs from his afflicted Heart; Oh inufferable Grief! (aid he) Oh Miery that the incened Gods have let fall upon us! what inatiable Fury purues us with uch rage, banihing us from our Country, betraying us to Shipwrack, and Pyrates by Sea, and Thieves by Land, depriving us of all our Riches! only one Comfort did remain; but, alas! it is now taken from me; Chariclea lies here dead, he that was dearer to me than my Life, hath lot hers by the hand of a cruel Enemy, quetionles in defence of her Honour, reerving her elf for me; yet here the poor unfortunate lies dead, not having reaped the Fruits of Beauty in the Flourih of her Age; at leat (my Love) bid me farewel, peak to me, give me but your lat Commands: Mierable that I am, he anwers not, and eternal ilence hath ealed
her Heavenly and Prophetick Lips that pake with o much Muick; Darknes covers now the Light of Sacrifices; the Temple of the Gods, and their fairet Ornament is now return'd to Chaos; thoe Eyes have lot their Beams that enlightned the whole world, which I aure my elf the barbarous Murderer did not ee. By what Name hall I call thee? my Contracted! Alas, the Contract's broke: my Wife? Thou never knewet what Marriage was: No, no, I mut call thee the weetet of all Names, Chariclea. Oh Chariclea, let your Spirits be appeaed; you have a faithful Friend that hall not long be abent from you; for I go now to celebrate your Obequies, and to acrifice unto you in your Lovers Blood: This Cave, a rude Tomb, hall contain us; here we may enjoy one another after death, though living, the Gods would not permit: At thee words, feeling for his Sword, he cried out, Oh Knemon, thou hat kill'd me now the econd time, and again wrong'd Chariclea, depriving her of the Friends Company he mot deires.

Speaking this, he heard a voyce out of the bottom of the Cave, that called Theagenes; but he, without being troubled at it, I come (aid he) my dear Soul, this gives me knowledge that you wander yet upon the Earth, partly becaue you cannot leave o fair a Body, whereof the poeion was untimely taken from you, partly, becaue yet you have not the Rites of Sepulture; and therefore the Shadows that inhabit the lower Kingdoms, will not uffer
you to remain among them. In the mean time Knemon returning with his Torch relighted, the ame voice was heard again, calling Theagenes. Oh good Gods! aid Knemon, is not that Chariclea's Voyce? ure it is Theagenes, and doubtles he yet lives; for the ound that beats upon our ears comes out of the bottom of the Cave, where I remember I did leave her.
Will you not forbear (replied Theagenes) to mock me and abue me yet again?

Indeed I deceive you (anwered Knemon) and my elf, if he that lies here be Chariclea; and preently he turned her upon her Back, for her Face lay to the Earth; and when he had look'd upon her, he cried out, Oh Gods! You Authors of Prodigies, What Portent is this? This is the Face of Thesby: preently he tept back, and tood as if he had been frozen with amazement; but Theagenes, that now began to take new Hope and Spirit, brought Knemon to himelf, and intreated him to lead him where Chariclea was; and Knemon, after a little paue, again took view of the dead Body, and aw auredly that it was Thesby; and finding a Sword lying beide her, he knew it to belong to Thyamis, who tranported with his wild Fury, had left it in her Wound; alo he took a Letter out of her Boom, which he would have read; but Theagenes would not permit him, calling upon him, and aying, firt let us recover my dear Chariclea, unles now, as before, ome God or Devil take a Pleaure in deluding
us, the Letter we may read at leiure.
