Knemon gave way to his deire, and cloing the Letter, took up the Sword, and hated to Chariclea, who was creeping towards the Light upon her Hands and Knees, and met Theagenes, who folding her Arms about his Neck, repeated many times, And art thou come again Theagenes? and he, Does Chariclea live; till in the end, they fell down upon the ground, tangled fat in their Embraces, not able to utter any thing, but a kind of groaning; and it was hard to judge whether they were dead or not; for many times an exceive Joy vaniheth into orrow, and immoderate Pleaure begets Pain, which we vainly call in upon our elves; thus they preerved beyond Hope and Opinon, were endangered, till Knemon chafing the Rock with his Hand, and receiving in his Palm the Humour that detill'd by drop and drop, cat it in their Faces, and topping their Notrils, recovered them out of their Swoon, who finding themelves o kindly laid together, preently tarted up, and bluh'd that Knemon had beheld them (epecially Chariclea) intreating him to pardon their Exorbitances, who miling to himelf, and turning it to Mirth; This (aid he) deerveth Commendations, if I may be a Judge, or any other man that hath entred the Lits with Love, been happily conquered by him, and made acquainted with his inevitable Accidents; But to peak truth, Theagenes, I cannot in any ort approve, and indeed I was ahamed
to ee you embrace a trange woman with o much paion, and to bath o freely with your Tears the Body of a Slave, to whom you had no Tye, o much as of acquaintance, epecially, when I told you, and proteted that Chariclea was alive and afe. I pr'y thee Knemon (aid Theagenes) do not traduce me to Chariclea, whom I lamented in the peron of another, believing it was he that was o cruelly murdered; but ince ome favourable God has now hewed us our Error, give me leave to put you in mind of the generous and contant Spirit wherewith you firt deplored my Misfortune, and afterwards coming unexpectedly acquainted with the dead Body (as if it had been ome Devil in a Play) you ran away armed, and your Sword drawn, from a Woman, a dead Woman; A brave Athenian Soldier! Hereat they began to mile a little, but as if forced, not without Tears; being engaged to Sorrow by their preent Miery.

After they had a while tood ilent, Chariclea touching her fair Cheek with her hand, Bleed (aid he) do I eteem her, whooe're he be, that Theagenes has kit and mourn'd for! and if you would not think me jealous, I would deire to know that happy Womans Name, and by what Error you mitook a Stranger for me, and honoured her Funerals with your Tears; if you know, tell me who he is.

You will wonder, replied Theagenes; for Knemon ays it is Thesbe, that Athenian Lutenit, the
Inventres of the Plot that Damoeneta had upon him.

p.U: tarting at this News, How is it poible Knemon (aid he) this Woman hould in an intant be thus tranported, as if he had been hot out of an Engine, from the midt of Greece to the farthet parts of Egypt? And how chanced it we aw her not as we came down?

div.p: I cannot anwer you to that, aid Knemon; but I hall tell you what I have ince undertood of her.

After Damoeneta was circumvented by her Cunning, and had precipitated her elf into the Pit, my Father recited the whole buines to the People, and was preently abolved; then he olicited for my repeal from Banihment, enquired my Abode, and reolved to embark himelf, and come in peron to bring me back. Whilt he was thus employ'd, Thesbe made it her Vacation-time, and offering her Service at all Feats and Meetings, impudently protituted both her Art and Peron: Now he was oberved to be more gentile than Arinoe, who ung only ome looe Ayrs coldly to her Flute, whilt Thesbe curiouly touching her Lute, and marrying her voice to the oft trings, ravih'd her Hearers. This made Arinoe conceive againt her an Envy and Emulation, joyn'd with a particular Spleen, epecially when a certain Naucratian Merchant named Nauicles began to fall in love with her, and neglect Arinoe, that had late been his Mitres, didaining
her, becaue when he had play'd upon her Flute, he oberved her Face grow red, her Cheeks well, and hold an unhandom competition with her Noe, and her Eyes ready to tart out of her Head: The lighted Arinoe, burning with Spite and Jealouie, found out the Parents of Damoeneta, and to them dicovered all the Treaons and Villanies Thesbe had practis'd againt her Mitres; part whereof he but upected, and the ret Thesbe had told her in the height of their Familiarity. Aoon as the Friends of Damoeneta were advertized, they aembled, and conpired againt my Fathers Life, and fee'd the prime Orators of Athens with great Sums of Money, to accue him; who exclaimed unto the People that Damoeneta had perihed injutly, unconvicted, and the crime of Adultery was only a pretext to cover her Murther; requiring he might be brought alive or dead with whom he was pretended to have wronged my Father: Finally, they commanded, that at leat he hould be named; demanding Thesbe to be delivered to them, to the end, that putting her to the Torture, they might rack out the Truth. My Father promied to produce her, but he could not hear his Word; for Thesbe, preventing the danger if he hould appear, whilt they were taking out the Proces for her, fled away, according to agreement, with the Merchant Nauicles: this dipleaed the People, yet they did not judge him to be the Murtherer, but an Acceory to the Plot againt Damoeneta,
and conenting to my unjut Banihment; therefore they expell'd him the City, conficating all his goods: thee were the fruits he reaped of his econd Marriage, and this was the reaon made the wicked Thesbe ail from Athens, who now before my Eyes receives the punihment he had deerv'd.

Thus much one Anticles told me in the Iland of Aegina, with him I put to Sea again, bound for Aegypt, that if happily I hould light of Thesbe here in the City of Naucratia, I might carry her back to Athens, to dicharge my Father of the crime whereof he was fally indicted, and withal to ee her treacheries and malice duly punihed by the Laws; but now I am here detained a Prioner, as you are; at another time you hall know the caue and manner of my taing, the fortune I have ince endured, but how Thesbe came into this Cave, and who hath lain her, we need ome God for an interpreter. Yet if you pleae, I will read the Letter that I took out of her Boome, which may perhaps give us further intelligence; They intreated him to do o, and opening it, he read thee words.

body.head: To her Mater Knemon, Thesbe his Enemy and Revenger.
body.p:
FOr my firt News, know Damoeneta is Dead, by my means, for your ake; The way I did it (if you pleae to receive me) I will relate unto your elf; it is now ten days that I have been in this Iland, taken by one of thee Thieves, that boats himelf to be the Captains Page, and keeps me locked up, not giving me the Liberty to walk, or look abroad: punihing me thus (as he tells me) for the love he bears me; but (as I conjecture) it is for fear let ome body hould take me from him; yet for all this, ome Angel directing me, as you paed by yeterday, I aw and knew you, and have now ecretly ent you this Letter by an Old Woman; my Keeper charging her to preent it to the fair Grecian, that is near the Captains Peron; I beeech you, Sir, free me from this Thief, and receive your Handmaid: and if it be your pleaure, ave my Life; conidering wherein I offended you, Neceity contrain'd me; but that I have revenged you of your Enemy, was the free motion of my Soul, notwithtanding that you be o incened againt me, as that you are reolved not to pardon me; ue me as you pleae, let me dye, o I may dye yours. For I eteem it much more noble, at your hands to receive Death, and funeral Rites according to the Cutom of Greece; than to endure a Life more terrible then Death: and the love of a
Barbarian more bitter then the hatred of an Athenian. Thus Thesbe and the Letter pake. Oh Thesbe, Thesbe! aid, Knemon, thou hat received a jut Judgment, and thy elf the Meenger that tells it to us, delivering us a Letter (contains part of thy Misfortunes) after thou art Dead; by this we know the Fury that revenged thy wickednes upon thee, whipt thee about the World, and never held her hand, till he had brought thee before me, thy wronged Mater (though I lived in Aegypt, and made me a Spectator of thy Tradegy: But what new Stratagem hadt thou againt me? By thee Letters that Fortune took out of thy hands, I cannot but upect thee yet, and I much fear that Damoeneta's Death is but a thing devied, and put into their Mouths that told me it, and that thou art come thus far by Sea, to make me as Tragick a Spectacle now in Aegypt, as before at Athens.

div.p:
Why Knemon aid Theagenes, till o valiant! will you not yet leave fearing Spirits and Shadows, my error was but a Deceptio vius, but I am no actor in this Scene; She is dead I warrant, never doubt it: but who is Author of this favour to thee, and has killed her to thy Hand, I cannot imagine; nor how, or when he came down hither. I am not able further to reolve you, (aid Knemon) but auredly Thyamis is he that killed her: That which makes me believe it, is his word, we found dropt out of her Wound; for I know it to be his, by the Ivory Pommel cut in the figure of an Eagle, which is his Cret: Cannot you
tell us aid Theagenes, when, or how, or for what caue he did this Murther? How hould I know? (replyed Knemon) for this Cave hath not made me Prophetical, like that of Apollo at Delphos or Triphonius his Den, from whence men come out inpired with a divine fury: Preently Theagenes and Chariclea fell a weeping, and cryed with one voice, Oh Apollo! O Delphos! this amazed Knemon, not being able to conceive why the names of Apollo and Delphos hould o much trouble them; Thus were they buied.

Now Thermutis the page of Thyamis, that was hurt in the Battel, when he had recovered Land by Swimming, the night now growing Dark, he found a Boat Shipwrackt by the Fen-ide, and entring it, plyed his Oares towards his Captains Iland to ee Thesbe, whom a few dayes before he had taken from the Merchant Nauicles, as he was leading her in a narrow way that lyes along the Mountain ide, where Thermutis lay in Ambuh to Rob Paengers; and as Thyamis at the firt noie and arrival of the Enemies, had ent him to eek a Beat to Sacrifice to the Gods for Victory, Thermutis deperately in love with this Woman, deirous to keep her out of danger of the War, and to preerve her for himelf, ecretly conveyed her into the Cave, and for fear and hate left her at the Mouth thereof, where he remained, not daring to tir; both frighted with the Alarm and the preent Dangers, and not knowing the windings of the way that conducted to
the Bottom; and thus Thyamis finding her at his entry, lew her: believing that he killed Chariclea. Thermutis therefore having ecap'd the Battel, fled to find her in the Iland, where arriving, he ran with all hate towards the Tent of Thyamis, which was now but ahes; and with much difficulty finding the Cave by a Stone that covered the entry, he lighted a few Reeds that were yet unconumed and ran down, calling Thesbe (which name was all the Greek he had) but when he aw her tretch'd Dead upon the Earth, he was o atoniht, as a while he had no Motion; at length hearing certains Sounds and Murmurs out of the hollows of the Cave, (for Theagenes and Knemon were yet dicouring) he upected thoe to be the Murtherers of Thesbe, this confued his thoughts, not knowing what to reolve or do; for the natural cruelty and barbarous humour of the Thief, his rage exaperated by this accident frutrating him of the enjoying of his Love, incited him to run to the bottom and fall upon them he eteemed the Authors of her Death; but wanting Arms, he was reclaimed to Moderation againt his will: he thought it his bet way at firt to accot them as his Friends, but if he hould chance to find upply of Weapons, then to fall upon them as his Enemies. This being deigned in his mind, he approached Theagenes, and look'd upon him with an Eye of Fury, dicovering his ecret purpoe.

But when they perceived a naked Man coming upon them on the udden, hurt, and his Face all Bloody, they were diverly affected at the ight, Chariclea ran down as low as he could; Knemon aid not a word, but retired himelf ome paces, though he knew Thermutis; but eeing him come o unexpected, he feared ome Stratagem: but the Spectacle did not o much terrifie, as provoke Theagenes; who laid his hand upon his Sword, as if he would kill him, if his rahnes hould make him attempt any thing. Stay (aid he) or come upon thy Death and know the reaon; I have held my hand, is becaue I begin to know thy Peron, though I doubt thy Meaning; Thermutis intreating Pardon for his intruion, fell at the feet of Theagenes as uppliant, rather temporizing, and for fear of Danger, than having changed his mind to be revenged of them; and beeeching Knemon to peak for him, pleaded, they were tyed to ave his life having never done them Injury, and the day before been there Companion, and now fled to them as his Friends. This moved Knemon, and made him come in and raie Thermutis, who was protrated on the Earth; and many times demanded of him what was become of Thyamis? Thermutis told all his Captains Fortune, how he had fought in the midt of his Enemies, neither paring theirs nor his own life, and how by a commandment to take him alive, they forbare to hurt him though he lew them, and o he left him invironed, finding himelf o wounded as
he could hardly wim to Land, and that for the preent he was come into the cave to look for Thesbe; they ask'd him how he came to know Thesbe, or where he had got her? He told them, how he had taken her from the Merchants, how he fell in love with her, how for a while he concealed her in his Cabbin, and at the coming of the Enemy, put her into the Cave, where he now found her lain, but by whoe hands he knew not, yet would be glad to be informed the Author and Occaion of the Murther; Knemon deirous to free himelf of the upition, preently told him Thyamis was the Murderer; and to confirm it, hewed him the Sword he had found beides her: When Thermutis aw the Blade yet dropping Blood, and hot, and knew it to be his Captain's, fetching a deep igh, not able to imagine what hould move him to that Act, blinded and dumb with Grief, he left them, and returned to the Body, and falling upon it, laying his head in her boom, he cried, Oh Thesbe! forgetting all other Words.

Theagenes, Chariclea and Knemon being now alone, began to tudy what coure they were bet to take, and made a hew as if they would conult together; but the multidue of pat Mieries, the perplexity of preent Calamities, and the incertitude of the future yet hanging over their heads, o confued their Spirits, that they did nothing but look one upon another, expecting who would firt begin the Overture; that
Hope failing, they bowed down their Eyes, and again liting them up, ighed; o eaing their ad Hearts: At length Knemon tretched himelf upon the Earth, Theagenes ate down upon a Stone with Chariclea on his Knee; and a long time they put off Sleep, deiring by ome good Counel to provide for their Affairs; but broke with Grief and Labour, though unwilling, they obeyed the Law of Nature, and from the extremity of Sorrow lided into the weetnes of a Sleep, the reaonable part of the Soul being forced to conent to the neceity of the Body.

When Slumber had new eized upon them, and but even joyned their Eye-lids, and a little lightned them of their Burden, Chariclea that lay in the Boom of Theagenes, dreamed that he aw an ugly man come towards her, having his Hair all matted and Elfe-lock'd, looking like a Traytor, his Eyes unk in his Head, and his Hands bloody, who running at her with his Sword, truck out her right Eye; he preently crying out, called Theagenes, and aid her Eye was gone; he preently awaked, and deplored her Misfortune, as if he had dreamed o too; but he feeling about with her hand for the Eye he had lot in her Sleep; and oon recollecting her elf, aid, I did but dream, I did but dream, Theagenes; my Eyes are afe: do not afflict your elf.

Thee Words gave new Life to Theagenes: The Gods be thanked (aid he) that have preerved thoe Sun-Beams: But what was the Matter?
what Terror did invade you? Oh, aid he, a wicked and ill-favoured man, not fearing your unconquered valour, with his Sword drawn inulted over me, that had taken Sanctuary in your Boom, and methought he truck out my right Eye, and would it had been Truth, not a Dream: The Gods forbid, replied Theagenes; Why ay you o? Becaue, aid he, it had been better for me to have lot an Eye, than to have been put in uch a fear for you; for I doubt this Dream portends ome ill to you, who are dearer to me than my Eyes, or Life it elf. No more of that, aid Knemon (for he had heard all, awaking with the firt Cry of Chariclea) To me this Dream ignifies quite another thing; tell me, Are your Parents living? Chariclea aid Yes; Then aid Knemon, Believe your Father to be dead. Thus I conjecture it; Our Parents are the Authors of our Life, and it is by their Means we ee and enjoy this Light; therefore I hold it apt to compare our Father and Mother to our Eyes, the ene capable of Light, and whereby we dicern things viible; and this is the meaning of your Dream. A heavy Sence, replied Chariclea; yet rather be this verified than the other. May your Tripos divine rightly, and I prove a fale Prophet. The Event will crown my Divination, replyed Knemon, and o ret you content.

But methinks we dream yet, that o much trouble our elves about imaginations, and omit to reolve what we hould do whilt this Egyptian
(meaning Thermutis) hath left us for a while, to mourn for his dead Mitres; Theagenes catching his Word, prithee Knemon, aid he, ince ome Divine Power hath joyned thee to us, and made thee our companion in Miery; firt give us thy Advice, for thou knowet the Country, and undertandet the Language; and we, that are never very apprehenive, are at this intant o dulled with Calamity, as we have not undertanding in our own Affairs.
Knemon pawing a while, pake thus;
I know not which of us have greatet hare in Misfortune; I have a Burden great enough; yet in regard you command me (as the eldet here, and mot vered in the World, to give my Opinion, this it is;

This Iland as you ee is laid wate and deerted, containing now no living creatures but our elves, within this Cave is great tore of Gold, Silver and Silks (for it is hardly to be imagined what quantity of rich Spoyls Thyamis hath taken both from us and others, and depoited here) but for Corn and other Ammunition neceary to maintain Life, there is left no more but the bare Names; if therefore we tay here long, it is to be feared we hall perih either by Famine, or the Enemy, that may return, or by our own Fellows, if they make Head again; for they are not ignorant where the Treaure lieth, and are likely to come hither for upplies of Money, and then we cannot ecape their Fury; or if
they hould deal mildlier with us, yet we hould be obnoxious to their Petulancies, and uffer the Indignities of their barbarous humors; for Thieves are men that naturally keep no Faith, and les now than ever, having lot their Captain, that could by his Authority bridle their Inolencies; therefore we mut leave the Iland, and get away from it as out of a Net or Prion; but firt let us free our elves of Thermutis, under pretence of ending him to try if he can hear any News of Thyamis; and when we are none but our elves, we hall more eaily conider and reolve what we have to do: and it much concerns us to dipatch away this incontant, quarrelom and ill natur'd man, and that hath us in upition for the Death of Thesbe, and will not be at quiet in himelf till he be revenged upon us if occaion be preented.

They approved his Counel, and thought bet to follow it: Then going forward to the Entry of the Cave, they perceived it was Day; and awaking Thermutis, whom they found in a dead Sleep; and he being a light and credulous man, they eaily perwaded him as they pleaed; acquainting him (as he believed) with their Purpoes; the Body of Thesbe they laid in a little Pit, and covered it intead of Earth, with Ahes, the Ruines of their late Houe, and performing the Ceremonies that Piety owes to the dead, as fully as the time would uffer, and for all Funeral Offerings make a Parentation of their Tears, they
ent Thermutis to eek Thyamis, He had gone but a little way, when uddenly he turned back, and told them he would not go alone, nor object himelf to the danger of being a Spy, unles Knemon would be a Partner with him: Theagenes perceiving Knemon to hang back for fear of the Egyptian, as might eaily be judged by the Character he had made of Thermutis, wherein he had pictured his own Fear; What, aid Theagenes, o trong in Counel, and o weak in Execution! Take heed you do not make my upition of your Valour prove a Truth; revive, rouze your Spirits, Man, and at leat make a hew as if you were content to go along with him, let your refual make him upect our flight: Away, go with him; there's no danger, you have your Cloaths on, and a Sword by your ide, why hould you fear to walk with a naked man, that hath no Weapon to offend you? And then taking your time, you may ecretly forake him, and come to us at an appointed place, which hall be ome Neighbour-Town, if you know any uch, where the Inhabitants are civil men.

Tis very well advis'd, aid Knemon; let us meet at Chemmis, a rich Town, well Peopled, and near hand, ituate upon the skirts of Nilus, below the Banks, that defend it from the Surprizes and Incurions of the Heardmen; when you have pat the Lake, it is but a hundred Furlongs thither, and you mut go directly South: We hall hardly reach it, aid Theagenes, Chariclea hath
not been ued to o long Journeys; yet we will go and diguie our elves like Beggars or poor Fortune-tellers that travel about the Countrey to charm all Alms from thee hard People. Oh! you will make excellent Gypies, aid Knemon, Out upon you, what black deformed Faces you have, epecially Chariclea, that hath lately lot an Eye! and yet by your Habit you will be uch fine Mendicants, that ure the Countrey People will think you wander about to beg Jewels, Gold, Plate, and not a poor Alms, or a Morel of Bread. At this they could have been content to laugh; but their Mirth only extended to a Smile: Then taking a olemn oath never to abandon one another, confirming what they had determined, they dipoed themelves accordingly.

Knemon and Thermutis paing the Lake whilt it was yet early day, took their way through an intricate thick Wood, Thermutis went before, Knemon having entreated him, becaue he was skilful in the ways, that were difficult; but indeed it was to ecure his own Life, and to prepare occaion to give him the lip: when they were now come into the thicket of the Wood, they met a Flock of Sheep, and killing the Bell-weather, laid the Fleh to roat upon the Fire which the Shepherds (that fled at ight of them) had kindled for themelves; neither would their Bellies let them be in quiet till the Meat was enough, but Hunger made them o fierce, as like Wolves or Tigers, they devoured it in great
Gobbets, only a little black'd with the Fire, the Blood running about their Mouths. When thus they had atisfied their Hunger, and quenched their Thirt with Milk provided for the Shepherds they held on their Journey.

Now it was time for Knemon to hew all his Cunning, for they were come to the top of a Hill, whence Thermutis hewed him a Town in the Bottom, where he imagined Thyamis to be a Prioner, either in the Gaol, or in his Grave; for thither he heard that he was carried.

Whilt he pake this, Knemon made as if his Belly aked, and told him he began to feel the crudities of the Meat, and that he feared the Milk he drank had curdled upon his Stomach, for he was in extream torment; therefore he intreated Thermutis that he would go on, and he would follow him; this he did once and again, and the third time, as if it had been real, and that he had overtaken him with much difficulty, inomuch as the Egyptian gave Credit to his counterfeit Dieae; and being now ued to attend his coming, Knemon lengthned his Expectation, and tayed for altogether, running counter through the obcuret Paage of the Wood, and cating about by the Hill ide, fled with all poible peed.

Thermutis paing the Hill-top expected Knemen, and the Night under whoe favourable had-dow they might pas into the Town; and learn the tate of Thyamis: often looking behind him to ee if he did come, and Plotting in what manner he hould kill him; for he yet upected his conent to Thesbe's Death, and therefore meant to ferve him in the ame kind; and then, at his return promiing himelf to Sacrifice Theagenes to his revenge. But Knemon not appearing, and Night now growing Black, he fell aleep: which was his lat, the Iron Sleep of Death, bitten with an Apick; perhaps by the fatal pleaure of the Gods, a death anwerable to his life, tealing upon him as he had done upon others.

But Knemon after he had lot ight of Thermutis, never taid to take his Breath till darknes arreting his eyes, topped his flight, and in the ame place were the Night urpriz'd him, he hid and covered himelf all over with leaves a great part of the Night, never hutting his eyes, but Sweating, and Fearing every noie and every breath of Wind, and every motion of the leaves to be Thermutis. If at any time leep pret upon him, he dreamed that he was Flying, and awaking, looked behind his back for him, that was not now in cae to follow: many fearful viions tarted him and hindered his deire, and putting him in greater terror than if Thermutis had come indeed; Finally he grew angry with the Night, and thought in the longet that ever was ince the beginning of the World.

But when with infinite joy he perceived the firt pring of Day, preently he cut off his long Hair, which he had let grow after the fahion of the Thieves, for fear thoe he hould meet would either hun him, or upect him; for the Ilanders among other coures they take to appear terrible, let their Locks at full length hang dangling upon their Shoulders, not ignorant that long hair is an ornament in a Lover, but a horror in a Thief; having therefore left himelf as much hair as the neater ort of People ued to wear, and les then the Heards-men, he hated the nearet way to Chemmis, the Town Theagenes had appointed him for meeting.

Being now near unto the river Nilus, ready to take Water for Chemmis, he aw an Old Man walking up and down upon the Shoar, as if he had been dicouring with the Stream; his white hair he wore long in fahion of a Prophet, a great long Picked Beard, his Caock and his other Rober reembling a Greek Habit. Knemon tood till a while and looked upon him, but the Old Man paing by many times and not perceiving him, being wholly fixt upon his Meditation; Knemon tept in before him, and aluted him, bidding the Gods bles him. No aid the old Man, Fortune hath otherwie dipoed: Knemon wondring at his Anwer, asked him, Are you a Grecian, Stranger, or of whence? Neither a Grecian, nor a Stranger, he replyed; but this Countryman, an Aegyptian: How come you then to wear thee Grecian
Robes? (aid Knemon) Calamity (anwered the Old Man) hath put me in this glorious Habit, and changed my ordinary Dres; Knemon admiring how Miery hould make any Man go in richer Cloaths, and deiring him to unfold the Riddle; Oh! aid the Old Man, To relate my Fortunes, would bring my elf and you into a Labyrinth, whence we hould not get out, and but load you with my burden; But, young Man, whither lies your journey? Or whence do you come? Or how is it you peak Greek in Aegypt? This is ridiculous, aid Knemon, to enquire of my Affairs, and tell me nothing of your own, and I asked the firt quetion. Well, I am content to bear your Jet, aid the Old Man; for it appears you are a Grecian: and I believe that in this play of Fortune you have changed hapes as well as I; but ince you eem taken with a curioity to undertand my Etate, I will atisfie you; for know I am big with grief, and if I had not light of you, perhaps I had expreed my elf to thee Reeds. Bur firt, let us leave this Shoar and River of Nilus, for this is not a convenient place for o long a Narration, the heights of this Bank lying open and expoed to the Noon-Day-Sun, let us Ferry over to the Town we ee upon the other Side; if happily ome greater buines doth not call you away, there I will bid you welcome, not in my own Houe, but in the Houe of a good Man that receives me as a Suppliant. There I will inform you, if you pleae, of my affairs,
and you hall recompence me with a relation of yours; Along then aid, Knemon, for I have buines to the Town; I mut there expect the coming of ome Friends.

Then taking Boat (many Oars lying upon the River to tranport Paengers for their Money) they paed over to the Town, and the Old Man brought Knemon to the Houe where himelf was a Guet; they found the Mater of the Houe from home; only his Daughter that was now Marriageable, entertained them, and every ervant of the Houe was officious to them; both their Mitres and they oberving the Old Man as if he had been her Father; for o it is likely they were commanded: one bruhed the dut off their Cloaths, brought water for their Feet, and wahed and dryed them; another made their Beds Eaie and Soft, another kindled the Fire, ome cover'd the Table, others brought Water and a Towel for their Hands, others et Manchets upon the Board, and erved in the Fruits of the Seaon, whereof their was Variety. Knemon wondring at their entertainment, Sure Father, aid he, we are come into the Houe of Jupiter the Hopitable; they do us o much obervance, and hew uch ingular alacrity: This is no Gods Houe, aid the old Man; but it belongs to one that is a true Adorer of the Gods, that worhips Jupiter the Hopitable and Patron of the Suppliants. For Child, he is a Merchant and hath pent his life in Travel; een many Cities and Nations, and tudied Men
and Manners, and having himelf been a Pilgrim in the World, I take it to be his reaon why he entertaineth others, and among the ret, Me, that a few days ince was a wanderer in thee parts.

How came it to pas, Father, aid Knemon, that you hould be compelled to wander abroad? Being deprived (replyed he) of my Children by Thieves, and though I know the Villains well enough, yet not having power to revenge my elf, I remain here hovering about them, and complaining like the poor Bird that hath her Net robb'd by a Serpent devouring her young before her Eyes, whilt he fears to come near, yet hath no power to fly away: for love and grief ditract her, crying, he flies about the Beieger, and pours the orrow of a Parent into the ears to which nature hath taught no pity.

Oblige me (aid Knemon) with the knowledge of the circumtance and time wherein you uffered this great conflict in your Spirits; Anon I will inform you, he replyed; now it is time to appeae our appetite and content our belly; which drawing us away how great oever the buines be we have in agitation, is properly called pernitious by the admirable Homer. But firt following the percepts of the Aegyptian Widom, let us offer the firt fruits of our repat to the Gods; a cutom I hall never violate, and my grief how trong oever it is, hall never prevail with me o far as to blot out of my memory the divine powers, and the honour I am bound to render them.

Then pouring on the Earth clear water out of a Vial, I offer he aid, this effuion to the Gods of Aegypt and of Greece, to Apollo of Delphos, and to Theagenes and Chariclea the bet and noblet; therefore I think it lawful to number them amongt the Gods: With this he wept, making a econd offering of his tears to orrow.

Knemon was amaz'd to hear thee names, and began to take a tricter veiw of the Old Man: How ay you Father, aid he, are Theagenes and Chariclea your Children? They are (replyed the Old Man) my Children born without a Mother, for the Gods have miraculouly been pleaed that I hould get them by accident, and be delivered of them not without the grief and paions of my Soul. My Love, though not my Nature, was a Father to them, o they eteemed and called me; But tell me how came you to know them? I do not only know them, anwered Knemon; but I am able to aure you they are in health and afe, Oh Apollo! and all other Gods, cryed the Old Man, inform me in what part of the world they live; I will eteem thee my Preerver and the Equal of my happiet Stars; But what will you give me aid Knemon? For the preent aid he, my thanks, a grateful heart, accounted the fairet preent a wie man can receive; I have known ome would treaure up this gift as their bet riches, but if the Gods pleae I hall recover my own (as I have their promie it hall be hortly) I will reward you nobly, make you a rich Man: Said
Knemon, you promie things future and uncertain, I look for preent pay: Let me know what it is you demand, aid the Old Man, do you ee any thing you would have? If it be any part of my body, I will cut it off, and eteem my elf the ounder Man. It is only this, aid Knemon, that you will truly relate to me of whence they are, their Parents and their Fortunes: A great Donative! replyed the Old Man: There is no other comparable to it, though you had asked all the riches of the Earth and Sea, but you hall have it only firt; let us take a little repat, for it will be a long time of imployment for us, both mine to relate, and yours to hear.

When they had now filled themelves with Nuts, Figgs, new pulled Dates, and uch like Fruits, whereon the Old Man ued to feed (for he never eat any thing that had life taken from it) they drank the pure 'Water; but Knemon pure Wine. After they had a while kept ilence, Father you are not ignorant, aid Knemon, how good a companion Bacchus is, how much he delights in Entertainments, Vere, and Stories; he hath now taken up his lodging in my Brain, and makes me extreamly covetous of the reward you promied me; and therefore, Father, it is now time you bring thee perons upon the Stage: I will, replyed the Old Man: and I wih with all my heart the honet Nauicles had been with us, who hath often been earnet with me to dicoure thee paages; but I have till put him off
from time to time. Where is he? aid Knemon, hearing him name Nauicles: He is gone a hunting, aid the Old Man: not to chae Beats, but wilder Creatures that are called Men and Heardmen, but they are Thieves, and not without much difficulty to be taken, the pernicious Otters live in uch an Iland of invincible Earth and Water: But how have they offended him? They have (aid the old Man) robbed him of an Athenian Gentlewoman, named Thesbe; Oh ho! aid Knemon, and took himelf in the manner, and o topped his Speech: The old Man asking him what was the matter? Knemon diverted him to another conideration; I wonder aid Knemon, under the aurance of what forces he durt fall upon thee Robbers! the great, King replyed the Old man, hath made Oroondates his Lieutenant of Aegypt, by whoe command Mitranes Captain of the Garrions is billeted in this town for our defence; and Nauicles with a great um of Mony, hath procured him to lead his Hore and Foot againt the Ilanders, being in an extream rage that they hould take from him this Athenian Woman; not only becaue he is his friend, and playeth curiouly upon the Lute, but principally becaue, as he telleth me, he was to carry her to the King of Aethiopia to be near the Queen, to pas her time, and teach her the fahions and the language of the Grecians; the pite to loe o great a remuneration as he expected, makes him now ue all the Engines of his wit and power to
recover her, I my elf have been a Principal in perwading and encouraging him, becaue o (happily) I may come to find my Children.

Enough aid, Knemon, let us now leave talking of Herdmen and Thieves, Lieutenants, Captains and Kings; for I protet you had almot inenibly tollen away my Mind to a new Matter, making a long Preface nothing to my purpoe; therefore I pray you bring about your Oration to the Path you promied me; for methinks I ee the Pharian Proteus revived in you, not that you turn your elf into as many commentitious Species, and fluxive Forms, appearing and vanihing, but that you would transform me, and change the Mould of my Imagination. I will recount the Truth unto you (aid the old man) without diguies, whatoever you are pleaed to think of me; but firt I will make you a brief Dicovery of my own Fortune, becaue theirs depends upon it.

There City of Memphis is my Countrey, my Fathers Name was Calairis, o is mine; my preent condition is no better than a poor Pilgrim, that was ometimes in that City honoured with the Charge of the Chief Priet; I had a Wife by the Intitutions of our Town, but I lot her by the Law of Nature: After he was departed from her mortal Body to eternal Ret, for a while I lived and felt not Miery, commforting my elf in my two Sons he had left me; but it few years,
my better Stars having finihed their precribed Circle, the Face of my Affairs began to change, and Saturn with an ill Apect beheld our Houe, threatning the Ruine of it, which I had widom to foreee, but no power to prevent; for any man may predicover the immutable Decrees of Fate; but no man can avoid them: only this good there is in Fore-ight, that it rebates the Point, and takes off the edge of our Diaters, which, (Child) if they fall udden, are intolerable; but fore-eeing, we are prepared to receive them; otherwie Fear diquieting the Soul, makes us bear them with impatience, but this Acquaintance renders them familiar to our Reaon: My firt Misfortune was this;

A Thracian Woman, in the perfect Flower of her Age, the fairet, as I think, next to Chariclea in the world, naming her elf Rhodopis, I know not whence or how, but by the advere fate of thoe that were acquainted with her, was brought to travel through Egypt, and with a petulant Confidence hewed her elf at Memphis, followed with a great Train of Maids and Men that erved her, her Carriages richly laded, and her elf exactly tudied in all the Charms and Allurements of a Venus; it was not poible for any man to ee her, but he mut be taken; uch an inevitable facination hot from her eyes: She often came into the Temple of the Goddes Iis (whoe Priet I was) and hewed great Devotion to the Goddes, being frequent in Sacrifices, making
Rich and Princely Offerings at our Altars; I bluh to peak it (yet you hall know all) her Beauty that I had often tood the aaults of, at length conquered me, and forced my Continency, which till then I had afely guarded all my Life: a great while the Eyes of my Soul reited thoe of my Body; but after a long fight I was contrained to yield, the Paion of a Lover preing upon me, and lying heavy as a Load of Chains; therefore I found this Woman to be the firt Mover and beginning of thoe Evils which hanged over me, (a long while before dicovered by my Art) undertanding there was fatal neceity in it, and that the Devil that troubled my Repoe, had put on that Form and Shape to perecute me; I reolved howoever not dihonour my Prietly Function, wherein from a Child I had been bred, and rather die than prophane the Temples and Altars of the Gods; at length Reaon obtaining the Empire of my Soul, to atisfie for the fatal offence I had committed, not actually (which Heaven forbid) but in thought only, I punih'd my Concupicence with voluntary Banihment, and left my Country of my own accord, as well to obey the force of Detiny, and uffer it to do with me what it pleaed; as alo to avoid the ight of the execrable Rhodopis: For (Friend) I was afraid let Love laying iege to my Heart, (that was yet defended by Reaon) hould at length take the Fortres, and make me commit ome foul thing: But that which principally expell'd
me, was, my Children, who (as the Gods by their Myterious Widom had revealed to me) were to fight a ingle Combat fatally together; therefore to take from my Eyes the ight of uch a lamentable Object (which I imagine the Sun himelf will not behold, masking his Beams behind a Cloud) not to make a Father o unhappy as to tand by and ee his Children murder one another, I abandoned my Country and my Fathers Houe, not making any one privy to the Caue of my Departure, nor whither I was bound; pretending a Journey to the great City of Thebes, to ee my Elder Son, who remained there with his Grandfather by the Mothers ide, his Name was Thyamis.
Again Knemon tood wondring, as if the Name of Thyamis had trook him, yet he forbare to peak, impatient to hear out the Dicoure, which Calairis thus continued;

Young man, I leave out my Journey, and the Paages thereof, as not pertinent to the Story you deire; but having often heard that in Greece there was a City named Delphos, particularly dedicated to Apollo, yet that there was a common Temple, wherein alo all the Gods were honoured, and a kind of Fellowhip or niverity of Wie men, eparate from the Tumults of the Vulgar, I eteem'd it would be the mot proper and convenient retiring place for a Prophet, as a City detined to Sacred Ceremonies; then looing out from the Gulf of Criaeum, and arriving at Cirrhus, I was no ooner Landed, but I hated towards
Delphos, and coming near the Town, a Sound (doubtles Divine) preently beat upon my Ear. Methought this City was the weetet place of Abode that ever I had een, both for its own Beauty, and in regard Nature and Art had been in trife to fortifie it; the Mountain Parnaus hangs over it, with his tretched ides flanking in the Town, as with a Bulwark.

You ay true, aid Knemon, and like a man inpired by Apollo; for my Father made the ame Decription unto me of the ituation of Delphos, when the Town of Athens ent him thither Ambaador from the Etates of the Amphictiones.
Then you are an Athenian (aid Calairis) I am; Your Name I pray you? Knenion, he replied. Your Fortune? You hall know mine hereafter: But now follow your Dicoure: Content, replied Calairis.

After I was come up to the Town, and that I had delighted my Eyes with the great Plains, fair Fields, Places of Exercie, Rivers, Springs, and the Catalian Fountain, where I purified my elf, I hated to the Temple, following the Pres of People that went thither, it being then the hour wherein the Prophetes ued to be inpired, and peak Oracles: Having entred the Temple, adored the God, and commended my Wihes in a hort Prayer, the Prietes, whom they call Pythia, thus replyed;

q.l: Wandring from fruitful Nilus, thou dot fly,
Poor Voluntier, thy too trong Detiny:
Stay, for black Egypt hortly I'le again
Retore thee; here till then, our Friend, remain.

div.p:
When he had uttered this, I protrated upon my Face before the Altar, humbly praying Apollo to be propitious to me in all Affairs: All that were preent greatly praied the God for having vouchafed me o gracious an Anwer at my firt Arrival; and thenceforth the People honoured and oberved me, wondring at my good Fortune, who they aid was the only man that ever Apollo had called Friend ince one Lycurgus a Lacedemonian; and when they knew I deired to dwell within the Cloyter of the Temple, they permitted me, and decreed me a publick Allowance to defray my Charges. In um, there was no good thing wanting to my content; for either I was buied to enquire the Reaons of the Ceremonies, of the many and different Sacrifices both Strangers and the Inhabitants offer to the God, or ele I pat my time in Conference and Dipute with the Philoophers repairing thither in great numbers, as to a Colledge conecrated to the Mues, whereof Apollo that inpires them, is the Mater: at firt they moved many Quetions to me, ome of one thing, ome of another; one demanded in what manner we Aegyptians worhiped our Gods? another asked me why we adore Creatures, and hold them Sacred and Divine? ome enquired of the form and tructure of our Pyramids?
Many were curious in quetioning me about the Art of our Conduits and Water-works; and not to particularize, they left nothing unenquired that concerneth us; for the Singularities of Aegypt do marvellouly take the Ears of Greece.

Finally, ome of the graver ort put Quetions to me about Nilus, which were his Springs, and the peculiar Nature wherein that River differed from others, and why only thoe Waters increae in Summer time; I told them what I knew, and had found written in our Sacred Books, which are not to be read nor undertood by any but our Prophets, recounting to them that the Head and Source of Nilus rieth from the Mountains of Aethiopia, in the farthet parts of Lybia, there where the Eatern Climate ends, and the Meridian takes beginning: It increaes in the Summer (not as ome imagine, becaue the Winds named the Eteiae, blowing contrary to their Stream, make them regurgit and overflow; but in regard the ame Winds riing about the Summer Soltice, violently chae and drive all the Clouds from North to South, that carried upon their wift Wings to the torrid Zone, are there topped, and by the incredible vehemency of the circumfued heat, their motion is beaten back, and the humor that before was gathered and condened, then thaws, and detilling in great howers, making Nilus o proud, that he no longer endures to be a River, but paing his Limits, covers Aegypt with his inundation like a Sea, making fruitful the Country as he paeth, this is the reaon his Waters are o weet to drink, becaue he receiveth them
from Heaven, and they are fine to bath in, not hot as when they fall, yet Milk warm as retaining part of their original; hence it comes that of all Rivers only, this exhales no vapours: which would necearily follow by natural reaon, if (as certain learned Grecians have conceived) the Tides had taken their increae from Snow melting and pouring off the Mountains.

As I dicoured thus the Priet of Apollo my intimare Friend, named, Charicles, You peak aid he, excellently well, and I aent to your opinion; for it is the ame I heard of your Priets in the Catadupes of Nilus.

Were you ever there Charicles? aid I: I was, replyed he: I demanded if he had any buines there? he anwered, my advere Fortune at home made me travel thither, and was the caue of my elicity; I marvelling at his words, as implying contradiction: You will not wonder (he aid) when you hear all the paages which I will tell you when you pleae: We cannot have a better time, I aid: Be it now if you think good. Then Charicles taking me aide, Know aid he, I have long wihed to give you the relation of my Fortunes, as having need of your aitance, wie Calairis; After I was Married, I was ome years without Children: at length growing into years yet continuing earnet in my Prayers to the Gods, they bleed me with Iue, and made me Father of a Daughter in the declining of my Age; but with ad predictions, that her Birth hould be unfortunate:
he being now grown Marriageable, many Suitors were ambitious to be her Husband, I matched her to him that in my Judgment bet deerved her; but even upon her Marriage-Night in her Husbands Bed and Arms, the Mierable dyed uffocated by Fire; either from Heaven, or cattered from the hand of ome too careles Peron: o Mourning and Tears took place of her Nuptial Bravery, and of the Epithalamion that was yet ung from her Marriage-Chamber, he was carryed to her Tomb; and the ame Torches that were lighted at her Wedding, erv'd for her Funeral-Fire: nor did the divine Powers let this Tragedy end here; but added her Mother to the Scene of Death, Heart-broken for her Child. I having not contancy enough to upport thee rigours of the Gods, would not yet exile my elf from Life (obeying the more probable Doctrine of Divines) but reolved to forake my Country, and no more to ee the olitude and orrow of my Houe; for it is a great eae to Miery to remove the ad Object from our Eyes: And having wandred many Countreys, at length I came into your Aegypt, and travelled to the Catadupes, to ee the Cataracts and falls of Nilus: Here you have the reaons of my Journey, but I deire you hould know the Head, or rather Crown of the Narration.

As I was there walking the Streets, and buying ome Rarities, whereof there was carcity in Greece (for now time having digeted my Sorrow,
I longed to return into my Country) a venerable black Man (with a face full of Gravity, though he were but newly tepped out of his Youth) came to me, and aluted me; telling me in broken Greek, that he deired to have ome conference with me; I obeying his deire, he carried me into a Temple hard by; and aid, I aw you buying ome Indian and Aethiopian Herbs and Roots, but if you will have them incere and without all Sophitication, buy of me; With all my Heart aid I: Pray you hew them; But take heed, aid he, you be not too wary a Buyer: Look you, aid I, you be not too dear a Seller.

Then drawing out a little Cabbinet that he carried under his Arm, he opened it; and hewed me certain Gems of an inetimable value; there were Pearls of the bignes of a Hael-Nut, exactly round, and fair without a Flaw; Emeralds, and Jacinths; the one hewing like the green Corn in the Spring time, hining in their Polih as if oyled, the other imitating the colour of the Sea-hore under a high bending Rock, dying all below it in a purple Colour. In fine, of all the Stones together, there was a mixt and various Water infinitely pleaing and delightful to the Eye: When I had well conidered them, Friend, aid I, you mut eek you other kind of Chapmen than I am, for all my wealth will not be great enough to purchae me the leat of thee. If you have not means to buy them, aid he,
yet I hope you have power to receive them as a gift: That's true, I replyed, I think my power were ufficient to receive them; but I cannot imagine what hould induce you thus to mock me: I mock not, he replyed, but what I do is erious: and I protet unto you by the power that is Patron of this Temple, I will give you all thee provided you will receive with this a richer git. At this I fell a laughing; and he demanding the caue, I told him it eemed to me a ridiculous thing, that offering me uch Riches, he would yet promie a Reward for receiving of them of far richer Value; Believe me, replyed he, but let me take your Oath withal that you will nobly ue this gift, and as I hall intruct you. A while I tood in doubt, yet I did wear, won with the hope of uch a promie; but when I had taken my Oath in the form he gave it, he took me along with him, and hewed me a Maid endowed with an incomparable Form and Grace, as he aid, but even Years old; but to me he eemed almot marriageable; o much doth the excellency of a Face add to the lownes of a Stature. My eyes dazling at this wonder, I tood amazed and peechles (partly becaue I was ignorant of what he meant to do; but principally out of an inatiable deire of beholding the young Lady) till he awaked me with thee words.

Stranger, This Maid thou eet, for ome caues thou halt undertand hereafter, was expoed by her Mother in her wathing-Bands; and left to
the uncertainty of Fortune. I lighting by chance upon her, took her up; for I had been Wicked and a Villain, if I had uffered a Soul to float in o much danger, that had once entred a humane Body: for this is one of the Precepts of our Gymnoophits, whoe Scholar, though unworthy, I have been. But that which mot moved my Charity was a kind of Divinity that I aw hining in the Infants Eyes, whilt it earnetly looked upon me; and though dumb, begged Pity weetly: With her was laid forth this heap of Pretious Stones I lately hewed you; and a Silk-Mantle wherein was ewed in Gold in her Country Characters the Relation of her ad Fortune: Nature (as I think) having made her Mother furnih the Child with thee Additions, whereby one day he might be known: When I read the Scrowl, I knew of whence, and who he was, and carried her from beides the City far into the Country, and gave her to a Sheperd to be brought up, threatning to kill him if he told how he came by her: The things that were expoed with her, I retained, let the Child hould be made away for them; thus at firt I did conceal her.

But as he grew in Years, he grew in Beauty and Perfection; and ure a Beauty (though hidden in the Center of the Earth will be dicovered;) therefore fearing he would be known, and both he and I dye for it, I laboured to be ent Ambaadour to the Lieutenant of Aegypt, and
coming hither brought her with me, deiring to ettle her Etate; the Governour hath ent me word I hall have Audience to day, and he hall now hear the reaons of my Embaage. Therefore now I recommend the Child to you, and to the Gods that have o dipoed of her, under the conditions of your Oath, being always to maintain her Liberty, and to match her to a Man as free as you receive her from my Hands; or to peak better, from her ad Mothers, that expoed her; I am confident you will accomplih all your promies confirmed unto me by the Religion of your Vow, and the Candor of your Manners; which ince your being in thee parts, I have curiouly oberved, and know them to be worthy of a Grecian. This is all I have to ay to you for the preent, my Legating Affairs now calling me away; but to Morrow meet me in the Temple of Iis, and there I will more plainly, and particularly inform you of the Secrets that concern the Maid.

I was punctual in oberving his Commands; and taking the Maid, I ecretly conveyed her to my lodging, where I imployed the whole day to entertain her the mot honourably and repectively I could; tudying to win her Heart with all weet ways, and rendring great thanks to the Gods for the Exchange of Children they had pleaed to make me; from that hour eteeming and naming her my Daughter.

Next Morning early I came to the Temple of Iis, as I had promied the Stranger; and after I had walked there a long time, he not appearing, I went to the Governors Houe, and demanded if any one had een the Aethiopian Ambaador? Preently one told me that he departed, or rather was expelled lat Evening before Sun-et, the Governour threatning he hould loe his Head, if immediatly he did not quit his Frontiers; informing me alo the Caue: That delivering his Embaage, he commanded the Aegyptian to forbear to dig the Emerald Mines, as appertaining to the King of Aethiopia; I returned to my Lodging ad and penive, as one that had hard Fortune, being not able to get any knowledge of the Child, who, or of whence, or of what Parents he was born. It is no marvel, aid Knemm, interrupting him, for I my elf am mightily troubled that I can hear no more; but yet I hope I may. You hall, replied Calairis; but now I will follow the Dicoure Charicles then made me.

After, aid he, that I was returned to my Lodging, the little Maid came to meet me, uing Action for Words, having not yet learned to peak any Greek, he aluted my by giving me her hand, and her Eyes pake that he received contentment in my preence. I was amazed; he would leap for Joy, look me in the Face, and oberving the Repect and Love I bare her, he paid me with the honour and reverence of a Natural Child, I therefore reolved to tay no longer in the Town
of Catadupes, fearing ome malevolent Fortune in a trange Countrey, might deprive me of this other Daughter; and taking Boat, we rowed down Nilus to the Sea, whence I ailed home; where to this intant I have kept and cherihed this Child as tenderly as if Nature, not Accident, had betowed her on me, giving her my own Name, and my Content depending only upon hers, o prodigal hath Heaven been of Graces to her, that he anticipated my Wihes; for peedily he attained to the Greek Tongue, in uch an intant he came to the Spring of her Age, like a fruitful and noble Plant, blooming early, and with wonder; in Beauty he had no Equal; but all mens Eyes, both Grecians and Strangers were fixed on her; for in what place oever he appeared, either in the Temples, at the Theaters, or any other publick Meetings, as if he had been the Statue of ome Goddes newly made, no man could think or look upon any thing ele.

But though he is no les than I have pictured her unto you, yet he cruelly afflicts my Heart, denouncing open War to Marriage, reolving to pend all her Life in the tate of Virginity, and as a follower of Diana, loves Hunting, and practieth her Bow and Arrows, whilt my Life grows bitter to me, being frutrated of my Hope to match her to my Siters Son, a civil and wellbred Gentleman, endowed with many excellent good Qualities; but in vain we court her, he hath o hard an Opinion of Marriage, that neither
by Service, Prayers, or Promies he can be perwaded; but, which adds to my Grief, he ueth my own Weapons againt me, employing the Rhethorick I have taught her, to find Arguments to confute mine, and prove that he hath choen the bet kind of Life, elevating a Virgins Life with Divine Praies, and placing it near to the immortal Gods, calling it pure, incorruptible, and uncontaminate, but extreamly undervaluing and deteting Love, Venus, and all Nuptial Pomps and Ceremonies: Now this it is wherein I implore your Aitance, and taking the offer of this Occaion, have made you o tedious, but neceary a Dicoure: Do me this Favour, good Calairis, to eek ome means out of the Secrets of your Widom, be it by Incantation, Words, or Examples, to make her know her Nature, why he was born a Woman: I know, if you pleae, you can eaily perwade her; he hath no averion from holding conference with Men, but hath been ever bred amongt them, and lives now in the ame Houe with you here within the Walls and Cloyter of the Temple: Neglect not my Intreaties, I beeech you, and permit me not without Children, Comfort or Succeor, to live grieved in my old Age: By our Apollo, and your Tutelar Gods of Aegypt, I conjure you. At thee Words (Friend Knemon) I could not refrain weeping, becaue Charicles made this Suit to me with Tears, the bet Aitance in my power I promied him.

Whilt we were deliberating upon the Matter, one comes in runing, and tells us, the General of the Aeneans was at the Temple Gates, and asked for the High Priet, to begin the Sacrifice. Idemanded of Charicles who thee Aeneans were, and what the Sacrifice was they celebrated? The Aeneans, hereplied, are a certain People of Thealy, the noblet and truet Grecians of that Country, decended from the Greek Deucalion, and inhabit along the Gulf of Melia, where they have their Capital or Metropolitan City, named Hipata, as they will have it, becaue it commends the ret; but as others eteem, it hath that Name, becaue it is ituate under the Mount Oeta; now they end this acred Embaage every fourth Year, at the time when the Phthian Games were celebrated (and this as you know is the time) wherein they do honour to Neoptolemus, the Son of Achilles, lain traiterouly at the very Altar of Apollo, by Oretes the Son of Agamemnon; and this Embaage is at this preent celebrated with more Solemnity than in precedent times; foramuch as their General boats himelf to be decended of Achilles, whom my Fortune being to encounter the other day, methought there hined in the peron of that young man ome peculiar Graces worthy of a Decendant from uch an Ancetor, of uch a Form and Goodlines of Stature, as it confirms him to be derived from a Goddes; but I wondring how he being of an Aenean Family, could draw his Line from
Achilles, (for the Aegyptian Homer's Poeie hews us that Achilles was a Phthiot) Charicles anwerred, This young Gentleman, and the other Aeneans affirm this Heros to have been born in their Country, and ay that Thetis went out of the Gulf of Mela when he was matched to Peleus, and that all the Coat there was anciently called Phthia, and that all others are Liars that challenge the Glory to have this Demi-God their Countriman; but this General draws his Pedigree from the Aecides another way, producing Menethius the Son of Sperchius and of Polidora, the Daughter of Peleus, for one of his Ancetors, that was one of the chief Captains with Achilles in the Expedition againt Troy, and for the proximity of his Blood with Achilles, commanded the firt Squadron of the Myrmidons, and to tie himelf on all parts to the Race of Achilles, he brings for an Argument this Parentation ent to Neoptolemus, wherein (as he aith) all the Thealians yield the firt place to the Aeneans, confeing thereby they are the nearet allied unto him: I do not envy them, Charicles, aid I, whether they arrogate this Honour, or claim it as their Right; but I pray you commend the Captain of this Embaage to be admitted: for I have an incredible longing to behold him.

Charicles making the Sign, one called him in, and truly methought I aw omething of Achilles in him, uch a Face, uch a Comportment, holding his Head upright, his Hair combed back,
his Notrils freely ucking in, and breathing out the Air, a Sign of Courage, and trong Spirits, his Eyes growing to a Brown, his Apect fierce, yet amiable, like a Sea new calmed.

After he had aluted us according to the Cutom, and we him; he told us it was time to offer Sacrifice to the God, that we might have day enough to finih the Obequies and other Funeral Pomp. Be it o, aid Charicles; and riing, he told me in my ear, This day you hall ee Chariclea; for the manner is, that he, being the Prietes of Apollo, hould ait at the Proceion, and Funeral Ceremonies of Neopotolemus; but Knemon, I had een the Maid before, for he had often acrificed with me, and many times made Propoitions to me of things Divine; yet I hold my tongue, expecting the future: and Charicles and I went together to the Temple; for all things appertaining to the Sacrifice were now prepared by the Thealians: When we approached the Altar, and the Chief Priet had made his Prayer, and the Young Gentleman begun the Sacrifice, the Prietes of Apollo from the mot holy and ecret part of the Temple pronounced this Oracle;
Her Name that Grace begins, and Glory ends,
And his that from a Deity decends,
Sing Delphians; thee two hall (ayling from
My Temple) to a Sun-burnt Climate, come,
And as their Virtues Coronation, there,
Loos'd from black Temples, hall white Garlands wear.

When the God, by the Mouth of his Religious, had poke this Oracle, all the Aitants were confued, not being able to interpret it; for ome crewed it to one Sence, ome, explicated it in another; and every one made a Conjecture conformable to his own Deire; but not any could touch upon the true meaning, Oracles and Dreams being commonly judged by the Event: So the Delphians amazed and atonihed, departed to ee the Magnificent Funeral Shew, neglecting to earch more curiouly the Truth hidden in his Oracle.

div.head: THE AETHIOPIAN HISTORY.
The Third Book.
div.p:
BUT after the Proceion was ended; I hope, Father, it is not ended yet, aid Knemon; for you have not yet made me a Spectator of the Ceremonies, but only told me of them, and poet me with an incredible longing, making me run to get a ight, and then like a man that cometh when the Play is done, I have een the Theater open and hut in the ame intant. Oh Knemon! aid Calairis, I would not draw you from the purpoe, non trouble you with digreions, but lead you on to the principal Subject of my dicoure, and your firt demand; but becaue you
long to know omething by the By (a ufficient Tetimony that you are an Athenian) I will make you a brief Decription of the Celebration, both for its own Excellency, and things depending thereupon.

Firt, there paed along a Hecatomb, which was a Hundred Oxen led by Slaughter-Men in a Rutick habit; they had on white Frocks girt about their wates, their right Arms and Elbows bare to their Paps, and haking Axes in their hands: all the Oxen were Cole Black, playing with their Heads a little raied, and their Necks bending in the Middle, their Horns broad and equal, not wreathed at all; ome had them gilded, ome crowned with Chaplets of Flowers, their deep Dewlaps hanging down to their Knees; they were followed with different Troops of many other kind of Victims; every Species being eparate, and martialled in fair order, with Flutes, and Hoboys: playing the tune of a Mytique Ode ing as an Anthem to the Sacrifice: Thee Troops and their Leaders were followed with two Bands of Thealian Ladies, all fair, and in rich long Robes, their Hair hanging looe; thoe that were in the firt Bond, carried little Baskets full of Fruit and Flowers, the others had little Boxes filled with Comfits and weet Odours, that as they pat prefumed the Streets: Nor did they ue their hands to thee, but carried them upon their heads, and held hands, that they might the freelier dance and march together; thee of the firt Figure, gave
the Tone and Cadence to the econd; for they were to ing a Hymn, and to dance to it; and this Hymn contained nothing but the Praies of Thetis and Peleus, of their Son Achilles, and of his Son Neoptolemus. Good Father, aid Knemon, do not offer again to deprive me of o weet a Paage, but let me hear this Hymn, unles you will make me a beholder of this Solemnity, only o far as my Eyes will reach, and uffer me to receive no pleaure by Ear. Since you are o deirous of the Song (replyed Calairis) you hall hear it.

q.l: I Thetis, fair hair'd Thetis, ing,
That did from deathles Nereus pring;
Whom Jove to Pelus match'd our bright
Beam'd Venus, and our watery Light.
That (Mother of our Mars) did bear
Achilles raging with his Spear;

l.hi: Our Thunderbolt, to whoe fam'd worth

q.l: Pyrrha Neoptolemus brought forth;
Troy's Fate, the Greeks Peace, be to us
Propitious Neoptolemus;
Whom our blet Pythique Soil inters,

l.hi: Receive the Hymns our Zeal prefers;
All woe from this Town banihing,

q.l: I Thetis, fair hair'd Thetis Sing.

div.p:
As far as I remember, Knemon, the Song was this; but the meaure of their Dance had uch Correpondence with the Muick, and their Feet
did o beat the Tune, as the Eye neglecting what it aw, uffered the Soul to be charmed through the Ear; the People following the March of the maids dance, as if they had been attracted by their voices, till a Troop of Hore, all young Gentlement, but beyond all, their Captain did preent a hew that gave the Eye precedency of all the Ears Delights; they were fifty Hore divided into two Troops of five and twenty, marching five and five a Breat; the Captain of the acred Embaage riding in the midt; they had all Purple Buskins tyed with Ribbons, and turned down to their Ankles, their Robes were white, bordered about with azure purles, and fatned at their Brets with Buttons of Gold; they were Mounted on Thealian Hores, whoe fair Shapes and Spirit witneed the weetnes of the Soil that patured them, and eemed as if they corned the command of the Bit; making it all a foam: but yet, as if they obeyed the Riders powerful Soul, they would come off and on, make tops and turning as he pleaed: They had all fair Caparions and Bridles, the one part Silver, the other Silver gilt; o curiouly wrought as it appeared they had a trife in point of Glory.

But (Knemon) all thee Gallants the Beholders eyes paed by and lighted, being only fixt upon their Captain (my charge, Theagenes) that like a Lightning did obcure all that which hined before; o did he trike our Sences, being an excellent Horeman, in his Armour, and haking in his
hand an oaken Spear with a point of Steel, he wore his Beaver up, dicovering the prefect Beauty of his Face; his Baes were Purple imbroidered with Gold in Figures of the Battel betwixt the Centanrs and the Lapiths. The Button that fatned it before was Amber, wherein was the Image of Pallas, bearing in her Hand Medua's Head; the wind (that eemed to be for him) made and addition to his Grace; for it weetly breathing, played with the Curls of his Hair, and made his Baes flow upon the Sides and Buttocks of his Hore; you would have thought the Hore had been enible of the perfections of his Rider, he did rein o proudly, raiing his Cret, and pricking his Ears, rolling his Fiery Eyes, carrying and being carryed with like Pride; when his Mater lack'd the Bridle, he gallop'd on o finely, as he only touched the Earth with the Tips of his Hoofs, tempering the fiercenes of his Motion, o as he did not the leat diorder the Ranks, to the atonihment of the Beholders, that gave the noblet Attribute of Form and Spirit to the young General; the impler Women had not o much dicretion as to couch their paions, but threw Flowers and Noegays at him, to get the happines of a look, or alutation from him: for the unanimous conent of all their Judgments, was, that no humane thing could hew more Beauty then Theagenes.

But when Roe-cheek'd Aurora did apper (as Homer ays) and that the fair and wie Chariclea
came out of the Temple of Diana, then at length we knew Theagenes might be conquered, but o conquered, as the bet native lovelines of Womens form, compared with Mans, is the better loadtone, and exceeds it in the power of Attraction; he rid in a Chariot drawn by two Milk-White Bulls, wearing a long Robe of Purple to her Feet, imbroidered with Beams of Gold; he had on a Girdle wherein the Workman had incloed all his Art, neither ever before, nor ever after being able to contrive the like; it was two Serpents that eemed to have tyed their Tayls in a knot at the Maids back, and had wreathed their necks in another at her Breat, lipping their heads out of the knot, and letting them hang on either ide like Pendants; you would have aid thee Serpents did not eem to creep, but did creep indeed, not with a terrible Apect, but as if they had languihed in a lumber, deiring to ret o near the Boom of the Maid; the Matter they were formed of was Gold, the Colour Blew, but the Workman had enamelled it with Black, that Blue and Black mixt with Yellow, might preent the native variety of the Serpents pointed Scales, her flaxen Hair was neither wholly platted, nor quite looe; the greater part of it at full length hanged down upon her houlders, her Topping and Hair before was crowned with a wreath of the finet Lawrel, this defending it againt the Wind, would not uffer it to be blown out of the handom and well becoming Order it was
laid in; in her left hand he bore a Golden Bow, and over her right Shoulder had a Quiver hanging in a Scarf; in her other had he bore a Torch of Virgins Wax burning, but yet her Eyes rendred a Light far greater.

The very ame Theagenes and Chariclea (cryed Knemon) Where are they for the God's ake? aid Calairis, thinking Knemon had een them; but he replyed, No Father, I do not ee them: but methought I did, though they were abent; you have decribed unto me o properly and directly uch as I aw them: I know not aid Calairis, if you aw them, uch as Greece and the Sun that day beheld them, o conpicuous, o bleed, as his eemed the height of Man's Felicity, and hers of Women: no Mortal thing was eteemed to be like them, only our Countrymen did more admire Theagenes, and the Thealians the fair Chariclea; for the ight of a new thing doth far more ravih us than what we uually behold; but O weet deception! with how much joy did you tranport me when I hoped you aw, and would hew me my Souls beloved Children; but you do nothing ele but mock me; for though at the beginning of my Dicoure, you promied me they would come immediatly, and I hould ee them; and in recompence before hand, I have made you this Narration, yet now it grows Night, and they appear not; Let not that trouble you, aid Knemon, for take my Word they will be here, though perhaps ome hindrance
upon the way may intervene and make then come later than the appointed hour; yet if they were here, you hould not ee them, till I had received my whole Reward. Therefore if you haten to their preence, perform your promie, and lead the Dicoure you have begun, to and end.

I do both hun (reply'd Calairis) the dicoure that may bring my orrows freh into my memory, and I alo doubt it that my long talking had been tedious to you; but ince you are o covetous of hearing, let us begin where we left: Having firt lighted a Lamp, and made our offerings to the Divinities of the Night, and performed our uual Ceremonies to them, we may go on with our Hitory, without being troubled with Phantams. Preently a Servant at his command, brought in a Lamp burning, and he pouring out a little of the Oyl upon the Earth, made his Libation, invoking all the Gods; beeeching a Night of Happy Dreams, conjuring them with all the Power of Prayers, that his beloved Theagenes and Chariclea, might appear to him in his Sleep.

Now Knemon, after the Proceion thus paing had gone round about the Sepulcher of Neoptolemus, and the troop of Hore had thrice wheeled about it, the Women began to fill the Air with funeral Cryes, and the men with a wild Howling: then the Oxen, Sheep, and Goats, (at a Signal given) were immediately Sacrificed
as if one blow had cut all their Throats. Latly, all thee Beats being laid upon a great Altar, and ix hundred Billets under them, they Prayed the Priet of Apollo to begin the Sacrifice, and give Fire to the Wood; Charicles reply'd, the Sacrifice did only belong to him, but the Firing of the Altar, to the Captain of the Sacred Legation, receiving the Torch at the Hands of the Prietes of Diana, for o it was etablihed in the Ceremonial. This he aid, and began to make the offering, while Theagenes took the Torch from the hand of Chariclea; ure Knemon, that the Soul is a divine thing, and allied to the uperior nature, we know by its Operations and Functions; aoon as thee two beheld each other their Souls as if acquainted at firt ight, preed to meet their equals in worth and Beauty, at firt they remained amazed and without motion at length, though lowly, Chariclea gave, and he received the Torch; o fixing their Eyes on one another as if they had been calling to remembrance where they had met before, then they miled, but o tealingly, as could hardly be perceived, but a little in their Eyes, and as ahamed they hid away the Motions of Joy with Bluhes; and again, when Affection (as I imagine) had ingaged their Hearts, they grew pale. To conclude, in a little pace, a thouand changes wandred in their Faces, both in their Colour and their Eyes, deciphering Trouble in their Sorrows.

The Vulgar knew not this, being according to their Imployment, buied and intentive upon other matters; Charicles oberved it not, being hindred with making the accutomed Prayers and Invocations; but I (ever after the Oracle was pronounced to Theagenes, acrificing in the Temple) did nothing ele but note all the Actions of this young Couple, conjecturing by their Names that it was meant of them; Chariclea ignifying in your Language, Grace and Glory, and Theagenes born of a Goddes, yet I did not hitherto exactly undertand what the later part of the Oracle intended. But after (though long firt, and as it were by force) Theagenes was parted from Chariclea, he fired the Altar, and o at length the Pomp brake up; the Thealians going to Feat, the ret of the People every one departing to their Houes, and Chariclea covering her elf in her white Mantle, accompained with ome few Ladies, her Familiars, returned to her Lodging, within the Verge of the Temple; for he dwelt not with her uppoed Father, eparating her elf from him, let he hould have too much opportunity to perwade her to a Marriage.

This I had een, and the ret that I imagined making me till more inquiitive, I chanc'd to meet with Charicles; he asked me, Hat thou een the Light of mine, and all the eyes of Delphos, Chariclea? This is not the firt time I have een her, I replyed, but often before as often as the People were aembled in the Temple, and that not as
paing by, but he hath many times Sacrificed together with me; and when at any time he doubted of Divine or Humane things, he hath put Quetions to me, and been intructed by me. But how did he hew to day? aid Charitles: Did he add any ornament to the Ceremony? Would you heve me tell you how the Moon excells the Stars? aid I: But ome commended the Young Thealian, aid Charicles, and gave him the econd place; yes, and the third too, I replyed; but the Crown and Eye of all the Pomp was really acknowledged to be your Daughter: this pleaed Charicles at the Heart, and I by peaking the truth, did prepare way to my Aim, being only to make the man confident in me; who miling, told me, he was then going to her and that if it pleaed me I hould go along with him to viit her, and know if the great prees and tumult of the people had not troubled her, I was glad of the of fer, yet I eemed to neglect ome other buines to attend him.

When we were come to the Lodgings where he had retired her elf, we entred her Chamber, and found her languihing upon her Bed, not able to ret, Love bathing in the Moiture of her Eyes, he imbracing her Father as he was accutomed, and he asking her how he did? he aid, her Head aked; and that he would willingly take a little ret. At this, Charicles troubled, went with me out of the Chamber, commanding her Attendants to make no Noie; and
when we were without the Doors, Oh good Calairis, aid he, what doth this mean? What indipoition has eized on my Child? You need not wonder, I replyed, if in o great a Multitude of People as attended the Proceion, he hath perhaps attracted the Poion of ome envious Eye; Charicles miling at thee words, as in deriion, do you alo (aid he) believe with the Vulgar, that there is any Facination or Bewitching by the Eye? I do believe it, I replyed, as an Opinion grounded upon truth; and thus I do conceive it, this Air circumfued on every ide about us, penetrating by our Eyes, Notrils, Mouths and other Paages and Pores of our Body, and bringing in with it the Exterior Qualities wherewith it is infected, uch as it flowes unto us, uch impreion it make in us; therefore when any one beholds a rare Creature with Envy, he preently fills the Circumference of the Air with that infeting quality, and breaths into his Neighbouring object a Spirit full of Bitternes, which being thin and ubtil, peirceth to the Bones and Marrow; and thus hath Envy been to many the caue of a Sicknes, whoe proper Name is Facination; Moreover, conider Charicles, how many have got ore Eyes and caught the infection of the Plague, that never came near the Dieaed Perons, never lay in their Beds, nor eat or drank, or had any thing common with them but the Air: amongt other things that might perwade you, the Original of Love may be a pecial
Argument proceeding and occaioned from the object of the ight, drawing the paion through the Eyes into the Soul; and it is cononant to reaon, for the Eye being the mot harp and fervent of all our pores and enes, and capable of mot changes, it receiveth eaiet all affections that are preented to it, attracting with inflamed Spirits the flowings of Love.

But if it be required, I can produce you an Example out of our acred Books, where they treat of the nature of living Creatures; the little Bird they call the Loriot, cureth thoe that have the Jaundice: who if any one looks upon her that is troubled with that Dieae, cloing her Eyes he flies away from him, not as ome ay, envying to give him help, but in regard that beholding him, he naturally calls and attracts the Fluxive dieae unto her elf, and therefore he declines their ight as her own Heart. I doubt not but you have heard how the Serpent named the Bailisk, only by her Eyes and Breath dries away and poions every obvious thing; neither is it a wonder if ome do faccinate thoe they wih well to, and love dearet, for being by nature envious, they do not what they would, but what their natural infirmity move them to.

Charicles pawing a while, In conideration of thee words you have aid, he diolved this controvery with mot wie and probable Arguments, but would the Gods were pleaed this that troubles her were Love; for then I hould eteem her
