to be in perfect health, not ick; and you know that to this end I have implored your aitance: but at this preent nothing les is to be feared than an accident of affection, he hunning love, and hating as a crime the Nuptial Bed: ure ome envious Eye hath bewitch'd her, and I doubt not but you have power and will to break the charm: I know you love me, and I am confident your widom hath acquired a knowledge in all things of the World: I promied him I would do my bet according as I found her Malady.

We thus dicouring, there came a Man to us in terrible hate, why Signiors aid he, how happens it you are o low as if you were ummoned to a Battel, not invited to a Feat prepared by the noble Theagenes, in Honour of the Demi-Deity Neoptolemeus? Away, and do not make them tay for you: All the other Guets are come already: Then Charicles whipering me in the Ear, Here is one (aid he) that invites us with a Batinado! What a brave fellow is Bacchus? But let us go, for it is to be feared he will beat us if we tarry any longer. You are a merry a Man, aid I, but let us away. When we were come thither, Theagenes placed Charicles next himelf, and did me ome honour for his ake; But why hould I trouble you with the recital of the Particulars at this Feat, the Maque of the Ladies, the Muique, the Pyrrhique Dance of the young Gentleman in Armour, and other Entertainments wherewith Theagenes graced his Feat that was
great, and the Cover often changed and new furnihed with everal Services of the mot Exquiite Dainties; but I will give you an account of that will bet pleae you to hear, and me to relate.

Theagenes put on a Face of chearfulnes, forcing himelf to entertain the Company with all humanity and free dicoure; but I found him preently which way he tended, when ometimes he would roul his Eyes and lift them up, ometimes fetch a deep Sigh upon the udden, then adly fix his Eyes upon the Earth, and preently reume a Countenance and Shew of Mirth as if he had been guilty of an Error and corrected it, and preently fall again into new changes: for the Spirit of a Man that is in Love, is like to his that is in Drink; o Flexible, o Uncertain, both alike, Floating in a humid Paion; therefore a Lover is apt and prone to be Drunk, and a Drunken Man to be in Love; but after his ad promies grew more frequent, and his Looks more contantly Sad, all the Company took notice that he was not well, inomuch as the good Charicles that pierced no deeper than the change and trouble of his countenance, aid to me oftly in my Ear, Some envious Eye hath alo beheld this Gentleman. I think it to be the ame that did behold Chariclea, the very ame by Iis: I replyed, you judge aright, and with great appearance of Reaon; he being the fairet next to her in all the glorious Show; Thus we two whipered, and
when the Goblets were to go about, Theagenes drank to us although againt his will, only to bid us welcome; But when it came to me, I telling him I was his Humble Servant, and would receive the Favour not the Wine, he looked upon me with harp and fiery Eyes, thinking himelf lighted; which Charicles perceiving, told him I drank no Wine, nor eat any thing that had been a Senitive Creature; He demanded the caue; Charicles replyed, he is an Aegyptian, a Nemphian, and the Priet of Iis: Theagenes undertanding I was an Aegyptian, and the Chief Priet, felt his Soul ravihed with a preent joy, as they that by Fortune find a treaure in their way; and preently etting himelf upright, he called for Water, and drinking it to me, aid, at leawie, Sir, be pleaed to pledge me in this Beveridge; you affect, and let this Table be the Witnes of a Tye of Friendhip made betwixt us: Be it o noblet Theagenes, I replyed, it is long ince contracted on my part; and o I took the Cup and pledged him; preently they took away, and we did rie from the Table, every one preparing to go home; and Theagenes imbrancing me with the dearet protetations of affection.

Being returned to my Lodging, I went to bed and pent mot part of the Night, not having power to cloe my Eyes, but tumbling and toing with the care I conceived for the young Couple, and ifting out what the lat part of the Oracle hould mean; it now growing Midnight, I
aw Apollo and Diana, as I thought (if I did think, and did not rather truly ee them) and he delivered to me Theagenes, he Chariclea; telling me it was time I hould return into my Country, for o the Laws of Detiny had ordained. Go therefore, aid they, and make thee two thou hat received thy Companions, adopting them thy Children, and lead them out of the Land of Aegypt, where and how the Gods hall pleae: Having aid this, they departed, making me know it was not the viion of a Dream, but a true Appartion. I had now got out the whole meaning of the Oracle, yet till I doubted to what People or what Country I hould lead them; But how do you know Father, aid Knemon, that it was not a Dream, but a real Viions? even o Son (he replyed) as the wie Homer gives it us as in a Riddle: though many light Enigma's; It is a paage where he peaks of Neptune.

q.l: For I his Feet and Thighs together pi'd,
Cutting the thin Ayr, with an eaie lide:
The Gods may thus be truly een and known.

div.p: I confes, aid Knemon, I am of the number of thoe many you peak of; and happily you have cited this Vere, to ee how I undertand it, which is in no deeper ence than the vulgar Interpretation made unto me when I firt learned the Signification of Words; I am altogether Ignorant what ecret of Theology may be Couched in it.

Then Calairis conidering a little, and collecting all the forces of his Undertanding, as being to peak of a high Mytery; When the Gods (aid he) and Divine Spirits pleae either to come to, or go from us, they take the imilitude eldom of Beats or other Creatures; but many times they cloath their Divinity with the form of Men, to be known to our fancy in the likenes of our elves, that we may rather take it for the viion of a Dream: But though prophane Perons know them not, yet they cannot ecape from a wife Mans dicovery, but may be deciphered by their Eyes, when they hold always fixt, and never move their Eye-lids, yet by their going they may be better known; for their pace is not made by tepping or tranpoition of the Feet, but by a certain aery violence and quick even Motion, that they rather ail or cut, than pas the Air. This is the reaon why the Aegyptians make the Statua's of their Gods joyning their Feet, and as it were uniting them together; which Homer knowing, as being an Aegyptian, and intructed in our Sacred Doctrine, involvedly incerted this Mytery in his Veres, leaving it for thoe that could, to undertand him. Of Phallas, he ayes,
div.q: Her harp Eyes parkled as he look'd like Fire.
div.p: And as before of Neptune,

q.l: His Feet and Thighs together I epy'd,
Cutting the thin Ayr with an eaie Slide.

div.p: As Sailing intead of Going, for this is the meaning of an eaie Slide; not as ome wrongly interpret him, that to know the Gods was eaie Divine. Sir, aid Knemon, You have initiated me in a great Mytery: But having oberved you many times in this Dicoure to have called Homer an Aegyptian, not being able to believe you; yet admiring what hould be your reaon, I beeech you not to pas this undicued. Though it be, Knemon, aid Calairis, a thing far from our intended Subject to dipute this now, yet I will briefly touch it.

Many Countries challenge Homer, and every Country is a Wife Mans own, but the truth is, he was my Countryman, an Aegyptian, born in the hundred-gated Thebes, as himelf names it; his eteemed Father was the High Priet of that City, but his true Father Mercury; but the Priet was his uppoed Father inamuch as his Wife leeping in the Temple at the Celebration of certain Ceremonies of our Country, the God lay with her, and got her with Child of Homer, who from his Mother Womb brought
forth a Mark of her Illegitimate Copulation; For one of his Thighs had upon it a great quantity of long Hair; and afterwards in his Travels through the World, and epecially amongt the Greeks inging his Poey, they gave him the name of Homer; not that it was his own Name, or the Cities, or Nations whence he was, but thoe that knew that privy Mark, gave him that Sirname, ignifying, a Thigh: But what was his reaon (Father) to conceal his Country? (aid Knemon) Becaue, replyed Calairis, either he was ahamed to be known for a Fugitive, for his Father had expelled him his Houe, when his Name was to be inrolled amongt the young Initiates that took Orders, becaue in the earch he was found to have a mark of Batardy; or ele he did this wiely, that concealing his true City, he might challenge every City of the World for his: This you have aid hews like a Truth, aid Knemon, when I conider his Mytical Poems, that have a mixture for all weetnes and pleaure out of the excellency of Nature; and ure, they would not o excell all others if ome Divinity had not been the Ground of uch Perfection.
But after you had known the Gods following the mark that Homer gave you, what was the Sequel I beeech you?

Anwerable to the promie (Friend Knemon.) The ret of the night I could take no Sleep,
but lay conidering and canvaing uch thoughts as Night uggets. It rejoyced me that the Gods would effect my buines, which as then I thought not of, and that I hould expect to return into my Country; but it grieved me to think that Charicles hould be deprived of his Daughter, and it troubled me the more, becaue I knew not what coure to take, or how to teal away the two young Lovers; I feared our flight would not be ecret, but that ome accident would dicover us: Then I doubted of the way, whether we hould go by Sea or Land. Finally a torm of Cogitations toed my Spirits, and I lay waking till the Morning.

It was hardly day, but I heard one knocking at the Gates, and the voice of a Page that called: One of my Servants demanded who he was that knocked o rudely, and his Buines: The Page wihed him to tell his Mater Theagenes, the Thealian would attend him; I was very glad of this News of Theagenes, and commanded my Man to wait of him in, making accompt that occaion offered it elf of its own accord to deliver me of the care that troubled my thoughts, for I perwaded my elf that he having heard at the Feat that I was an Egyptian, and a Prophet; came to me to demand my uccor in his Love; being as I imagine in the ame error that many fall into, who believe the widom of the
Egyptians be one; and the ame thing wherein they much deceive themelves; for there is one knowledge vulgar, and as I may term it, creeping on the Earth, the ervant of Images, and buied about dead Bodies, believing in the power of Herbs and Incantations, not tending to any good end it elf, nor conducting thoe that ue it, But lameing mot its Precepts, and implying contradictions; the effects it produceth are mall and bae, as to give Viions of things that are not, as if they were, to frutate Men of their hopes; being an Art that is the Inventres of detetable things, and the Miniter of profued foul pleaures: But Son, there is another, that is real Widom, and from which this Adulterate hath degenerated, and as a Batard fally aumed the Name; whereof, we that are Priets, and all that decend of the Prophetick Line, do make Profeion, and are bred in; it elevates its elf in contemplation of Celetial things, convereth always with the Gods, and participates of the Divinity; earching the Motions of the Stars, and delighting to fore-know the Future; making a Man a tranger to terretrial evils and vices, and conducting to the profit of humane Society; this was it that made me leave my Country for a time, to hun if it were poible the mieries that I preaged to my elf, and not to behold the Bloody Duel of my Sons. But I leave all to the Gods, and Detinies,
in whoe power it is, whether thee Mifortunes hall or hall not happen, and that have not impoed this Banihment upon me only for the caue that I have told you, but principally, that I hould meet Chariclea; by what means you hall know hereafter. Now let us return to Theagenes.

When he was come into my Chamber, and we had aluted, I made him it down by me upon my Bed, and quetioned him what Neceity had brought him o early to me? But after he had held his hand upon his Face; I am infinitely troubled (he replied) but I bluh to dicover it, and o held his peace: Preently I apprehended it was time for me to lie, and to divine what I already knew; therefore looking in his Face, and miling; Though you fear (I aid) to expres your elf to me, yet nothing can be concealed to the Gods, and to our Widom; then raiing my elf a little, and counting upon my Fingers, haking my Locks as thoe that are poet with a Prophetick Spirit, I aid, My Son, you love: He tarted at this Oracle; but when I had added Chariclea, then eteeming my knowledge to be inpired, he would have fallen down and adored me; but I not uffering him, he embraced me, and often kied my Hand, rendring Thanks to Heaven that he had not been deceived in his Hopes, and praying me to ave his Life that would be but hort if he had not preent help, o great was his Affliction, and o violent his Flame,
being the firt Wound that Love had given him, until the Beauty of Chariclea had unouled and conquered him, and that not in regard of any natural Strength or Weaknes; but that he had never till now een a Woman worthy of his Love. At thee words he wept, witneing, that he was overcome not by his own weaknes, but by her inevitable Force: I comforted him the bet I could, wihing him only to take his wonted courage; and ince he had recoure to me, he hould find Chariclea's Beauty had not the trength to prevail againt our Widom; for though, aid I, he be very refractory, depiing Love, not enduring to hear Venus named, and not without much difficulty to be drawn to ubmit to the Laws of Marriage; yet for your ake I will try all ways, and you hall ee Art conquer Nature; be you only confident, and fail not to obey my neceary Commands: He promied to follow my Directions, though I hould bid him march upon the Points of Swords.

When we were come to Chariclea (why hould I ue many Words?) we found her engaged deeply to affection, the Roes and Lillies of her Cheeks were faded, and the Water of her fair Eyes had extinguihed the Fire that ued to parkle in them; yet aoon as he perceived us, he did her bet to compoe her elf, and endeavoured to call back the accutomed Lovelines and Graces of her Beauty; Charicles kiing and embracing her, not omitting any Ceremony that endears Repect and Love. O Child! O Daughter! aid, he, can you conceal the Evil that torments you from your Father? and being facinated, do you make it a Secret, as if you had done wrong, and not received an injury from the Eyes that have o maliciouly beheld you? But reume your Spirits; I have entreated the wie Calairis that you ee here with me, to undertake your Cure, and he is able to perform it; for he (if ever any) excelleth in divine Knowledge, as being by decent a Prophet, and which is more, our epecial Friend; therefore you hall do wiely to commit your elf wholly to his dipoing, whether he hall pleae to ue incantation, or heal you by any other means: But I need nor ue perwaions ince you naturally honour and affect the company of Learned men. Chariclea replied not, but only bowed her head in ign of conent to her Fathers Counel.
This done, we retired our elves; Charicles renewing his Suit to me, that I would remember my Promie, and bethink me of a way to induce Chariclea to a milder Contruction of Men and Marriage. Thus I brought him off, and left him joyful, giving him my Word his Deire hould hortly be accomplihed.

div.head: THE AETHIOPIAN HISTORY.
The Fourth Book.
div.p: THE next day the Pythian Games ended; but the Paion and Strife of the young Men grew more violent under the Empire of Cupid, who was their Judge, and by two Champions of his, intended (as I believe) to hew the World his Combate is the greatet. Thus it happened:

All Greece were lookers on, the Amphyctiones were the Judges, that is, the Deputies of every Communalty of Greece. After all the other Contentions were concluded with Magnificence, as Chariot-Races, Wratling, and Quoiting of the
Sledge, at length the Herald cried, Let the Armed Men tand forth;, and preently at the further end of the Lits we aw Chariclea hining; for he was come, if not willingly, yet to oberve the Cutom of the Countrey, or rather in my opinion hoping to ee Theagenes; in her left hand he bare a burning Torch of Virgin-Wax, and in her other held forth a Branch of Palm: She no ooner appeared, but he turned all the Eyes of the Theater upon her; but I believe not any Eye out-tripp'd that of Theagenes; for the Eye of a Lover is wift to py out her that is deired; and he having before heard of the Ceremony, had all his Spirits et to watch her coming; and when he aw her, he was not able to contain himelf, but pake oftly in my Ear; for he had placed himelf next to me of purpoe, That is he, it is Chariclea: I bid him hold his peace, and be at quiet.

At the Cry of the Herald, one preented himelf in light Armor, of goodly Shape, by his Carriage appearing already as a Conqueror, and promiing to himelf the Prize and Victory, as having many times been Crowned in the ame Coure; and at that time having none to oppoe him, as Antagonit; which caued the Amphyctiones to return him back, the Law not permitting him to enjoy the Crown that had not endured the Conflict: But he intreated the Herald might demand, if any Man would run: The Judges commanded it hould be o; and the Herald
made Proclamation, If any would run, he hould come forth into the Lirts. Heark (aid Theagenes to me) That Man calls me. I asking him what his meaning was: It hall be o, Father, he aid; for never hall any Man in my preence, and I looking on, hare away the Reward of Victory from the hand of Chariclea: But, aid I, you do not apprehend nor weigh the Dariger and Ignominy that attends the Conquered: Why, Father, who is he (replied Theagenes) that will o fervently contend to ee and approach Chariclea, as to outtrip me? or to whom will her Looks give wings, and make him fly in the A
s like me? Do not you know that Painters draw Love winged, ignifying as in a Riddle, the agility of thoe that he urprizes? and if a man might boat himelf, there is this day none that can glory to have over-run me.

At thee Words he uddenly roe, and tepp'd forth into the Lits, to make his Name be publihed, and the Place of his Birth; and o being engaged for the Coure, he put on compleat Armor, and tood to the Barriers, o boyling with deire to run, that his impatience would hardly permit him to attend the Sound of the Trumper: The Spectale was pleaing and conpicuous; for you would have aid it had been Achilles, as Homen paints him fighting upon the Shore of the River Seamander.

This unexpected Champion moved all Greece, and they did wih the Victory to Theagenes, as
paionately as if every one had run in his own Peron; for Beauty hath a trong power to work upon the good wills of the Beholders: But above all, Chariclea was mot troubled; and having et my elf to oberve her, I perceived he often changed her colour; for after the Herald had pronounced o loud as all might hear the Combatants Names, Ormenus the Arcadian, and Theagenes the Thealian, the Barriers were opened, and the Coure began o wiftly as mens dazled Eyes could hardly overtake them: Every Spectator, to whom the Event was yet in upence, found himelf full of care; but I epecially that had reolved with my elf to be as careful of him as of my own Son. No marvel, aid Knemon, if thoe that were preent found themelves troubled; for at this hour I fear for Theagenes, and do entreat you if he had the Victory, to keep me no longer without the knowledge. When now (Knemon) they had finihed half their Coure, he looking back, and frowning to ee Ormenus run o near him, lifting up his Buckler and his Head, and fixing his Eyes wholly upon Chariclea, he hot to her as an Arrow to the Mark, and o far out-tript the Areadian, as he left him many paces behind. The Space was after meaured: o running to Chariclea of purpoe, fell upon her boom, as if it had not been in his power to top himelf; and taking the Branch of Palm, I perceived him kis her hand.

I am glad with all my heart (aid Knemon) that he hath won the Crown and toln a Kis; but I pray you what follows? How (aid Calairis) will you never be atisfied with hearing? have you not yet a mind to leep, being the Night is pent o far? Is not my Dicoure yet tedious? No Father (aid Knemon) I could chide Homer, who tells us we may urfeit of all things, even of Love; which in my Opinion admitteth no Satiety, neither in the enjoying nor dicoure: And who is he, unles he have a heart of Adamant or Iron, that would not receive Content to hear the Loves of Theagenes and Chariclea, though the Story hould lat a year? therefore continue it I beeech you.

Theagenes (Knemon) was then crowned, proclaimed the Conqueror, and conducted with the glad Acclamations of the People; but Chariclea was then quite vanquihed, and her Heart more fettered in Affection than before; having the econd time beheld Theagines; for the interchanged Eyes of: Lovers is a renewing of their Paions, and their Looks inflame their Minds, as Fire approaching to its Matter; the Maid returning home, had as ill or wore a Night than ever; and I again was not able to cloe my Eyes, inceantly plotting how we hould conceal our Flight, and into what Countrey the God would bring the two young Lovers; I conjectured we were to take our light by Sea, gathering it out of thee Words of the Oracle,

q.l: They two hall, ayling from
My Temple, to a Sun-burn'd Climate come.

div.p: But to what part of the Earth I undertood not; and I aw no other means to come to the knowledge of it, unles I could get the Facia that was expoed with Chariclea, wherein Charicles had told me he conceived the Dicoure of her Fortune to be writ; for out of thee Characters I doubted not but to get out her Country, and her Parents, which I began now to upect, and that the Gods would end her back to them.

Next Morning, coming to Chariclea's Chamber, I found others of her Friends weeping, but Charicles mot bitterly: I asked him, what the Matter was? O Calairis? aid he, The Sicknes of my Daughter till more and more increaes, and this Night he hath reted more unquietly than before, Get you away, aid I, and command the ret out of the Chamber, only let ome one bring a little Lawrel, Fire and Incene, and let none trouble me before I call. Charicles commanded it hould be o; and it was done accordingly.

Now being alone with her, I began to play my part, as a Mountebank upon a Stage; I put the Incene in the Fire, and made as if I muttered certain Prayers betwixt my Lips; I
carried the Lawrel up and down from the head to the foot of Chariclea, and gaping over her like a leepy man, at length I made an end of my Pageantry; he often moved her Head, and miled to her elf, as if he would tell me I was ignorant of the Caue of her Dieae: Therefore itting nearer to her, Daughter, aid I, chear your Spirits, for yours is a common Infirmity, and the Cure eaie; no doubt but you were facinated when you aited at the Proceion; but epecially when you gave the Palm to the Conqueror: I upect him that hath bewitched you, to be Theagenes; for I aw he looked fixedly upon you, and his Eyes were awcy with you. She replied, whether he charmed me o or not, well may he do; but do you know what Country man he is, or of what Family; for I aw many look upon him, admiring him with a kind of an atonihment. Did not the Herald tell you that he was a Thealian (I replied) when he proclaimed his Name? and he himelf glories to be decended of Achilles; and doubtles he was his Ancetor; for he has the Stature, Form and generous Comportment of Achilles, only he is not o proud and arrogant as he; but he allays and tempers the fiercenes of his Spirits with a mixture of much weetnes; yet though he be thus excellent, I wih him more pain than he hath made you uffer by the Witchcraft of his envious Eyes.
I thank you, Father, (he neplied) that you have compaion of my Miery: but why do you vainly wih him ill that hath done us no wrong; for I am not facinated? ure mine is ome other Sicknes.

Why therefore do you conceal it (Daughter) aid I, and not rather open your Infirmity with confidence, that you may receive help with peed? Am not I your Father in years, more in well-wihing? Am not I your Father's Friend, profeing the ame Studies, which the more in-dears me to him? Expres your Grief, I will be faithful to you: If you will not believe my Word, you hall have my Oath: Speak boldly, and let not your Pain gather trength by your ilence; for every Malady that is preently known, is eaily remedied; but old Wounds are almot incurable; for Secreie is a nourihment to Dieaes, whilt thoe that are unconceal'd, may be ure to have ome help.

At thee Words he pauing a little, and by her Face auring me of much Confuion in her Thoughts; Give me time this day, he aid, and then you hall know it, if already you do not, ince you are a Mater in the Art of Prophecy. I roe and left her; willing to give her leiure to moderate her Fears, and to contrive in what manner to expres that he was ahamed to tell me. Charicles came running to meet me, and asked me, what I thought of his Child? O well, well; I replied: To morrow he will be delivered
of the Burthen that afflicts her, and there will be a beginning of omething that will give you great content. In the mean time it will do no harm if you end for a Phyician. This aid, I made hate away, let he hould interrogate me further.

I was gone but a little from the Houe when I perceived Theagenes walking in the Cloiter of the Temple, and dicouring with himelf, as if he were highly contented only to look upon the Lodging of Chariclea: I turning a little out of the way, paed by as if I had not een him; but he called to me; Save you Calairis! a Word with you; I taid for you: Preently I turning back, Lord! aid I, is the fair Theagenes here, and I not ee him? How can he be fair, replied Theagenes, that pleaes not Chariclea? I making my elf to frown, as if I were angry with him, Will you never leave, aid I, to diparage me and my Art, by which he is taken and compelled to love you, deiring to have the happines to ee you. What ay you Father, he replied, would Chariclea ee me? why then do you not carry me to her? and therewith he tarted forward; but I catching him by the Vet, Stay, aid I, though you have the Crown for running, this is not a buines to fall upon it like a Prey; nor is it eaie to be compaed, or expoed to him that will venture for it; but it requires deep Conultation and great Preparatives to ecure the doing. Do you not know that the Maids Father is one of the
principal Men of Delphos? Do you not fear the Law, that pronounces Death upon Offenders in this kind?

'Tis no matter, he replied, Let me die o I may enjoy Chariclea; yet, if you pleae, let us make Suit to her Father that he will betow her on me for my Wife; my Affinity will be no Digrace to Chariclea's.

We hall never obtain it, aid I; not that any thing can be reprehended or thought defective in you; but in repect Charicles hath detined her to his Siters Son: He hall repent if whooever he be (aid Theagenes) for no other man hall ever make Chariclea his Bride, and I alive, having this Hand and Sword.

Away, away (aid I) there hall be no uch need; only be ruled by me, and do as I command you: for this time depart, and take heed you be not een often in my Company, but meet me ever alone, and without Noie: immediatly he went away omething ad.

Charicles met me the next Morning, and aoon as he perceived me, ran and caught me in his Arms, printing many Kies on my Head, cry-power is Friendhip! the great Work is finihed, the impregnable is now taken, and the invincible is vanquihed; Chariclea is in Love.

Then I began to take tate upon me, looking uperiliouly, and walking gravely; There was
no difficulty (aid I) but that he could not hold out the firt Aault; and yet I planted no great Engines againt her: But Charicles, how come you to know he loves?

Following your Counel (he replied:) for having ent for our principal and mot approved Phyitians, I brought them in to ee her; promiing them all my Patrimony for their Fees, if they could cure her: They asked her where her Pain held her mot? but he turning from them, pronounced this Vere of Homer;
div.q: Achilles the mot Valiant of the Greeks.
div.p: Then the prudent Phyitian Acetinus (perhaps your know the man) caught hold of her Writ, and felt her Pule, judging thereby (as I imagine) the motion of her Heart; and after he had felt the Artery a good while, taking an exact and curious obervation of her, Charicles (aid he) you have ent for us in vain; Phyick can do her no good.
O Gods! I cried, what do you ay? mut then my Daughter perih? Is there no hope of her Recovery?

Do not afflict your elf, replied he, but hear me; and taking me aide from Chariclea and the ret, Our Art (aid he) profeeth the Cure of a ditempered Body, and ometimes of the Soul; but that is only when it uffers and feels the indipoition of the Body, and that being
healed, the Soul again Recovers, and is well: It is true, your Daughter is ditempered, but not in her Body; Her Head aches not, no Feaver inlames her Blood, her Body uffers not by Sicknes, neither in any part nor in the whole. I intreating him if he undertood the Nature of her Dieae, to let me know it: There is no Child, aid he, but may know it is a Paion of the Mind, and evidently the Dieae that we call Love; do you not ee that her Eyes are welled, her Countenance dicompoed, Her Colour pale; yet he complained not of any Pain in her Heart; add that her mind wanders; what falls into her thoughts he peaks, and caueles cares do trouble her repoe. In hort, Charicles you mut find out the Man whom he deires; having aid this, he left me.

But I made all the hate I could, to meet you my Preerver and good Genius; whom both he and I acknowledge to have the only power to do us good, for after I had long intreated her to tell me, what it was that troubled her; he replyed, no more but that he her elf was Ignorant, only Calairis knew a remedy for her: and he Prayed me that I would end to her, whence principally I conjectured he was gained by the Secrets of your Widom; but (aid I, to him) as you tell me he Loves; can you tell me whom he Loves? No, by Apollo, replyed he: For how, or whence hould I know
that? But I would give my Eate, that it were Alcamenes my Siters Son; whom long ince in my mind, I had deigned for her Husband. I wihed him that he hould make a Tryal; Bring the Young Man, and hew him to her: he commended my Counel, and preently went about it.

Not long after, he came and found me, when the Exchange was full; I have (aid he) a thing to Communicate to you, that greatly troubles and afflicts me: I fear my Daughter is out of her Wits, he hath uch Strange and Extraordinary Fancies. I brought my Nephew, Alcamenes, as you wihed me; and hewed him to her in his Richet Habit: But he as if he had een Medua's Head, or omething more formidable with a loud hrill Voice, cryed out, and turned her Face to the other ide of the Chamber; putting her hands like a Cord about her Neck, threatning and wearing he would kill her elf, unles I preently would take him away out of her Sight; but aoon as he could peak it, we retir'd our elves: For what hould we do, eeing uch a trange Aburdity? Therefore again, I am become a Suiter to you, that you will not uffer her to perih, nor me to be frutrated of my Expectation; O Charicles! (aid I) now you have hit it, the Maid is Mad: For he is poeed and agitated by the Spirits that I have put into her, which are not of the meanet ort; but a thing that was necearily to be
done to force her Inclination, and make her to have a mind to that which by nature and breeding he abhorred; but ure ome God oppoes my Deign, and countermines my Work: And therefore of Neceity, you mut hew me the Mantle that was Expoed with her, which you told me you received with the ret of her things; for I much fear, that ome Enemy hath poioned it with a Charm to make her out of Love with Love; to the end that deteting Marriage, he might wear out all her life time, without the Bleing to be a Mother. Charicles approving my conjectures, preently brought me the Mantle; But I aid, he mut give me a little time to be private: he did o; and aoon as he was gone, I began without the leat delay to read what was ewed in the Mantle; being formed in Aethiopian Characters, not vulgar, or uch as the Common People ue, but Royal; uch as are proper only to their Princes, bearing a reemblance to thoe we Aegyptians call the Sacred or Prietly Characters; reading it, I found the Scrowl contained thee Words. I Perina, Queen of the Aethiopians, draw this lamentable Complaint for the lat Preent I can give to her, whom I know not how to name, and whom I can call Daughter only by the pains of Child-birth.
I was amazed (Knemon) when I read Perina's name, yet I perited to read the ret, which was this;

The Sun who is Author of our Blood, be my Witnes; O my Child! It is not for any Spot of Sin that I have expoed you in your Cradle, and concealed you from your Father Hidapes: yet if you hall ecape and live, thus far Daughter, let me excue me to you, and to him that hall find you, if the Gods make any one o happy; Be it alo known to all orts of People, the caue that forced your Mothers Heart to leave you to the Mercy of Fortune; Our Ancetors of the Gods are Sol, and Bacchus; of the Demi-Gods, Perius and Andromeda, and after them Memnon; thoe that from time to time have builded and enlarged the Palace of the Kings of Aethiopia, have enriched it with divere Pictures, excellent Pieces taken from the Actions and Battels they have performed, and have put their Statua's in the Galleries and Gardens with Tabels, preenting to the Life the valorous performances both of the Gods and Men; and my own Chamber was hanged about with everal Pieces of the Loves of Andromeda and Pereus. I had been ten Years marry'd to Hydapes, without any fruit of Wedlock, yet it happened, that from a certain hour, I found my elf, with Child; all the time till my down-lying, there were Publick Feats, and Sacrifices of Thankgiving to the Gods; the King hoping for a Succeor to ucceed him in his Throne: But when I brought forth thee a White Child, an unuual Colour to the Ethiopians; I my
elf knew the caue; the Picture of Andromeda naked was before my Eyes (for then Perius had newly brought her down from the Rock) Her Face being Apparelled in her weetet looks, as freed from being devoured by the Sea-Monter. A Beauty like hers in that Table, it was my hard Fortune to conceive thee; wherefore to deliver my Dignity and Peron from an Ignominious Death, auring my elf thy colour would convince me a Adultery, and no Man believe me when I hould peak the Truth of uch an Accident; I reolved from the hour of your Birth, to commit you to the uncertainty of Fortune, which I imagined you your elf would rather wih than a certain Death, or the name of Illegitimate.

And o faining to my Husband you were born Dead, I ecretly expoed you, laying with you in your Cradle my bet Jewels for a Reward to his Piety, that hould preerve you, and covering you, with this Mantle, in which I have Printed with my Blood and Tears the Mierable Relation of your Fortune and my own, that have been o unhappy a Mother in my firt down-lying. But my weet Child, and that mut be mine but for a little time; if you urvive, remember your great Birth, be jealous of the Honour of your Chatity, the only bet Character of a Ladies Virtue and Spirit; imitate your Ancetors, and following their Example, make the
World know the Glory of your Illutrious Blood; particularly, remember among the Jewels I have laid forth with you, to look for a certain Ring, and keep it to your elf; your. Father gave it me upon my Wedding Day; his Arms are herein engrav'd, the Stone is named a Pantarbe, conecrated in the Collet: I ue this way of writing, to advertie you hereof, ince the Gods have denyed us any other means to peak together; this may prove dumb and unprofitable unto you; it may alo inform you, and do you ervice; for the events of Fortune are not in the compas of Mans knowledge: finally, thee Cahracters I have tained in this Mantle; O Daughter! Fair in pain; whoe Beauty is my unjut Accuer; if it happen to you, be preerved by thee Tokens, you will be known; if not (which Heaven keep from my knowledge) let the water of thee Gems preent your Mothers Funeral Tears.

When I had read this to an end, then Knemon I knew, not without being ravihed with admiration, the Ordinance of the Gods, and my Soul felt a new Motion, that made Tears pring from my Eyes mixed with joy and orrow, infinitely contented to have found what I deired; namely, the reolution of the Oracle, but exceeding trouble that I could have no perfect knowledge of the future; complaining to my elf of the mierable condition of Mans Fortune, nothing but intability; whereof Characlea appeared
to me a ingular example. I wandered in a maze of thoughts, conidering who her true Parents were, who her uppoed, how far he was ditanced from her Country; having lot her own, and being only known by a feign'd Name. To conclude, I tood a great while in a dull fear, having caue to pity and deplore her paed mieries, and not daring to ay her fortune hould be happy in the future; till at length collecting my reaon, I reolved the deign I had undertaken, hould go on without delay; and coming to Chariclea, I found her alone, wearied with the Fight betwixt the forces of the Spirits, and the powers of Love, that made her fair Body the Field and Seat of War, which her Soul triving to make good, dit but the more afflict her, being not able to reit the fury of the aailant; then I commanded thoe that were without to wait till they were called, and not to trouble me, as if I had certain Prayers and Invocatiions to make for the Maids health. Now Chariclea (aid I) you have time to perform your yeterdays promie, to dicover to me what it is torments you, and no longer to conceal it from your true friend, whom it lyeth not in your power to hinder of the knowledge, thought you hould live and dye obtinate in your ilence. At thee words he taking my hand, and kiing it many times with tears: Mot wie Calairis (he aid) Oh do me the favour to let me uffer my ill fortune
without confeing it, ince, as you ay, you know what troubles me; I hall eteem it ome benefit to avoid an Ignominy, by concealing that it is a hame to uffer, but more hame to peak; and though my icknes growing upon me, puts me to great pain, it is my greatet, that I did not at firt conquer it, but yielded to that paion I had all my life time in uch horror, as only to hear it named, I thought it a tain to the acred title of a Virgin. Then to encourage and comfort her; Daughter, aid I, you do wiely to keep your reaons ecret, for two caues; for it were but uperfluous to tell me that, which by my Art, is long ince known unto me; and you do your modety right to pare your bluhes, in revealing that ought ever to be hidden deepet in a Maids heart; but ince you now feel what Love is, and that at firt ight you were taken with the perfections of Theagenes, (for this I know by Revelation) know you are not alone, nor the firt than hath been taken in this kind, but it is the common cae of many illutrious Ladies, and chate Maids; for Love is the greatet of the Gods, and at times hath had the Victory of them all; but now conider where you are, and what you have to do: 'Tis true, 'tis a great bleing not to be in Love, but when you are once caught, it is the bet of widom to regulate your deires, and direct them to ome Honourable end.

This is the reaon of my coming hither to accomplih my Oath, though that was not the only motive of my Journey; yet, by the great providence of the Gods, in travelling hither I have found a means to diengage me of my promie. You know, ince I firt aw you, I have been ever ready to do you ervice, not omitting the leat occaion to expres me yours, yet concealing my reaons till occaion would erve to recover this Mantle, that it might confirm your belief of my relation: Therefore it were good you would take my Counel, before you be forced to endure, againt your will, the Marriage of Alcamenes, which Charicles means to follow with all violence; in place whereof you may recover your Country and
Parents, and match with Theagenes, who is prepared to follow us into any part of the World; changing a private life in a trange Country, to that of a Princes in your Native oyl, where you hall be Crowned, and Reign with him you love dearet, if we may have Faith in the Gods, both in other preages, and even in the Oracle of Apollo. Then I put her in mind of the tenour of the Oracle, and expounded the meaning. Chariclea perfectly knowing it, as being now vulgarly ung, and every one making aay to interpret it. This truck her ilent again.

At length he aid, Father, ince you ay, and I believe this to be the pleaure of the Gods, what hall I do? You mut make a hew (aid I) to entertain the Match with Alcamenes. It will be a hard thing, (aid he) if not bae, to prefer any one before Theagenes, though but in words; but ince I have committed my elf to the power of the Gods and yours, Father, let me know what will be the iue of this Fiction, and how it may be broke before it come to the effect I fear. Let the event inform you, I replied, for there are certain deigns, where-with, if Ladies be unacquainted beforehand, they will fear and delay, but if they undertake them on the udden, they will finih them with a greater Reolution. Do you follow my advice both in other things and this, and make of difficulty to accommodate your elf to the deire
of Charicles, to match you with his Nephew, for be aured he will do nothing in it without my conent and approbation. She promied it, and o I left her weeping. I was hardly out of the Gate, but I perceiv'd Charicles, hanging down his Head, as oppreed with extreme grief: This is a trange humour, worthy Charicles, (aid I) to appear in this ort afflicted, when you ought to ill your heart with Joy, and offer Sacrifice and Thankgiving in the Temple, the Gods having now granted your long fuit, and bleed the ecrets of my knowledge and endeavours to her, incliming her mind to a deire of Marriage: Lord, why hould you weep, I protet I cannot imagine the reaon. How can I chue, replied he, ince my beloved Daughter hall be taken out of this World, before he be ubjected to the Laws of Marriage, as you promie, if we may believe Dreams, both at other times and (which with terrour I remember yet) this night methought an Eagle, flying from Apollo's hand, in an intant (alas!) eiz'd my poor Child, and ravihed her from my boom, carrying her into the farthet Region of the habitable Earth, full of obcure Images and Shadows of black Men; and, which grieved me mot, I could not dicern what became of her, an infinite pace of Earth and Air interpoing it elf betwixt us, o as the cruel Bird did overfly my ight, and vanihed. When he had hold me this, I preently conceiv'd which
way the preage tended; but to divert him from his Melancholly wherein he was drown'd, and to draw him as far as might be, from the upicion of the future; You being a Priet, (aid I) and of all his Priets the mot converant in the Myteries of your Prophetick God, yet methinks you have not the art of interpreting a Dream; your Dream indeed preaging to you the Marriage of your Daughter, and by an Enigma howing to you how her Husband hall take her from you like an Eagle, and that with the conent of Apollo, as ending him to her from his own hand, yet you are troubled at it, and wret your Dream to the wort ene; therefore let us take heed our miconjectures do not provoke the Gods, reigning our elves wholly to their wills, and employing our bet indutry to conform your Daughter to your pleaure.

Then he demanding what were bet to be done to win his Daughter; If haply, aid I, you have yet any Jewels or rich Embroideries, or ome Ring of a great value, let Alcamenes preent them to her, as Marriage-gifts, and this will charm her to be his; then you mut make other preparations for the olemnity, and make no delay, but conclude the Marriage, whilt yet the power of my Art is working, and makes impreion in her Soul. Doubt not, aid Charicles, I hall not omit any thing in my power; and he had carce poken the words,
but he ran with joy to put them in Act, and did as I entreated him, without any procratination, as afterwards I undertood, carrying to Chariclea, as Nuptial gifts from Alcamenes, not only rich Vetures, but alo the precious Jewels Perina had put in her Cradle, when he was expoed.

But I went preently to Theagenes, and asked him where his Thealians were, that did ait at the ceremony of the Proceion: He told me, the Ladies were gone oftly before, to make the eaier Journeys; and how the young men burned with o great a deire to ee their Friends at home, as be hardly had power to tay them any longer: Undertanding that, I intructed him what he hould ay to them, and what they hould do, commanding him he hould oberve when I would give the ign, and then take heed not to loe the time and occaion offered: o I left him.

And going to the Temple of Apollo, I intended to make my Prayer to the God, that he would pleae, by his Oracle, to direct me what coure I would take to convey away the two young Lovers; but the God was wifter than a thought, for the Heavenly powers do favour uch as reign their will to theirs, though not implored; often preventing mens Petitions with their bounty; as at this time Apollo anticipated my demand, with his reply, making me know his pleaure and direction; for as I
was hating towards the Prophetes, troubled in my mind how I might execute my deign, a voice tayed me as I paed, aying, Do you go o fat, and hear not how thee Strangers call you? They were a company of Merchants, that to the ound of Flutes and Hoboys, were doing Sacrifice, and celebrating a Feat in Honour of Hercules.

I tayed when I perceived them, for I hould have offended the Sacred Myteries of Religion, to have paed by them without repect, the Divine Voice having invited me, after I had put Frankincene in a Thurible, and incened the Altar, offering a little Water, it eem'd they thought me very umptuous in my oblations, and intreated me to take part of their Banquet; I obeyed them o far, and when I was et down upon a Couch, which the trangers had trew'd with Myrrh and Bays, and had tated uch things as I ued to eat: Noble Gentlemen, aid I, you have done me the Honour to feat me o, as I cannot deire any greater dainties, I now only long to know your Etate and Fortunes, therefore now it is time, if you pleae, to tell me who, and of what Country you are, for it would be rude, and an Incivility in me, having at with you at the Feat of a Sacrifice, and imitated Friendhip by you, by the Communion of a acred repat, if we hould part without having a more particular knowledge one of the other. Then they told me they were Phoenicians,
of the City of Tyre, by their Trade Merchants, that were then bound for Carthage, in Africa, with a Ship laded with rich Merchandies, they had brought out of India, Aethiopia, and Phoenicia; and at the preent were Sacrificing a Feat no the Tyrian Hercules; foramuch as that Young Man (aid they, pointing to one that ay by me at the Table) hath gain'd the Crown and prize of the Lute, and proclaim'd our City of Tyre Victorious among the Greeks. This Youth, when we had doubled the Cape of Malea, and by advere Winds, were forced to land in the Ile of the Cephalians, there he proteted to us by this God, the Patron of our Country, that he had foretold him in his leep the Victory he hould obtain in the Pythian game, perwading us to turn our coure, and Sail hither, where the effect hath proved the truth of his Prediction; and he that was but late a Merchant, is now proclaim'd a Conqueror, and now in gratitude to the God, makes him this Feat, for the favour of premontrating his ucces; but to morrow morning, if the Wind erve, we intend to weigh Anchor. Is that your reolution, aid I? They told me it was: You hall have me your Companion, I reply'd, if you will give me leave, for I mut make a Voyage into Sicily, about my affairs, and you know thoe that Sail for Africa, mut pas by this Iland. If you pleae (aid they) we hall be happy in your Company, for we hall make
accompt, properity will attend us o long as a Wife Man, a Grecian, and one belov'd of the Gods, as your experience peaks you, will go along with us. I deired (I aid to them) if you will but give me one day to prepare my elf, and before I go, to give ome order for my buines here: You hall have all to morrow, they reply'd, provided you come a-board us oon at night, for the night is very erviceable to us, mall breaths of Wind riing from the Earth, and wafting away a Ship, without moving of great Waves.

I promied not to fail, firt taking their Faith by Oath, they hould not looe to Sea before the time appointed; and o I left them Dancing to their Muick, that play'd quick trains like Jiggs, which they footed in the Ayrian garb; ometimes with little Skips capering in the Air, ometimes bending their Knees to the Earth, and skrewing their whole Bodies, as if they had been poet with ome prophetick Spirit. And coming to Chariclea, I found her with the Jewels yet in her lap, that Charicles had preented her: Then I went to Theagenes, and having advertis'd them both what they hould do; I retir'd to my Lodging, attending with impatience, the iue of my project.

The next day this happen'd. When Midnight drown'd all the Town in Sleep: A Troop of Young Gentlemen Armed, beieg'd the Lodgings of Chariclea. Theagenes was Captain of
that Amorous War, making his Young Thealians put off their glorious habit, and put on their Armours; who uddenly filling the Air with cries, and terrifying thoe that were between leep and wake, with the noie of their Shields and Swords, with Torches burning in their Hands, they brake into the Houe of Charicles, eaily forceing the firt Gate (for the Locks and Bolts were prepared to admit them) and took away Chariclea, who was ready and expected them, uffering them to force her with her own conent; and with the Maid, coveyed away uch portable Riches, as he pleaed, and returning through the Streets, they renewed their Warlike Clamours, and doubled the ound and terror of their Arms, frightning the City almot out of their Wits; and chooeing the dead of night to that end. Finally, they made uch a noie, as the Mountain Parnaus echoed, and replyed to the clahing of their Iron: And thus marching out of the Town, they did ride upon the Spurr, to the Mountains of the Locrians and Oetians.

But Theagenes and Chariclen, doing as I advied them, left the Thealians, and came ecretly where I expected them: Where falling at my Feet, they trembling cry'd, Save us, Father; Father, Save us: Chariclea bluhing, and bowing her Face to the Earth, as aham'd of her new Act: But Theagenes, to his other Supplications, added, Save O Calairis, two Poor Strangers
thy Suppliants, exiled from their Country, depriv'd of their Friends: Only to purchae thee for all; preerve two Poor Creatures, now expos'd to the power of Fortune; the Captives of chat Love banihed, but voluntarily banihed, and with joy repoing in you all their hope of afety. Thee words, Knemon, o touched me at the heart with pity, as I wept upon them with my Soul more than with my Eyes, o as they perceived not my orrow, yet I eaed my Spirits; I did raie and comfort them the bet I could: To conclude, auring them of a happy Iue, and that I had aupicated this buines, by the Commandment of the Gods. I will now go, aid I, and dipatch the ret: Do you expect me in his place, taking a pecial regard, you be not oberv'd by any. Then I was going away; But Chariclea caught me by a part of my Robe and tayed me: O Father, aid he, this beginning were injutice, rather a betraying, if you hould go and leave me alone with Theagenes, not conidering how unfaithful a Guard a Lover is, having the cauer of his flames in his own power. Therefore I will not eave you, till for this preent, and the time to come, you hall oblige Theagenes by vow; not to importune me, for any favour in that kind, before I do recover my Country and Parents. Or if Heaven be not o pleaed, yet till uch time as with my conent, he hall receive me for his
Wife. Admiring the vertues of the Maid, I reolved it hould be done accordingly: And making an Altar of a Table, taking Fire from the Chimny, Theagenes made his vow, profeing we had done him wrong, to cut off, by the prevention of an Oath, the voluntary intregrity of his Soul, and that he could not commend an Act done for fear, though of the Gods: Yet he did wear by Apollo of Delphos, by Diana, by Venus her elf and Love, to do nothing that hould dipleae Chariclea. Thus calling the Gods to Witnes; they accorded thee, and other Articles betwixt them.

I holding on my coure to Charicles, found his Houe full of Tears and Tumult: Foramuch as the Servants of Chariclea had already brought him news of the carrying away of his Daughter, and Citizens came in from all parts of the Town, and flocked about depairing Charicles. In umm, the ignorance of what was done, and the want of Counel in what was to be done, confued them all: I therefore thundering amongt them with a loud voice; O mierable Men (aid I) how long will you tand like tupid things, mute and dull, as if you were deprived of your Judgment with your Fortune? What will you not Arm and purue your Enemies? Will you not take and punih them who have done you uch an injury? But Charicles replied, it were perhaps uperfluous and vain to truggle longer with thee diaters, for I
am aured the Divine wrath inflicts this punihment upon me; when coming once at a forbidden hour into the Sanctuary of our Temple, I aw what was not lawful for Man to behold. Then the God foretold me, for my preumption I hould be deprived of that was dearet to my Eyes: yet let not this hinder you to fight (as they ay) with the Gods themelves, if we knew whither we hould go, and who hath been o cruel to us: It was (aid I) even the Thealian whom you o much admired, and would needs make me acquainted with him; it was Theagenes and his youthful company; perhaps you may find ome of them yet in Town, for ure they cannot be all departed; therefore rie and call a Council of the people. It was done o as I appointed, and the Captains ent their Men to proclaim, by ound of Trumpet, that the Townmen hould aemble: immediately the people came in, and they held a Council, by night, upon the Theatre.

p.U:
tood forth into the middle, and preently et them all on weeping, beholding him in his Mourning, his Head and Face covered with ahes; but much more when his affliction unfolded it elf in his words: Perhaps, dear Country-men, (aid he) eeing me thus tand forth, you may eteem me come hither to eae my heart, and to have convoked o great an aembly to be pectators of the enormous greatnes of my mieries; but this is not my meaning,
for though I have often utained calamities equal with Death it elf, and that my Houe is now deerted, laid wate from Heaven, and mut remain deolate ever hereafter, having lot, one after another, all that were dear to me, and in whoe beloved acquaintance I took the only joy of my life; yet vain hope (an error) common to all the World, makes me reolute to be patient, and not die, yet perwading my elf my Child may be recovered, but that which moves me mot, is this City, which I deire and expect to ee victorious before my death, and revenged of thoe have offered her this violence, unles thee Thealian Youths have alo ravihed from us our generous Spirits, and our indignation for the abue to our Country, and our Gods protect us, for it would be a grievous heartbreak to us all, if a few dancing Boys, the Miniters of the acred Legation, hould go away with the poils of the principal City of Greece; having robbed in my ight, ah me, the Temple of Apollo of its mot precious treaure, my Chariclea. O implacable and obtinate wrath of the detinies to wards me, firt, as you know, they extinguihed my own Daughters life even with her Nuptial Torches, then took away her Mother from me, eized with uch a orrow at her Death, as it cot her preently her life; oon after they chaed me from my Country, but all this methought was upportable, after I had found Chariclea. Chariclea was all my
Life, my Hope, the hope of my Succeion, Chariclea was all my Comfort, and, as I may ay, my Anchor; but woe is me, this Tempet, whenceoever it aroe, hath cruelly broke all my Cables. Neither was this done imply and accidentally, but expresly to inult over us, at uch an unexpected eaon, taking her away from her Bed, almot her Nuptial Bed, as you all know, for I had publihed to you my intention of her Marriage.

div.p:
He, peaking thus, and falling from his matter into Complaints, the Provot Hegeias cut him off, and wihed him to go home, peaking to the People in this ort: My Lords Aitans, and the ret, Charicles hall have free liberty to make his Complaints hereafter when he pleaeth; but let us not be drowned in his orrow, nor inconiderately be carried away with his Tears, as with the current of a River, neglecting the occaion, which in all things, and principally in affairs of War, is of greatet importance; for if now from this aembly we would et forward, there might be ome hope we hould overtake them, whilt they march carelesly, thinking us unprovided to purue them; but if we tay longer to condole with Charicles, with feminine Faces, pitying his diaters, it will only remain, that by our delay, we hall give them means to ecape, and our elves be laught at, and by Boys, which we hould have preently taken, and nailed upon Gallowfes;
making ome of them uffer with uch ignominy, and transferring the diparagement down upon their Families; which would be an eaie thing, if we exaperate the Thealians againt thee Men, (if any of them hall ecape us) by interdicting them by our Decree, to end any more of their Nation to perform this Sacrifice; and ordaining, by Common Council, that hereafter the olemn Anniverary of the Demi-god Neoptolemus, hall be celebrated by our elves at the publick charge. Whilt they were commending his Speech, and paing an Act againt the Thealians: Let it be confirmed by your uffrage, if you pleae, aid the Captain, that the Prietes of Diana hall no more preent herelf to give the Palm to thoe that run in Armour; for, as far as I am able to conjecture, it was from thence the Sacrilegious flame of his Love kindled in Theagenes; who, as it eems, tudied this rape from the time that he firt aw her; and it will be good, for the future, to take away the occaion from others of the like attempt.

Having obtained this, by the common conent and vote of all the people, Hegeias gave the word, the Trumpets ounded the Alarm, and the Theatre broke up, diolving into a War; running confuedly into the Field, not only uch as Age had trengthned, and were able to bear Armour, but Boys and Youths promicuouly upplying the default of Forces, by
the force of their Affections; bold to partake the fortune of that expedition. There were alo multitudes of Women, that carried with greater Spirits than their oft Sex permitted, and taking up any Weapons that were next their hands, followed with the ret; but in vain, for their natural debility having made them know it had not force enough, they aw they were frutrated of their deires to revenge themelves of the Thealians: There you might ee old men truggling with their Age, their Souls, as it were, drawing their Bodies with uch a promptitude, and boyling ardour, as they eemed to reproach and upbraid their own weaknes; o paionate was all the Town for the los of Chariclea, and as if one Spirit had moved them, they all together allyed forth in the puruit, not o much as expecting the day-light.

div.head: THE AETHIOPIAN HISTORY.
The Fifth Book.
div.p:
IN this trouble and hurly-burly was the Town of Delphos, but whether they performed any ervice or not, I cannot tell; for their puruit did give me the occaion to take my flight; o as taking the two young Lovers with me, I brought them down to the Port at that hour of the Night, and we went aboard the Phaenicians, who were ready to weigh Anchors, if we had tayed never o little longer; foramuch as they perceiving the day began to appear, and that we came not, they made account they hould not falifie their Oaths made unto me, being to attend one day and one night
only; but we coming jut upon the time, they received us with great joy; and preently cutting the Water with their Oars, they rowed out of the Haven to the Main, and then a oft Wind breathing from the Coat full upon the Poop, moved little waves, that eemed to play be ind the Ship, and uffered us to pas with all our Sails pread. You would then have aid, the Gulf of Currha, the Elevation of Parnaus, the Promontories of Aetolia and Caladonia Hed from the ight of our Veel, that paed as nimbly as if it were flying by them; and having fail'd all the day, we came within kenning of the pointed Ilands, both in name and figure, the Sun then etting.

But why am I o uneaonably tedious, and what is my reaon o to forget both my elf and you, as to tretch this dicoure, as really to commit you to the mercy of a Sea? Let us now leave work a while, and take a little Sleep, for though you are very attentive, and reit Sleep valiantly, yet I am perwaded, Knemon, you cannot hold out long, the better part of the night being pent in his ad repetition; and, Child, Age lying heavy on me, and the memory of my calamities infeebling my Spirits, I mut needs have a little ret. You have done well, Father, now ceae, aid Knemon, not that I am weary of the Relation, for that I hould never be, though you hould peak many days and nights together; there is uch Magick
in your words, and weetnes, that exceeds the voice of Syrens.

But I have heard a kind of murmuring a good while, and a noie about the Houe, and, I confes, it troubled me, but I was forced to be ilent, drawn on with a deire to hear you. I heard nothing, aid Calairis, foramuch as happily Age hath debilitated my ence, for old Age is a malady of all the parts of the Body, principally of the Ears; and perhaps it was becaue my thoughts were entirely fixt upon my Story, and ure 'tis Nauicles, the Mater of the Houe. but what (O Gods) hath he performed? All to our wih (aid Nauicles) entering at thoe words; And I know, good Calairis, you did long to hear the News, and that your Spirit was in the Field with me: I have had many proofs of your affection; and it is not the leat that I heard you remember me in my abence, and wih my fortune; but who is this Stranger? A Grecian, aid Calairis; you hall know the ret hereafter; but do not hold us longer in upence: if you have propered in your expedition make us partakers of your content: You hall hear that to morrow too, aid Nauicles, for the preent let it uffice you to know I have recover'd my Thisbe, much fairer than he was; and o I leave you, for my Journey and the troubles of my mind require ome ret: Having aid this, he went to make his word good.

But Knemon at the hearing of the name of Thisbe grew very Melancholy, and began to think of former paages betwixt them; paing the night as if he had lain upon Thorns; Weeping, Sighing and Tormenting himelf o grievouly, as he awaked Calairis, though he lept oundlier than his cutom was; the old man raiing himelf, and leaning upon his Elbow, demanded what the matter was; and why he o diquieted himelf, like a Mad-man? Would it not make any man mad, aid Knemon, to hear that Thisbe is alive again? Who is that Thisbe, aid Calairis, how come you to know her, having heard her named? and why doth it trouble you o much to undertand he lives? I will tell you that another time, aid Knemon, when I make you a rehearal of my fortunes; but for the preent, know, I did ee her dead before my Eyes, and with thee two hands I my elf buried her in the Iland of the Herdmen. Sleep, Sleep, aid Calairis, you hall know to morrow how all goes. I cannot leep, aid Knemon; I pray you, do you take your ret; I do not think I hall be able to live, unles I get up, and make ome means to be more curiouly informed whether Nauicles be in an error, or whether the dead do only revive among the Aegyptians: At this Calairis miled, and fell aleep again.

But Knemon went out of the Room very gingerly, and oftly, as was fit, being in the dark,
in a trange houe; but he was content to venture, longing to free himelf of the fear and upicion he conceived of Thisbe; till at length, though it was long firt, groping and turning about, paing and repaing the ame places, as if they were different, he heard a Woman, like a Nightingale in a Cage, with oft and lamentable accents, complain of her hard fortune; and laying his Ear to the crevice of the door, he ditinguihed thee words;

Poor mierable, I though my elf afe out of the hands of Thieves, and that I had ecaped the horror of a Bloody death, which I expected, hoping to pas the ret of my life with my Beloved, which, though it had been the life of a tranger and a wanderer, yet living with him it had contented me; for there can be nothing o rigorous, or full of moletation, that his weet preence will not make upportable; but the yet pityles Detiny, that hath perecuted me from my Birth, having once more flattered me with hope, hath again deceived me. I eteemed my elf free from ervitude, and behold I am a Slave again: I imagined I hould be no more a Prioner, and I am as traitly kept as ever before: I was environed in an Iland, envellopped in darknes; the etate of my preent Fortune reembles my late Miery, or rather is more wretched, ince he is forced from me, that by his conolation would and could weeten any bitternes; The lat day the
Cave of the Thieves was my Retreat; and what was it but an Abys, a Hell, or properly a Grave; and yet the preence of my Love made it a weet place; there he mourned for me, living, believing me to be dead; and weeping for me, as murdered by the hand of a cruel Enemy; but now, alas, I am deprived of uch comforts, the companion of my mieries is perihed, that did bear grief with me, as a common burden; and I am left alone, foraken, a Captive, wretched, every way expoed to the cruel mercy of Fortune; only contented not to die, becaue I hope my dearet Friend yet lives; but, O my Soul, where are you now, or what new accident befals you! are you, ah me, a Slave, as I am? is that free and generous Courage (patient of any Servitude but that of Love) now made a Captive? yet love whatoever you indure live till, and hope at length to ee your Thisbe, for o you mut call me, though I know it is againt your will. Knemon was no longer able to contain himelf when he heard this, and had not patience to tay the ret, at firt upecting her for another; but in the end of her Speech concluding her to be Thisbe; he had much ado to keep himelf from falling down almot at the door.

But he held out the bet he could, and for fear ome of the Houe hould take him there (for now the Cocks and crowed the econd time) he ran away, ometimes breaking his Shins againt
the Stools that tood in his way; ometimes running his Face againt the Wall, and now tum ling at a Threhold or Door Pots: In the end he got to his Chamber where he preently cat himelf upon the Bed, where he began to tremble and his Teeth to chatter, in uch ort, as he had been in danger of his Life, unles Calairis had intantly been aware of him, and cherihed and comforted him, making him come to himelf again: And after Knemon began to breathe again, Calairis ask'd what had frighted him; I am lot he reply'd, for it is true the wicked Thisbe is reviv'd: And when he aid this, he fell into a wound again, and the Old Man took a great deal of pains again, while he endeavour'd to recover him; it was evidently ome God that took a delight to play with Knemon (as all things in the World, is only their game and mockery) and would not permit him to enjoy without grief, the weets of his deire, but mixed with bitternes, that which preently after was to give him thhe height of his content, foramuch as happily they intended to how what was their cutom, and it may be the reaon of it is that humane nature is not capable to receive a imple joy without ome allay, as may be judged by this Example of Knemon, who at that time fled away from the object he mot wihed, and was frighted with the weetet accent could befal him; for the Woman that he had heard lamenting was Chariclea, and not Thisbe, and thus it came about.

After Thyamis was faln alive into the power of his Enemies, that he was taken Prioner, and that the Fire had reduc'd all the Iland to Ahes, and unpeopl'd it of the Herdsmen. Knemon and Thermutis, the Page of Thyamis, ferry'd over the Lake in the morning to venture as Spies among their Enemies, to get knowledge of the etate of their Captain: The events of their journey you have heard before, but Theagenes and Chariclea remain'd alone in the Cave, reputing the delay of miery as a great good Fortune, for then finding themelves free without any peron to trouble them, they imbraced, gave and received o many mutual Kies, as falling into a languihing oblivion, they remain'd along time as if they would have grown into one body, yet feating themelves with chat and pure delights.

But at length the care of their affairs return'd into their memory, and neceity contrained them to give over their Carees. Theagenes beginning in this ort to peak; Our chiefet wih, and our continual Prayer to the Gods of Greece, my fair Chariclea, is, That they will permit us to pas the coure of all our years together, and to enjoy the happineswe prefer before all others; in hope whereof we have utained o many evils. But foramuch as the condition of all Worldly things is variable and o untable, as that we ee inclineing one way, in a moment we perceive changed to the contrary, we have already uffer'd much
and are yet to expect more miery, being to go to the Town of Chemis as we have promis'd Knemon: And what will heare befal us, Heaven knows! and from thence quetionles it will be a mighty journey ere we hall arrive in the Country we are bound for; therefore I think it would be good we hould agree upon ome Cyphers or Privy tokens, by means whereof, when we are together, we may ecretly interchange the expreion of our minds, and find out one another, if by Fortune we hould be eparated; for the bet guide after one hath trayed, is the memory of ome marks he hath taken of his Friends. Chariclea approv'd his invention, and they agreed, in cae they hould be parted, That upon all the famous Temples and Statua's, Images and Stones in cros ways, he hould write Pythias and Chariclea Pythia, expreing whether they were gone to the Right or the Left, into what Town, Village or Country, adding the day and hour; but if by chance they did meet, it would uffice that one hould but ee the other; foramuch as time would never deface thoe amorous marks that were imprinted in their Souls: Yet Chariclea hewed him her Fathers Ring that was expoed with her; and Theagenes let her ee a White Scar upon his Knee, given him by a Wound he receiv'd fighting with a Wild Boar; and o they reolved there hould be ecret words betwixt them; hers was the Torch, his the Palm. In confirmation of this agreement,
they imbraced and wept again, pouring (as I conceiv'd) their tears, intead of o ferings, and ealing to it with Kies in the place of vows.

This done, they went forth of the Cave not touching any of the Treaure there incloed, for they eteem'd Riches gather'd by Robberies, as a polluted thing, but they took again their own which they had brought from Delphos, and been depriv'd of by the Thieves: Chariclea changing her habit, and putting her Jewels, Crown and Sacred Robe in a little Knapack; to diguie her elf the more, he went in a poor Gown, and gave Theagenes her Bow and Quiver to carry; a carriage that was weet and uitable to him, being Cupids Arms, the God that had made him a vaal to his Empire.

Let us do as it pleaes you, replied Theagenes, and o followed, as if he had drawn him after her, but they could not reach the Cave in time; but while they only regarded thoe that came to them in front, they perceived not themelves to be incloed by another company of Souldiers, that had landed in another part of the Iland; at lat falling upon thee, they tayed in a maze, epecially Chariclea, who fled into the Arms of Theagenes; if he were to die, deiring to die there: Some of thee that invaded them, lifted up their hands to trike them down; but after the young Lovers had looked upon their Enemies, their pirits fail'd them, and their hands were benummed; for even the barbarous, as it eems, do bear repect to Beauty; and thoe Nature hath indued with perfections, do mollifie the Eyes and Hearts, that are by Nature fierce and bloody. Having taken them, they preently conveyed them to their Captain, ambitious to be the firt that hould bring him the fairet poils: And indeed this was all they
were likely to preent him, for when they had run all over, as if they would have put a Net about the Iland, no one ele could find any thing, for all the Iland was burnt in the former War, only the Cave remained, and that they knew not. Then the Souldiers led them to their General, whoe Name was Mitranes, Captain of the Garrions to Oroondates, who adminitred the Government of Aegypt, as the Great Kings Lieutenant; and for a great umm of Money given him by Nauicles, had enter'd the Iland with him to recover Thisbe.

Now after Theagenes and Chariclea, often invoking the aid of their good Genius, were brought o near that Mitranes might dicern them, Nauicles, that tood by him, adviing himelf of the right trick of a Merchant, active in matter of profit, tepped forth, and running to Chariclea, cryed with a loud voice, Behold my Thisbe, the very ame thoe wicked Rogues, the Herdmen, took from me. But now, Mitranes, by your favour and the Gods, I hall recover her; then the eiz'd upon Chariclea, feigning to receive great contentment; and whipering in her Ear, in Greek, that the ret hould not undertand, wihed her to confes her name was Thisbe, if he deired to be afe: His Sophim had the ucces he hoped for, for Chariclea hearing him peak Greek, and conjecturing the Man intended her ome good, accommodated herelf to his intention; and being
demanded her Name by Mitranes, he aid he was called Thisbe. Then Nauicles, with open Arms, ran to embrace the Neck of Mitranes; many times kiing his Head, and admiring his good fortune, puffed up with vanity the heart of the Barbarian; telling him, it appeared that his other Exploits in War were great, ince he had o happily conducted the preent enterprie. The Captain, blown up with a flattery of his praies, and deceived by a fale name, though he was amazed to behold o much Beauty in o poor Clothes, hining, like the Moon, behind a Cloud, notwithtanding the levity of the mans Spirit, was caught with the uddennes of the Plot, and could not for hame refue to give her to Nauicles; Take her, aid he, ince it is o that he is yours; I have recovered her for you, do with her what you pleae: And at thee words delivered her into his hands, looking continually towards her, and manifeting it was againt his will, and for the Money he had taken, that he yielded poeion of the Maid: But this (aid he, pointing to Theagenes) whooever he be, he is our Prioner, and hall follow us, with a Guard upon him, to be ent to Babylon; for the hape of his Body is o fair, as he is worthy to erve at the Kings Table: Things thus ordained, they paed the Lake, and then were the Lovers eparated; Nauicles with Chariclea returning to his Houe at Chemmis; and Mitranes, with his Men, viiting
other Towns that were under his command, without delay dipatched Theagenes with Letters to Oroondates, who was then at Memphis. The tenour of his Letter was this:

body.head: The Captain Mitranes, to the Vice-Roy Oroondates.
body.p: I Send you a young Grecian we have taken, that merits noblier than to be my Servant; and, in my opinion, is worthy to wait only in the preence of the Great King, our God; affording you hereby the means to end a preent to our Mater, uch as the Court never yet beheld, nor hall ever hereafter ee like.

div.p:
But before it was clear day, Calairis and Knemon, hoping to inform their ignorance, came to Nauicles, and demanding what he had done; he related all the paages how he had paed into the Iland, how he had found it deerted, at firt not encountring any peron, and how he had ubtilly abued Mitranes, receiving a Young Maid as if he had been Thisbe, that by good Fortune appear'd in the Iland, and was o fair, as he would be much more advantagenous to him, than if he had found Thisbe: For there was no les difference betwixt them, than in the comparing of a Goddes to a Woman; that he had never een a Beauty o perfect, but it was much below this Strangers; and that he had not
words ufficient to expres it; neither was it needful, ince he would how her to them. When they heard this, they began to upect who he was, and were very earnet with him to command, the Maid might be preently brought in, for they knew it mut needs be the ineffable Beauty of Chariclea: Who being come before them, was veiled to the Eyes, and thoe he bowed to the Earth; till Nauicles auring her there was no caue of fear, he lifted up her Eyes a little, eeing and being een, contrary to all expectation, immediately the three fell a weeping; and as if there had been a ign amongt them, or that they had all received one wound, were loud in their paion, nothing being heard from them, but O Father, O Daughter, my true Child Chariclea, not Knemon's Thisbe. This amazed Nauicles, o far as he had not a word to ay, when he aw Calairis embracing Chariclea with tears, not knowing how this mutual Knowledge came about, being like the meeting of Friends in a Comedy upon ome tage; till Calairis kiing him for joy, pake to him thus:

Bet of Men, may the Gods ever grant the ucces you deire, and amply atisfie your wihes; you are the preerver of my never-hoped Daughter, and it is by your means I now enjoy her ight, the weetet object of the World: But, O my dear Child, O Chariclea, where have you left Theagenes? At his demand
he wept, and for a while being not able to bring forth a word, at length he replied, He is taken Prioner, and he, whooever he is, that delivered me to this Man, hath led him Captive. Then Calairis deired Nauicles to declare to him what he knew touching Theagenes, and who he was that had him in his power, and to what place he was led Captive. Nauicles undertanding thee were the ame the old man had o often mentioned to him, told him the umm of all; but he added, That knowledge would not at all advantage poor men, for he could hardly believe the offer of a great Ranom would redeem him from Mitranes. We have Money, aid Chariclea oftly to Calairis, promie what umm you pleae; I keep till the Jewels you know, and have them about me: This put Spirit into Calairis, but fearing Nauicles hould enter into ome upicion what it was that Chariclea pake of; Good Nauicles, aid he, a wie man never wants, but is ever as rich as he can wih himelf, for the Gods will end him as much wealth as he judges to be fit to demand of them; therefore only ay where he is that detains Theagenes, and the Divine Bounty will not fail, but will furnih us with as much as hall erve to content the Perian avarice. At thee words Nauicles could not chue but mile; And you will then (aid he) make me believe that it is poible for you to grow rich of the udden, as if it were by
