the turning of an Engine: If you will firt pay me down a ranom for your Daughter, for you know well the Perian and the Merchant only tudy for their gain: I know it, aid Calairis, and you hall have it as it is good reaon; but why are you o free, that amongt all your other benefits you will alo anticipate our Suit, and are pleaed of your own accord, to propoe the retitution of my Daughter. I will only firt intreat your leave, to make my Prayers to the Gods: With all my heart, aid Nauicles, I my elf am now going to offer Sacrifice, I hall deire you preence there, and that you will pray the Gods to end me riches, and receive for your elf, that which I have in preent: Do not you mock me nor be incredulous, aid Calairis, but go before and prepare the Sacrifice; and when all things are ready, I will come. He did o, and a while after a Servant came from Nauicles, to wih him to make hat to the Temple, and they (for now they had contrived how they would have it) went thither joyfully with Nauicles, and the ret of the invited men; for he had provided a Publick Sacrifice, and Chariclea with the Daughter of Nauicles, and other Women that had eayed to flatter her orrows, with many conolatory words, and had intreated her to go along; but I believe they had never prevail'd, if by Fortune it had not come into her thoughts, that under pretext of the Sacrifice, he might make her Prayers to the Gods, for the afety of Theagenes.

Being now come to the Temple of Mercury, (for Nauicles Sacrific'd to him as the God of the Exchange and Merchants) Calairis a while comtemplateing the entrails of the Beat, by the changes of his countenance, made them evidently know the Gods foretold him many trange adventures, intermixt with Joy and Sorrow. Then putting his Hands upon the Altar where the fire of the Sacrifice yet burned, and feigning to draw out of the middet of the flame, that which he had before prepared about him; Behold faid he, O Nauicles! what the Gods end you by us, for the ranom of Chariclea: And with thoe words preented him a certain Princely Ring, a rare and divine thing, it eem'd the circle was of Amber, and within the Collet was et an Aethiopian Amethyt, gloriouly parkling, of the bignes of the eye of a Young Maid, much urpaing in Beauty thoe that come from Spain or Britain, for thoe are of a faded red that hath no plendour, and reembles Roes blowing from their buttons; when the beams of the Sun begin firt to et, bluhes on them: but the Aethiopian Amethyt hath a fire parkling from the bottom of the Stone; which if you turn it in your hand, cats a beam of Gold before your Eyes: Not uch as dazleth the ight with too flaring brightnes, but clears it with a pure and delicate light: This in the natural propriety is of much more power than thoe of the Wet, for it doth not challenge its name faly,
but really, keeps the wearer ober at all Feats; All the Amethyts that come from the Indies, or Aethiopia, have the like virtues, but that which Calairis preented to Nauicles, was yet more precious: For it was ingraven with the Figures of living Creatures to the Life.

There you might ee a little Boy feeding Sheep, tanding upon a Rock, that was not very high, to look about him, as from a little watch Tower, making his Sheep feed with the Muick of his Pipe; and you would ay, that his Flock liten'd and went forward to the Cadence as he ounded: Some would conceive them to have Golden Fleeces; not that Art o adorn'd them, but it was the proper colour of the Amethyt hineing upon their Backs. There were the Figures of young Lambs, eeming to make little Skips: Some that ran in Flocks towards the Rock; others that went circling about it, making the Rock a Patoral Stage: Some appear'd playing in the flame of the Amethyt as in the Sun; and in leaping, craped the Stone a little, only with the tips of their Feet. But thoe that were the liveliet of them, you would have thought, their leapings would have broke the Border of the Stone; but that the indutry of the Workman had kept them off; parking them in with a Golden Pale that went about the Rock, which was a true Rock, not an imitation. For the Workman had reerv'd a corner of the A methyt to make it: Serving himelf with a
native thing, to repreent which he meant to counterfeit, for he eteemed if uperfluous, that a Stone hould be feigned in a Stone, uch was the Ring and Sculpture.

But Nauicles was much amazed with the unexpected accident, and overjoyed with the great value of it, etimating it no les than all his Riches. Believe me (aid he) good Calairis, I did but jet, not peak eriouly, when I demanded the Ranom of your Daughter, for my meaning was to retore her freely to you; yet in regard the gifts ent us by the Gods (as you wie men ay) are not to be refued, I receive this Stone, as ent from Heaven, believing auredly, that Mercury, the bet of the Gods, and my Patron, according to his cutom, hath furnihed you with this Preent for me, from the Fire, for you may ee the Flame is in it yet; beides, I mut needs eteem that gain mot honet, which, without the leat endamaging of the giver, enricheth the Receiver. At thee words the Sacrifice being ended, Nauicles invited all the Aitants to it down to the Feat, commanding the Tables hould be covered apart for the Women in the heart of the Temple, and in the Porch for the Men. After they had eaten liberally, and the Cloth was taken away, and that, according to the fahion, the Cups for drinking Healths were et upon the Table, the Men invoked Bacchus, drinking in honour of him, and nging to him the uual
Catch, that is ung to the Boone Voyage, when they go aboard; and the Women danced to the Tune of a Hymn, compoed in the praie of Ceres. But Chariclea, retiring herelf, conidered of her affairs, offering her Devotions for the life and afety of Theagenes; and now the drink began to heat the company, every one preenting his ervice to his friend in Wine; when Nauicles holding out a Vial of pure Water; Honet Callairis, aid he, I drink to you, ince it o pleaeth you, in this cold Nymph, that is no companion for Bacchus, but for Nymphs and Virgins; but if you pleae to pleadge us in the Relation we o much deire, you hall chear our Spirits with the bet Beveridge: Do you not hear how the Women, to lengthen out the Feat, and to avoid drinking, are fallen to dancing; as for us, the dicoure of your Voyage will be a noble entertainment for us after our Feat, weeter than any Dance or Muick; and ince, as you know, you deferred it before, when it might put you in mind of your diater, then new, and uch as drowned your Soul in grief; now you cannot put it off to a more convenient time, ince at this preent one of your Children, your Daughter, is afe before your Eyes; and you hall ee your Son, by the favour of the Gods, ere many days be pat, if you do not anger me by deferring again the relation of your Fortunes.

The Gods, O Nauicles, aid Knemon, then give to your heart the effect of your deires; ince having ent for all forts of Muick to your Feat now neglect them for the preent, and leave them to uch as have more low affections in their Souls, while you are covetous to hear acred and mytical things, mingled with a kind of a divine pleaure; wherein, I oberve, you well know the power and nature of the Divinity, placing Mercury next to Bacchus; and o mixing with the delights of Feating, the content of weet dicoure; and therefore, though I jutly admired the plendour and preparation of your Sacrifice; yet I cannot believe it is poible to pleae Bacchus more than at a Feat made in his honour, to bring in the recital of ome fine tory, Speech being his proper Sympbol.

Calairis obeying their deires, recounted the entire Hitory unto them, as well to gratifie Knemon, as to oblige Nauicles, for the affairs he was hortly to have with him: He then told them his Fortunes from the beginning, repeating ummarily, and in few words, the chief heads of what he had aid before to Knemon; and purpoely paing over many things that he held not neceary Nauicles hould undertand, but that which was not as yet related, and depended upon the premies, he continued in this ort;

After they were fled from Delphos, and imbarqued in the Phoenician Ship, they Sailed at firt as they could wih, being wafted with a oft breath of wind full in the Poop, but when they fell into the Streights of Caladonia, they were greatly troubled, the Sea in that place being naturally unquiet, and ever turbulent.
But Knemon aid him here, entreating him to pas no further, without telling them the caue (if haply he knew it) why the Sea in that place is continually in uch violent agitation.

The Ionian Sea, replied Calairis, being there, from a large and pacious Main contracted to a Streight, and pouring it elf into the Gulph of Cria, as through a narrow Flood-gate, hating to mix with the Aegean Sea, meets with the Ithmus, or neck of Land, in Peloponneus, that beats back its waves, hindring their impetuoity, doubtles by the Providence of Heaven, which et that promontory to break the violence of the Streights, let they hould overflow the oppoite Shore; and hence, as it is probable, come the turbulency of this Sea, the waves being more preed together in this than any other place of the Gulph; foramuch as the Stream that flows in, and the Waters that flow back, encountring and beating one another, makes the billows boyl, and, by their concuion, covers all the Sea with a foam, no les than in a violent Tempet.
All the company having with praie and applaue allowed his reaons, Calairis thus purued the eries of his dicoure.

After we had paed other Streights, and lot ight of thoe that are named the acute or pointed Ilands, it eemed to us we aw the Promontory of the Zacynthians, like a Cloud in the Air, o far off as our Eyes could hardly dicern it. Then the Pylot commanded them to hale in the Sails, and we demanding what his meaning was to lack his coure, ince the wind was favourable; becaue (replied he) if we go with full Sail, we hall arrive at the Iland about the firt watch of the Night; and it is to be feared, let in the dark we hould run upon the Rocks, which lie hid with the Sea in many places thereabouts; therefore it were bet to pas this Night upon the Main, where we have Sea-room, and to take no more wind than will erve to bring us to land about the break of day. Thus aid the Patron, but yet, Nauicles, it was not done, for the Sun was rien before we cat our Anchors; thoe of the Iland that lived about the Port, being not far ditant from the City, ran in from all parts to behold us, as to ome new and trange Spectacle, wondring (as we conceived) at the ervice-ablenes of our Ship, that was o fair, o tall, and yet o light, admiring therein the workmanhip of the Phoenicians, and telling us we had unuual and incredible fortune, to ail afe
in the midt of winter, when the Pleiades were et. All the ret of our Mates, while the Sailors were looing of the Tacklings, went aland, and ran into the City to traffick with the Zacynthians.

But I (having heard the Pylot ay we hould winter in that Iland) went along by the Sea-Coat, to enquire out ome poor Lodging for us, not being willing to remain in the Veel, but avoiding it, for the trouble of the Mariners, as an inconvenient Lodging; and hunning the Town, as unafe, for concealing the flight of the two young Lovers. I had not gone far, but I aw an old Fiherman itting before his door, mending his Broken Nets; and approaching him, I aid; Save you, honet man, I pray you tell me if there be a Lodging to be taken hereabouts? It was about yonder Promontory, replied he, that I cat this Net yeterday, upon a Rock covered with the Water, and o tore it as you ee; I do not ask you that, aid I, but you hall do an office of humanity if you will receive me into your houe, or hew me ome other place, where I may lodge. It was not I, aid the good man, I was not in the Boat, Heaven forbid Tyrrhenus hould mitake o grosly, or that Age had o much infeebled his Brain: It was the fault of my Boys, that, ignorant of the places where the Water covered the Rocks, cat their Nets where they hould not.

At length perceiving he was omewhat deaf, I began to peak more loud. It was Good morrow to you that I aid, and my requet was, You would hew me and my company, being Strangers, ome houe where we may ojourn. The Gods conerve you alo, he then replied, if it pleae you to take uch poor entertainment as I am able to give you, you hall be welcome to me, unles you be ome of thoe that look for Houes furnihed with fair Beds, or have many followers: After I had told him we were but three, my two Children and my elf; It is a good number, replied he, you hall find but one more with us, for I have two Children yet at home, (their elder Brothers are married men, and houe-keepers themelves) and the fourth is the Nure of my Children, for their Mother is lately dead; therefore, Sir, make no delay, and doubt not but we will receive you joyfully and chearfully, I having known as oon as I heard you peak, you were a Gentleman, by your fahion.

I did o, and immediately coming with Theagenes and Chariclea, the good man Tyrrhenus entertained us with a very good will, and gave us the better and warmer part of his Houe: And indeed at the beginning we paed the Winter contentedly, remaining all the day long together, never parting but at the hour of Bed-time. Chariclea did lie with the Nure, Theagenes and I in a room by our elves; and in another little
Chamber Tyrrhenus and his Children. We ate all at the Table together, which we furnihed with all Meats but Fih, wherewith Tyrrhenus abundantly upplied us from the Sea. Sometimes Fihing alone, ometimes to pas the day we helped him. He was a Mater of his Trade, and knew how to Fih in divers manners, according to the diverity of the eaon. He never cat his Nets, but he drew them full, o as many attributed that to good Fortune, which ought to have been acribed to his Art and Experience.

But once unhappy, and ever unhappy (as they ay.) Neither could the Beauty of Chariclea remain in this Solitude without Trouble and Misfortune, for the young Tyrian Merchant that had obtained one of the Prizes in the Pythian Games, and with whom we had imbarqued our elves, did grievouly molet me with his continual importunities, that I would give him Chariclea in Marriage, addreing himelf as if I had been the Father that begot her; and perpetually boating; now telling me of his illutrious Family, then counting his Riches, how the Ship was his own, and that he had the greatet part of the Merchandie that laded her, which were Gold, Silver, Precious Stones and Silks; and to give no little acceion to his Splendour and Glory, he again put me in mind how his Victory was proclaimed in the Pythian Games, and many uch like things.

But I pretending preent poverty, and that my heart would never conent to Marry my Daughter to a Stranger, that hould live in a Region o far off from Aegypt. Father, aid he, let not this trouble you, I hall eteem your Daughter herelf a ufficient Portion, greater than a Million of Talents, or all the Riches of the World: I hall alo willingly change my Country and my Friends for her, turning my intended coure to Carthage, and accompanying you to what place of the Earth you hall pleae to ail; then finding it was not poible to atisfie the Phaenician, but that his Flame increaing he grew till more paionate, and would never let me ret, I thought bet to put him off with fair promies, leat he hould make ome violent attempt upon us in the Iland, auring him I would do as he deired, when we hould arrive in Aegypt.

But ee the Fortune; I was no ooner freed of this Merchant, but (as it is aid) one Wave followed another: for a few days after, Tyrrhenus taking me aide to a place where the Shore did bow and make an Angle. O Calairis, aid he, I vow to you by Neptune and the other Sea-Gods, that I ee you with as much joy, as my Brother, and your Children, as my own; and I mut tell you, there is a train laid for you, that will be very hard for you to ecape; but I held it not lawful to conceal it from you, in repect, we have now a long time lived together
in one Houe; and being it concerns you to know it, There is a Pirate, whoe Galley lies under the covert of this Promontory, that watches for the Phaenician Ship, and ends out Spies to oberve their getting forth to Sea; therefore take heed what you do, and look well to your elves; for I advertie you, they have conceiv'd this cruel, but cutomary deign for you, or rather for your Daughter.

The Gods, aid I, be as good to you as you have hewed your elf true to us. But Tyrrhenus, how came you to dicover this Plot? By my Trade, replyed he, I am known to them, and ue to carry them Fih, becaue they buy dearet and give me greater rates than any other; and yeterday as I was drawing my Net by the ide of yonder Rock, the Captain of the Pirates met me, and demanded if I knew not when the Phaenicians meant to looe out of the Haven? I preently doubting his demand tended to ome Stratagem; I cannot jutly tell you, Trachinus, aid I, but I believe it will be the Spring before they depart: And the Maid that Lodges at your Houe doth he go along? I do not know, replyed I, but why do you enquire o curiouly? Becaue, aid he, I am deperately in Love with her, and o ravihed with the wonder of her merit, though I have but once beheld her, as I can hardly be my elf; neither can I remember I ever fortun'd upon uch a Beauty, though I have taken many and fairer Captives; then pulling
him nearer to me that I might the better get out his whole Plot? what need have you, aid I, to Fight with thee Plaenicians ince that without the los of Blood, you may eaily take her from my Houe before they imbarque. No, replyed he, there is a concience among Thieves, and we oberve the Laws of courteie and humanity towards our Friends; for your ake therefore I forbear, leat it hould bring you into trouble, in regard your guets being lot, would be required at your Hands, and with one Labour I mean to gain two things, the Riches of the Ship, and the enjoying of the Maid; one whereof I mut necearily forego, if I execute my deign upon the Land; beides I hould run a deperate hazard, the Port being o near the Town, as they would preently get notice of it, and o I might come to be purued. So after I had admired his Widom, and praied the Excellency of his judgment; and now having dicovered the Plot, thee. Villains have appointed, I earnetly beeech you to employ all your thoughts to provide for the ecurity of your elf and Children.

When I had heard this news, I retired very ad, and agitated in my fancy many ways and means of aety, till accidently meeting the Merchant, and he moving me in his old Suit, I took hold of the occaion, and concealing what I pleaed of the Advertiements given me by Tyrrhenus. I only told him, I had notice given
me by a Friend, how a certain Great Man of the Country, had a deign to teal away my Daughter; and, aid I, you are not trong enough to oppoe your elf, or make reitance, it would better pleae me to betow her on you, both for the knowledge I have of your peron and wealth; but pecially for the promie you have made me, when you have Marryed her to live with me in my Country; therefore if your Love anwer the profeion you have made; let us weigh Anchors preently, before we be prevented or contrained to uffer the effects of ome violence: he was extreamly taken with my words: It is well advied Father, aid he, and then falling upon my Neck, kied my Head, and demanded when my pleaure was, that we hould Sail, for although the time was not yet eaonable, yet we might ecape the Plots that were laid againt us, by removing to another Port, and there attend the aurance of the Spring. I deire, aid I, if my command have any power with you, to depart hence about the beginning of the Night; after he had anwered if hould be done. He left me, and I returned to our Lodging, where I aid nothing to Tyrrhenus, but advertized my Children, that in the Evening we were to go aboard again: the uddennes of the news amazed them, and demanding the reaon of me, I put them off, promiing to tell them at another time, but for the preent it was neceary it hould o be done.
So after we had made a light Supper, and were retired to take a little ret, an Old Man appeared to me in my Sleep, his Body as dry as an Anatomy, aving that under his Robe he hewed the proportion of a Thigh, witnesing the able forces of his Limbs, when he was in the Flower of his Youth, his Head was covered with a Helmet, he wore his Beaver up, and upon his Forehead appeared the marks of a Cautelous and Prudent Man, and he drew one Thigh after him, as if he had received ome hurt when he came near me; with a kind of a threatning Smile, he aid, O Sir, you make no accompt of us, for of all thoe that ever pat along the Iland of the Cephalenians, you only didain to viit our Houes, or take notice of our Glory, which all other Men have done; but you are in that height of pride, as you corn to peak to us in your paage, though I have thus long been your Neighbour; therefore know you hall not pas many days without being punihed, and you hall uffer the like Calamities as I have done, falling into the Hands of your Enemies by Sea and Land; but falute the Maid, that is with you in my Wife's name, tell her he kies her Hands becaue he loves and preferrs the Honour of her Chatity before all things, in repect whereof he ends her word, a happy Fortune hall end the coure of all her Mieries.

I tarted, trembling at the viion, and The-agenes
asking me what the matter was? I fear, aid I, we have taid two long, and neglected to imbarque our elves; and this was it that o troubled my thoughts; but rie you and get your things together, and go and call Chariclea. The Maid was ready when he was called. Tyrrhenus himelf hearing us, roe out of his Bed, and demanded what we meant to do? I told him what was done for the preent, was by his advice; we do endeavour to avoid the practices that are contrived againt us; and I pray the Gods for the good and charitable Offices we have received in your Houe, to have you always in their protection. This lat favour let me intreat you to do for us, that you will pas over into the Iland of Ithaca, and make a Sacrifice for us to lyes, to pray him, that he will mitigate his wrath towards us for our didain, and contempt of him, as he imagines, for o he taxed me in my Sleep this Night. Tyrrhenus promied to perform it, and o brought us down to the Water ide weeping abundantly, and praying the Gods to end us a good Voyage and favourable Winds, to wat us to the place where we did wih to be. Why hould I trouble you with many words?

By the time the Morning Star appear'd we were lanched into the Main; the Saylors being at firt exceedingly againt it; but in the end they were perwaded by the Tyrian Merchant, telling them, he fled from a Pirate that lay in
wait for them, and he pake truly, and knew not, for his meaning was to make a lye.

But the Wind was o full againt us, the Tempet waxed o great, and the Waves welled in that horrid ort, as that it was a thouand to one our Ship had perihed; but in the end, we came by the Lee of a certain Promontory in the Ile of Candy, having firt lot the half of our Rudder, and a great part of our Sail-yards being broke and blown over-board; therefore we thought it bet to tay ome days in that Iland to new rigg our Ship, and recreate our elves: this done we were all commanded to reimbarque upon the Firt Day of the New Moon, after her Conjunction with the Sun.

Being Lanched forth upon the Main again; the Wet Winds of the Spring now weetly breathing, the Patron Night and Day directed his Coure to the Coat of Africa: for, he aid, We might cros the Sea directly, by a Line, if the Wind changed not. But that which mot moved him to peed his Voyage, was to gain ome Road or Port; becaue afar off he decryed a Pirate's Galley, that came full in his Poop; for, aid he, From the time we looed from the Promontory of Candy, he hath always followed our Track and contantly ailed, as if he were bound for the ame place; and I have often oberved he made the ame turns with us; having many times (the better to dicover him) exprely declined my Veel from her coure: Some
were moved at thee words, encouraging their fellows to prepare for their defence; and ome there were neglected them, aying, It was ordinary for the leer Bottoms to follow the coure of a great Ship, as believing it to be guided by a more Experimented Pilot: the Day paed on in this dipute; and it was about the hour the Labourer returns weary with his Travel, having newly looed his Oxen; and now the overtoiled Wind began to languih, and diminihing by little and little, in the end it had no force at all, o as the breath it pent upon our Sails, erved only to hufle them together, not at all to blow us on: briefly it etled into a Calm as if it had et with the Sun, or to peak more properly, as if it would accommodate it elf to their deign that chaed us, becaue our Sails being more large than theirs, and by conequence requiring the more Wind. But as oon as this tranquillity of the Heavens had moothed the Seas, the Galley was come up to us ooner than I can peak it; for (as I believe) all that were within her put their Hands to the Oars; their Veel alo being light and nimble of it elf; when they were very near us, a Zacynthian Paenger in our Ship cryed to us, Friends we are all undone, this is a Pirate, I know the Galley of Trachinus.

At the report of this News, a udden fear eized our whole Ship, and in a Calm we had a Tempet, riing in tumult, Crys, Tears, and
running up and down, ome running under the Hatches, ome tanding upon the Decks, animating the ret to endure the Fight, and there were ome would have got into the Long-boat and fled, till by their two long delay the Fight urprized them within the Ship, forceing them to remain, and to take in their Hands what they could find to defend themelves. Theagenes full of Courage burned with deire of the Battel, but Chariclea and I with our Imbraces hindred him from attempting any thing, he vowing Death hould not eparate him from her, but the ame Sword hould give her the like wounds, and make her an equal harer in his Misfortune. But I (after I undertood our Enemy was Trachinus) prepared ome Sleights might afterwards do us good ervice, which fell out as I expected.

For the Pirates approaching circled about our Ship, to make tryal if it were poible to take her without Blood; therefore they did attacque us, but till rowing about us, they would neither uffer us to go forward nor backward. Briefly it eemed as if they had Beieged us, and would compel us to render our elves upon compoition. O poor unfortunate Men, aid they, what Blindnes hath eized your Spirits? and why are you o deprived of Judgment, as thus to precipitate your elves into the danger of an evitable Death, by attempting to reit invincible Forces, to which yours are nothing? it is yet in your choice
to be dealt humanly withal, we permit you all that will to take your Long-boat and ave your elves. Thee were their Propoitions; but thoe of our Ship o long as they fought only in words, and aw no Blood, were daring and reolute, and aid they would tand to it to the lat Man.

But after one of the bolder Pirates had boarded us, putting all he met to the Sword, and teaching us that the Ceremonies of War were Death and Slaughter, the ret of his Company immediately leaping after him; then the Phoenicians began to repent their Courage, and falling at his Feet, beeeched him to hew mercy to them, and they were ready to obey all his Commandments: and although the Pirates were now fleht, and began to pleae themelves in Murder (for the ight of Blood doth irritate and excite the Spirit) nevertheles by the Command of Trachinus, beyond all Expectation, he pardoned the Supplicants, and made a Peace under uch conditions as were more cruel than the War it elf; for he ordained they hould depart the Ship with no more but the Cloths they had on, making it Death to him that hould do otherwie. But it eems there is nothing more precious to a Man than Life, which was the caue thee Phoenician Merchants having now lot the hope of all the Riches in the Ship, as if they had lot nothing, but rather gain'd, and made an excellent Voyage, did trive who hould firt get into
the Boat, and every one was more deirous than other to urvive the los of his Goods.

But as we alo (obeying the decree) were about to pas into the Boat, Trachinus took Chariclea by the Hand, and aid, Fair one, this War concerns not you, but Was undertaken for your ake, and ince the Day you left the Promontory of Zacynthus, I have till followed you, adventuring thus far upon the Sea, and facing danger for your Love; therefore let not any fearful apprehenion eize you, but confirm your Spirits, and know with the Empire you already are poeed of in my Soul, you hall be the Lady of all the Wealth you ee, thus he aid; but Chariclea full of dicretion, and knowing by the intructions I had given her how to apply her elf to the time mot excellently well, preently cleared her look from all the marks of Sorrow that now incompaed her, and Painting upon her Face an appearance of joy, made this reply; I render thanks to the Gods that have put it into your mind to ue us favourably, but if you will have me be confident, pleae to make me this firt demontration of your Love, ave this my Brother and my Father, and command them not from the Ship; for if I be once eparated from them the World hath nothing can perwade to retain Life. And peaking this he protrated at his Feet and imbraced them a long while. Trachinus pleaing himelf therein, and therefore deferring the grant of her demand: at length her
Tears making an impreion in his pity, having no power to refue, when uch a Beauty was a Suitor, he raied her, and thus aid; For your Brother I am very well contented to betow him upon you, for I ee he is a Young Man of a great Spirit, and conequently fit for the Life we follow; and for this Old Man, though he will be but an unerviceable charge to us, yet for your only repect I am pleaed he hall tay.

Now while thee things were aid and done, the Sun being in his Circuit come full Wet, that pace which is betwixt the Day and Night grew very Dark and Foul, and on a uddain the Sea began to be troubled; it may be the Seaon caued the preent change, or perhaps it was by the Pleaure of ome Detiny afar off, the murmur of the decending Wind; and preently a violent and horrid Tempet breaking in upon us, the Hearts of the Pirates were frozen in their fear, who having foraken their own Galley and put themelves into the Merchants Ship to Pillage her, were there urpized with a Tempet, not knowing how to govern o great a Veel, every one doing ome Office of a Mariner in that which came next to his Hands, without any knowledge at all: ome vainly upon their own genious undertaking one Art of Navigation; others another; ome confuedly truck the Sails; ome unskilfully ditributed the Cordages; One As took upon him
to order the Prow, another as wie as he to guide the Poop and govern the Helm.

But that which principally cat us into Extreamet danger, was not the violence of the Tempet (for the Waves were not yet at the height of their fury) but it was the ignorance of him that took upon him to be Pylot, who reited the Storm o long as there was any Day light, but when it grew black Night, gave over his Charge; and when they were now ready to ink, at firt ome of the Pyrates did endeavour to have recovered their own Galley, but were beat off from their deign by the Tempet: Trachinus alo taying them and making a Remontrance, that if they could ave the Ship and Riches in her, they hould have Wealth enough to purchae a Thouand uch Galleys; and peaking thoe words, he cut the Cables that held them together, telling them that whilt they kept their own Veel they drew another Tempet after them, and that in doing o he provided for their ecurity, ince whereoever they hould arrive it would draw upition upon them, and inquiry would be made after the Perons that Sailed in the Empty bottom.

This he aid appeared to them to be reaon, and they approved his Council, out of two repects, being already enible of the one; for they were no ooner evered from the Brigantine, but they felt the Sea did not tos them o much as before, yet were they not quite out of the
danger, but one Billow tumbling upon another toed them o violently; as it contrained them to cat much of their Lading over-board: breifly there was no kind of danger that did not preent it elf, till having will much difficulty ecaped that Night, the next Day, about the etting of the Sun, the Tempet cat us into a Road near the Mouth of one of the Arms of Nilus, named the Heracleotique, accidently, and now againt our wills arriving in Aegypt the Pirates were joyful, but we were exceedingly afflicted, reproaching the Sea as cruel in the favour it had done us to ave our Lives, envying us a Death free from all injury, and delivering us to the Land in a more fearful Expectation than at Sea, being expoed to the diordered pleaure of barbarous and wicked Pirates, which preently appeared.

As they Landed they carryed from the Ship great Veels of Tyrian Wine, and divers other things, aying they would Sacrifice to Neptune, and render Thanks for their deliverance; ome were alo ent to the Neighbour Towns, and a great deal of Money given them to buy Beats, with command they hould give what Price oever was demanded; and it was not long before we aw them return, driving before them a Flock of Sheep and a Herd of Swine; and having brought them in, they kindled the Pile, and prepared us a Feat of the Roafted Victims. Then Trachinus taking me
aide, where none could over-hear him; Father, aid he, I intend to take your Daughter to Wife, and this Night, as you ee, Imean to celebrate our Nuptials, joyning that weetet Solemnity of Men with the Sacrifice to the Gods; therefore leat you hould take it ill, if I made you not acquainted therewith, and be ad at my Wedding Feat; and to the end your Daughter being dipoed of with your conent, may receive the Bleing of our Marriage with more joy, I thought it bet to let you know my pleaure, not that it is needful it hould be confirmed by your uffrage, for it is in my power when I will to accomplih my deires, but I hold it more noble and a better Omen, if the Bride be prepared for the Marriage by her Father, becaue it will more content her, and he will addres her elf to the Ceremony with more joy.

I approved his words, and feigned my elf to be overjoyed, rendring great thanks to the Gods that had done me the Divine favour to make my Daughters Mater willing to take her for his Wife; then retiring my elf a little to tudy what was to be done, I intantly returned, beeeching him what was thus happily begun might be accomplihed a little more honourably, appointing the Ship to the Maid for her Marriage Chamber, and forbidding his Men to enter or any way to diturb her, that o he might have leiure to apparel her elf like a Bride, with as much Ornament and care as the time would permit,
for it would be aid, It is a poor and mibecoming thing, that a Maid decended of a Rich and Noble Family, and which is more that mut be the Wife of Trachinus, hould not at leat, upon the Day of the Solemization of her Nuptials, be dret in the Richet Robes and Jewels he then had, ince Fortune and the place had deprived us of a more glorious Habit.

At thee words Trachinus was tranported with joy, and promied he would do it willingly, and immediately commanded that all things whereof they had need, being exported out of the Ship, no peron hould dare to approach it any more: They obeying the charge he gave them carryed to Land Tables, Cups, Tapetries, Carpets, Works of Tyre and Sydon, and many other Moveables and Utenils, that might be erviceable at a Feat. Finally every one took without meaure and loaded their Shoulders without order with thoe Riches, which much labour and many frugal Hands had gathered; and which Fortune had expoed to the profuion of thee Pyrates, to make a diolute Banquet full of prodigious abues.

But I taking Theagenes with me, when we came to Chariclea we found her Weeping; O Daughter, Miery is now your acquaintance, not a Stranger to you, and will you yet take on, or is it not for thee old diaters that you weep but for ome new? For altogether he replyed, but above all for the odious good will Trachinus
bears me, from which I hourly expect ome violent effects, to which the time will now tempt him; for unexpected properities ue to make Men bold to commit acts of inolence; but I am reolved to punih Trachinus and his loathed affection, preventing the effects of his deire by Death, and that which for the preent melted me into Tears, was the thought of my being o unhappy, as before I die, to be eparated from Theagenes and you: you have (aid I) divined aright, for Trachinus will convert the Feat after the Sacrifice into his and your Nuptial Feats; he dicovered this intention to me as to your Father, though I knew his furious diire to injoy you long ago, by what Tyrrhenus had told me at our conference in the Iland of Zacynthus, but I would not let you know it, fearing to afflict you before the time, and that the grief would fall upon your hearts, while the calamity hanged over your Heads, epecially conidering it was poible to avoid his deign. But ince it is o, my dear Children, that fortune hath appeared againt us, and cat us into the ame danger we endeavoured to hun, let us make a generous and brave attempt, and preent our Lives to the Swords point, to the end that if if ucceed well, we may urvive with Liberty and Glory; or if ill, at leat we may have the contentment to die nobly, you chatily. After they had promied me to execute whatoever I hould command,
and that I had intructed them as I thought bet, I left them to prepare themelves.

And addreing my e;f to him, that amongt the Pirates was the econd in Authority after Trachinus, as I remember he was called Pelorus, I told him I had a Secret to impart to him would be for his profit; and he willingly followed me: when I had brought him out of the hearing of his Fellows, Give Ear my Child (aid I) to that I hall declare to you in few words, for the time is too narrow for a Long dicoure, my Daughter loves you, your merits and perfections have conquered her, but he upects your Captain prepares his Feat for her Nuptials, for ome uch thing he ignify'd to be curious in putting on her Richet Ornaments; therefore bethink your elf, if you can find a means to prevent him and poes your elf, for he ays, he had rather die than Marry with Trachinus: be confident (aid he) and do not put your elf into any farther fear, for I have long burned in an equal flame with your Daughter, and did but only wait for an occaion to have a paage open to obtain her; therefore aure your elf, Trachinus hall either voluntarily yield his Bride to me, or this Arm hall make him feel a bitter Wedding Night.

Having heard this I hated from him, leat if we were both miing we hould be upected; and coming to my Children, I confirmed their
brave Spirits with the good News, that our Plot went well in a right Path.

A while after we at down to Supper, and when I aw them high flown in Wine, and knew their heated brains were apt to petulancy, I wipered Pelorus in the Ear, (for I at next him for that purpoe) Have you not een (aid I) how my Daughter is Apparelled? he replyed he had not: but you may now ee her conveniently (I told him) if you will go privately to the Ship, and take heed no Eye dicover you, for you know Trachinus had forbid it: There you hall ee Diana her elf, but be modet in beholding her, leat the Goddes trike you dead. I had carce poken thee words but without any delay he roe from the Table, as if he had been preed with ome udden buines, and ran ecretly to the Ship.

There he beheld Chariclea wearing upon her Herd a Crown of Lawrel, Apparelled in a refulgent Robe of Cloth of Gold (for he had put on the Sacred Habit that he brought from Delphos, that it might either erve to adorn her Victory or Funeral,) and eeing the Cabbin where he was, accommodated to the form of a Nuptial Chamber, the ight (as it was likely) et him all on fire, Love and Jealouy augmenting his amorous torment o, that when he returned to us, one might read in his Eyes the rage imprinted in his Soul, and it was evident his thoughts laboured with ome
furious deign, and he was carcely et down again at the Table, but Choler parking in his Eyes, he aid, Why have not I the reward of my merit for being the firt that boarded the Ship? becaue (aid Trachnus) you have not demanded it, and that yet we have not divided the poils. I deire then, replyed Pelorus the Captive Maid: and when Trachinus added, That, excepting her, he hould take what he would. What (aid Pelorus) will you break the Law of Piracy, that gives his choice of the prey to him that firt boards a Ship, and for all his Fellows runs the hazard of his Life? Friend (aid Trachinus) I violate not that Law, but I ground my elf upon the Authority of one more powerful, that commands us to obey the wills of our Captains without contradiction, the Maid has wounded me to the Heart with her bright Eyes, and to heal my wound I am forced to marry her; and, Sir, I hope it is a reaon I hould be preferred before you, and if you will not obey this Law, I will make you preently repent it with a blow of this Cup I hold in my Hand: Then Pelorus looking upon his Companions, You ee, aid he, what recompence our Labours are to expect; thus you hall one day ee your merits frutrated of the reward of your virtue, and be, as I am, Slaves to this tyrannical Law.

Now, Nauicles, what do you imagine became
of thee Pirates? after Nauicles had poke thee words you would have compared them to a calm ea well'd with the udden Tempet, uch a Blind and Brutih motion in an intant put them into o wild a tumult, inflamed with Wrath and Wine, as if ome fury had poet them; ome rank'd themelves upon the part of Trachinus, and cryed the Captain ought to be obeyed; others ided with Pelorus, aying, the Law of Piracy ought to tand. In the end Trachinus lifted his Hand to trike Pelorus with the Cup he held; but Pelorus that was prepared before, broke the effect of his fury and truck a Ponyard to his Heart, o as he fell down mortally wounded, but a cruel War kindled and continued amongt the ret, inter-murdering one another without giving any quarter; ome as revenging the Death of their Captain; others as defending Pelorus in his jut quarrel. The crys of Men, and ounds of Levers, Stones, Cups, Tables, the Wounders and the Wounded made one fearful groan; but I retiring a great way off, tood upon the rie of a Hill, and thence beheld this furious pectacle; yet neither Theagenes nor Chariclea were exempted from the danger, but following what was determined, he with his Sword in his Hand joyn'd himelf to one of the Factions at the beginning, and fought as if ome fury had tranported him, and he after he aw the Fight begun hot from the Ship, looing her Arrows with a contant
Hand, and paring no Man but Theagenes, he never took her Aim amis, every hot he made was Death. Neither did he only gall the one ide of the Battel, but both indifferently, none of the Pirates eeing her, yet he clearly beholding them by the light of the great Fire of the Pile yet burning, o as they could not imagine whence their Death came; but thought it to be ome Plague from Heaven. To conclude, the War conumed them all, and only Theagenes remained fighting ingle with Pelorus, an able and reolute Man, and one that had been fleh'd and bred up in Murders.

And now Chariclea's Shooting could no longer avail her Theagenes, grieving he could not ait him, but the fear he had to mis her Aim did hold her Hand; inamuch as they fought o cloe, the Eye could hardly ditinguih them. In the end Pelorus was forced to give ground before him, for when Chariclea aw her Arrows could do him no more ervice, he ent her words to his Succour, crying to him; Now my bet Friend hew your Courage. At the hearing of thee words his trength redoubled, to which Pelorus was not able to make reitance longer, s if the voice of his Mitres had infued new vigour into him, letting him know the reward of his Victory was yet living. For now reuming the heat of his firt Spirit, tho broken and weigh'd down with many Wounds, he made a blow at Pelorus with his Sword full at
his Head, which he hoped to cleave a under, as auredly he had done, if the Pirate had not declined his Neck; yet he ecaped not, for the Sword decending, took away the top of his Shoulder, and falling right upon the Elbow joynt of his Sword-hand, cut it quite off; then Pelorus fled to ave his Life, Theagenes following him.

What the equel was I cannot tell you, but that I aw not when Theagenes returned; for remaining upon the rie of the Hill, I dared not to tirr in a place full of Enemies by Night, when my Friends could not know me; but Chariclea was more bold, and if eems more quick ighted for with the firt dawning of the light, I perceived Theagenes lying tretched out upon the Earth like a Dead Man, and aw her itting and Weeping over him, with evident demontrations that he intended to kill herelf, but that ome little hope of his revival retrained her as yet, and held her Life in equal upence with his. But I, unfortunate Man, had not o much as time to peak to them to weeten their Calamities with my words, or to apply remedy to his wounds, o fat did the evils at Land (without a breathings pace) ucceed to thoe at Sea.

For, at the firt Spring of the Morning, as I was decending from the Hill where I had pitched for that Night, I aw a Troop of Aegyptian Theives, running from the top of the Mountain, that lyeth along that Coat, who preently
eized upon my poor Children, taking them away and all the Riches they could carry out of the Ship. I pake afar off to them, and in vain bad them farewel that could not hear me, deploring their Fortunes and my own; but neither being able to defend them, or holding it good to go and mix with them, I reerved my elf to hope to uccour them ome other way. And indeed it was not in my power to do them preent ervice, being left far behind, my Age like a heavy burden not uffering me to march o quick a pace as thoe Aegyptians, that mounted and decended by trange Paths, and through Wild places. Now by the Mercy of the Gods, and your favour, worthy Nauicles, I have found my Daughter then lot, having contributed nothing to her recovery but my abundant Sighs, Tears, and Lamentations.

Speaking thee words he wept, all the Company were forced to do the like, changing their Feat into a Sorrow, intermixed with joy, (for Wine intenerates the Eyes and makes them apt to Tears) and they were not able to contain their flux of pity, till Nauicles pake thus to confort Calairis. Father (aid he) chae away thee ad conceptions and fill your Heart with Joy, ince you have now recovered your Daughter, and that only one Night remains to interpoe it elf betwixt you, and the contentment you hall receive in beholding your Son, for to Morrow Morning we will Ride to Mitranes,
and deal with him all poible ways, for the redeeming of your beloved Theagenes. O may the Gods be o favourable, replied Calairis: but now it is time to diolve the Feat, let us therefore give thanks to the Gods, and drink at parting; o Wine being brought, taking their leaves they drank to one another, and o did rie from the Table. But Calairis looking about for Chariclea and not finding her in the multitude, was greatly perplexed, till at length a certain Woman advertized him, that he aw her enter the Sanctuary of the Temple. He preently ran thither and found her protrated at the Feet of an Image, where by reaon of the length of her Prayers, and the weight of Sorrow that lay upon her Heart, he was faln into a Swoon. Then after he had hed ome Tears, and humbly conjured the Gods to change the rigour of her detiny into better Fortune, he oftly awaked Chariclea and returned to his Lodgings with her. Being now in the Houe he retired to the Chamber of Nauicles's Daughter, lying with her, but not taking any ret, care not permitting her to cloe her Eyes.

div.head: THE AETHIOPIAN HISTORY.
The Sixth Book.
div.p:
CAlairis and Knemon being retired to leep in the Lodgings appointed for the men, as oon as the ret of the night was pent, which paed more low than they deired, but more quick than they expected, becaue the greater part thereof was taken up with the Feat and length of the dicoure, that entertained them with unatisfying weetnes, not having patience to expect till it were clear day, they went to Nauicles, praying him to let them know where Theagenes was, and with all peed to lead them thither: Nauicles to give them content, preently made him ready
to go along with them; but Chariclea, though he made all the prayers love and impatience could invent, was yet forced to remain, Nauicles auring her they would not go ar, and promiing her within few days to return with her Theagenes; o they let her floating betwixt orrow for their departure, and joy for the good he expected.

At their going out of Chemmis, as they pat along the banks of Nilus, they perceived a Crocodile labouring to wim from the one hore to the other, but the wit current and wild waves till broke his force, and often duckt him to the bottom of the River. This moved none of their company, as being a common ight with them, aving that Calairis aid, it preaged they hould enounter ome hindrance in the way; but Knemon was running back again, extremely frighted, though he had not een the Beat entirely, but only her hadow, and not all that, the greater part of her being till under the water: This et Nauicles a laughing, and Calairis cryed to him, Why Knemon, I thought only the fears of the night had troubled you, and then only when you had heard ome trange noie, envelopped in the horrour of darknes, but I ee you have the ame valour by daylight; and that not only the hearing of a name breeds terrour in you, but ordinary pectacles, obvious and ighted by every man, do terrify you. What God or Demi-god was that (aid
Nauicles) whoe name was uch a bug-bear to his ears?

Alas (replied Calairis) if it had been a God or any Divinity, I hould have had nothing to ay to him, but he trembled all over, hearing the name (not of any man, the glory of whoe valour is blown about the World, but) of a woman, and he was dead too. For the ame night you came from the Iland of the Herdmen, bringing chariclea afe for me, I know not how or where he had heard a name you ued, but it o truck him as he would let me take no ret, and was often almot quite dead for fear, and ure had dyed if I had not taken a great deal of pains to recover and bring him to life again; and but that I doubt his relape, I would tell you the name to make you a little more port; immediately he aid the name was Thisbe.

But Nauicles was now pat laughing, and grew very ad, tanding a long while peniving, and earching in his Spirit for what occaion, or from what knowledge of Thisbe, Knemon hould be o tranported, when he heard her named; then Knemon fell in a laughter for very joy to ee him melancholick: O good Callairis, you now ee (aid Knemon) how great the force of this name is, and that, like a phantam, it hath not only frighted me, but even Nauicles himelf, cauing a trange alteration in our humours; for I now laugh, knowing her for certain to be dead; and Nauicles that was o
valiant, and made himelf o merry with our fear, is now truck into amazement. Enough, aid, Nauicles, you are ufficiently revenged upon me; but I conjure you, Knemon, by the Gods of hopitality and friendhip, by our free converation, and the courteous entertainment thhat I think you think you have received at my houe, to tell me how you came to know that Thisbe, and why her name was o terrible to you, or whether you have made this betwixt you to play upon me?

Now Knemon (aid Calairis) it concerns you to anwer, and to acquit your elf of your promie to me, that I hould have the relation of your fortunes, which ever yet you have avoided with many light excues; you cannot find a more convenient time, for you hall both do a pleaure to Nauicles, and by your dicoure horten and weeten the travail of our joyrney.

Knemon conented at their requet, and to atisfie them, compendiouly ran over all he had recounted formerly to Theagenes and Chariclea: How he was born in the City of Athens, that his Fathers name was Aritippus, that he had a tep-mother named Demaeneta; then he related the detetable love wherein Demaeneta languihed for him, and that failing of her hope, to content her looe deires, he laid trains for him, uborning Thisbe for her intrument. He added the manner, and how he was exil'd from his Country, the people of Athens o condemning
him, as believing him to be covinced of an intent to commit Parricide. That living in the Ile of Aegina, an old companion of his, one Charias, firt brought him news of the death of his Mother-in-law, and the circumtance thereof, he being over-reached by her maid Thisbe. And ince then, a econd, named Aicles, had informed him that his Father was alo banihed, and all his goods conficated, by reaon the Friends and Allies of Demaeneta bandying againt him, to make ure his condemnation, had begot a belief in the peoples eaie mind, that he was the murderer of his Wife. He alo told them how Thisbe was fled from Athens with a certain Merchant of Naucratia, that was in love with her; and that he himelf imbarqued with Anticles for Aegypt, in hope to meet that Thisbe, his deign being, if he hould find her, to carry her back to Athens, that he might dicharge his Father of the calmuny they had falely impoed upon him, and deliver her to be jutly punihed: And that ince that time to this preent, he had run through many dangerous fortunes, any tryed many different calamities, falling in his Voyage into the hands of Pyrates, whence he found means to ecape, and arrive in Aegypt, where he was taken by the Herdmen, and there came acquainted with Theagenes and Chareclea, with whom he had joyned in the types of an inviolable friendhip: Inerting the death of Thisbe, and all that had ince happened, to the
paages that were known to Nauicles and Calairis.

Nauicles having heard this, found his mind aailed with millions of contrary thoughts; ometimes he was minded to declare to them all that had paed betwixt him and Thisbe; ometimes he held it the better way to defer it yet a while; in the end, half againt his will, he contained himelf, partly his own reaon judging it to be convenient, partly being accidentally hindred: For when they had gone about three miles, and began to approach the Town where Mitranes made his uual reidence, they perceived coming towards them a man of Nauicles's acquaintance, who demanding whither he was going in uch hate? Do you ask me (replyed the man) whither I go o fat? as if you knew not to what mark my aim is till directed, my deires and tudy only tending to the peedy execution of the commands of the fair Iias, the glory of your Chemmis. It is for her plant I cultivate my grounds, for her ake I gather all the weath and rareties I can. It is for her that I watch days and nights without ever cloing my eyes, not failing to erve her in any thing, how little or great oever, though I have no other recompence but her dipleaure, and my own labour for my pains. At this preent I am hating to her (as you ee) with this Phaenicopterus, a certain Bird of the River Nilus, which he enjoyned me to bring to her.
To what a gracious Mitres (aid Nauicles) have you dedicated your affections, whoe commands are o eaie, as he asketh only the Phanicopterus, and not the Phoenix her elf, that is brought us from the Indies and Aethiopia. Indeed (Replyed he) it is her cutom thus to make her patime of my ervices. But now let me quetion you, I pray, whither, or upon what occaion are you travelling? But after they had told him they were going to waint upon Mitrues: Is it o (aid the tranger) then your journey is to no purpoe, for Mitranes is out of the Town, gone this lat night with a great Army againt the Herdimen that inhabit the Town of Bea, becaue thoe Beians, and one Thyamis, they have elected for their Captain, by urprize have taken a young Prioner, a gretian, whom Mitranes was to have ent to Orrondates.

This is the occaion of Mitranes his abence from home, but for my part I mut make hat to Iias, who already is looking harply about for me, thinking my imallet delay a Sin againt Love. Oh She is too ubtle in accuing me without Caue, and inventing Crimes to lay to my Charge! He had no ooner given them this Relation, but they tood ilent and tupifi'd, to find themelves o unexpectedly diappointed. Nauicles at length brought them again to themelves, admonihing them that they hould not be o dicourag'd with one diappointment
(which was but for a hort time) as to cat away all Hope and Care of what they had in hand: That is was now their bet way to return back again to Chemmis, as well to take council about their affairs, as alo (having furnihed themelves with freh proviions for a longer Journey) to reume their earch of Theagenes, whereoever they hould hear that he was detain'd, whether amongt the Thieves or elewhere; every where propoing to themelves good hopes of finding him.

For even this did not eem to happen without the providence of the Gods, that they hould o unexpectedly meet with an acquaintance, by whoe dicoure they were in a manner led by the hand to the place where it was mot proper to eek for him: wherefore they hould go directly to the Thieves Village. When he had thus poken, he eaily perwaded them, partly, as I uppoe, becaue another hope aroe from what he had aid, and partly becaue Knemon bid Calairis be of good cheer, for that Thyamis would preerve Theagnes. They therefore reolved to return, where they found Chariclea in the Porch, looking out to all quarters of the Country. When he did not perceive Theagenes with them, with great lamentation he cryed out, O Father, are you come back no more in number than you went forth? without doubt then my Theagenes is dead. I charge you by the Gods to deliver what you have to ay.
It is humanity to make hort the tory of misfortune, by whhich the mind is better fortifi'd againt the evil. Knemon therefore intercepting her orrow, aid, What means this practice Chariclea? You are always conjecturing the wort, and often without truth. Theagenes is, and by the Gods Providence hall be well, then briefly told her with whom he was, and in what manner. It is plain, O Knemon (aid Calairis) from what you have poken, that you never were in Love; otherwie you would know that Lovers fear where there is no danger, and give trut to nothing beide their own eyes, concerning the peron that is mot dear to them. Abence fills their minds with doubt, epecially having reolved never to be from each other, unles ome ad accident eparates them. Wherefore we mut excue Chariclea, who labours under the violence of Love. Let us however conult what is to be done in this affair. Having thus poken, taking Chariclea by the hand, with a fatherly obervance, he led her into the Houe. But Nauicles, being deirous to divert their care, ordered a more umptuous Banquet than uual, obliging them with the preence of his Daughter, mot plendidly apparelled. When they were refreh'd with the entertainment, he thus pake to them; The Gods are witnees (my dear Guets) that your company is mot delightful to me, and if you would pend your lives with me, you hould
command all that I am mater of as freely as my elf: Foramuch as I have not received you as Guets, but intimate Friends, and uch as will always have the ame eteem for me, I can think no obligation too much. I am likewie no les ready to engage my Friends and Acquaintance in any thing may do you ervice. Yet you mut be enible that my way of Life is Merchandie; this is the Field which I am obliged to cultivate. Since therefore the Weterly winds now blow favourably to make the Seas Navigable, and call forth the Merchant, my affairs, amongt others, ummon me to Greece. You will therefore do well to acquaint me with your deign, that I may order my affairs o as to make them erviceable to you.

When he had thus aid, Calairis, after a little Paue, thus reply'd. Succes (O Nauicles) attend your Voyage, may Mercury end you Gain, and Neptune calm Seas; my every Port afford you Harbour, and every City prove your Home! Since you have treated us here with o much courteie, and now diimis us at our deire, in all things fulfilling the Laws of Friendhip and Hopitality. As for us, though it be a great trouble and grief to depart from you and your Houe, which we have ued as our own; yet it is neceary for us to purue the earch of our dearet Friends. This is both mine and Chariclea's reolution: But for Knemon, whether he intends to wander farther with us and continue his
aitance, or what other purpoe he has, let himelf declare. Knemon was deirous to reply omething to this, and long attempting to peak, but ighs choak'd his peech, and tears drown'd his eyes: At lat collecting breath, and uttering a deep groan; O Fortune (he cry'd) how full of change and untable art thou! of which among many others I am a ad example. Thou hat deprived me of my Kindred and Fathers Houe, and ent me an Exile from the Country and City, that are mot dear to me: Thou hat driven me as far as Aegypt (not to mention my Diaters in the way) and put me in the power of Thieves and Out-laws: At lat I had a glimmering of hope, by falling into acquaintance and company with perons, who (though as wretched as my elf) yet they were Greeks of my own Country, with whom I thought to have paed the remainder of my Life: But even this Comfort is taken from me; Whither hall I turn my elf, or what hall I do? Shall I leave Chariclea, before he has found her Theagenes? This would be inhumane? Or hall I go with her to eek him: If we were certain at lat to find him, it were labour well undertaken, but if the event be doubtful and greater misfortunes befal, Where will our Travels end? What if now I beg leave both of the Guardian Deities, and of you, to peak at lat of returning to my Family and native Soil, epecially ince o fair an opportunity by the providence of the Gods offers
its elf, (Nauicles intending, as you heard himelf ay, to Sail for Greece) let by the Death of my Father, in my abence, our Houe be left deolate, and Family without and Heir: For howoever mean and poor I may be likely to live there; yet honety and common decency require the preerving our race. But, O Chariclea, (for to you I would chiefly be excus'd) do you give me pardon and grant me this leave: I will attend you as far as Bea, and entreat Nauicles to tay a while for me, o that if I deliver you not into the hands of Theagenes, yet at leat you hall acknowledge me faithful to the trut he committed to me: and from the good Concience in what has paed, depend at parting on Succes in what is to come. If after all (which the Gods forbid) we fail of that ucces, yet even o I hall eem to merit pardon, not even then leaving you alone, but in the Guardianhip of this good Calairis, your Guide and Father.

Chariclea conjecturing by many arguments, the Inclination of Knemon for the Daughter of Nauicles (o quick-ighted is a Lover to dicover the ame paion in any other) and alo by what had been poken, that Nauicles had endeavour'd the alliance, and given Knemon many ecret encouragements; upon the whole concluded that he was no fit Companion, but mut be upicious for the future; he made this reply:

Do what eems good to you (aid he) I thank you for the good offices you have already performed, and for the future there is no neceity for you to be burden'd with our affairs, or run the rique of other peoples fortune. Return to your own Country and dometick concerns; and by no means neglect your friend Nauicles, nor the opportunity which he offers. Calairis and my elf will engage all dangers that hall befal us till we have finihed our coure; and though no mortal hall ait us, we rely on the protection of the Gods. May all things (aid Nauicles) ucceed to your deire; may the Gods accompany you till you recover your Friends, which will be a jut reward of your Prudence and Contancy. But, Knemon, be not you concerned that you bring not Thisbe back to Athens, ince you have me, who was the Author of her departure: For I was that Merchant Naucratites, her Lover, who carry'd her away. But if you are as well pleas'd with the propoal as I, you hall under my conduct gain great wealth, and recover your Country. And if you are dipoed to marry, I will give you my Daughter Nauiclea with a great Dower, ince I know your Family. Knemon made no paue, finding what he had ecretly deired o fairly offer'd to him: Whereupon Nauicles deliver'd his Daughter to him, commanding his Servants to celebrate the Nuptials; himelf began the Dance, uddenly converting the Feat into a Wedding.
The ret of the Family in other Apartments olemniz'd the Marriage with Songs and Dancing, o that the Houe hone all night with Nuptial Torches. But Chariclea, eparating from the ret, went into her own Apartment, and making fat the door, to prevent diturbance, as if eiz'd with Bacchanal fury, tore both her hair and garments: Let us (aid he) perform our Ceremonies as the poture of our affairs require, with the outmot pomp of Sorrow. Let us weep intead of Singing, and beat our Breat intead of Dancing. Let us out with this troubleom Taper, while Night echoes to my complaints, and preides over the Ceremony. What Apartment has it prepar'd for me? What Bridechamber has it adorn'd? The God that has charge of me, is all my company; depriv'd of him who in name only is my Husband. Knemon leads up his Nuptial Dance, Theagenes is yet wandering, and perhaps a Prioner in Chains; nor am I certain that it is o well with him, or that he is at all. Nauiclea my Bed-fellow, is removed from me into the embraces of her Husband, Chariclea is left alone: I envy not her fortune, Gods, wihing her all happines; but complain of your dealing o hardly with me. You have drawn out my Tragedy beyond all bounds. But why do I charge the Gods with unkindnes? let the remainder of pleaure be perform'd. Yet, O Theagenes, my dearet care, if thou art dead, which I hope
never to live to hear, I hall make no delay to be with you. For the preent I perform thee Rites (wherewith he pluck'd off her hair and laid it on the Bed) and pour thee Libations from my Eyes, which are dear to thee (wherewith he bedewed the Coverlet with her Tears.) But if thou art alive and afe, O haten to my Arms, and at leat viit me in Dreams! Having thus poken, he cat her elf with her face to the Bed with vehement ighing, till tupify'd with her grief, he fell into a leep that continued till broad day. Calairis therefore wondring that he did not appear according to her cutom, enquired for her, and went directly to her Chamber-door, where knocking aloud, and calling her by her name, he awaken'd her. She, diturb'd with the udden noie, in that diorder of dres in which he lay down, open'd the door to let him in. He eeing her hair dihevell'd and garments torn, undertood the caue; wherefore having firt eated her on a Chair, and compoed her dres; O Chariclea (aid he) why do you thus torment your elf? Why do you abandon your reaon, and give way to misfortune? I my elf carce know you in this diorder, who were wont to have o much temper and reolution. Why do you detroy your elf before the day of your fortune approaches? Take pity on me, and pare your elf, if not for my ake, yet at leat for Theagenes, whoe Life is bound up in yours, and dear to him for
no other reaon. Chariclea bluh'd at what he aid, epecially when he recollected the manner in which he urpriz'd her. Therefore after a long ilence, Calairis deiring her to peak; You have good reaon, Father, (aid he) to chide me, yet I hope I deerve pardon. It is no new paion or concern that put me into this diorder: the abence of Theagenes caues this diturbance, and my grief is till the greater, becaue I cannot know certainly whether he be alive or dead. Be of good cheer as to that (aid Calairis) you have the Gods word for his being alive, and living with you hereafter: if you believe not their Oracles, at leat give credit to the peron who told us yeterday that Thyamis had carry'd him Prioner to Memphis: But if he is taken by him, he is mot certainly preerv'd alive, by reaon of the former acquaintance between them. Wherefore let us go without delay to Bea; you to find your Theagenes, and I both him and my Son; for you have heard that Thyamis is my Son. Thyamis (replyed Chariclea) is your Son, and only yours; and now our Affairs are running into extremet danger.

Calairis wondring at what he aid, and demanding the reaon; You know (proceeded he) that I was taken by the Herdmen, Thyamis, their Captain, was charm'd with this unfortunate Beauty with which I am endow'd; o that there is danger in our enquiry with him, let he hould know me to be the ame peron
that beguil'd him of his intended Nuptials, and compel me to performance. The Gods forbid, reply'd Calairis, that the preence of a Father hould not controul o unlawful a deire: Yet what hinders us from thinking of ome contrivance to ecure you from that which you fear? for I know you to be of great art and ubtilty in evading unwelcome addrees. Chariclea was a little exhilarated; And whether (aid he) you peak this jocoely or eriouly I will not examine; however I hall purue that contrivance which I had begun with Theagenes, which fortune directed us unto, and I hope will now proper. It being neceary for our flight from the Iland of Thieves, we reolved to change our Habit, and to pas through the Towns in poor and beggarly attire: wherefore, if you think fit, we will reume that diguie, and peronate Beggars: By which means we hall be les liable to injuries; for Poverty is more likely to meet with Pity than Envy, and we hall with more eae obtain our daily proviion, all things being old to trangers at dear rates; whereas they are given to Beggars. Calairis commended her deign, and haten'd for the journey. Therefore calling Nauicles and Knemon to them, they acquainted them therewith; and the next day et forth, not permitting Servant nor Hore to attend them, only Nauicles and Knemon, with the Servants, aw them on their way.

Nauiclea alo accompany'd them o far, her love to Chariclea being equal to that for her Husband. Having therefore gone almot a mile, where they took leave of each other with many tears, praying for mutual ucces on their affairs, Knemon particularly begg'd Pardon, that his new obligations permitted him not to accompany them, but that he would wait an occaion to follow them. Thus parted they from each other. But Chariclea and Calairis put themelves into Beggars habit, which they had prepar'd for that purpoe. Nor did Chariclea pare her Face, which he dicolour'd, and hung a Scrip upon her Arm, as it were to carry fragments of meat, but the real ue was to conceal the holy Vetment and Chaplets which he brought from Delphi, together with the Remembrances with which her Mother had expos'd her.

Calairis carry'd her Quiver, wrapt up in Leather, the wrong end hanging down over his houlder, as ome ueles Fardle; her Bow was no ooner untrung, but it came treight again, and erv'd him intead of a taff, on which he lean'd his whole weight. But whenoever he py'd any body coming towards them, he took care to make his burden eem more heavy, halting upon one Leg, and ometimes led by Chariclea. Having thus put on a counterfeit peronage, with ome pleaant dicoure between them, and repartees about their habit, they
paed on, begging of their guardian Deity that he would be atisfy'd with what they had endur'd, and here put an end to their ufferings. Thus they went forward towards the Village of Bea, where they hoped to have found Thyamis and Theagenes, but were frutrated of their expected happines: For coming near to the Town about Sun-et, they perceiv'd a great number of dead men newly lain, ome of them were Perians, which they knew by their habits; others were Inhabitants of the place. It appeared plainly that there had been a Battel, but with whom they did not know; till they had gone about the dead Bodies, to ee if any of their acquaintance lay amongt them, (for minds that are extremely ollicitous for the welfare of what is mot dear to them are always fearing the wort) they perceiv'd and old Woman fixt over one of the dead, a native of the place, and breaking out into many Lamentations. They therefore reolv'd if they could, to get ome information from the Beldame: Therefore going up to her, they endeavoured at firt to comfort her, and awage her vehement grief. When he had admitted their conolation, they began to demand of her, What peron it was whom he bewail'd? What War had been fought? Calairis peaking to her in the Egyptian Tongue. She gave them a brief account of all; That he lamented for her Son, who lay peechles; That he came with reolution into the Field that
ome of the armed men might kill her, in the mean time that he performed jut Rites of Grief towards her Son. As for the Fight, he gave this account; That a certain young tranger, of excellent form and tature, was led Captive to Oroondates, the Prince of Memphis: Tha the was ent, as he uppoed, by Mitranes, Captain of the Guards, for an extraordinary Preent. This peron, the people of our Town, which you ee yonder, affirm'd to be one of them, whether truly or out of deign, I cannot tell. Mitranes being inform'd hereof, was enrag'd, and accordingly drew up his Army before the Town two days ago. It is a mot warlike ort of people that live by Rapine, with the greatet Contempt of Death, and have left many women childles, as they have done me. When therefore by a certain ign they were aur'd of his approach, they placed Ambucades in convenient places, by which they overcame the Enemy; part of them etting upon the Perians Van, and the ret form their ecret places, upon their Rear, Mitranes was the firt that fell, and with him almot all his followers, being urrounded, ans of ours not a few: In this number, by the everity of fate, in his Breat by a Perian Javelin. This being expir'd, I lament; and am likely oon to do the ame for my other, he being gone with the ret of our Souldiers, againt the City of Memphis.

Calairis ask'd her the caue of that expedition? She, as he was inform'd by her Son that urviv'd, told them, That the Kings forces being cut off, and Mitranes their General lain, they were aur'd what they had done would be of no mall conequence: That Oroondates, who lay at Memphis with a great Army, would immediately approach and beet their Town, and revenge the injury, by cutting off the Inhabitants: They therefore determin'd, ince they had brought themelves into o great danger, to follow one bold attempt with a greater, that being the only means to ecure themelves from the Kings fury: Thingking with their udden approach to carry Memphis, and take the King Prioner; or in his Abence, if he were with his Army gone on expedition in to Aethiopia (as it was rumour'd) they might with more eae compel the City, being detitute of Defence, to urrender: And likewie to perform a coniderable ervice for Thyamis, who was by his younger Brother depriv'd of office of High Priet, which they would retore to him. But if they hould be frutrated in their deign, that yet they would dye with their Swords in their Hands, nor ever come into the power of the Perians, to uffer Scorn or Tortures: And now give me leave to ask whither you are going? To the Town, aid Calairis. It is unafe, aid he, at preent, epecially for trangers. But if you will receive us for your Guets (aid Calairis) we hall be
ecure enough. The eaon will not permit, reply'd he, I being this night oblig'd to perform funeral Ceremonies. But if you can endure it (and I uppoe it is neceary that you hould) to pas the night in ome place, remote from the dead Bodies, at break of day I will take you for your ecurity into my cutody. All this which he poke, Calairis interpreted to Chariclea; and took her with him to a private place. When they had paed a little way from the dead, they came to a little Cave, where he laid him down with Chariclea's Bow under his Head. Chariclea at down in another corne of the Cell, the Moon then riing, and lightning all without. Calairis fell into a fat leep, being tir'd at once with Age and the long Journey. Chariclea kept awake with care, became Spectator of a mot horrid eene, though uual amongt thoe people. For the Woman uppoing her elf to be alone, and not likely to be interrupted, nor o much as to be een by any peron, fell to her work. In the firt place he digg'd a pit in the Earth, then made a fire on each ide thereof; placing the body of her Son between the two plains; then taking a Pitcher from off a three-legg'd Stool that tood by, he pour'd Honey into the Pit, Milk out of a econd, and o out of a third, as if he had been doing Sacrifice: Then taking a piece of Dough, form'd in the likenes of a Man, crown'd with Lawrel and Bdellium, he cat it into the Pit. After this,
natching a Sword that lay in the Field, with more thatn Bacchanal fury (addreing herelf to the Moon in many trange terms) he launched her Arm, and with a branch of Lawrel bedewed with her Blood, he beprinkled the fire: with many other prodigious Ceremonies. Then bowing herelf to the Body of her Sons, whipering in his Ear, he awaked him, and by the force of her charms, made him to tand upright. Charilea, who had hitherto look'd on with ufficient fear, was now atoniht; wherefore he wak'd Calairis to be likewie Spectator of what was done. They tood uneen themelves, but plainly behled, by the light of the Moon and Fire, where the buines was perform'd, and by reaon of the little ditance, heard the dicoure, the Beldam now bepeaking her Son in a louder voice. The quetion which he ask'd of him was, If her Son, who was yet living, hould return afe home? To this he anwer'd nothing, only nodding his head, gave her doubtful conjecture of his ucces; and therewith fell flat upon his Face. She turn'd the Body with the Face upward, and again repeated her quetion, but with much greater violence, uttering many Incantations, and leaping up and down with the Sword in her hand, turning ometimes to the Fire, and then to the Pit; he once more awaken'd him, and etting him upright, urg'd him to anwer her in plain word, & not in doubtful igns. In the mean time Chariclea deired
Calairis that they might go nearer, and enquire of the old Woman about Theagenes; but he refus'd, affirming that the pectacle was impious; that it was not decent for any peron of Prietly Office to be preent, much les delighted with uch performances: That Prayers and lawful Sacrifices were their buines; and not with impure Rites and enquires of Death, as that Aegyptian did, of which michance had made us pectators.
