While he was thus peaking, the dead peron made anwer, with a hollow and dreadful tone: At firt I pared you, Mother, (aid he) and uffer'd your trangreing againt humane Nature and the Laws of Detiny; and by Charms and Witchcraft diturbing thoe things which hould ret inviolated: For even the Dead retain a Reverence towards their Parents, as much as is poible for them; but ince you exceed all bounds, being not content with the wicked action you began, nor atisfy'd with raiing me up to give you igns, but alo force me, a dead Body, to peak; neglecting my Seputure, and keepin me from the manion of departed Souls; hear thoe things which at firt I was afraid to acquaint you withal: Neither you Son hall return alive, nor hall your elf ecape that Death, by the Sword, which is due to your crimes; but conclude that life in ort time, which you have pent in wicked practices: Foramuch as you have not only done thee things alone, but made
other perons Spectators of thee dreadful Myteries that were o conceal'd in outmot ilence; acquainting them with the affairs and fortune or the Dead. One of them is a Priet, which makes it more tolerable; who knows, by his Widom, that uch things are not be divulg'd: A peron dear to the Gods, who hall with his arrival, prevent the Duel of his Sons prepar'd for Combat, and compoe their Difference. But that which is more grievous, is, that a Virgin has been Spectator of all that has been done, and heard what was aid: A Virgin and Lover, that has wander'd through Countrys, in earch of her Betroth'd; with whom, after infinite Labours and Dangers, he hall arrive at the outmot parts of the Earth, and live in Royal State. Having thus aid, he again fell protrate. The Hag being enible who were the Spectators, arm'd as he was with a Sword, in rage ought them amongt the dead Bodies, where he thought they lay conceal'd, to kill them, as perons that had invaded her, and crot the operation of her Charms: While he was thus employ'd, he truck her Groin upon the Splinter of a Spear that tuck in the ground, by which he dy'd; immediately fulfilling the Prophecy of her Son.

div.head: THE AETHIOPIAN HISTORY.
The Seventh Book.
div.p:
CAlairis and Chariclea having o narrowly ecaped, not only to avoid farther danger, but on account of what was foretold them by the dead man, haten'd their journey towards Memphis. When they arriv'd at the Town, they found the Preparations which they expected: For the People of Memphis, a little before Thyamis was compe up with his Beians, had hut up their Gates, being forewarn'd of his coming by a Prioner that had ecaped from him. Thyamis therefore encamping before the Walls, gave thee days repite to refreh his Army, weary'd with their march
and late Service. The Towninen, who before were terrify'd with expectation of great numbers, when they found their Enemies were few, drew up the Archers and Hore that were left to defend the Town, with the ret of the Citizens, arm'd as the udden chance could furnih them, prepar'd forthwith to fet upon the Enemy. A Peron of Age and Eminency diuaded them fromtheir attemyt, aying, That though Oroondates, the Deputy, were abent, yet it was meet firt to conult with Arace, his Wife; by which means the Souldiers who were left, would more willingly engage. They approved his Council, and accordingly went to the Palace, where Deputies reide in the Kings abence. Arace, beide the Charms of her peron and tature, had great managemment in affairs; uch as became her Royal Blood, and the Siter of a King: Yet for Luxury and diolute Life, deerv'd no little blame. Amongt other things, he was partly the caue of Thyamis's Banihment from Memphis For when Calatris, for thoe michiefs which were fore-told about his Sons, was withdrawn from the City, o long, that he was uppos'd to be dead, Thyamis, as his eldet Son, was immediately inveted in his place of High Priet: Arace immediately fixt her Eyes on him in the Temple, where, beide his youth and comely peronage, he appear'd more charming with the plendid habit of his Office. She forbore
not from immodet glances and igns, which Thyamis took little notice of, being of a chate temper. But his Brother Petioris, who had already envy'd his Dignity, and oberv'd the allurements of Arace, took occaion from thence to form a nare for his Brother. Therefore privately addreing himelf to Oroondates, did not only tell him the Inclination of Arace, but fally added, That Thyamis was contracted to her. He eaily believ'd, being already jealous of Arace, but as yet have her no diturbance, having no clear proof of his urmize; as alo out of repect to the Blood Royal, his upicion was to be uppret and conceal'd: Yet he forbore not to threaten Thyamis with Death, till he was expell'd the City, and Petioris made Priet in his tead. Thee things were formerly tranacted. When now the people were throng'd about the Palace, and told her the approach to the Enemy, which he already knew, and deired her Commands on the Souldiers; he anwered, That whereas they knew not as yet the numbers of the Enemy, nor who they were, nor for what caue they arrived, That it were expedient firt to go up to the Wall to take a view of the Enemy, and reolve as they aw occaion. They approv'd her counel, and went immediately upon the Battlements. There, when a Rich Pavillion was placed for Arace, and he he elf richly adorn'd, was eated thereon, with her Guards in Golden Armour about her;
holding out her Mace, for an Emblem of Peaceable Treaty, he commanded the chiefs of the Enemy to approach the Walls. Thyamis and Theagenes, who were elected by the Army to go forth, plac'd themelves under the Walls, cover'd in Armour all but their Heads. The Herald utter'd thee words: Arace, Wife of Oroondates, the Governour; and Siter to the King; demands of you, who you are? With what intention, or for what caue you are come hither with your Army? They rely'd, That their Troops were Beians. Of himelf, Thyamis gave thhis account; That he had utain'd injury from his Brother, as alo from Oroondates; That he was by Treachery depriv'd of the Priethood, and that the Beians were come to retore him: That if he were re-etled in his right, the Beians hould return peaceably, without doing them any damage; otherwife his Caue hould be decided by the Sword.

That Arace for her own ake hould comply, and take this opportunity of revenging herelf on Petioris, who had practis'd againt, and fally accus'd her to Oroondates; and on the ame pretence compas'd his Banihment from that City. The Memphians were much concern'd when they knew Thyamis, and were hitherto ignorant in the caue of his Banihment, and believ'd what he affirm'd. Arace, above all, was eiz'd with a Tempet of
Thoughts. Her Rage being renew'd with this Remembrance of her former injuries from Petioris, he conider'd which way to revenge herelf upon him. One while urveying Thyamis, and then Theagenes, he was divided in her deire, and ucceively had a paion for each: For the one a former flame, and for the other a more violent, though kindled that moment; inomuch that her concern was perceiv'd by her Sarvants. But when he came to her elf, like one from a woon; Excellent perons (aid he) what madnes has poet you, who have not only expos'd all the Beians, but your own beautiful elves, in behalf of Robbers; for you are not able, if we hould engage, to utain our firt Onet. The Kings affairs are not yet reduc'd to that ditres, though the Deputy be abent, but that you mut needs be encompas'd by the remainder of his Souldiers in the City. But I ee no reaon why the Publick hould be concerned in this difference; ince therefore the quarrel is private, let the deciion be o too; o that the Gods and Right mut determine the event. It therefore eems jut to me, that the Memphians and your Forces hould lie till, and not engage in a needles War. This Judgment of Arace was applauded with the houts of her people. They not only upected Perioris of Injutice, which they deired to ee punihed; but alo every one rejoyc'd to have his own Danger laid on another perons head. But
the Beian Army were not o well contented with the propoal, nor were willing to expoe their General to danger, till Thyamis with tears obtain'd their conent; alledging that Petioris was weaker, and not experienc'd in Arms, o that he having been vered therein, hould encounter him on advantage. Nor is it unlikely that Arace propos'd the ingle Combat, to obtain, with upicion, what he deired; it being mot probable that Thyamis would overcome. This reolve was no ooner mention'd that put in Action. Thyamis chearfully fitting on the ret of his Armour which was wanting; Theagenes aiting, and bracing his Helmet on, adorn'd with a mot graceful Cret and Plume. Petioris in the mean time was thrut out of the Town, much entreating them that he might decline the Fight. As oon as Thyamis beheld him, Do you not ee, aid he to Theagenes, how the guilty Petioris trembles? I perceive it, replyed he: But how have you reolv'd in this Encounter? The Enemy with whom you engage is your Brother. You ay true, reply'd he; I therefore determine, by the Gods will, to conquer, but not kill him: Providence forbid that former rage hould o far revine in me, as to make me, for wrongs that are pat, to imbrue my hands in a Brothers Blood. You peak like a Man of Honour, reply'd Theagenes, and vers'd in the Laws of Nature. But what Commands have you for me? There is little danger
in this Encounter (reply'd Thyamis;) yet ince all Events are in the hands of Fortune, if I Conquer, you hall enter this City, and live with me in full command of my fortunes; but if otherwie it hall happen, you hall be chief over thee Beians, that highly eteem you, till Providence hall better compoe your Affairs. This being agreed on, they embrac'd each other with mutual Tears and Kies. Theagenes fat down in the habit in which he was, to oberve the Combate; thereby (though unwittingly) affording a full view of himelf to Arace, who feated her wanton Eyes on his amiable Peron. Thyamis made up to Petioris, who would not abide the firt onet, but whilt he approacht, made toward the Gate, to helter himelf in the City: But to no purpoe, being again forced out by the Citizens; the perons likewie upon the Walls giving charge that none hould receive him. He therefore ran round the Walls, and at lengthh with part of his Arms thrown away. Theagenes follow'd to ee the event, but without Weapons, to give no upicion of aiting Thyamis; having cat down his Spear and Buckler in the place where he at in ight of Arace. Thus Petioris twice urrounded the City; but making the third round, Thyamis poiing his Spear, and calling to him to tand, unles he would receive a candalous wound in his Back: The whole City itting pectators, as it were in a Theatre. The Deity,
or Fortune, that governs humane affairs, as in ome labour'd Tragedy, where new events arie, had not only plac'd Calairis a Spectator at the Duel of his Sons, but alo made him one in chae. Who although he had uffered o many ditrees, and banih'd himelf into remote Countrys to avoid o cruel a pectacle, yet, by the power of fate, is compell'd to ee what the Gods foretold to him by their Oracles, He therefore, from a great ditance, beholding the coure, perceived by what had been revealed to him, that the two Combatants were his Sons. Wherefore, with greater peed than old Age would well permit, he hatned towards them, to prevent, if poible, their actual engagement: Approaching o near as to bear up with them; What madnes is this, O my Children, he often cryed out? But they not yet knowing their Fathers countenance, he being diguis'd in Beggars habit; their whole mind being taken up with the buines in hand, neglected him, as one of the Spectators, or ome peron ditracted. But thoe who were on the Walls admir'd that he took no care of himelf, but came between the Combatauts, while others laught at him, as a frantick man. When therefore the old man was enible that he was unknown through the meannes of his Garb, he threw off his outward poor Diguie; dicovering his Sacred hair, not yet unwreath'd; the Burden which he carry'd on his back, with the Bow,
being cat away, he renew'd his Prayers, and with Tears uttered thee words; O Sons, (aid he) behold Calairis, behold your Father, and deit from this fury, which, with ill fate, you have begun; and pay jut reverence to the preence of your aged Father.

At this they relented, and not only fell, but threw themelves headlong at his Feet, embracing his Knees, they look'd up to his Face, to aure themelves if it were he, and that they were not deceived by ome Spectre. As oon as they were confirm'd, they were eiz'd with various and contrary affections. They were overjoy'd to ee their Father alive, beyond their hopes or expectation, and were no les troubled for the manner in which he apprehended them; and, above all, were ollicitous of the event in this accident. While the perons from the Walls were beholding this Scene, and almot atoniht, through Ignorance of the matter, o that they tood mute and motionles as Statues, behold another turn in the Scene aroe: Chariclea following the teps of Calairis, while from afar off he knew Theagenes (for Lovers have harp ight) tranported with the view, with a cloe Embrace, hanging on his Neck, had no breath left to peak to him. But he, as it is likely, by her poor Dres and Face, didained her, thinking her ome Vagabond among the Crowd of Spectators, put her from him; and at lat, when he not deit, and vex'd
to be hinder'd from the Scene of Calairis, puh'd her away: She, with a low voice, cry'd, O Pythius, have you forgot this Taper? Theagenes truck with that word, as with a Thunder-bolt, by the igns agreed on between them, knew the Torch, and tranported with the ight of Chariclea, her Beauty now hining out, as through a Cloud, he threw himelf upon her Neck. The whole Battlements (where Arace at, who urvey'd Chariclea not without Jealouie) were urpriz'd at this Scene of wonderful repreentation. The dire contet between the Brothers is taken off, and the Battel, which was expected to the of bloody conequence, concludes in a happy agreement. The Father, who had beheld his Sons arm'd againt each other, inomuch that his Eyes were almot made witnees of his Childrens unnatural death, is now Arbiter of Peace between them. he that could avoid not their neceary detiny, makes now no les advantage of Fortune. The Children recover their Parent after ten years los, and he that was the caue of their bloody trife for the Priethood, is now himelf Crown'd by the Rivals, and led along in the Sacred Robes. But the hining parts in the Comedy were Theagenes and Chariclea, mot beautiful figures; who, beyond all hopes, had now recovered each other; and above all the ret, drew the eyes of the City upon them. The Inhabitants iued through the Gates, and
filled the Plain with their numbers; the younger ort repairing to Theagenes, and the elder thronging to Thyamis; the Virgins that were Marriagable, went over to chariclea: So that a kind of Religious Proceion was immediately contituted. Thyamis in the mean time dimiing the Beians, with thanks for the kindnes that they hewed him; he likewie divided Preents amongt them, an hundred Oxen and a thouand Sheep, with promie of ten Drachms apiece, in little time to be ent after them.

He then put his Neck under his aged Fathers Arms to upport him, languihing with years, and at preent with exces of Joy. Petioris on the other ide did the ame. Thus was the old Man carry'd to the Temple of Iis, urrounded with Applaue and Congratulations; Pipes and Sacred Flutes reounding all the way, that et the younger ort a Dancing. Arace alo performed her part, following the Pomp with her Train, and putting much Gold into the Temple of Iis, for an Example to the ret of the City. In the mean time, while Theagenes led Chariclea by the hand, officiouly keeping off the pres from her, he adminitred no mall Jealouie to Arace. Calairis went into the inward part of the Temple, where falling protrate before the Images, he almot expir'd in the adoration. But being recovered by the tanders by, as oon as he could tand upright, and had paid his Reverence to
the Goddes, he took the Wreath from his Brow and plac'd it on the Head of Thymis; telling the Multitude, That he was old, that the Enigns of Priethood were due to his eldet Son, who alo was qualify'd to utain that Office. When the people had with houts approy'd his pleaure, he, with his two Sons and Theagenes, repair'd to that part of the Temple which is aign'd to the Priethood: The ret departed every one to his houe. Arace likewie went away, but not without delays, and turning back again, as it were, to perform homage to the Goddes. All the while cating her Eyes towards Theagenes, as long as he could have ight of him. After he was return'd to the Palace, he betook her to her Apartment, where he threw herelf upon her Bed, without uttering one word. A Woman lacivious in her temper, but now with the urpaing beauty of Theagenes, inflam'd to a degree beyond what he had yet been enible of. She therefore continued waking all night, turning from one ide to the other, ighing deeply, ometimes riing up, and then throwing her elf down upon her Bed again. She often hatily call'd her Attendants to her, then ent them away again without any Commands for them. In fine, this paion had ditracted her, but for an old Woman, Cybele by name, the keeper of her Cabinet, and former Servant of her Love-intrigues. She gues'd the affair, and
came into the Chamber, as it were a Torch, adding fire to her flame. Madam, aid he, what frenzy is this? What new paion tranports you? What Perons Apect has diturb'd my Charge? Who is o vain and hardy, as not to be taken with that Beauty, and not account uch an enjoyment the greatet happines? tell me, my dear Daughter; for there is none o obtinate, as not to be vanquih'd by my Stratagems. You have already had good proof thereof. Thee words, and many more to this purpoe uttered he, embracing the Feet of Arace, and reply'd Arace, after a little paue. I have now receiv'd a deeper wound than ever; I have often found your skill uccesful in thee affairs, but know not now what it can do. The War which was this day almot begun before our Wall, prov'd unbloody to others, but to me the beginning of a more fatal War, wherein I am wounded to the very Soul; in unfortunately hewing me the youth that accompany'd Thyamis during the Combat. You know, Mother, whom I peak of; for with the plendour of his Beauty he oon clouded all the ret, dicovering no mean Birth, nor Averion to Love. This your Judgment cannot be ignorant of: Wherefore, ince you know my grief, 'tis high time to et all your Engines to work; to employ all your Art and Indutry if you would have your Daughter to urvive. For of what
ue is Life, without enjoyment of the peron whom I affect. I know the youth (reply'd the old Woman;) He that is full Breated, his Neck erect, his Eyes parkling, and at once diplaying Love and Severity; with fair and wellorder'd Hair, his Cheeks jut budding with youthful down; to whom a certain Damel, not diagreeable, but exceive impudent, approach'd, and cat her Arms about him: Is not this your Man, Lady? The very ame, Mother: And you have well brought into my mind that dometick Creature, who yet is far happier than I, in poeion of uch a Lover. At this the Old Woman miling, reply'd, Be of good heart, and lay aide care, Madam; It is but for a day that he is held beautiful by the tranger; but when I bring it about that he hall enjoy your Beauty, that ordid Harlot hall be depis'd. Do o, my dear Cybele, and you will at once eae me of a double grief, Love and Jealouie. Leave that to my care (aid he) in the mean time it is your part to compoe your elf with good hopes, and not to depair of my work before I begin. Having thus aid, he went away, taking the light with her, and making fat the Door. Arace no ooner perceiv'd day-light, but he call'd one of her Eunuchs, together with her Woman, to whom he gave little Cakes, and ent them to do Sacrifice at the Temple. When they came to the Gates, and told the Door-keeper their buines, That
they were come to do Sacrifice for Arace, who had that night been troubled in Dreams; the Officer forbad their entrance, acquainting them, That the Temple was at preent full of Sorrow: That the High Priet Calairis, the lat evening, enlarging his Soul in chearfulnes, and after the Banquet made long upplications to the Goddes: Then telling his Sons, That hitherto they had een their Father; and giving them trict Charge concerning the two Grecian trangers, he betook himelf to his Bed. After this, whether his pores were too much dilated through exces of joy, or worn out with Age, or by the fix'd decree of the Gods, about Cockcrow he expired, in preence of his Sons, who watched him. We have now ent Meengers to aemble the Priethood of the City, to perform thoe Funeral Rites, which, according to our Cutom, are due to him. You mut therefore depart; for it is not lawful for any Peron to enter the Temple, or do Sacrifice for thee even days but only the Priets. What then mut become of the two trangers, aid Cybele, during this time?

Our new Prelate Thyamis, (aid the Officer) has commanded a Lodging to be prepar'd for them without the Temple; and behold where they are now in obedience, going forth out of the Temple. Cybele having got this lucky opportunity, thus again bepeaks the Officer; O Friend, belov'd of the Gods, it is in your power
to do this young Couple a courteie, but a much greater to Arace, the Kings Siter. You know how he favours Grecians, and ues hopitality to trangers; Tell them therefore, that by Command of Thyamis, an apartment is provided for them in the Palace. The Officer did as he commanded, being enible of no harm, but thinking to do the perons a kindnes, in aiting their Reception to the Palace. Coming therefore up to Theagenes and Chariclea, drown'd in Tears; You are to blame, aid he, having been commanded to the contrary, thus to bewail the death of the High Priet, whereas our Divine Laws enjoin us to rejoyce for the conummation of his happines. However, you are partly to be excus'd, having lot (as you ay) your Father and Patron: Yet ought you not altogether to depond, ince his Son Thyamis, as you ee, ucceeds him in the Priethood, and is no les your friend. He has given charge in the firt place concerning you, and order'd you a dwelling, to which perons of the firt Rank are pround to be receiv'd, and therefore well may trangers be o, who eem of no extraordinary fortune. Follow therefore this Lady (pointing to Cybele) and obey her, as a common Parent to you both. Theagenes did as he aid, whether overcome by the udden accident, that, like a torin, fell upon him, or in uch a tate of affairs was content with any manion. I preume he would have taken care
of himelf had he upected the michief which that Reidence was likely to bring upon him. But the fate that govern'd them, after it had allow'd them one days refrehment, immediately follow'd it with misfortune; making them Prioners to their Enemy, though under appearance of Hopitality. When therefore they were come to the Deputies houe, where all appear'd too tately for any private peron; with Guards, and attending Courties; who all were urpriz'd at this preferment (as it eem'd to them) of the trangers. They were follow'd by Cybele, encouraging them to be of good heart, and expect the performance of her promie. At lat, bringing them into her own Apartment, the ret of the company being hut out, he at her elf down by them, and thus expret herelf: O my Children, aid he, I know the occaion of your grief, which is conceiv'd for the Death of Calairis, worthily honour'd by you as a Father: But it is now needful that you unfold your elves to me: who you are, and from whence. That you are Greeks I know, and of good Parentage, I eaily conjecture by your appearance. Your generous countenance and form aure me of your Birth; but from which Greece you come, and for what caue you wander'd, and arriv'd here, I deire to undertand, intending your good thereby; as alo that I may acquaint Arace my Lady, and Wife to our Deputy, with the particulars
of your Affairs; for he is famous for hopitality lity of trangers, and, of all Nations, an admirer of the Greeks, for the elegance of their manners: by which means you hall come into her Preence with Advantage. Neither hall you declare your elf to a Woman that is altogether a tranger, for I my elf am a Greek, Lesbia the place of my Birth; brought Captive hither, but to the improvement of my Fortune. I am Chief Agent for my Lady, he breathes not without me; I am her very Soul, and bring worthy Perons into her Acquaintance.

Theagenes comparing what was now poken by Cybele, with what had happen'd the day before, and the immodet getures of Arace, was about to anwer, when Chariclea aid to him in his ear, be ue in your dicoure to remember your Siter. He undertanding what he meant by that uggetion, aid; You know, Mother, already that we are Greeks; but I mut further inform you that we are likewee Brother and Siter: Who, in earch of our Parents, that were taken away by Pyrates, have our elves utain'd wore fortune, by falling into the hands of wore men: Robb'd of our Treaure, and carce ecaping with Life, we met, by Providence, with Calairis, with whom we deign'd to lead the ret of our Life: But he being now expir'd, we are left deolate, and the econd time depriv'd of a Father. This is the poture of our Affairs. But to you
we return our jut Thanks for your Courteous Hopitality; however, you will yet lay a greater obligation upon us, if you caue us to live retir'd and private, not introducing us into the Court, or acquaintance with Arace; for uch familiarities, you know, are mot fitting amongt Equals. Cybele could no longer contain, but by the chearfulnes of her countenance, dicover'd her joy to hear they were Relations; that therefore Chriclea would be no Obtacle to Arace's Deires. O lovely Youth (aid he) you will not peak this of Arace when you know her humour; She carries herelf equally to all fortunes, and with particular favour to dignity in ditres: Being herelf a Perian by Birth, he naturally admires the People and Manners of Greece. Wherefore the People and Manners fo Greece. Wherefore take heart, and aure your elf of all manly Offices about her, while Chariclea hall be her Intimate and Companion. But it is neceary that you tell me your Names. Which when he had heard, he deired them to wait her return; and o hatned to Arace, leaving Orders with the Door-keeper, That none hould be uffer'd to go in to them, nor the Strangers to go out. Not if your own Son Achemenes come (aid the peron?) Not even he, reply'd the other: Lock the door, and ay I have taken the Key with me. Even thus it happen'd; Cybele was no ooner departed, but left opportunity to Theagenes and Chariclea to bewail their misfortunes, which they
did in almot the ame words. O Theagenes, aid he; O Chariclea, he anwer'd, with an equal igh. What fortune has beet us, aid he! In what poture are our affairs, anwer'd he! Thus reply'd they to each, kiing and mutually embracing after every Sentence: At lat calling to mind Calairis, they broke out into a joint Complaint: Chiefly Chariclea, as having for a longer time been obliged to his Hopitality: O good Calairis, aid he, how am I in thee depriv'd of a Daughters name. The Father who begot me I never Knew, the Father that adopted me I forook; and latly, this that receiv'd, cherih'd, and preerv'd me, is now a dead Corpe, to which I am not permitted o much as to pay Funeral Rites. Yet, my Sutainer and Preerver, nay, I will add Father; where-ever I am confin'd, I will make jut Libations with my Tears, and pay thee Offerings: Herewith he pluck'd off her Hair, and threw it on the floor. Theagenes entreated her to pare her elf and be pacify'd; yet he went on with her Complaint. To what purpoe hould I now live, what hope is left? My Guide in this trange Land, the Staff of my Pilgrimage, my leader to my Native Soil; he that performed the Office of Parent; my Advier in Ditres, the Repeller of my Misfortunes, the Anchor of my Hopes, Calairis, is gone. While he utter'd thee Lamentations, Theagenes wept apart, adn retrain'd as much
as he could his grief, in pity to his Mitres. By this time Achemenes arriv'd, and finding the Door lock'd, ask'd the Door-keeper the reaon: When he knew 'twas by his Mothers Order, he went to the Door, where he heard Chariclea lamenting, and look'd through the chinks into the Chamber. Again he enquires of the Door-keeper; who aid, She uppos'd they were two trangers brought in thither by his Mother. He then toop'd down again, to try if he could know them. Chariclea he knew not, yet was taken with her Beauty; which he thought how great it was when not diguis'd with Grief. From Admiration he falls into Love. As for Theagenes, he could but gues at him. While he was thus intent, Cybele returns, having told all to her Mitres concerning the young Couple; commending that good fortune that had better crown'd her deires, than the wiet Councils could have done; to plant the peron he lov'd in the ame houe with her. Having thus enflam'd Arace with deire of eeing Theagenes, he yet with-held her, being diorder'd with want of Sleep, till he had reted, and would appear with better Advantage.

Leaving her thus atisfy'd, and in good expectation of the event, and reolv'd on what method to take with the Strangers, he return'd. What is it, Son, aid he, that you o curiouly enquire after? What Strangers are thoe within, (aid he) and from whence? I may not inform,
you, aid Cybele, nor mut you tell what you know, nor converer with the Strangers. He obey'd his Mother, upecting Theagenes to be reerv'd for Arace's ervice; but is not this the peron (aid he within himelf as he departed) who was recued from me by the Beians, when he was deliver'd to me by Mitranes, to conduct him to Oroondates, who was to end him to our great King? In which attempt my Life was in danger, and I only ecaped of thoe that guarded him? Do my Eyes deceive me? I have heard alo that Thyamis is arriv'd, and has fought in ingle Duel with his Brother for the Priethood. It is certainly the ame peron. But at preent I mut conceal the dicovery, and oberve Arace's proceedings with the Strangers. Thee were his private entiments. Cybele in the mean time entring in upon them, perceiv'd what had pat: For although at the operning of the Doors they endeavour'd to compoe themelves, yet they could not conceal their Grief from the ubtle old Lady; their Cheeks being till moit with Tears. She therefore Cry'd out, O my dear Children, why do you thus take on? When you ought to rejoice, and congratulate your good fortune: The mot excellent Arace contrives all things for your atisfaction; and has conented that to morrow you hall be brought into her Preence: Wherefore you mut put away thee Childih Lamentaions; it is meet for you to compoe your
elves, and be obedient to her Pleaure. The Death of Calairis (aid Theagenes) raied this orrow, in whom we have lot a Fathers protection. You trifle, aid Cybele; Calairis was but your peronated Father, and is expir'd, according to the Laws of Age and Nature. All things are retored to you in one Peron; Riches, Pleaures; adore Arace as your good fortune. Only be rul'd by me in what manner you are to approach her (ince he has o commanded) and what meaures you mut take in what he hall command. You know her Spirit is great, as being elevated by Quality and Beauty, and uch as will not bear Contempt, in any thing that he hall enjoin.

While Theagenes tood ilent, as conjecturing the flagitious meaning, the Eunuchs entred, bringing in Golden Chargers, the Remains of the Royal Banquet, that exceeded in Cot and Delicacy: When they had et them on the Table, aying, That their Lady, in honour to the trangers, had o commanded, they departed: Yet, to omit no part of their Office, they firt tated of every Dih. The ame was done in the Evening. The next Morning the ame Ennuchs coming to Theagenes, aid, You are call'd for (O happy man) by our Lady, and we are commanded to bring you into her Preence: Go therefore, to enjoy that Happines which is permitted to very few, and to thoe very eldom. He paus'd a while, and then unwillingly
riing up, Am I only commanded to go, or my Siter here with me? Only you at preent (aid they) he being afterwards to come by her elf. There are now certain Ferian Nobles with Arace: It is her manner to peak with Men apart, and with Women afterwards apart alo. Theagenes bowing, aid oftly to Chariclea, Thee things are neither honet, nor their meaning unupected by me: When he whipered to him again, That he ought not to diobey, but eem willing to perform her Pleaure in all things, he follow'd them forth. When they told him after what menner he was to be accoted; how he ought to adore her at his entrance, he anwered nothing. But going in, and finding her eated on a Tribunal, adorn'd in a Purple Robe, Embroider'd with Gold, Bracelets on her Arms, and a Rich Tiara on her Head, the Guards landing round, and the Nobles eated on each ide, his mind was not moved in the leat; but as forgetting what was agreed on between himelf and Chariclea, his Spirit was the more exalted againt the Pride of this Perian Pageant. Therefore, neither bending his Knee, nor adoring her, with an erect countenance, he aid; Save you, Arace, of Royal Blood, While thoe that were preent were enrag'd, and murmur'd at Theagenes's audacious Entrance without the uual Adoration. You mut excue him, (aid Arace miling) as a tranger to our Cutoms; and as a Grecian,
prejudic'd againt them. Withal, he put off her Tiara, though much prohibited by the Attendants; for this is the Perians way of returning repect to them that alute them. When, by her Interpreter, (for though he undertood the Greek Tongue he could not peak it) he had bid him be of good chear; to demand any thing he needed; beckning to her Eunuchs, he dimis'd him. He was attended forth by the Guards, among whom, Achemenes, having here een him again, knew him more exactly; and upecting the caue of the extraordinary honour done to him, yet conceal'd his thoughts, reolving within himelf what to do. Arace continued to receive the Perian Nobles and Magitrates with uch Magnificence, pretending repect to them, while the true caue of her holding the Banquet was to have dicoure with Theagenes; to whom he not only ent the choicet Dainties, but richet Preents, Tapetrys and Carpets of divers Colours, wrought at Sydom and Lydia. She likewie ent Servants to attend them; a young Maiden to Chariclea, and a Youth of Ionia to Theagenes: Very much urging Cybele to finih her Deign with celerity, for that he could no longer utain the violence of her Paion: Nor was he negligent in trying all ways to compas Theagenes. Indeed he told him not Arace's Deire in expres words, but with circumlocution gave him to undertand; magnifying the Bounty of
Arace towards him; etting before his Eyes not only thoe Beauties which appear'd in her, but likewie thoe that were conceal'd: Then he extoll'd her humour, that was affable and obliging, and the eteem that he had for Youths of noble Expectation. In hort, he made tryal by all he aid how he tood affected to the Delights of Venus. Theagenes acknowleg'd her Bourity towards him, her love to the Grecian cutoms; and on all accounts return'd her Thanks and Praie: But for the drift of her wiles he eem'd to take no notice. The Old Lady therefore was tung, to think that he undertood her intention, but depis'd and repell'd her attempts. She knew Arace would bear no longer delays, but exact performance of her promie; he therefore put her off with pretences, ometimes aying that the Youth was timorous, and ometimes that ill Accidents had happen'd. When therefore the fifth and ixth days were pat, in which Arace had again call'd Chariclea to her, and, to gratifie Theagenes, treated her with all imaginable courteie, he was forced to peak more plainly with Theagenes; to tell him her Ladies paion, auring him of ten thouand advantages if he aented. Why are you (aid he) o avere to Love? A Youth o beautiful, in the pring of his Age, belov'd by an equal Beauty, yet eteems not the good fortune: Epecially when no danger attends, the Husband being abent, and I (who have bred her,
and know all her ecrets) having the management of the affair. On your own part, there can be no impediment, having neither Mitres nor Wife. Though many have depied even thee coniderations, and thought they did not therein wrong their Dometick concerns; but took the opportunity at once of making their fortune, and enjoying their pleaure. Latly, he mingled Threats with Arguments; aying, That the mot obliging Women conceive the greatet dipleaure, when diappointed, and everely revenge the neglect. Think with your elf, That this Lady is a Perian, and of Princely Blood, as you have acknowledg'd; with what Power he is veted; o that at her pleaure he may reward her Favourites with greatet Honours, and punih thoe that dioblige her. For your part, you are a tranger here, deerted, and have none to uccour you. Take pity both on your elf and her. She is worthy of your Compaion, ince you were Author of her pain, and it is for you he languihes. At leat, fear a Lovers Rage, and beware of that Revenge which follows Contempt. I have known many of your temper, who have repented too late.

I have greater Experience in thee matters than you: Thee hairs are grown grey in the Employment; but o obtinate and incorrigible a Youth I never yet met withal. Then turning to Chariclea (of neceity indeed he hearing
all this dicoure) and do you, Daughter, (aid he) advie this Brother of yours, though I know not if he deerve that title. This buines will alo turn to your advantage; you will be never the les lov'd by him; you hall have all Honours conferr'd on you; be made as rich as you pleae, and advanc'd to a mot Honourable Marriage. Thee things are to be wih'd for by happy perons, not by the Detitute, and Strangers. But Chariclea, looking angrily and earnetly upon her, It were to be wih'd, aid he, on all accounts, that Arace uffer'd under no uch paion, at leat that he could moderate her deires; but ince humanity is liable to uch frailty, and that he is over-power'd, I would my elf counel Theagenes not to refue, if it may be with afety; let it come to light, by ome Accident, to her undoing, by the Deputies knowledge of it. Cybele leapt forth at thee words, Kiing and Embracing Chariclea; Well poken, Daughter, (aid he) this is agreeable to Nature, that you, who are a Woman, hould pity the ufferings of a Woman, and take care for your Brothers afety. But on this account there is no reaon why you hould fear, ince the Sun himelf hall not be privy to it. Deit at preent, aid Theagenes, and give us a little time to deliberate. Cybele immediately went out. O Theagenes, (began Chariclea) the Gods give us uch uccees, as bring with them greater Misfortune than the
Happines: Which ince it is o, it is the part of Prudence to make the bet of bad Circumtances. Whether or no you reolve in your elf on this thing I know not, but if you think the propoal dihonet and unworthy, feign a compliance, and ooth the Impatience of the Barbarian with expectation, let he determine omething fatal againt us. 'Tis probable that a little time (if you can delay her hopes) will afford us ome Remedy. But, O Theagenes, take care let the Contemplation betray into a Deire. To which Theagenes anwer'd, with a mile, Neither have you in your ditres ecap'd that Female Ditemper, Jealouie. But know that I cannot o much as diemble, or make a pretence in uch an affair; to act or ay, in unlawful things, is alike to generous minds. If Arace depair, there will be, at leat, this advantage in it, that we hall no more be troubled with her ollicitations. But if I mut uffer, both my pat fortune, and temper of mind, have inur'd me to bear what hall be put upon me. Chariclea aid no more, only deir'd him to take notice into what michief they mut inevitably be brought.

While they were thus taken up, Cybele having encourag'd Arace to good hope, for that Theagenes had expret o much, return'd to the Apartment; where paing over that night in Civilities to Chariclea, whom alo he made her Bed-fellow; next morning he again ask'd Theagenes,
What he reolv'd? When he manifetly refus'd her, and bid her expect no uch compliance: She return'd orrowful to Arace. When he had told her Theagenes Cruelty, Arace puh'd her forth headlong, and running into her Cloet, threw herelf on her Bed, tearing her Cloathes and Hair. Achemenes had no ooner py'd his Mother coming forth ad and weeping, but he ask'd her the reaon; If any Michief had happen'd, and any ill news diturb'd her Lady? If Oroondates had lot the Battel? And many more uch quetions. You triftle (aid he) and o went on. He nevertheles intermitted not, but taking her by the hand, begg'd her to acquaint her Son with her trouble: She therefore permitting him to lead her, went into a private part of the Garden. I would, aid he, to no other peron dicover my Ladies ufferings; but ince her life is at take, and I know her fury will return upon my head, I am compell'd to peak: If poibly you can contrive any help for her that brought thee into the light, and nured thee with thee Breats. She is deperately in love with a certain Youth; her paion is invincible; and after hopeful expectation, both he and I have found our labour frutrated. From hence proceeded thee manifold favours expreed to the Strangers. But ince the foolih Youth is intractable, I fear he will not live, and know my own Death to be certain. This is the ditreed
etate of our affairs. If you can give any relief, do it quickly; if not, prepare your Mothers Funeral. But what Reward hall I have, Mother, aid he; for it is not eaonable to tell you at large how far I can be erviceable, whilt you are in this diorder, and almot expiring. You hall have whatever you will deire, aid Cybele: You are already made, on my account, her Chief Cup-bearer: If there is any further preferment which you would have, demand it: The Riches hall be without meaure which you hall have, if you preerve her. I neither ask Preferment nor Wealth, aid he; let her only give the Maid, who is call'd the Siter of Theagenes, for my Wife, and all things hall ucceed to her deire. I am paionately in love with the Virgin: Wherefore our Lady labouring with the ame paion, will more readily gratifie my Deires, epecially for o great a Service. Doubt it not, aid Cybele; beides, I may privately prevail with the Virgin on your behalf. But tell me, What method do you propoe? I hall not tell it, aid he, till my Lady has promis'd me with Oath; nor do you till then attempt any thing with the Virgin; let by precipitance you detroy all, he being, as I perceive, of a great Spirit.

Hereupon he return'd to Arace, and throwing herelf at her Feet, deir'd her to take comfort, all things hall do well, only be pleas'd to call my Son Achemenes into your Preence.
Let him be call'd, aid Arace; but take care you do not again deceive me. Achemenes therefore enter'd; and when Arace, in expres words, had worn to him, That he hould Marry the Siter of Theagenes: Then, aid he, trouble not your elf, your Authority over Theagenes is abolute, let the Slave take care how he behaves himelf to his Mitres. How mean you, aid he? When he had thus ask'd, he told her all that had pat; That he had been taken, and was her Captive and Bond-man, by right of War: That Mitranes had ent him to him, to end him again to Oroondates, who was to convey him to the King: That he was recu'd from him, on the way, by the Beians and Thyamis: That he hardly ecap'd with Life: And above all, produc'd before Arace the Letters of Mitranes. If there were need of farther Arguments, Thyamis hould confirm it. Arace hereupon was a little reviv'd, and going from her Apartment to the Preence Chamber; where he was wont, on her Tribunal, to determine publick affairs: She commanded Theagenes to be brought before her. When he was brought, he ask'd him if he knew Achemenes, who tood by him? He confeing it; he farther ask'd, If he had taken him Prioner? Theagenes acknowledging that alo; You are therefore my Slave, aid he, and mut be at my dipoal. I betroth your Siter to Achemenes; who not only for
his Mothers, but for his own ervices deerves highly from me: I hould only o far defer it, till the requiite preparations for the Nuptials can be made. Theagenes was herewith truck, as with a Thunder-bolt, yet reolved not to contradict, but cunningly decline her fury. O Madam, aid he, we are obliged to the Gods, that ince we are born of noble blood, we have yet the comfort in our Misfortunes, to become your Servants: To you, who exercie uch courteie towards Strangers. But for my Siter, ince he was not your Captive, he cannot be made to erve; yet he has reolv'd in all things to obey; do therefore what you hall judge to be right. You hall be plac'd, aid Arace, among the Waiters on our Table, and learn the Art of Cup-bearing, to practie the Royal Service before-hand.

They went forth from her Preence; Theagenes with a thoughtful Countenance, Achemenes receiving him with coffs: Behold, aid he inulting, that you, who lately were o inolent, who thought your elf the only free man, who didain'd to bow your Head, and pay reverence, what you are now come to. Arace in the mean time ending the ret away, aid to Cybele alone, Now Cybele tell this proud youth, that if he will ubmit to our pleaure, he hall have his freedom, and live in wealth and plenty; but if he continues obtinate, I will ue him like my Slave, and impoe on him the vilet
Service and Punihments. Cybele came to him with the commands of Arace, adding alo to her words what he thought conveninent. Theagenes asking a little repite, aid to Chariclea apart; O Chariclea, our affairs are at an end; every Cable, every Anchor of Hope is cut off; our very Liberty is now taken away; we are Servants to Barbarians, and doom'd to uffer whatever they will impoe. Yet even thee things were tolerable, but Arace has promis'd you in Marriage to Achemenes, the Son of Cybele; which hall either never be, or at leat een by me while I am Mater of a Sword. But what is to be done? What contrivance can be found to free me from the deteted Embrace of Arace, and you from Achemenes? Yet methinks I have a udden thought, as neceity is fruitful in Invention: Then turning to Cybele, Tell your Lady, aid he, that I deire to peak with her alone, and in private.

The Old Lady imagining Theagenes to have conented, ran to Arace; and being commanded to bring him after Supper, he accordingly did o: Commanding the Attendants to leave their Lady to her Ret, and clear her Lodgings, he brought Theagenes into her Bed-chamber. The ret of the Apartments were all made dark, her Bed-chamber only had a Lamp in it.

Cybele would have withdrawn her elf, but Theagenes forbad her, aying, That he mut
be preent; I know that he is good at keeping Secrets; and with that, taking Arace by the hand; O Lady, aid he, I from the firt deferr'd your Commands only till I might with afety, obey you: But now, ince Fortune, by particular favour, has declar'd me your Servant, I am much more forward to obey you in all things. Whereas therefore you have promis'd me many Courteies, I beg but one intead of all, that you would revoked the Marriage of Chariclea and Achemenes: For, not to mention other things, it is unfit that he, being of Noble Birth, ould be wedded to a Servant. Otherwie, I Swear by the brightet of Deities, the Sun, that I will never comply with your demands; and before I will ee any violence offer'd to Chariclea, I will die by my own hand. You cannot but think me willing to gratifie you in any thing (aid Arace) who am ready to deliver up my elf to you; but I have already worn to give your Siter to Achemenes. It is well, Madam, aid he; give him my Siter if you pleae, but her whom I make love to, who is my Betrothed, and indeed my Wife, you neither will, nor can betow upon him. How ay you! Cry'd Arace: The matter anwers it elf, aid he, for Chariclea is not my Siter, but my Spoue; wherefore you are freed from your Oath: This you may alo confirm, whenoever you hall be pleas'd to perfect the Nuptials between her and me. Arace was
tung with Jealouie to hear that Chariclea was not his Siter, but his Spoue: Yet be it as you will, aid he, we hall make Achemenes amends by ome other Match. I hall likewie anwer your deires, aid Theagenes, when you have null'd this Promie. With thee words he bowed, as to kis her hand, but he tooping, receiv'd the alute upon her Lips: Theagenes then took leave of her. As oon as he could, he acquainted Chariclea with what had pat, (who heard him not without ome Jealouie) how all was compas'd by one means; the Nuptials with Achemenes broken, time gain'd to divert the ollicitations of Arace; and what would crown all, that Achemenes would put things into Commotion, enrag'd at his diappointment, and to ee me preferr'd to him in the favour of Arace: That nothing would be conceal'd from him, his Mother giving him the Intelligence: For I took care, for that reaon, to have her preent, as alo for a witnes of our Converation. It is to be expected (added he) that Achemenes will lay nares for Arace: a Slave by Birth (who have a natural inveteracy againt their Superiours) epecially being injured, and defrauded of her promie; eeing alo other preferr'd before him, and being concious to her practices, o that there is no need of forg'd Inventions, there being ufficient grounds of truth to work upon.

Having thus poken to Chariclea, and advis'd her to take ome hope, he was the next day brought by Achemenes to miniter at the Table: For this was enjoyn'd by Arace; and he was cloath'd in the Vetment which he ent him, adorn'd with Golden Wreaths, Bracelets, and Gemms. While Achemenes offer'd to hew him the manner of his Office, Theagenes ran to the Side-board, where the Golden Cups tood, and taking one up, I have no need of Teachers, aid he, but I will erve my own Lady after my own way. Fortune has well oblig'd you, to be skill'd in uch Offices, but Nature and Occaion hall intruct me what is to be done: Then lightly pouring forth, he bore the Cup to Arace. This draught more pleas'd her than uually, at once ipping of the Bowl, and fixing her Eyes on Theagenes, drinking deeper of Love than Wine. Achemenes was doubly wounded, fill'd at once with Rage and Emulation, o that Arace herelf perceiv'd his frown, and heard his murmurings to the tanders by. When the Banquet was done, I have one favour to beg, aid Theagenes, That you would pleae, Madam, to order me always to perform my Office in this Robe. Arace conenting, he reum'd his own dres, and went forth: Achemenes went along with him, upbraiding his inolence, and urging, That his Mitres excus'd his firt neglect, as being Ignorant, and a Stranger; but that for the future
he would not uffer it. This, ays he, I tell you as a Friend, and one whoe Siter, by my Ladies promie, is to be my Wife; with many more things to this purpoe. But Theagenes, as not hearing him, went forward, with his Eyes fix'd on the ground, till Cybele met him, as he was returning to lay her Lady on her Bed in the heat of the Day. Seeing her Son diturb'd, he demanded the reaon. This young Stranger, aid he, is preferr'd before me, for the Beauty of his Peron, and officiates in my tead; and this not without contempt of us that formerly had the Honour.

But thee matters we hall at another time have leiure to dicoure; in the mean time, Mother, I deire to olace my Grief by Marriage with Chariclea. What Marriage, Son, aid Cybele? You eem to me concern'd for light trouble, and yet neglect greater: You hall not now have Chariclea for your Wife. What ay you? anwer'd he, am I not worthy to marry my fellow Servant? For what reaon, Mother? For my ake, aid he, and my too much ervice to Arace: For after my preferring her to my own afety, and erving her pleaure, this Stranger at his firt admiion into her Chamber, was o much regarded, that he immediately prevail'd with her to break her Oath to you; and to conent that Chariclea hould be wedded to him, and not with you; he not being his Siter, but his Mitres. Has
he promied him, Mother? She has, my Son, in my preence and hearing; and will accordingly celebrate their Nuptials in few days: but for you he deigns another Match. Achemenes at this ighing deeply, and wringing his hands, aid, I hall render the Marriage fatal to them all; only do you ait me, by delaying the Nuptials for a time: and if any enquiry be made after me, ay that I remain ick in the Country. The Stranger calls his Siter his Spoue only to break off the Marriage with me: though if he hould Embrace, Kis her, or Sleep with her, I hall never believe but he is his Siter. This buines belongs to my Care, and to the Gods, whoe Honour is violated.

Thus poke he, being at once incens'd with Jealouie, Love and Diappointment, (which things are ufficient to make a peron troubleome, that were not barbarous) not weighing his Reolves by Reaon, but taking the firt heat, he mounted and Armenian Courer, that belong'd to the Deputy, and poted away to Oroondates, then mutering a great Army at Thebes, againt the Aethiopians; collecting all manner of Strength for the Enterprie, and now ready to March.

div.head: THE AETHIOPIAN HISTORY.
The Eighth Book.
div.p:
FOR when the King of Aethiopia had by Stratagem defeated Oroondates, and obtain'd the half of what they contended for, making himelf Mater of Philae; he at lat reduc'd him to thoe hifts, that he was forc'd to retreat by tealth, and in diorder. The City Philae is ituate on the Nile, a little above the Cataracts; and ditant from Siene and Elephantina about twelve miles and a half. This City being formerly taken, and poet by Aegyptian Out-laws, drew on a contet for the ame between the Aegyptians and Aethiops. The Aethiops pretending the Borders
of Aethiopia to tretch as far as the Cataracts; and the Aegyptians lay claim to it, on account of their Out-laws inhabiting there. This City was ucceively in the power of the one or other, according as they could oonet attack it; but at this time it had a Garrion of Aegyptians and Perians. The Aethiopian King, by Embay, demanded Philae of Oroondates, and the Precious Mines of Smaragdus: Which being deny'd, he commanded his Legates to go a few days journey before him, aying, That he would follow after, when he had made preparations, but acquainted none whither he intended. When he uppos'd the Legates to be arriv'd at Philae, where they were to lull the Inhabitants into ecurity, under pretence of coming to make a Peace with them, he himelf came uddenly upon the City, and beat out the Guards, who were not able to hold out againt the Number of the Enemy, and Engins, with which they batter'd the Walls with no damage at all to the Townimen.

Achemenes finding Oroondates troubled on thee accounts, gave him yet farther diturbance, by his udden and uncommanded Arrival. Asking therefore if any thing were amid with Arace, or his Family; he anwer'd, Tha
there was, but he would tell him in private When the Company were dimis'd, he unfold ed all; How Theagenes, take Prioner by M
tranes, and ent to him, to be again convey'd t
the King their Mater, being a handome Youth, and fit for Court Service, was recu'd by the Be Tians, who alo had kill'd Mitranes: He then proceeded to the affairs of Thyamis, and in the lat place told the Love of Arace for Theagenes; his Reidence in the Palace, and Honours conferr'd upon him; but that as yet perhaps there was nothing unlawful committed, the Youth being avere to her Deires. However, it was to be fear'd, that he would be won in time, unles he ent peedily to bring him to Memphis, and wholly cut off the Intrigue of Arace. That for this very reaon he haten'd and came ecretly to him, out of repect; not being able to conceal his Injury from him.

As with this dicoure he entam'd Oroondates with Jealouie and Revenge, o on the other ie he fill'd him with Love of Chariclea, of whom he next inform'd him; extoling her Beauty with Divine Praies; That never was her Equal een, nor ever hould be; That all his Concubines were nothing in comparion of her, not only thoe he left at Memphis, but alo they that followed his Camp. Many more things he added, thingking, That though Orrondates hould enjoy Chariclea, yet, after ome time, he hould, for this dicovery, receive her for his Wife. Thus was the Deputy thrown at once into the Toils of Rage and Love. Wherefore without delay, calling Bagoas, one of his Eunuchs, to him, (of great authority and trut)
with fifty Hore to accompany him, he ent him to Memphis, to bring THeagenes and Chariclea, as oon as he could find them.
He alo ent Letters: one to Arace, of thee Contents.

body.head: Oroondates to Arate.
body.p: THeagenes and Chariclea, the two Captive Kindred and Royal Servants, you mut end to me, to tranmit them to the King; end them willingly, for otherwie they hall by force be taken away, for I give Credit to Achemenes.

div.p: To Euphrates, the Chief Eunuch at Memphis, he wrote thus:

body.p: OF your Negligence in my affairs at home you hall hereafter give an account; at preent deliver the two Grecian Strangers to Bagoas, whether Arace be willing or not. Otherwie I have ent Orders that you be brought bound to me, and dicharg'd from your Office.

div.p:
Begoas therefore, according to Command, went with the Letters igned with the Deputies own Seal, that at Memphis they might give him the better Credit, and more eaily deliver the Strangers to him. Oroondates in the mean time et forward againt Aethiopia, commanding Achemenes to follow him; who knew
(thoughh no mention was made thereof) that he was kept in Cutody till the truth of what he had informed were known. Thee things paed at Memphis. In the mean time Thyamis (while Achemenes was upon his way to Oroondates) having in full power receiv'd the Office of High-Priethood, an Office of firt Rank in the City, and perform'd all Rites belonging to the Funeral of Calairis, to the outmot terms of the contituted time, he then called to mind Theagenes and Chariclea: for now it was permitted to him, by the Pontificial Law, to convere with Strangers. Therefore, upon enquiry, finding that they were carry'd to the Deputies Palace, he forthwith demanded them of Arace, alledging that they belong'd to him upon many accounts; That his Father Calairis, on his Death-bed, committed them to his care: Giving her thanks that he o courteouly treated the Strangers, during his Confinement to the Temple: But however, that he was obliged to remand the Pledges left to his Trut. I wonder, reply'd Arace, that while you acknowledge my Humanity, you condemn me at the ame time of Inhopitality, in uppoing me not able or willing to provide for the Strangers. Not o, aid Thyamis, I know they may live here in greater plenty than with me, provided they are o contentel. But ince they are of Noble Race, and have run through changes of Fortune, and till are wanderets, nothing can
be o deirable to them as to recover their Kindred and Country. In which, that I might be aiting to them, my Father left me his charge, beide many other obligations of Friendhip between us.

You do well, aid Arace, to urge your Right, by which you will ooner prevail with me, than by force. Have you then dominion over them, aid Thyamis? By what means? By right of War, reply'd he, which made them my Captives, and conequently my Slaves. When therefore Thyamis undertood that he pake of Mitranes; O Arace, aid he, it is not now War but Peace; as that brings into bondage, this hould et at liberty: Beides, War and Peace hould be judg'd not by the Name, but Reaon and Contitution. How can it be Creditable or Profitale to you to detain the Strangers?

Arace could no longer contain; but that happen'd to her which is uual for Lovers, while they think their entiments conceal'd, they have Modety; but when dicover'd, they loe all ence of hame. She therefore upecting that Thyamis perceiv'd her paion, made no account of his Prietly Dignity, but cating off the Modety of her Sex, told him, That what he had done againt Mitranes hould not pas unpunihed; for the time hould come when Oroondates would call his Murderers to account. For the preent I will not dimis my
Vaals, though in little time they hall be ent to the King my Brother. Wherefore leave your idle reaonings of Rights or Wrong, with them that have Authority, and depart willingly from our Palace, let you be compell'd by force. Thyamis therefore went forth, calling the Gods to witnes, and affirming that thee things could come to no good iue; reolving to acquaint th City herewith, and call in their aitance. Arace retir'd to her Chamber, calling Cybele to her, to take counel of what was to be done. She had now ome upicion of Achemenes his abence; and when he ask'd Cybele about it, he fram'd divers excues, affirming any thing rather than own his departure to Oroondates. Yet he did not altogether impoe upon her, the length of time creating mitrut. What hall we do, Cybele, aid he? Or how hall we work our elves out from the treights that encompas us? My deire is not leen'd but encreas'd by denial. The Youth grows more obtinate and intractable than ever. He has hitherto fram'd delays, but now he flatly denies me. And that which more troubles me, is lest he hould likewie apprehend what I upect of Achemenes. For Achemenes much diturbs me, being gone to Oroondates, to perwade him of what he knows or conjectures; if I could but ee Oroondates, one tender Word or Tear from me would overcome him. But I am afraid, let before I enjoy Theagenes, or can ee Oroondates, he hould
determine concerning me. Wherefore, Cybele, turn every Stone, try all your Art with the young man, ince you ee our affairs are brought to the lat exigence: For you mut imagine that when I depair for my elf, I hall pave no other peron. Therefore take advantage of your Sons endeavour, for I cannot conceive how you can be ignorant thereof. As for my Son, Madam, or my fidelity to you, you hall find that you cenure fally. Wherefore, ince you o negligently purue your Love, you mut not lay the blame on others: For you execrie not the Authority of a Mitres with him, but the ubmiion of a Slave. Which method perhaps was dicreet at firt, but ince he is obtinate, you hould make him feel your power, and contrain him, by Torments, to obey your pleaure. It is the manner of Youths to depie when they are Courted, but to ubmit on Compulion: Wherefore, he will do that by Punihment, which he refus'd on Entreaties. You eem to peak rightly, aid, Arace, but how can I endure to ee him chatiz'd. You are too tender, replyed Cybele, as though he would not by light chatiement be made to embrace Pleaure; and for your part of the uffering, you will be rewarded with your outmot Wihes; but if you cannot beat the pectacle, deliver him to Euphrates, to be courg'd as for ome fault, which you may hear though not ee; and if you find him change his mind, you
may at pleaure put an end to his Chatiement.

p.U:
uffer'd her elf to be perwaded; for Love, when depis'd, pares not the Object, but turns Kindnes into Revenge. Calling therefore the Chief Eunuch to her, he gave him Orders accordingly. He being by Nature envious, and poet with inveteracy againt Theagenes, for what he had een and upected, immediately threw him into Bonds, and afflicted him with Stripes and Hunger. The place was dark where he kept him, and though he knew the caue, he diembled, often asking Theagenes the reaon; who gave him no anwer wherefore he daily renew'd his Punihment, and more everely than Arace intended. Tormenting, and uffering none to come to him beide Cybele, who perpetually viited him, pretending to commierate his condition, on account of their former acquaintance, but indeed to find if he were to be wrought upon by the Tortures. He hew'd himelf more a Man, more reolute than ever, yielding his Body to punihment, triumphing in his Misfortune, that gave proof of his Love to Chariclea, and aying, That all was well with him if he did but know his Contancy; continually calling her his Light, his Life, and Soul. When Cybele perceiv'd this, (contrary to the will of Arace) he gave command to have his torments encreaed. Nei ther thus did he hope for ucces, but lat means
were to be try'd when affairs were deperate; he expected that Oroondates, when he hould hear of it, would take Revenge on Achemenes. She fear'd let Arace, when her paion was dicovered, would lay violent hands on her elf, and that conequently it were impoible for her to ecape; wherefore, if things came to the wort, he reolv'd to involve all together in the ame fate.

div.p: Returning therefore to Arace, We loe our labour, Madam, aid he, he is till more reolute and obtinate, having always Chariclea in his Mouth, and olacing his ufferings with her Name. Let us therefore cat forth our lat Anchor, and remove this Obtacle to our Endeavours: If he hall once know that he is dead, he will of coure admit your kindnes, depairing of his former Love.

Arace catcht at what he aid, being before enrag'd with Jealouie; you advie will, aid he, I will take care to have her dipatch'd; But whom hall we get to perform this? For though the power be in your own hands, yet the Perian Laws forbid to put any to Death without the Judgment of the Magitrates. You mut therefore contrive to lay ome Crime to her Charge: Yet if you think fitting (for I would run any hazzard for your ake) I will attempt her Life by Poyon. Arace approv'd hereof, and commanded her to do it. She therefore immediately went about it; and finding
Chariclea in Tears and Lamentations, nor only o, but contriving ome means to dipatch her elf, (for he now undertood what Theagenes uffer'd, though Cybele had long kept her in Ignorance, framing divers excues for his o long Abence) Fond Maid, aid he, will you never give over afflicting your elf without Reaon? Theagenes is well, and hall come to you this Evening: My Lady was angry for ome mitake that he committed in his Office, and caus'd him to be hut up, but this day he will be releas'd, which I alo entreated of her; for to day he is to celebrate a certain Fetival, after the manner of her Country. Rie therefore, compoe your elf, and now take ome Repat with me. What reaon have I to believe you, aid Chariclea? For it has been your continual practice to deceive me. I wear by the Gods, anwer'd Cybele, that this day all things hall be well with you, and you hall be freed from all your Cares: only do not before detroy your elf having now fated for o many days: Tate therefore of what is now et before you. Chariclea obey'd her, though not without upicion; but partly aenting to her Oath, and partly for Joy of what was told her: For the mind eaily believes what it earnetly deires. She therefore at down to eat. While the Attendant fill'd the Wine, Cybele beckon'd to her firt to give the Cup to Chariclea and after to her elf. But the Old Lady, before he
had drank to the bottom, pilling the ret, began to torm, and looking ternly upon the Waiter, was immediately enflam'd, and eiz'd with Convulions.

Chariclea was fill'd with horrour, and endeavour'd to lift her up; he likewie call'd the aitance of them that were preent; for the michief eem'd wifter than an Arrow, the Poyon being of o trong a Tincture, as to detroy the younget and tronget Contitution; but in a feeble and old Body it dipers'd it elf in a mimute through all the Vitals. The Convulions now remitting, he lay motionles, a blacknes overpreading her Skin. Though, I uppoe, her Rage, for being deceiv'd, gave no mall help to the ferment. For even now, breathing her lat, he did not intermit her frauds, but partly with igns, partly with broken words, perwaded them that Chariclea had Poyon'd her. At the ame minute that he gave up the Ghot, Chariclea was brought bound to Arace. She therefore demanding whether he had procur'd the Poyon, and affirming that if he deny'd, Tortures hould force her into Confeion, Chariclea became an unwonted pectacle to the Beholders. For without any meannes of Spirit, or concern in her Face, he enter'd miling into her Preence, partly out of Concience of her Innocence, and partly for Joy that he hould not urvive Theagenes, if he were dead; and alo becaue the
Death which he deign'd to perpetrate on her elf, was now to be perform'd by other hands. O Princes, aid he, if my Theagenes live, I am guiltles of this Action; but if he be dead, there is no need of calling Council, or inflicting Tortures, you may pare your elf that trouble: You have me here who detroy'd the peron that bred you up, kill me therefore without delay. You can do nothing more grateful to Theagenes, who has reited your impious ollicitaitons.

Arace was enrag'd hereat, and commanded her to be truck: Carry, aid he, this Victim, bound as he is, to let her Lover ee how gloriouly he returns his Contancy; command Euphrates to load her all over with Chains, and leave them together, till the Perian Magitracy hall be aembled to morrow for her Condemnation. By this time the Maid that erv'd the Wine was brought in: She was an Ionian Slave, and the ame that by Arace was appointed to wait on Chariclea. Whether therefore he was mov'd with kindnes to her, or by Divine Impulion, he igh'd and wept mot bitterly. O wretched Creature, aid he, and void of all Crime! The tanders-by being in wonder hereat, and urging her to peak plainly, he confeed that he her elf gave the Poyon to Cybele, having receiv'd it firt from her, to adminiter it to Chariclea: That, whether it was through concern at o unwonted a
Practice, or whether mitaking the Signs of Cybele, ordering to miniter firt to Chariclea, he changed the Cups, and gave the Poyon to the Old Lady. She was therefore led to Arace, as thinking he hould pleae her in clearing Chariclea. But when he had given her this account, Arace commanded her alo to be taken into Cutody, as an Accomplice in the fact, and to be kept for the next days Seion. She alo ummon'd the Perian Magitrates, by Meengers, to be ready. When therefore they were at, early in the morning, Arace gave in her Accuation, telling all that had pat, condoling alo with Tears, the los of the peron that bred her, who was dearer to her than her life; appealing to the Judges with how much courteie he had treated the tranger, who in return had done her uch Injury. Chariclea anwer'd nothing to the Charge, but confet the Crime, affirming that he gave the Poyon, adding alo that he would likewie have taken off Arace, had he not been prevented. For having told her reolutions over-night to Theagenes, and conferr'd with him, he reolv'd to undergo any manner of Death, to depart from a life o full of trouble, of implacable Fortune, and endles Wanderings; he there bid him her lat farewel. The Bracelet and Jewels, with the ret that were expos'd with her, which he always ecretly preerv'd, he now placed next to her Body, carrying; as it were, with her the Rites of her Funeral,
She therefore own'd every Crime that was alledg'd, and more than were charg'd. For which reaon the Judges hardly forbore from inflicting the outmot Tortures, after the Perian manner; yet moved with her Youth and Beauty, they only entenc'd her to die by Fire. She was therefore eiz'd by the Guards, and hurry'd forth beyond the Walls, the Beadle continually crying out, That it was for Poyon that he uffer'd; a vat multitude from the City following them. Some of them had een her led to Tryal, others, by reaon of the rumour pread all over the City, came to have a view of her. Arace was alo preent, and at a Spectator on the Wall: For it would have troubled her not to have beheld Chariclea uffer. When therefore the Officers had raied a great Pile, and et Fire thereunto, Chariclea begg'd repite from thoe that led her, aying, That he would of her own accord acend the Pile. O Sun and Earth (he cryed out) O powers above, and you that below take Vengeance on wicked Souls, you are witnees that I am Innocent of all that is laid to my Charge. But that I my elf willingly ubmit to Death, for the intolerable troubles which I utain. Receive me therefore with favour. However, take vengeance of this Arace, for whoe crimes I uffer; he is an Adultres, and does this to deprive me of my Husband. When he had thus poken, the people thouted, ome aying, That he hould be reerv'd
for another Tryal, others endeavouring to recue her; in the mean time he acended the Pile, where for a long while he tood unhurt, the Fire rather circling about, than approaching her, erving only to make her Beauty more conpicuous, and adorning the Pile, as it were a Nuptial Bed. She paed from one part to another, admiring at what happen'd, and tempting Death, but in vain, for the flame till turn'd off from her. The Officers, in the mean time, omitted nothing on their part; Arace alo beckning to them from the Wall to do their duty; wherefore they heap'd on more combutible matter. Neither could they thus prevail. The Citizens were troubled, thinking there was ome Divine Aitance, and cry'd out, That he was innocent. Several approaching to the Pile took off the Torturers, Thyamis beginning, and encouraging the people thereunto, (for the clamour had now brought him abroad.) Being therefore deirous to deliver Chariclea, they durt not themelves approach the Fire, but call'd to her to come out; for that there could be no danger for her to leave the Fire, who had continu'd therein without hurt. She hearing this, and judging herelf to be preerv'd by Divine Providence, would not be Ingrateful, and refue their favour: She therefore leapt down from the Pile. As the Multitude for Joy and Amazement houted out, Arace, not able to bear it, ran down from the Walls through a little Gate,
and with a trong Guard of Perians laid hands on Chariclea. Then looking ternly upon the People, Are you not aham'd, aid he, to recue from punihment a Woman that is a Witch and Poyoner by her own Confeion? While you give her aid, you do violence to the Perian Laws; to the Judges, Deputy, and King himelf. You are mitaken, in imputing her delivery to the Gods: Will you not come to your ences, and find that this is the effect of her Witchcraft, in which he has uch command, as even to retrain the power of Fire. Aemble therefore to morrow in Common Council, and you hall not only hear her Confeion, but alo thoe of her Accomplices, whom I have in Cutody.

Herewithal he led her away, herelf going next to her, and commanding the Guards to keep off the Crowd. But the People were enrag'd, part of them had thoughts of reitance, part of them having till ome upicion of her Witchcraft, and the ret fearing the Power of Arace. Chariclea therefore is once more deliver'd to Euphrates, and loaded with more Irons; reerved for a econd Sentence and Execution: But till bleing her fortune, in eeing Theagenes, and conferring with him about what had paed. For Arace had o order'd it, out of Malice, that the young pair might behold each others miery, and be mutually afflicted with each others ufferings: For he knew that the
torment of the peron belov'd, more affected the Lover than the party that uffer'd. But it was by them eteem'd as an Advantage, to ee each others Contancy. It was ome relief to convere together, and comfort one another with the conideration, that what they endur'd was upon the account of Truth and Vertue.

After they had till midnight dicours'd, in uch a manner as was proper for Lovers that were never more to talk together; they at lat talk'd of the Miracle that happen'd about the Fire. Theagenes imputed it to the kindnes of the Gods, who hewed their Indignation againt the unjut Decree of Arace; but Chariclea was doubtful. That Accident, aid he, eems to have come by Divine Providence, but to be reerv'd only for greater Misfortunes, cannot proceed from the Gods, unles they have ecretly decreed to give relief at the greatet Extremity.

Theagenes advis'd her to think more honourably of the Divine Powers: Be propitious to us, O ye Deities, aid he! Was it a Dream or Reality, which now comes into my mind? it happen'd the lat night but one; I know not how I came to forget it, but it now returns to my Memory. The Dream was a Vere which Calairis eem'd to expound. The words were thee:
Thee from the Flame Pantarbe's Pow'r hall guard
Strange Force! but nothing to the Gods is hard.

Theagenes now eem'd inpir'd, and leap'd forth as far as his Chains would permit, crying, Be merciful to us, ye Gods. For I further remember another Oracle deliver'd to me by a like Prophet (whether it were Calairis, or ome God is his form) containing thee Words:
You with the Nymph hall Aethiop reach, and be
To morrow from Arace's Bondage free.

That which concerns me herein, I undertand; for thoe Manions of the Dead underground, eem, proper to the Land of Aethiopia: By the Maid, I uppoe, Proerpine is meant, with whom I hall inhabit; and my freedom from Chains, my departure from this Body. But what can the Rhime contain concerning you, which conits of Contradictions? for wherea Pantarbe ignifies fearing all things, yet it commands not to fear the Flame. Then, aid Chariclea, continuance of calamities, my Theagenes, makes perons hope thhe wort in all things; for people uually accommodate their Minds to their Fortune: But I have better hopes of this Prophecy than you. What if I am the Nymph with whom you are to arrive into Aethiopia, after you have ecaped from
the Bonds of Arace? But how that hall be, is neither manifet nor credible to us, but to the Gods it may be poible: Let them take care of that who gave the Prophecy. That part which related to me you have already een accomplihed in my wonderful preervation. And though at that time I knew not that I carry'd my afeguard about me, yet I now undertand that I did. Thoe precious things that were expos'd with me in my Infancy, I have always accutom'd to carry conceal'd about me, to upply our neceities when brought to the lat difficulty; but if Death hould overtake me, to anwer the Charge of my Funeral. Amongt thee, Theagenes, there are Bracelets of great value, with Indian and Aethiopian Stones, with a certain Ring given by my Father to my Mother, in which is the Stone call'd Pantarbe, et in a Square, with Sacred Letters about it. It eems to have ome Divine Virtue in it, by which it repell'd the power of the Flames, preerving thoe that carry it, from any hurt. I conjecture, and know o much, by what was uggeted by the Divine Calairis, who told me, That the ame was expreed in the Writings that were found with me. This eems probable, aid Theagenes, by the Deliverance that you have had; but what Pantarbe hall defend us from to morrows danger? For though it hould till defend from the Fire, it cannot give Immortality; and Arace's Malice will contrive
ome more violent means to detroy us. And would to Heaven that the ame ort of Death, and in the ame hour, would dipatch us both! I hould think this Death but a Releae from all our ufferings. Take heart, aid Chariclea, we have another Pantarbe promis'd in the Oracle.

While they were employ'd in thee Coniderations, each affirming, That the others miery more afflicted them than their own: obliging themelves, by mutual Oaths, to preerve their Loves and Vertue to Death. It being now in the very dead of night, Bagoas, with his fifty Hore, arriv'd at Memphis. When they had waken'd the Sentinels, and had given account of themelves, they were immediately receiv'd into the Deputies Palace. Bagoas left this Company without, to guard the Houe, to be ready for his Defence, if any Reitance were made.
