He himelf, in the mean time, went a private way, eaily forcing the Doors, and commanding Silence, to the place where Euphrates was, the Moon not being yet quite et; finding him therefore in Bed, he awaken'd him, who in diorder cry'd out, Who are you? It is I, aid Bagoas, command a light to be brought in. He therefore order'd the Boy that waited on him, to bring in a Taper, o as to diturb none of the ret. When this was done, and the Boy departed, What Michief, aid Euphrates, has occaion'd this untimely and unexpected Arrival?
There needs not many words, aid Bagoas, read thee Letters, but before take notice of the Seal, and know that Oroondates ent them; and that it is as much as your Life is worth, not to perform what they import.

When Euphrates had run over the Letters; As for Arace, aid he, he will be orry, having yeterday fallen into a Fever, which till continues o violent, that there is mall hope of her Life. But for my part, I would not deliver thee Letters to her, though he herelf ask'd for them; for I know he would detroy both her elf and us, before he would end away the young Pair. Know however, that you are come in good time to take them away, and mut therein ue your utmot endeavour. Take compaion on them, they having uffer'd a hundred Tortures, unwillingly inflicted by me, but enjoyn'd by Arace. They eem however of Noble Birth, and for the Experience that I have had of them, of Vertuous Coveration. Having aid this, he brought him to the Prion, where Bagoas no ooner beheld them, though wated with Watchings and Torture, yet he was atonihed at their Stature and Beauty. But they uppoing that Bagoas was come at that ilent time of the Night, to lead them to a Clandetine Execution, were a little troubled. But oon recovering a chearful countenance, they made it appear how little they were concern'd. Euphrates now coming up, and knocking out
the Wooden Peg with which their Irons were joyned, Take your Sacrifice, Arace, he cry'd out: She thinks in night and darknes to conceal her horrid Crime, but the Eye of Jutice is harp in dicovering and bringing to Light the Deeds of Darknes. Do you execute what you are commanded, and whether Fire, Sword, or Water is determin'd againt us, let us only have the ame Death. Chariclea deired the ame. The Eunuchs weeping, led them forth in their Chains. When they were come out of the Deputies houe, Euphrates tarid there. But Bagoas, with his fifty Hore, having taken off their Bonds, and left only what might ecure, but not burden them; mounting them on everal Hores, and putting them in the middle of the Guards, made towards Thebes as fat as he could. When they had travell'd all the ret of the night, and till nine the next morning, without any top, the Sun then growing hot, they could proceed no farther, being pent alo for want of Sleep, Chariclea epecially; they determin'd therefore to take up omewhere to ret themelves, and refreh their Hores. There was a certain Valley at the foot of a Promontory of the Nile, almot urrounded with the Water, which made an Eddy: There was much Gras and Herbage on the place, as being always well Water'd, every where haded with Sycamore Trees, and uch others as grow on the Banks of the Nile: The Bagoas, with his Company, took up,
uing the Trees for a Tent, he at down with the ret to feed, compelling alo Theagenes and Chariclea to do the ame. They thought it needles for perons that were preently to die; but he perwaded them there was no uch thing intended; That they carry'd them not to Death, but to Oroondates. But now the Heat of the day decreaing, the Sun being no longer over their Heads, but faln Wetward, and beating on their ides, while Bagoas was going to take Hore again, a certain Hore-man in a weat, and out of breath with hard Riding, came up, and took him aide to peak with him: He fixing his Eyes upon the ground, as it were, full of thought concerning what had been told him: Take Comfort, Strangers, aid he, your Enemy Arace is dead by her own hand, undertanding that you were taken away, preventing a neceary, by a voluntary Fate: For he would never have ecaped punihment from Oroondates, or the King; and if he had not been put to Death, at leat mut have led the remainder of her Life in Digrace. Euphrates ends me this Intelligence. Wherefore be of good Hope, for I am well aur'd that you have done no body wrong, and he that injur'd you is Dead. Thus pake Bagoas in imperfect Greek; adding alo, That he himelf was glad, having uffer'd under the Tyranny of Arace: Wherefore he the more encourag'd his Prioners: For he hop'd that Oroondates would be pleas'd with his ervice, if he
carry'd them afe to him; the Youth being likely to grace his Retinue, and the Virgin, o matchles Beauty, would probably be made his Wife, ince Arace was dead. Theagenes and Chariclea rejoyced at the News, highly praiing the Jutice of the Gods; nor did they think they could afterwards be much ditres'd, whatoever Fortune hould befal them, ince their mot inveterante Enemy was gone. When now the Evening drew on, with a cool breeze, inviting them to et forward, they mounted again, and rode all that night and part of the next morning, if poible, to overtake Oroondates, before he went from Thebes. But they met with a Souldier from the Army, who told them Oroondates was gone from thence, having ent him to draw out all the Garrions, and haten with them to Syene, all things being in diorder, and fearing let the City hould be taken. For the Deputy coming too late, the Aethiopians had marched their Army thither with uch peed, that prevented the news of their approach: Bagoas therefore turn'd off from his intended Journey, and took the next Road to Syene. But approaching to the Town, they happen'd upon a Party of Aethiopians, who were ent as Spies to ecure the Paes for the Army.

But by reaon of the night, and their unacquaintance with the Country, (for they were order'd to plant an Ambucade in every place which they found convenient) they poted
themelves amongt certain Buhes by the River ide, partly for afeguard, and partly for concealment from their Enemies: And here they tood upon their Watch. Therefore at break of day, when they perceiv'd Bagoas, with his Hore-men to pas by them, and were aured there were no more to follow, they iued from their Covert, with loud houts. Bagoas therefore, and his company, urprized with the noie, knowing them, by their colour, to be Aethiopians, and eeing their number too great to be encountred, (for there were in all a thouand ent out for Scouts) he fled, without once looking them in the face; yet no o fat at firt as he could have done, but o as to preerve his Order. The others puru'd, ending out two hundred of their Troglodytae.

The Troglodytae are a people of Aethiop addicted to Patures, and Borderers on Arabia, who have wonderful wiftnes both by Nature and Exercie from their Childhood. They are not us'd to heavy Arms, they therefore ue Slings in fight to wound the Enemy at ditance, and trut to their heels when they find themelves over-power'd. They know 'tis impoible for the Enemy to overtaken them, till they can hide themelves in Rocks and Caves. Thee therefore purued on foot, dicharging their Slings, but not being able to tand againt the Hore, return'd to their own Party. But by freh numbers iuing out upon then, the Perians are catter'd,
Bagoas himelf thrown from his Hore; and taken. Theagenes and Chariclea partly thinking it unworthy not to ait Bagoas, (who had us'd Civility to them, and to whom they were likely to have been farther obliged) leapt down to uccour him, but to no purpoe, not being Arm'd. This is my Dream, aid Theagenes to Chariclea, and thee the Aethiops, into whoe Country I was to be carry'd. I therefore hold it better to ubmit our elves to them, rather than experience a doubtful fortune with Oroondates. Chariclea undertood the ret, the Accident now leading her, as it were, by the Hand, judging them rather to be Friends than Enemies. Yet he told not her entiments to Theagenes, only aid that he was contented to do o. When therefore the Aethiopians came up, and knew Bagoas, by his Face, to be an Eunuch, and the Perons that were unarm'd, of mot beautiful frame, they asked them, Who they were, both by an Aegyptian and Perian, as not doubting but that they undertood the one or other Language. Wherefore Theagenes, who had Aegyptian enough to anwer hort Quetions, told them, They were chief Servants to the Perian Deputy, but themelves Grecians, taken Prioners by the Perians, but now, they hoped with better fortune, put into the hands of Aethiopians. They therefore reolv'd to pare them, and carry them Captive to their King, as the firt Booty of the War, and the mot eminent
Ornaments of the Perian Court. For the Eunuchs are the Eyes, and Ears of the Perian Court, as having neither Children nor Kindred, on whom to place their Affection, and are therefore wholly devoted to the Interet of their Mater, on whom they depend. But for the young Pair, they reckon'd that they would be no mall Grace to their Kings Palace. They therefore et them all upon Hores, Bagoas being diabled, by his Wound, from walking, Theagenes and Chariclea weary'd with their Chains.
This eem'd the beginning of an Interlude, in which the perons that were now in expectation of udden Death, were no longer Captives, and thoe that had them in Cutody, themelves made Prioners.

div.head: THE AETHIOPIAN HISTORY.
The Ninth Book.
div.p:
SYene was now almot urrounded in Siege, as it were in a Net, by the Aethiopian numbers. For Oroondates hearing of the Enemies approach, left Cataractae, and went with his Forces to Syene, which he enter'd, hutting up the Gates, and planting Slings and Engines on the Walls, conjecturing that which afterwards happen'd. While therefore the Aethiopian King, at ome ditance, was inform'd by his Spies that Oroondates was making to the Town, he haten'd his March to prevent him, but however came too late. He then planted his Army round the City, and o without
any Engagement, fat as it had been in a Theatre. He brought with him ix hundred thouand men, and Cattel, with which he cover'd all the ground about Syene. The Spies finding him there, brought their Captives before him. He was not only delighted with their Beauty, but with the good Omen of having Prioners in Chains et before him. Behold! aid he, the Gods at our firt Arrival end us Slaves in Bonds. Thee perons therefore being the firt fruits of our War, hall be kept in Cutody till our return, then to be offer'd to our Gods in our Triumphal Sacrifices, according to the Ancient Laws of our Country. Having therefore rewarded the Spies, he gave the Prioners into the cloe cutody of perons that could peak their Language; giving them great Charge to treat them with Repect and Care; to upply them with the bet Proviion, and above all, to preerve them from all Contamination, becaue they were reerved for Victims: Latly, That their Bonds of Iron hould be taken off, and Fetters of Gold put upon them: For Gold amongt the Aethiopians is made ue of for all things that Iron is amongt other Nations.

This was done as he commanded. When therefore the former were taken off, and the Golden Chains put on, Theagenes miling, aid, What means this plendid Change? Fortune flatters us, in rendring us rich by our Captivity,
ince we are only Captives of greater Price. Chariclea alo miled, and deired him to conceive better hopes of what the Gods fore-told. Hydapes now attacking the City, and thinking to carry it at firt onet, found himelf deceived, the Beieged o manfully reiting his Forces, and beating them off; adding alo Scoffs and Contumelies. He was therefore enraged that they o much as offer'd to reit, and did not urrender themelves on the firt Attack: He reolved to loe no time, or make uch a Siege, whereby ome might be taken, and ome ecape; but at once to overthrow the whole City by an inevitable Detruction.

He thus order'd the Word: He made a Ditch about the Ground that lay next to the Walls, (yet at uch ditance that the Slings and Arrows from the Town could not reach it) appointing ten Men to every ten Yards, to be dug of a ufficient breadth and depth; ome therefore broke the Earth, while others receiv'd the Mold, which they piled up on that ide of the Trench that was next his Camp, which erv'd as a Counter-Fortres to the Town: None from thence offer'd to molet the Work, not daring to ally forth againt uch Numbers; and their Slings not throwing o far, as the ditant pace reach'd between the two Walls. Having preently finih'd this affair, by multitude of hands, he began another Project. When this Round Ditch was compleated, he left part of it without
cating up a Bank, and from thence made another Trench, that turned off to the River Nile, (which Trench he banked up on both ides) when therefore he had joined the foreaid Banks to thoe of the River, breaking down the Fence, as it were, by opening a Sluce, he let the Stream into his Trench, which by the decent from the River to that lower Channel, made uch a dreadful noie, that it was heard at a vat ditance. When the Citizens heard and aw into what ditres they were brought by this Inundation, which preently over-ran the Plain between the Walls, and the Enemy, preventing their Ecape, and that it was equally dangerous to tarry, they et themelves to do all that was poible for perons in uch exigence. In the firt place, as the Wood-work of their Gates began to give way, the topt up the Chinks with Straw and Pitch, etting props and weights againt them; they alo ran up Buttrees to upport their Wall. One brought Earth, another Stones, a third Straw, and whatever they could get together; no Hands were unemploy'd, Women, Children, and Old Age et themelves to the work: for o general and preing a Calamity excued none. But to the more Youthful, Orders were given to make a ubterranean Paage to the Enemies Bulwark.

The Work was performed after this manner. They firt unk a Pit, five yards deep perpendicular, then by the help of Torches, they dug
trait before them, a paage to the Enemies Banks; thoe that were behind till in order receiving the Earth from them that were before; which was convey'd into the City-Garden, and there laid on a heap. This they did, with deign that when the Water hould fall into this Cavern, it hould force it elf a paage out another way. But they were prevented, for the Nile fell o plentifully into the Upper Channel, that the pace between the two Walls was now a tanding Lake, o that Syene, an inland Town, was now turn'd into an Iland, quite urrounded with Water. The Wall utain'd the weight thereof for one whole day, but when it was welled higher, and alo had unk underneath the foundation, the ground being oft and pungy, it then in everal place began to yield, and threaten a Delugen on the City.

The next Evening, a Part that was between two Towers, fell down; yet not o as to lye below the Flood, but o as preently to threaten an Inundation: Upon which a great Cry was et up amongt the Inhabitants, that reach'd to the Enemies Camp; and with hands lift up towards Heaven, beeech'd the aitance of the Gods. They beought Oroondates to end Meengers to beg Peace with Hydapes. He was forced to ubmit, but being hut in with the Waters, no Meengers could pas: He therefore faten'd Petitionary Letters to Stones, which he threw from Slings, but to no purpoe,
for the ditance prov'd too great to permit their coming home; he then try'd by way of Arrows, while the Archers and Slingers vved with each other, but till in vain: In the lat place, they tretch'd forth their hands towards the Enemies Bulwark in uppliant manner, to ignifie what they intended by their hootings; and ometimes put them behind their Backs, to hew that they were willing to receive their Chairs. Hydapes undertood their Signals, and was inclin'd to Acceptance: For the ubmiion of an Enemy commands Clemency from generous Minds. But he firt thought fit to make tryal of what they meant, in order whereunto he elected ten Boats, which fell down to his Bankide, from the breach of the Nile; into thee he put Archers and armed men, with Commands, as the thought fit, and ent them over to the Perians. They therefore told them, That if they had any Hope or Confidence left, they hould prepare for Fight. It was a new Spectacle on an inland Soil, to ee Boats rowing from Wall to Wall, over cultivated Grounds. It was yet a greater wonder to ee a Naval Army torming a Town, and Land Souldiers contending with them. They therefore that were in the Town, eeing Ships, with Armed Men, approaching that part of their Wall which was broken down, were eiz'd with terrour, (as people in great ditres and extremity are always upicious.) They hurl'd Stones from the Walls,
and hot Arrows into the Boats, that came for their preervation. Thus Men that depair of Life, yet reckon it as an advantage, for a while to delay their Fate. Yet they o order'd their buines, as not to wound, but only to keep them off. The Aethiopians likewie dicharg'd their Arrows, not knowing the intentions of the Perians; by which means everal of the wounded fell down headlong from the Wall into the Water. The War therefore grew hot, till a certain Illutrious Peron of Syene coming between, intercepted thoe that were on the Wall, by peaking on this manner: O frantick Men, aid he, and grown tupid with Calamity, do we repel thoe perons whoe Aid we o lately begg'd, and make War with them at the intant of their coming to relieve us, beyond our expectation? If they come with a friendly mind, declaring matter of Peace, they are our Preervers: if with hotile intentions, you will eaily vanquih them, though they were arrived to the very Wall. But to what purpoe (if we regard our afety) hould we detroy thee, when we are environ'd with uch a Sea, and vat numbers behind? Why do we not therefore receive them, and know for what purpoe they are ent? His Judgment was approved by all, the Deputy himelf applauding it; they then eparated themelves, and ceaed from any further Action.

When the paage for the Ship-men was clear, and the Townmen, by White Flags, ignifying that they hould have free Landing; the Aethiopians went nearer, and from their Veels, as it were o many Pulpits in a Theatre, they poke in this manner; O Perians, and Inhabitans of Syene,, know that Hydapes, King of the Eatern and Wetern Aethiopia, and at preent alo yours; as he knows how to Conquer, he likewie undertands how to hew Mercy: That is the part of Courage, but this of Humanity. The one he accounts the Vertue of a Souldier, the other peculiar only to himelf. Whereas therefore he has your Lives in his power, either to give, or take them away; but ince you are uppliant, he offers you deliverance, without the ruine of War. Moreover, he does not impoe the terms of freedom upon you, but leaves you your elves to chooe them: For he governs not the Fortunes of Men by Tytanny, but Clemency. To this Meage the Syeneans anwer'd, That they would deliver Themelves, Wives and Children, into his Power, to deal with them as he pleaed: That they wold likewie deliver the City into his hands, if they urviv'd, which in that extremity was uncertain, unles their Detruction was prevented by Hydapes. Oroondates offer'd to urrender Philae and the Smaragdan Mines, which were the occaion of the War, but deired that he would exact no more from him, nor require
him to reign up himelf or his Souldiers. But if Hydapes were pleas'd indeed to exercie Humanity, That he would uffer thoe that made no reitance to depart to Elephantina; for that is were the ame thing for him to die now, as to be afterwards put to death, by his King, for giving up his Army: Nay, it would be much wore, ince the preent would be only a ingle, and uual ort of Death, but the other with the everet kind of Torment.

When the Legates heard this, they turn'd their Prows, and related all to Hydapes. He miling, and much reproving the folly of Oroondates, to init upon Terms, who yet depended on another perons pleaure, whether he hould live or die: Yet, aid he, it is not jut, for the offence of one man, to uffer o populous a City to be detroy'd. Wherefore he permitted thoe that were with Oroondates to depart, though they carce forbore from Reitance. He therefore ordered ome of his own Men to damm up the breach in the Bank of Nile, and to others to break down part of what he raied. That by means of the Inlet of Nile being topped, and paage made for the Water that was taken in, to go away, Syene might be the ooner made dry. They therefore etting cloe to the work, finihed it by the next day.

Nor did they that were within the Town pare their pains, not depairing of preservation, though beyond hope. They therefore made
Suffs under ground, to receive and carry off the Water. Others brought props to the Walls, which they eaily did, heaping the Stones which from the ruines fell into the Town. But after they thought themelves afe enough on this account, yet they were not without Apprehenion; in the middle of the night, a certain part of the Bulwark, which the Aethiopians in the Evening had begun to dig down, (whether it were that that part was more looely heaped up, o as to let Water ink into the Foundation, or whether it broke the ides, being almot dug through, when the Work-men were gone, or whether it happen'd by Divine Will) beyond all expectation, if fell down, with o great a noie, that both Armies were atonihed, both Aethiopian and Syeneans concluding the Town-walls to be tumbled down at once: But thee being ecure, continu'd in their Tents, remaining atisfy'd to know what it hould be, when day-light was return'd. But the Citizens ran every where to their Walls, and as every one aw his own part entire, concluded the ruine was on ome other ide; till the breaking day dipell'd their fears, when they aw where the Breach was, and that the Waters were paed away. But now the Aethiopians diverted the Flood, making Cataracts, which they propt with Timber, lining them alo with Mud and Straw, which the multitude of hands eaily brought together. Thus the Waters paed
away entirely, yet was there no paage to each other, for the depth of Mud which remain'd, which, thought it eem'd dry and cruted above, yet it continued moit at bottom, o that neither Men nor Hore could pas, without being foundred therein.

Thus the time paed for two or three days; The Townmen, by etting open their Gates, and the Aethiopians, by laying down their Arms, mutually declaring Peace. This Truce was more remarkable, becaue it was without Conference of the Parties, and neither of them et any Watch. They that were in Town gave themelves to Patimes, for it happen'd then to be the Fetival of Nile, which is accounted the greatet of any among the Aegyptians; which is celebrated at the entrance of the Summer Soltice, when the River firt begins to well; and for that reaon this Solemnity is held by them in greatet Honour. The Aegyptians uppoe Nilus to be a God, and the mot Supream, his Stream vying with the Coeletial River, becaue it waters their Fields without Rain, or Aitance from Heaven; it elf upplying the want of howers with its yearly overflow. Thee are Vulgar Traditions. But a likelier reaon of giving him this Divine Honour, is their reckoning the Copulation of hot and moit, the caue not of generation, but preervation of Man; and that the Nile upplies the Moit, and their Earth the Dry. Yet thee are
alo Vulgar Conceptions: But the mot skilful in Myteries, ay that Iis ignifies the Earth, and Oyris the Nile, changing the names for the things. That therefore the Goddes burns with Deire of him, and always rejoyces at his return; and he being retired, laments again, as truck with blating Lightning. This fiction their Divines have framed, as I uppoe, becaue they would not have their Myteries pryed into by profane perons.

Let this uffice for the preent; for our of Reverence we alo forbear to mention their deeper Myteries. We will therefore return to the Tranactions of Syene. This Fetival Day being rien, the Natives apply'd themelves to the killing of Sacrifices; though their Bodies were over-labour'd with their Ditrees, yet their Minds were never the les active for the ervice of their God. But Oroondates watching his opportunity, in the dead of the Night, when the Townmen, after their Banquets, were bury'd in Sleep, by tealth led out his Army, having an hour before given the charge of that Gate, through which he meant to pas, to Perian Centries. Command was given to the Officers to leave all their Hores behind them, that they might be no incumbrance, nor by their Noie dicover what was done; but every man to take his Armour, and a Board or Plank along with them.

After they were thus aembled at the Gate, they cat down the Planks which each had brought, placing them along in uch Order that the one touched the other, the lat till handing them to thoe that went before; by which means, as with a Bridge, they paed afely over the Slime. Coming to dry ground, (the Aethiopians upecting no uch thing, nor keeping any Watch) they marched with all poible peed by them, towards Elephantina. And without any obtacle, were received into the Town, by reaon of two Perians, that (as it was agreed between them) at upon the Walls, to expect their coming at that time of the night, who accordingly et open the Gates for their Entrance. At the break of Day, the people of Syene perceiv'd the Perians were fled, every one miing him that lodged in his Houe: They were further inform'd by conferring together, and latly, by the Bridge of Boards, which they found laid over the Ooze. Once more therefore they were eized with Terrour and Conternation, that they hewed o little Faith to Hydapes, after having o much experienced his Clemency, in permitting the Perians to ecape. They therefore reolved with one Voice, to go out of the City, and urrender themelves to the Aethiopians, with Oaths of their Ignorance, if poibly they might obtain Mercy. Being therefore all gather'd together, of both Sex, and all Ages, with Boughs in their
hands, and lighted Tapers, to hew their ubmiion, bearing the Images of their Gods before them. When they had paed the Bridge, they fell on their knees, at ditance, before the Aethiopians, and, as it were, at a Signal given, et up a general and lamentable Cry, deprecating Punihment by their humble Poture. Latly, to move the greater Compaion, they et down their Children before them, permitting them to go which way they would, mollifying the Rage of the Aethiopians, by the Age, free from all upicion of Deceit. The Infants therefore, with Conternation, through Ignorance of what was done, and frighted with the foreaid Lamentation, ran away from their Parents, towards the Aethiopians; others, not of growth to follow, fell on their faces, and lay crying on the Ground; Fortune even in them hewing the poture of Suppliants, begging Mercy.

p.U:
eeing this, and uppoing that they came only in a more humble and earnet manner to upplicate, ent Meengers to know the meaning; and why they came without the Perians? They inform'd him of all, the flight of the Perians, their Innocence, the Fetival, and how, after the Banquet, being poes'd with Sleep, the Perians ecaped; whom yet they could not have hinder'd, had they known thereof. Hydapes believing what was told to him, upecting what afterwards happen'd, the Treachery of Oroondates, calling only their Priets
to him, with the Gods, which they brought for the greater olemnity, conjur'd them thereby to tell if they knew any thing of the Perians Deigns; Whither they were gone, or in what they placed their greatet Trut? They anwer'd, They knew not for certain, but conjectur'd that they were gone to Elephantina, where the greatet Party of their Army were gather'd together: Oroondates putting his greatet Trut in his Bard Hore.

div.p: When they had thus upplicated, Hydapes did not think fit to enter the City, but ent two Companies to earch if there were any Treachery in the buines, and if they found none, to continue there as a Garrion. Having therefore diinied the Townmen with gracious Promies, he drew forth his Army in Battel aray, to receive the Perians, if they came out againt him; and if not to et upon them. Nor had he put them into a readines before he was inform'd that the Perians were on their way toward him. Oroondates having drawn the greatet part of his Forces to Elephantina, was forced himelf with a few to take into Syene, as we have already hewn, where he receiv'd Mercy of Hydapes; yet was he o full of guile, as to withdraw to his foreaid Army, placing all his hopes in Celerity, and thinking to come upon Hydapes unprovided.

When the two Armies were now in ight of each other, the Perian Pride was hewn, dazling
the whole Field with Golden and Silver Arms, for the Sun then riing full upon the Perians, reflected from them, like Lightning, to a great ditance. The Medes and Perians made up the Right Wing, their Armed Men going before, and the Archers bringing up the Rear, that being eas'd from the Incumbrance of Armour, they might more dextrouly hoot their Arrows, protected by the Armed Body. He placed his Aegyptian and African Companies on the Left Wing, adding alo Archers and Slingers, whom he commanded to make Excurions, and gall the Enemies Flank. He himelf came with the Main Body, plendidly eated on a Chariot, with Guards on each ide for his ecurity, his Bard Hore being ranked before him, in which he put his greatet trut; in his poture he adventured to begin the Battel. For this Party was mot Warlike, and like a Wall or Bulwark, planted before the ret of his Army.

The manner in which they were Armed was thus: A choen peron, of great Strength and Stature, put on a Helmet, with a Face made to it, exactly reembling that of a Man: This covered the Head all down to the Shoulders, places only being left open for the Eyes: His Right Hand held a Weapon bigger than a Spear, while their Left was free to manage the Reins; a Sword hanging by his ide; not only his Breat, but his whole Body was covered with Armour,
joined with Scales of Iron and Bras, in form of a quadrangle; one being laid waving over the other; which thus by degrees went to their extremity, the Plates being firmly riveted together, yet framed o as to it without any Incumbrance to the Body, and every where plying to it: Every joint thereof turning on Wire, and extending or contracting with the motion of the Peron. Thus was it wrought from the Head to the Knee, a vacancy being only left for the inide of their Thighs, that at next to their Hore. Such is the Fabrick thereof, that it repels all manner of Darts or Spears. From the Foot there was an Iron Boot, that at the Knee joined curiouly with the Armour. In the ame manner they alo Armed their Hores, ecuring their Legs, while their Head to their Cret is entirely Armed, a Covering of Iron Plates thrown over his Back, falling down on each ide to his Flank, yet o looe as not to incumber his going, while it gave him protection. The Man being thus equipp'd, and, as it were, cat in Armour, is lifted up upon his Hore, not being able, by reaon of the weight, to mount himelf. When the Fight is begun, giving the Reins to his Hore, and clapping Spurs to them, he ruheth upon the Enemy, as it were a Tempet.

The Pike, near to the part where a long Steel Blade comes out, is faten'd to the Hores Neck, by which means it is upported; it is alo hung
at the other end by Thongs to the Hores Shoulder, in uch manner as not to hinder, but ait the Hand of the Peron that directs it: So that by the Hores motion, the force is encreaed; by which means two or three at a time are often born upon the Poin.

The Deputy being thus provided, and his Forces drawn up in this manner, left the River on his Back, being much les in number than the Enemy, which erved him for a Wall, to keep him from being urrounded. Hydapes, on the other ide thus order'd his Battel: Againt the Perians and Medes, in the Right Wing, he placed his Souldiers from Meroe, skilful in tanding Fight; as alo the Troglodytae, with thoe of the Neighbouring Country, from which Cinnamon is brought, in light Arms, and wift of foot, to engage the Adveraries Left Wing. But undertanding the Perians middle Ranks to be their chief trength, he oppoed to them himelf, with Elephants bearing Towers, joining to them the Blemmii and Seri, with Intructions what to do when they were engaged.

When Signals on both ides were given, by the Perians with Trumpets, by the Aethiopians with Hammers and Kettle-drums. Oroondates encouraging his Party, led them on. Hydapes commanded his Men to advance flowly at firt, that the Elephants might keep up with them, and alo that the Perian Hore in the middle might be diorder'd, before the whole Bodies
were join'd. When they were now within the Cat of a Dart, and the Blemmi perceiv'd the Bard Hore of the Enemy to come on fiercely, they oberv'd what had been commanded by Hydapes, the Seri being left to guard the Elephants, they made up peedily before the ret, againt the Bard Hore, who thought them ditracted, being o few in number, to et upon a Party o well Armed. The Perians likewie purred up fater, to take advantage of their nahnes, not doubting to dipatch them at the firt Encounter.

Then the Blemmi, when they were come hand to hand, as it were at one ign, unk down all together, etting one Knee to the ground, and putting their Heads and Backs under the Hores Bellies, receiv'd no harm, but from their treading ometimes upon them. But they perform'd what was beyond all expectation, tabbing the Bard Hore up into their Bellies, which part alone was unarm'd: Wherefore not a few were cat off by their Hores, enraged with their wounds, whom the Blemmi tabb'd (as they lay on the ground) on the inide of their Thighs. For the Perian Cataphract is o incumbred with Armour, that he cannot tir, when once diimounted. Thoe that kept their Saddles were carry'd directly upon the Seri, who on their approach, retreated behind their Elephants, whoe vat Bodies erved them for a Bulwark. By this means there was great
Slaughter made of the Hore, inormuch that they were almot utterly cut off: For the Hores frighten'd with the ight of the Elephants, leaped and tarted, ome flying out one way, and ome another, putting their own party into diorder. They that at upon the Elephants (ix Archers being allotted to each Tower, whereof each Beat carry'd two) hot o fat from thence, that their Arrows eem'd a Cloud, and o exactly aim'd, that they generally wounded the Perians in the Eyes, who accordingly ran confuedly one amongt another. All that were born forward againt their wills by the mettle of their Steeds, came directly upon the Elephants.

They were therefore thus conumed, being partly trodden down by the Elephants, partly cut down by the Seri, making Excurions from behind their Elephants, as it were from an Ambucade. The few that ecaped, went off without any memorable performance, and not the leat hurt done to the Elephants. Thoe Beats are clad in Iron when they go to War, beide the natural hardnes of their Skin, overgrown with a tough Scurf or Scale, too firm for any Spear to pierce.

All being at length put to Rout, the Deputy himelf fied at lat mot hamefully on a Nyaean Hore, leaving his Chariot behind him. However thoe that were of his Left Wing were yet ignorant hereof, and tood toutly to their
work, though receiving more Wounds than they gave; utaining all difficulties: For the Troops from the Cinnamon Region, with whom they encountred, preed them very hard, and reduced them to the lat Ditres; flying off whenoever the others came on, far out-tripping them; yet hooting back, and wounding as they led: But as the others Retreated, came furiouly again upon them, galling their Flanks with Slings and little Darts, all which were notwithtanding Mortal, the Piles being dipped in Serpents Blood. They bear a round Cover on their Heads, tuck through with Arrows, the haft end whereof is placed next their Heads, the Pile, even to the Feathers, coming out above. Thus every one marches clattering to fight, expoing a naked Body to the Foe: Crowned, as it were, with Arrows, which have no Iron on their Points, nor have any need of it: By reaon that they are made of a Dragons Back-bone, an ell in length, the natural hardnes whereof being harpen'd at one end, erves for a point, from whence the Greeks call uch kind of Arrows, Bones. The Aegyptians notwithtanding tood along time to it, joining their Shields together, and utaining howers of Darts, though they were impatient of War, yet now either glory
ng in contempt of Death, or fearing the pu
hment of Revolters.

But when they knew the Cataphracts, the chief hope and trength of their Battel, were
fled, the very Perians, and Deputy himelf, withdrawn without any ignal performance (ave ome mall damage done to the Meroenes) but much more receiv'd, even they at lat gave over the Conflict, and turned their Backs.

Hydapes beholding the Victory from a Tower, raied high on an Elephant, ent after the Chaers, to bid them abtain from laughter, but to take as many alive as they could, epecially Oroondates. For the Aethiopians tretching their Wings in circular form, took in o vat a compas, as wholly to encloe the Perians; leaving only one paage open for them, and that was towards the River: Into which a great number of them, being forced by the Hore-men, Scyth-Chariots, and others preing upon them, found that the Stratagem which the Deputy had laid againt the Enemy, was unreaonable, and foolih: Foramuch, as while he kept the Nile on his Back, for fear of being urrounded, he was not aware that he cut off from himelf all poibility of flight. He therefore was taken Prioner amongt the ret.

Achemenes, the Son of Cybele, finding how affairs tood, endeavour'd treacherouly to kill him, (for he now repented himelf of the dicovery he had made touching Arace) ince the Arguments by which he was to prove it, were taken away) but diappointed of his expectation, the Wound which he gave Oroondates was not mortal. For which attempt however h
receiv'd punihment, being run through by a certain Aegyptian, who knew the Deputy, and would have kept him alive, according to the Command of his Mater.

The Deputy therefore was brought to Hydapes by the peron that took him: He therefore eeing him fainting, caus'd his Blood to be tanch'd, determining, if he could, to preerve him, alo confirming his purpoe with thee words: That you are preerv'd by my good will, is jut and fit; for it is the buines of generous Enemies, to overcome an Enemy that reits with Courage; and when fallen, to upport them with Mercy: But what reaon was there to make you o perfidious? To you indeed perfidious, reply'd Oroondates, but true to my Mater. Hydapes farther asked him, Since he was overcome, what punihment he determined upon himelf? Such, anwered he, as my Mater would inflict on one of your Commanders, that had been faithful to you. Certainly, aid Hydapes, he would praie, and end him back with Rewards, if he be a true King, and no Tyrant; and one that would be a Pattern for Princes. You ay you have acted faithfully, but if not foolihly too, in expoing the Lives of o many Thouands, do you your elf judge. It was not imprudent, replied he, conidering the temper of my King, who is much freer of his Punihment to the Cowardly, than Rewards to his Valiant Servants. I
therefore reolved on the danger of the Field, where I might either perform omething that was beyond expectation, as many opportunities happen in a Fight skilfully managed, (the event of War it elf being always uncertain) or, at leat, if I ecaped with life, to have excue left, nothing that was in my Power having been omitted.
Hydapes hereupon commended him, and ent him to Syene, with charge to the Phyicians to ue their bet endeavour for his Cure.

He alo went himelf, with the chief of his Army, the people from the Town, of all Ages and Qualities, meeting him on the way, cattering Flowers amongt his Souldiers, applauding his Vertue, and congratulating his Victory. When he was carry'd on his Elephant, into the Town, he immediately bent his mind to Divine Worhip, and rendring Thanks to the Gods. He demanded the Origine of the Nile, and if there was any thing in the City worth Sight or Admiration? They hewed him a Well, like to that which is at Memphis, made of Polih'd Stone, on which are drawn Lines, at an Ell ditance, the one above the other: Into this Citern the River Water being let, by Subterranean Paage, hews the Inhabitants the Encreae or Decreae of the Nile, riing or falling below uch or uch a Mark on the Stone. They likewie hewed him Gnomons of Horocopes, that at mid-day give no
hadow. The Sun being at the Soltice, perpendicular over Syene, inomuch that their deepet Wells are then illuminated. Hydapes was not much urprized at this, the ame being alo ound at Meroe in Aethicpia. They then told him of the Nile, extolling it with their praies, calling him the Son and Author of Plenty, the Preerver of Upper Aegypt, the Patron and Tiller of the Lower: Every year rolling down fertile Slime, from whence he is call'd Nile, by the Greeks; that is, the Ditinguiher for Seaons; his Flow hewing the Summer, his Ebb the Autumn, the Spring with Flowers; that the Nile indeed was nothing but the Year it elf: The Letters of whoe Numbers being computed, according to the Figures which they repreent, making three hundred ixty five Unities, according to the Days in a Year. When they had farther poken of the Nature and Properties of certain Plants, Flowers and Animals: Thee are not o much Aegyptian Relations (aid Hydapes) as Aethiopian. But whether this River be indeed a God, as you eteem him, and brings other Rivers along with him from Aethiop, he is duly worhipped by you. We both adore him for other reaons (anwer'd the Priets) and particularly for the preent favour of ending you to us, our God and Preerver.

Hydapes warned them to be moderate in their Praies of him; and pent the ret of the day in diverion, entring Banquet with the Aethiopian
Nobles, and Priets of Syene; and permitting all the ret to do the ame. The Syeneans, partly elling, and partly betowing on the Army vat Herds and Flocks, with Plenty of Wine.

The next day, itting on a Tribunal, he ditributed the Booty of the War amongt his Army, to every one according to his performance. When the peron that took Oroondates came before him, Demand what you will, aid Hydapes: There is no need (anwer'd he) of my demanding any thing more, if what I have already taken from Oroondates (whom I preerv'd, according to your Order) be adjudg'd to me by you. He therewith hew'd Oroondates Dagger, tudded with precious Stones of vat price, and worth many Talents of Gold; inormuch that the tanders-by cry'd out, That the fortune was too great for a private Man, and fitting only for the Kings Treaury. What therefore is more Kingly, aid Hydapes, than for me to preerve that greatnes of mind, as not to covet o great a Prize. The poil of a Captives Body by right belongs to him that takes him Prioner. Wherefore let him o depart, who perhaps had not granted us the ame favour, though we would never have received it.

Next came the perons who took Theagenes and Chariclea: O King, aid they, our Spoils are neither Gold nor Gems, which are of little price in Aethiopia, and pave the Royal Palaces; but whereas we have brought you a Grecian
Youth and Virgin, of incomparable Stature and Beauty, excelling all Mankind in Peron, your elf excepted; we beg alo to be partakers of your Munificence and Bounty. You ay well, anwer'd Hydapes, and I remember uch Perons, though I had but a traneant ight of them: Wherefore bring them with the ret, to our Preence. When the Meengers came for them, they ask'd, Wither they were to be carry'd? Before Hydapes, anwer'd they. Hydapes! O ye Guardian Angels, aid they; for as yet they were uncertain who was the Conquerour. Theagenes therefore aid oftly to Chariclea, Unfold the State of our Affairs to the King, ince Hydapes Reigns, whom you have often told me was your Father. O Dearet, aid he, great affairs need great preparations, for where the Gods have given intricate Beginnings, the Concluion mut be leiurely unravell'd: epecially, the firt Rie and Foundation of this Intrigue (I mean my Mother Perina) being abent, whom yet, by the Gods favour, we hear to be alive. But there is danger of our being Sacrific'd before that time, aid Theagenes. None at all, anwer'd he, for I have often heard our Keepers ay, we were reerv'd for Sacrifices to the Gods of Meroe: Wherefore there is no fear of our being Slain, or ent away to another Country, being already, by Vow, given to the Gods, which cannot be violated by any Pious Monarch. However,
though we hould flatter our elves with thee hopes, we hall imperfectly make out our Account, when the Perons are not preent, that can acknowledge and jutifie the Authorities which we produce. Wherefore there is danger, let through his Ignorance in the Evidences, we hould exapertate our Judge; who will think corn, that Captives detin'd for Sacrifice, hould preume to call themelves Children to the King. But your Tetimonials, reply'd Theagenes, which you have carefully preerv'd, will hew that it is no Forgery. The Credentials, aid Chariclea, are Credentials to them that expoed them, but to them that know them not, or at leat not all of them, they are no more than common Jewels and Bracelets; which alo may bring with them upicion of Theft. Or, uppoing that Hydapes acknowledge them, who is there to perwade him that Perina gave them or was Mother to the Child?

By this time they were come in ight of the King, Bagoas alo was brought along with them. Hydapes eeing them rais'd himelf a little from his Throne; and crying out to the Gods to be propitious, at down again. His Attendants asking what happen'd to him, and occaion'd that Start; This morning I imagin'd jut uch a Daughter to be born to me, and in a days time grown to her full Stature: And whereas I am no regarder of Dreams, I forgot it, but now on ight of her likenes it returns to my Mind.

They peruading him, that there were certain Images often form'd in the fancy, that betoken future realities; he nevertheles neglected the Viion, and ask'd them who, and what they were. Chariclea being ilent, and Theagenes anwering, That they were Greeks, and Kindred: Hail Greece, aid he, that furnihes us with uch Noble Sacrifices for our Triumph. Then miling to his Attendants aide, Why had I not a Son likewie born to me in my Dream, (aid he) if Dreams are, as you ay, Pictures of things to come? Then turning to Chariclea, and peaking to her in the Greek Tongue, (which is of high eteem amongt the Gymnoophits of Aethiopia,) But why, Virgin, are you ilent, aid he, and Anwer to no Interrogations? At the Altar of the Gods, anwer'd he, to whom we are detin'd Sacrifices, you hall know both me and my Parents. Hydapes again ask'd her, Of what Country? They are partly preent, aid he, and hall be altogether o at that time. Hydapes then mil'd, and aid, Certainly this Daughter of Viion, dreams her elf, in imagining to find her Grecian Parents in Meroe. Let them therefore be taken care of, to be made Ornaments of our Sacrifices. But who is this that tands next them, and eems to be an Eunuch? The Servants anwer'd, That he was indeed an Eunuch, and named Bagoas. Let him follow them, aid he, not to be himelf a Victim, but to take care of another Victim, this Virgin, that
he be preerv'd Immaculate for the Ceremony. Eunuchs are the bet Guards, for being deprived themelves of enjoying, they out of envy take care that no body ele hall.

He then urvey'd the remainder of Captives, and dipos'd of them, giving ome for Servants, whoe condition was formerly uch; but Perons that were of free Birth, he retored to Liberty. Ten Youths and as many Virgins of flourihing Beauty and fairet Stature, he appointed to attend Theagenes and Chariclea in their Detiny. Anwers being alo given to all others that brought any Claim. In the lat place, Oroondates was et before him; to whom Hydapes expret himelf, That ince he gain'd the points for which he made War, he was not affected like mot Monarchs; that he would not abue the kindnes of Fortune, to covet more than others; nor extend his Empire by his victory; that he was contented with the bounds which nature from the beginning had et, dividing Aethiopia from Aegypt by Cataracts. Wherefore having obtain'd what I came down for, I return an adorer of Equity. As for you, if you urvive, continue in your Office of Deputy; and tell the King of Peria, that his Brother Hydapes has overcome, but retores you to your Dignity, being deirous of Amity; but prepar'd to renew the War if provok'd thereunto: But enjoin that exemption from Tribute, for ten years be given to the Syeneans.

Having thus poken, both the Citizens and Souldiers applauded him with Shouts, that were heard at great ditance. Oroondates with his Hands tretch'd out, the Right interchangeably over the Left, bowed his Body forward with Adoration; which by the Perians is given only to their own King. Let me not be thought aid he to the tanders by, to violate the Cutoms of my Country, adoring my Retorer, who had both Power and Provocation to kill me. The Dignity that belongs to himelf by right of Conquet, he confers on me: For which, if I urvive, I hall always be an intrument of Peace, between the Aethiopians and Syeneans; but if I dye of thee Wounds, let the Gods return this Kindnes of Hydapes, both on himelf and his Poterity.

div.head: THE AETHIOPIAN HISTORY.
The Tenth Book.
div.p:
THus have we given account of what was tranacted about Syene, which after uch extremity, was retored by the Jutice and Clemency of the Conqueror. Hydepes now ending the greatet part of his Army before him, returns into Aethiopia: Both Perians and Syeneans following him with Congratulations and Prayers for his afety. He therefore took his journey by the Banks of Nile, and through the adiacent Countrys. But being come to Cataractae, after Sacrifices to Nile and the Tutelar Gods of the Borders, he turn'd off through the Midland Regions. When he
was arrived at Philae, he reted two days for Refrehment of his Souldiers; therefore once more ending the multitude before him, he himelf tarry'd in the Town, to repair the Walls and ettle a Garrion. Then chooing out two Meengers with orders to change their Hores, for dipatch on the Road, he ent them with Letters to inform his Friends at Meroe of his Victory.
To the Wie Men call'd Gymnoophits, who were of his Councel Royal, he wrote thus:

body.head: Hydapes to the Divine Aembly.
body.p: Thee are to acquaint you with our Victory, not boating of our Succes or Management (ince events of War are at the dipoal of Providence) but to expres our repect for you, requeting you to meet at the appointed place, and to grace our Sacrifices for our ucces with your preence.

div.p: To his Wife Perina he wrote as follows.

body.p: KNow that we are Conquerours, and what mot concerns you, afe in our Peron. Wherefore make preparation for Triumph, and Sacrifices of Thanks, and come with our Gymnoophits into the Field before the City, which is dedicated to the Gods of our Country; the Sun, Moon, and Bacchus.

div.p:
Having read thee Letters, this is the Sene of my Viion (aid Perina) for lat night in my Sleep, I fancy'd my elf deliver'd of a Daughter of full blown Beauty and Stature: The Pains ignifying the troubles of the War and the fair Offspring, the compleat Victory. By this time the City was fill'd with the news; the Meengers Riding through the principal Streets on white Hores and in white Vetments, being Crown'd with the Plants of Nile, and bearing Branches of Palm in their Hands, by their very Habits and Geture declaring their Meage. The City being thus fill'd with joy, they perrform'd Sacrifices Night and Day in their ditinct Tribes, Streets and Families, crowding the Temples; not o much for ake of the Victory, as for the afety of Hydapes: Whom for his Clemency and Jutice, they look'd upon as their Common Parent, as well as their King. Perina therefore having ent vat Herds and Flocks, with all manner of Beats and Fowl into the Sacred Field; partly to make Hecatombs therewith, and partly for Proviion, in the publick Feat, went to the Grove conecrated to Pan, the Reidence of the Gymnoophits, to whom he gave the Letters from Hydapes, deiring them to obey his Orders, and grace the Solemnities with their Preence. They entreated her to tay a while without, while they went into the Oratory, to conult the Gods Pleaure. From whence returning, after a
mall tay, Syimathres, the Provot, the ret keeping ilence, poke thus: We hall attend you, aid he, for o the Gods command: But withal, they forehow ome tumult and diorder that will happen in the Ceremonies, which yet hall have a happy Concluion, foramuch as a Member of your Body, which has long been lot, hall now be retor'd unought. Whatever misfortune hall happen, reply'd Perina, all things will do better for your Preence. As oon as Hydapes arrives, I hall inform you. There is no need of that, aid Syimathres, for his Letters will tell us that he will to morrow be here. Accordingly it happen'd; for before he was return'd to her Palace, a Meenger overtook her with the ame tydings. The publick Officers therefore haten the preparations for the Sacrifices, permitting only Male Perons to be preent: for the Worhip belonging to the Sun and Moon, the mot pure and chat Deities, they excluded Women from the Devotion, let any Pollution hould happen therein. The Prietes of the Moon was only permitted, which Office Perina herelf utain'd; as Hydapes, the King, was High Priet to the Sun, by the ancient Rites of the Country. Chariclea was likewie to be preent, though not as Prietes, but Victim. The people therefore were too impatient to wait till the day was come, but the Evening before came over the River of Atabora, ome by the Bridge; thoe that lived
at ditance, in Boats, which was eaily done, by reaon that each containing not above two or three at once, was made by plitting of a Cane Trunk into two parts, each half, without further labour, erving for a Boat.

The city Meroe is a Triangular Iland, made by the Confluence of the Nile, the Atabora and Alaobus: This inland Spot being miles in length, in Breadth, is furnih'd with Animals of vat bulk, the Elephants being bred there: And as it bears ome Plants naturally, is by Improvement upply'd with others: For beides Palm-trees of prodigious Tallnes, it alo bears Corn of uch height, that a Man on Hore-back, and ometimes on Camels, is hid in paing through: It is withal o fertile, that the Grain which is own comes up three hundred fold.

The people being thus tranported over the repective Rivers, they all met, and joint'd Congratulations to Hydapes, as it were to ome Deity; but thee however at a ditance: The Gymnoophits were admitted nearet to him, o as to join Hands, and alute him, before the Sacred ground. After them tood Perina, in the Entrance to the Temple. After they had here finih'd Adorations and Praie, they turn'd off to the Publick Sacrifices, placing themelves in Tabernacles that were before prepared. Thee were compoed of four Canes, newly cut down, each Cane being cut four quare, erv'd for a
Pillar; the Covering was made of everal Boughts, the fairet being Branches of the Palmtree. In another Tabernacle was placed the Images of their Gods, with Pictures of famous Perons, of Memnon, Pereus, and Andromeda; uppoed, by them, the Authors of their Royal Line. In Seats below at the Gymnoophits, with the Images of their Gods likewie over their Heads: Before them Bands of Souldiers, with Shields, to keep off the Pres of the people, and preerve room for the Solemnities. Hydapes, in few words, told the company his Service perform'd for the Commonwealth, and commanded the Sacrifices to begin. Three Altars were erected, two of them appertaining to the Sun and Moon, the third to Bacchus, et at ditance, to whom they offered all manner of living Creatures. Upon the Suns Altar were Sacrificed young Hores: A yoak of Oxen to the Moon, as being erviceable in Husbandry. In the mean time there was a voice heard among the Crowd, Let the uual Sacrifice of the Country, for our common afety, be firt made; and after that, the firt fruits of the War be offer'd. Hydapis undertanding them to mean humane Sacrifices, as was uual of Captives taken in Foreign Wars, igned to them with his hand, that they hould intantly have their Deire: Withal commanding the appointed Prioners to be brought forth: Among them came Theagenes and Chariclea, guarded, but not
bound. The ret were penive, only thee miled with chearful Countenance: Chariclea looking contantly on Perina, o that he was concern'd thereat, and aid, O Sir, What a Virgin have you commanded to be Sacrific'd? I never aw o great Beauty and Reolution. Her Age and Form extremely move me; if our Daughter had liv'd, he would have been now of her years: I wih to the Gods you could find ome means for her Delivery. I hould be pleas'd to have her an Attendant at my Table. Perhaps the unhappy Creature is a Grecian, for never was there uch a Beauty in Aegypt. She is a Greek, anwer'd he, by Father and Mother, whom he promis'd to produce in this preence, but how that can be poible, I do not imagine: But that he hould be deliver'd from this Sacrifice, I am ure is abolutely impoible, though I my elf could wih it, and am touch'd with Compaion for her. Our Laws exact a Man to be Sacrificed to the Sun, and a Virgin to the Moon; and he being firt taken, the people will not otherwie be atisfy'd: One help only remains, which is, if he prove not a pure Virgin, for uch the Sacrifice requires; and if o, he is uncapable of your Reception. Let her be o found, aid Perina, rather than Die; nor can he be much blamed, after uch Exile and Travels, epecially having Beauty, that could carce ecape Force and Rape. Hydapes then commanded Fire to be brought, by the Priets, from
the Temple, on which the Captives were to tred. Bars of Gold were heated over this Fire, and had this Virtue, That every unchate or perjured peron were burned with treading on them, but uch as were otherwie, receiv'd no harm. The Corrupted Perons they appointed to Bacchus, and other Gods. After Theagenes had trod thereon, and was found Chate, which was with wonder beheld, he being of uch Youth and Vigour; wherefore he was et apart, to be offer'd to the Sun. Then, aid he to Chariclea aide, is Death the Reward of Chatity in Aethiopia? But wherefore do you not now dicover your elf? What other time do you expect? or will you tay till the Knife has pierc'd our Throats? Therefore declare your elf: When you are known, 'tis poible I may be aved for your ake; at leat you will be afe your elf, which will be my atisfaction in Death.

She told him her Time was now at hand; and o, without command, put on her holy vetment, which he brought with her from Delphi, wrought with Gold, and et with Jewels; then with her hair dihevell'd, and, as it were, inpired with Divine fury, he leap'd upon the Coals, where he tood a long time without hurt, the Fire only giving addition to her Beauty; o that in that Holy Attire, he eems to the Beholders rather a Goddes than Mortal Woman: So that the mot Supertitious amongt them heartily wihed her Deliverance.
Perina, above all others, was troubled, and aid to Hydapes, How unhappy is this wretch that boats of a Chatity that is o fatal to her! What is there to be done for her Relief? You trouble me in vain, aid Hydapes; your pity is foolih on one that cannot be aved; and eems from the Beginning, for her Excellence, to be reerv'd for the Gods. Then turning to the Gymnoophits, he asked them, Why they did not begin? The Gods forbid, (anwer'd Syimathres, in Greek, that the people might not undertand him) for we have too much profan'd our Eyes and Ears with what is already done. As for our parts, we will retire into the Temple, being of opinion that thee humance Sacrifices are abomination to the Gods; we could alo wih no Blood of any other Creature to be hed on uch account, as knowing that Prayers and bloodles Offerings are mot grateful to the Divine Powers. However, your preence, Sir, is neceary, ince the cutomes of the Country exact it, and your people will not otherwie be atisfy'd. Yet you may be enible that there can be no good event, becaue the Gods, as you ee, protect the Strangers, by keeping the Fire from harming them. Having thus aid, he, with the ret of his Brotherhood, went away. Then Chariclea leaping from the Fire, ran to Syimathres, as he was going, and falling at his feet, (in pight of the Officers that would have hindred her, as uppoing he begg'd of him to
pare her Life) aying, Stay a while, mot wie of Men, for I have a Caue to plead before the King and Queen, and know that the Sentence on perons of my Birth, can only be given by you: They gladly heard her thus Speak, and Inform'd the King thereof. Hydapes miled, and askt what Judgment that could be? Or how he could come in any Danger from her? What he hall deliver may inform you, aid Syimathres. But take heed, aid he, you do not wrong our Majety, in making a King to Plead with a Prioner: Equity and Jutice, anwer'd Syimathres, are without ditinction of perons: The Law permits you, reply'd Hydapes, to determine Controveries, between the King and his Subjects, but not with Strangers. Wie and Jut Men, return'd Syimathres, are impartial in detribution of Equity. Well, quoth Hydapes, Let her Speak ince Syimathres deires it; though it be certain She will ay nothing to purpoe, only ome devied matter, as people in her Extremity are apt to do. Chariclea was the more encouraged when She heard Syimathres Name, he being the Peron that had firt taken her; and Ten years before, had given her to Charicles, when he went Embaador to Oroondates, and even then the Chief of the Gymnoophits. Chariclea knew him not by ight, as being eparated from him o young; yet She remembred his Name: Wherefore She hoped that he would now be her Advocate. Therefore
lifting up her Hands to Heaven, She aid aloud that all might hear; O Sun, thou Founder of my Pedigree, and all ye other Deities and Glorious Spirits: Bear Witnes that I hall deliver nothing but Truth. Then (turning towards the King) Do you command, Sir, Strangers or People of this Country to be offered? Strangers aid he? Then is it time for you to to provide other Victims; for I am of this Country, and Born your Subject. He admired hereat and aid, She poke fally: You wonder at mall things anwer'd Chariclea; I have yet greater to deliver, being not only of this Country, but of the Blood Royal. Hydapes at this turn'd aide with Scorn: She then proceeded aying, O Father do not thus depie and deny your own Daughter: The King then fell into Indignation and aid, Syimathres, how long will you abue our Patience? Is She not ditracted, or of inufferable Boldnes, thus to Claim Kindred with us, to ave her Life? You your elves know, that I was never o Fortunate as to have a Child. Wherefore take her away. No Man anwer'd he mut carry me away, without Command of my Judges: You your elf are now judged: Perhaps O King the Law of this Country uffers you to Kill Strangers; but neither that nor the Law of Nature to Kill your own Children; for that you are my Father the Gods hall prove this Day. All Controveries in Law, conit in Two Points; that is Writings,
and Confirmation by Witnees. I have both thee to prove my elf your Daughter: For a Witnes I will produce, no meaner a peron than the Judge himelf; I will likewie lay Writings before you, that hall fully expres my State. Having thus aid, She unfolded her Facia, and gave it to Perina: She no ooner fixt her Eyes thereon, but She was truck with terrour, and diabled from Speaking, at once trembling and glad for what She aw; epecially with the uddennes of the Chance. Yet was She afraid to expoe it, leat Hydapes hould give no credit thereunto; and conequently would inflict Punihment on her. He perceiving her o much concern'd, ask'd the meaning. Doth ought in that Writing trouble you? My Lord, King and Husband, aid She, I have nothing to ay; take and perue it your elf, which with ufficiently inform you: Having given it to him, She at down again penive.

When Hydapes had ran it over with the Gymnoophists, he marvelled extreamly, and the more to find Syimathres, much concern'd and abahed: Wherefore a Thouand thoughts roe in his mind, he looking often upon the Facia and often upon the Maid: Having throughly perued it, and found both her Expoition in her Infancy, with the Reaon of it: I know, aid he, that I once had a Daughter, but was told, and by Perina her elf, that She was Dead, but now perceive that She was expos'd in her Infancy.
But who was the Peron that found her, took her up, and bred her, I am yet to eek; or who it was that carry'd her into Aegypt. How may I be aur'd that this is She? And whether the Infant that was expos'd be not Dead, while he that found her, took advantage of his good Fortune; to impoe on our deire of having a Child, by propoing a Changeling intead; and Colouring the Cheat with this Facia.

Your firt doubt I can clear, anwer'd Syimathres: I was the Peron that found the expoed Child, bred her for ome time, and carry'd her with me to Aegypt; when on Embay you ent me thither. You know well, that our order dare not peak untruth: I likewie know the Facia to be the ame by the Royal Characters, and impoible to be counterfeited; even you your elf may know Perina's Hand-writing therein: But there were other Tetimonals found with this, and by me deliver'd to the Peron to whom I gave her, the Man a Greek, and of eeming Honety. They are alo preerv'd, aid Chariclea, and produc'd the Bracelets. Perina was now more atonihed: Hydapes asking her if he knew them? She anwer'd he did? And that this Examination would more properly be made at Home; and not in o publick an Audience. Then was Hydapes more anxious than before: Then aid Chariclea, thee Signals were my Mothers, but this, Sir, is properly your own; giving him the Ring with the
Pantarbe-Stone. Hydapes knew it, it being the ame he gave to Perina, on his Contract with her. I know thee tokens, aid he to Chariclea; but not that you came by them, as being my Daughter; for not to init on other Doubts, your Colour is trange and never een in Aethiopia. The Infant was alo white which I carry'd away (aid Syimathres) beides the time of her Age agrees, it being now Seventeen Years ince he was expos'd. Beide I perceive the ame Lutre of her Eyes, the ame Fair Lineaments, Complexion, and unparrallell'd Beauty. You peak well, aid Hydapes, and rather like a Patron, than Judge of her Caue; but take heed, leat in favouring her, you bring quetion of Scandal upon my Wife: It being impoible, that we being both Aethiops, hould have a Fair Child. We call him the bet Judge anwer'd Syimathres, who is a Patron of Equity: But how do we eem more, to Patronize the Maid than you? For your Cenure we are not concern'd, whoe buines is more to approve our elves to the Gods than to Men: So that is enough for us to atisfy our own Conciences. As to your Doubt concerning her Colour, the Facia it elf anwers it: That Perina conceiv'd a Daughter of this Complexion; by looking on the Picture of Andromeda, in your Bedchamber: If you doubt the likenes, the Picture is here at hand, compare them together, you will ee no difference between the Living and Painted Virgin.

When they were et together, the Beholders were urpriz'd at the Reemblance, which rais'd a great noie; thoe who tood nearer, informing them that were at more ditance: So that Hydapes himelf could no longer doubt, but tood Speechles with Joy and Admiration. At lat there is one thing yet wanting: O Syimathres, aid he, there was a certain Speck or Mole above my Daughters Right Elbow: which was found alo on Chariclea.

Perina could no longer contain her elf, but leaping from the Throne, threw her Arms about her Neck, weeping for Joy, and almot ready to faint away. The ame Parental Affection eiz'd Hydapes, though with more manly Government, yet he alo embraced her, and not without Tears. After this, waving his Hand, he ilenced the buzzing amongt the Croud. O you that are preent, aid he, you have een and heard me this day prov'd a Father beyond all expectation. Yet uch is my regard to you, that waving the care of Succeion and Paternal Joy, I am for your akes ready to deliver her up to the Gods in Sacrifice: For though I ee you alo concern'd for the Misfortune of o fair a Virgin, yet whether you will or no, I mut perform the Cutom of our Country, and prefer the publick Interet to private Affection.

Having thus poken, he took Chariclea by the Hand, as to lead her to the Altar; at which
the whole multitude et up a Cry, not uffering him to lead her one tep forward, but calling out ave the Maid, ave her whom the Gods would have preerv'd: We return you our thanks, our Laws are atisfy'd. We acknowledge you our King, do you acknowledge your elf a Father. There is no man than will lay Hands on her; you that are Father of your Country, be Father of your own Houe: Thee and many more uch Expreions were utter'd; downright reiting his Propoal, and aying, the Gods would be atisfy'd with other Offerings. Hydapes uffer'd himelf to be overcome, and took pleaure in the Violence.

Standing therefore next to Chariclea, dearet, aid he, that you are our Daughter, the proofs are ufficient; but who is this Youth, who was taken Prioner with you, and is now et before the Altar? or how could you call him Brother, when you were together brought into my Preence at Syene? For how hall he be found our Son? For Perina has but once been deliver'd, and that only of your elf. Chariclea bluhing and cating her Eyes on the ground, I feign'd him indeed to be my Brother in that Exigence, but who he is, he himelf will better inform you. Do you therefore take place by your Mother on the Tribunal; filling her with greater joy, than when he firt Bore you; entertain her with the Hitory of your Affairs, while I take care for the Sacrifices, and chooe ome
Virgin to be made a Victim in your tead, with the Grecian Youth.
Chariclea could care forbear crying out at the mention hereof, but governing her Affection; once more attempted him in thee words:

O Sir, there is no need to eek for another of my Sex, ince the people have excued me: But if you mut, there mut alo another Youth be found, or if that be not done, no other Maid, for I my elf mut alo die: For the Gods have determin'd me to Live and Die with him.

Hydapes not yet undertanding her, aid, I commend this Humanity in you Daughter, towards a Grecian and Stranger, the Companion of your Exile; but it is impoible to exempt him from Sacrifice without Violation of our Religion, neither will the people dipene therewith. O King, anwer'd he, if I may not call you Father, if the Mercy of the Gods has pared my Body, the ame Clemency will pace my Soul: But if the Detinies mut have it o, that this Youth mut needs adorn the Ceremonies, grant me yet one Requet, that he may be kill'd by my Hand.

What Contradictions are thee (aid Hydapes) the Peron whom but now as a Friend you endeavour'd to ave, you now beg leave to Kill with your own Hand as an Enemy. I ee, but grant it might, you may not be permitted, it being only lawful for the Priets of the Sun and Moon, and amongt them only the High Priet,
that has a Wife and Prietes, who has a Husband. All this can be no hinderance reply'd Chariclea.

Hydapes conidering her late proof of Virgin Etate by enduring the Fire, thought her dicompos d in her Senes, and deired his Wife to dicoure with her apart, to bring her to her elf. In the mean time, I will give Audience to the Embaadours that wait to congratulate our Victory; and till another Virgin be Elected in her tead. Having thus poken, he acended a Chair of State not far ditant from the Tabernacle, commanding the Embaadours to come before him with their Preents. The Mater of Ceremonies Harmonious, ask'd if all hould be admitted together, or if they hould come ditinctly, according to the Dignity of their repective Nations: In order, aid Hydapes. Shall Merabus your Brothers Son come firt, aid the Officer? Stupid Man, aid Hydapes, why did you not intantly inform me of his Arrival, whom you know to be no Legate but a King, Son to my Brother, Heir to his Throne, and my own adopted Succeour? As oon therefore as Merabus came near his Preence, a Manly Youth and tall of Stature urpaing all about him, the Aethiopian Guards with repect, made way for him.

Hydapes came down from his Throne to meet him, embracing him with paternal Courteie, and aying; you come in good time, my Son, to ait our Triumphant Rites, and alo your
own Nuptial Ceremonies: Since the Gods, who were Authors of our Love, have, beyond all expectation, produced a Daughter for us, and for you a Bride. Of this affair more at leiure; at preent, if you have any thing to mention on behalf of your Country, declare it. Meraebus at mention of a Wife, bluhed o as to have it perceiv'd through the duskines of this Complexion. After a little paue, Other perons, aid he, will preent you with the bet Rareties of their Country to adorn your Triumph, but I, with what I judg'd mot uitable to your Martial Temper, for a Preent offer you a Swordman, inur'd to Blood, and exercied in Arms, o that none dare oppoe him; in Wretling, Whirl-bat, or any other Warlike-Exercie, of uch Skill and Strength, that none are able to contend with him. Accordingly he beckon'd to have him brought in preence.

He therefore cam forward, and was of that tature, that when he tooped to alute Hydapes Knees, he till eem'd tall as any of the ret. Immediately, without waiting for Command, he tripped himelf before all the company, challenging any peron to ingle Combat. When none appear'd, though the King often ummon'd, by the Herald; You hall receive, aid Hydapes to him, a Preent fit for your Courage and Bulk; withal commanding an Elephant, of vat Magnitude, to be brought forth for him: He willingly receiv'd it. The people,
when the Beat appear'd, laughed extremely at the pleaant Humour of the King. With this Deriion taking Revenge on him whom they did not dare to encounter. After Meraebus, were admitted the Embaadours from the Seri, bringing two Vetments, made by Inects of their Country, the one of Tyrian Dye, the other Snowy White. Having tender'd their preents, they were rewarded by the King, with Releae of certain Prioners in his cutody.

The Arabian Legates came next, with Spices and Perfumes, the product of their Country, in uch quantities, that they perfum'd all the Air around. After them, the Trogloditae, with Gold, and Griffins with Golden Bridles. Then the Blemmi, with Arrows made of Dragons Bones, and made up in circular form: And thee, O King, aid they, we preent you with les cotly than others Offering, but of Service to you againt the Perians on the Rivers Bank. They are more eteem'd by us, aid Hydapes, than o many Talents of Gold, withal inviting them to make what Demands they pleaed. When they requeted abatement of Tribute, he releaed it to them for ten years ucceively.

When thee had thus made their Complements (mot of them being remunerated by the King with richer gifts than what they brought) in the lat place came the Axiomati, who indeed paid no Tribute, but were in League with him. They alo brought Preents; amongt others,
an Animal of trange Form and Nature, of the ize of a Camel, but of potted Skin, and cover'd with Scales. His hinder parts and Belly like a Lion, his fore Legs and Shoulders exceeding other Members; a long Neck, and waxing very lender, from o large a Body: His Head reembling a Camel, in bignes twice exceeding the Lybian Otrich, horribly rowling his Eyes, that eem'd as if enlam'd with Red Lead. His Gate was till more trange, being like no other Animals, but moving the two Legs on his Right Side together, and then thoe on his Left, carrying forward firt the one Side of his Body and then the other. Of temper o tame and gentle by ue, that his mater led him up and down, with a mall Cord in his Hand. When this Creature appear'd, the multitude were amaz'd, and gave him from his Various Shape, the name of Camelopardalis. He was the occaion of a great Diorder which thus happen'd.

There were a Yoak of Bulls placed before the Altar of the Moon, four White Hores at the Altar of the Sun, ready for the Sacrifice. The Hores pying this trange Monter, were o terrify'd that two of them broke out of their hands that held them, as alo one of the Bulls, and ran out wild. They could not however break through the pres, the Souldiers joining in a Ring, and with their Shields obtructing their paage. They were at once the occaion of great Laughter and Terrour; the perons at
ditance houting to ee others born down, and trodden by them: All things were overturn'd that tood in their way. The Clamour was o great, that Perina and Chariclea, open'd the Curtain to look out. At this time Theagenes, whether out of his Natural Vigour, or Inpiration from the Gods, eeing his Keepers dipers'd with the fright, tarted up from the Altar where he kneel'd, and natching from thence a cleft tick, leap'd on the Back of one of the Hores that were left, and uing his Main for a Bridge, forc'd him on, and turn'd the Bull that had broke looe. The Spectators at firt though that he intended to make his ecape, and et up a cry that they hould not uffer him to pas. But they oon perceived he had no uch intention: For puruing the Bull, and catching hold of his Tail, he drove him before him, dextrouly avoiding his hort Turns. With this management he o brake his Mettle, that he now uffer'd him to ride ide by ide to him, inomuch that the Sweat of each Beat mingled with the other.

They ran with their Heads o even together, that the people, at ditance, took the Hore and Bull for one Creature, and applauded Theagenes as the Author of a Miracle. Thus were all the Multitude employ'd. Chariclea in the mean time look'd on with horrour, not knowing what he intended and fear'd more for his danger than for her own Life when lately at Stake. Perina perceiv'd her
concern, and aid to her, You are troubled, Daughter, for this Stranger; I confes I cannot my elf help pitying his Youth, but Yet I hope he will ecape this hazard, and be preerv'd afe for the Sacrifice. How aburd is it (anwer'd Chariclea) to wih him to ecape Death, that he may Dye! But Oh Mother, if you can ave his Life, you will do a thing mot grateful to me! Perina partly upecting her paion, aid, Though it be impoible for me to preerve him, yet take Courage to acquaint me with your concern with this Stranger; if it has not been altogether vertuous, yet a Mothers kindnes knows how to indulge the frailty of a Child. Chariclea then wept bitterly, and cry'd out, 'Tis the extremity of my Misfortune to peak to undertanding perons, yet not be undertood; but mut be forced to an open and gros Confeion.

As he was now going to reveal the whole matter, he was once more hindred by a new hout amongt the people. Theagenes having now fronted the Bull, quitted his Hore, leaped on the Bulls Neck, and claping his Arms round the roots of his Horns, his Hands faten'd in his Fore-head Taock, his Face lying between the Horns, the ret of his Body hanging with all its weight, down over the Beats right Shoulder, inomuch that he was often trod upon; yet he o incumbred his paage by this means, and tired him, that directly over againt the place where Hydapes ate, he tumbled down on his Head, but o
that his Hoofs were turn'd uppermot, and his Horns truck into the Sand, o that his Head eem'd fat rooted to the Earth; his Legs all the while prawling in the Air.
