The agenes alo till held him down with his Left Hand, his Right lifted up towards Heaven; and thus with generous Countenance urvey'd Hydapes and the Company; provoking them to Laughter with the pectacle; the Bull all the while with Bellowing, like a Martial Trumpet, ounding his Conquet: The people anwer'd with houts, and promicuouly gabbling, extoll'd him to the Skies. The Kings Servants, therefore, as they were order'd, ome led Theagenes to the King, others fatning Ropes to the Bulls Head, led him with the Hores once more to the Alar. Hydapes beginning ome dicoure with Theagenes, the people who were pleas'd with his Peron from the firt minute they aw him, but not tupify'd at his Strength and Courage, in the lat place envying the Honour given to Meraebus his Aethiopian Wretler, with one Cry, demanded that he who had received the Elephant, hould engage in ingle Combat with him that conquer'd the Bull. When they had long preed for it, Hydapes at lat conented. The Aethiop was immediately put into the middle of the Circle, ternly and proudly urveying all around him, tretching himelf, and taking lofty vat teps, compaing an Ell at every tride.

When he was come up before the Council, Hydapes poke to Theagenes in Greek; It is the peoples deires that you undertake this Combat: Let is be o, aid Theagenes, But after what manner? Wretling, aid Hydapes: Why not rather with Swords, aid Theagenes, by which ome Honour might be gain'd; at leat, with my Death, content Chariclea, who, I find, conceals our affairs, and forakes me at the lat. What you mean by mentioning Chariclea, aid Hydapes, I know not; but you mut Wretle, and not fight with Swords; for we may not uffer any Blood to be hed before that of Sacrifice. He undertanding Hydapes's meaning, that he fear'd let he hould be kill'd before he dy'd in Sacrifice; You do well, aid he, to reerve me for the Gods. With thee words he put himelf in puture: fixing his Feet firmly to the ground, his whole Body put in the bet order: Thus he impatiently waited the aault of his Adverary.

The Aethiop eeing this, with a look of Deriion and Indignation mixt together, ran furiouly upon him, hitting Theagenes on the Neck with his Elbow, as heavily as if he had truck him with a Leaver; then drawing back, laughed out aloud at his own performance.

Theagenes, who was vers'd from his Childhood in Exercies, knew that uch robutuous Strength, wanot directly to be engag'd, but deluded by Art, expos'd the other ide of his Neck for a econd blow, which the Barbarian repeated,
and then withdrew as before: He therefore now depiing him, and coming on the third time more carelesly, Theagenes lipping under his Elbow, and claping his Arms round his wat, which he was carce able to embrance, cat him quite over his Shoulders, and pitcht him all on a Heap, with his Head firt to the ground, to the hazard of his Neck. The people now Shouted louder than before; nor could Hydapes longer contain himelf, but leaping down from his Throne, cry'd; O hard neceity of Law, what a Noble Youth are we compell'd to detroy. Then calling him to him, aid, it only now remains, that thou be Crown'd for the Sacrifice. This Famous though unerviceable Victory, deerves a Crown: That I hould et you free is not in my Power, but as much as I can do in favour of you, I will; o that if you have any requet to make to me before you Die, propoe it. With thee words, he put a Golden wreath on his Head, beet with Diamonds. Grant me therefore, aid Theagenes, what I hall requet, ince you have promis'd it. If I may not ecape being acrific'd, at leat let me be Kill'd, by the Hand of your new found Daughter.

Hydapes was tung at this motion, reflecting on Chariclea's requet, which was like this, yet thought it not worth his while, nicely to earch the matter: Thoe things, O Stranger, aid he, which were in my Power, I commanded you to ask, and promis'd that I would grant: The
Law exacts, That the Slayer of the Sacrifice, be a Wife and no Virgin. But he has a Husband, anwer'd Theagenes: You rave, aid Hydapes, and thee are words of a peron under Conternation of Death. The Fire has prov'd her free from Man: Unles you call Meraebus here her Husband, nor can I gues how you could come to urnize o much, neither is he yet her Husband, but in Intention only: Neither hall he ever be, aid Theagenes, if I know any thing of Chariclea's mind; or as Divine Sacrifice, can fore-hew any future event. But Sacrifices, aid Meraebus, can give no Divination till they are Slain, and their Intrals laid open. Wherefore, O Father, you have rightly Spoken, that the Stranger raves with apprehenion of Death. Therefore if you pleae, let ome body take him to the Altar. Theagenes was accordingly led away: But Chariclea, who was a little relieved at his Victory, and conceiv'd better hopes; when he aw him led again to the Altar, relaps'd into Sorrow. Perina comforted her, aying, it was yet poible for him to be recu'd, if he would plainly and fully declare, what he demanded to know. Chariclea found there was no longer time for delay, and therefore freely began, to tell the principal parts of her Story. Hydapes in the mean time, ask'd by his Officers, if there were any of the Embaadours yet unanwer'd? Only the Syeneans, anwer'd Harmonias, who wait with Letters from Oroondates.
They are newly arriv'd, and bring matters of ome moment: Let them alo appear, aid Hydapes.
Accordingly they were brought, preenting the Letters which Hydapes read, of thee Contents:

opener.salute: To the Merciful and Fortunate King of the Aethiopians, Oroondates, Deputy to the Great King.

body.p: SInce after Conquet over me in Field, you again overcame me in Clemency, retoring me to my Office, it will not eem trange, if you farther grant me a mall requet: A certain Virgin, as he was led along, became your Prioner of War; that he was by you ent into Aethiopia, I am inform'd: He I intreat you to restore to me, not only for her own ake, but her Fathers, for whom I would preerve her. He has travelled far in earch of her, and was taken Prioner during the War by my Garrion at Elephantina: He has therefore deired me to recommend him to your Clemency. You have him therefore amongt other Legates, uch a Peron as by his Apect may be known to be Noble, and deerve what the hall beg at your hands. Send him therefore back to me pleaed, and rejoice the heart of a diconolate Father.

div.p:
When Hydapes had read this, he ask'd which was the Peron amongt the Leagates, who was
mention'd in the Letters, who is in earch of his Daughter: When they hew'd him the Old man, O Stranger, aid Hydapes, I will do all that Oroondates has d eired: Ten Virgin Captives only we brought away, and whereas one of them is known not to be her, do you urvey the other Nine; and if you find her, take her. The Old Man fell down to embrace his feet, and urveying the Virgins, as they were brought before him, found not her amongt them; therefore he orrowfully aid, None of thee, O King, is he. I was ready to gratify you, aid Hydapes, you mut blame your fortune if you cannot find her; for you are free to atisfie your elf that none other came with our Camp.

When the Old Man had bent his brows, and wept a while, he lifted up his Eyes, urveying the Company around, and of a udden ran forth as if he had been mad. When he was come up to the Altar, taking off his Cloak, and twiting it like a Rope, he cat it about Theagenes his Neck, and cry'd out in all their hearing, I have found thee, O my Enemy, I have gotten thee, thou michievous and accured Man! The Officers would have taken him off, but he would not quit his hold, till he had leave to bring him before Hydapes and the Council; to whom he addret himelf in this manner, O King, aid he, this Man is the Robber that has taken away my Daughter even from the Temple of Apollo, and now, like a pious peron, he kneels before
the Altar. All were atonih'd at what he aid, not undertanding the Words, but urpriz'd with the Action and Manner.

Hydapes commanding him to peak more plainly, Charicles (for he was the Old Man) conceal'd the Truth concerning Chariclea, fearing let if he were dead by the way, he hould be troubled by her true Parents. But he thus briefly utter'd what could little harm him. I had a Daughter, O King, if you had een how beautiful and urpaing in Widom, you would not blame my Sorrow. She led her Life in Virginity, and was Prietes to Diana, which is worhipp'd at Delphos. That Maid, this bold Thealian, has toln out of the Temple of Apollo, while officiating a Holy Embaage to that City; during the Celebration of our Fetival. He mut therefore be cenur'd, to have offended your God the Sun (who is all one with our Apollo, and done Sacrilege on his Temple. A fale Priet of Memphis, was alo his Companion in this hainous Fact. I went to Memphis in earch of them, which I uppos'd to be the place, whither Calairis would go: When I arrived there, I found that he was Dead, and was inform'd by his Son Thyamis, of all that had befaln to my Daughter; wherefore you hall well perform the part of a King, in accepting the Deputies requet on my behalf. Here he held his peace, and wept mot bitterly. What ay you to this, aid Hydapes, turning to Theagenes?
All that he has laid to my Charge (anwer'd Theagenes) is true: As to him, I am a Robber, but to you, I have perform'd good Service. Retore therefore, (aid Hydapes) what is not your own, to become a pure Sacrifice to the Gods. Not he that did the wrong (aid Theagenes) ought to make retitution; but he that has the benefit: Seeing therefore you have her, do you retore her, Chariclea is the Peron, whom he alo will own to be your Daughter. No man could longer contain himelf: Syimathres kept ilence along time, notwithtanding he knew the whole Mytery, till it were bolted our by little and little: Then coming forth, he Embraced Charicles, and aid, your Adoptive Daughter, whom I once deliver'd to you, is well, found, and prov'd to be Daughter to the King, which you your elf, alo well know. Chariclea alo ran forth from the Tabernacle, like one ditracted, without regard to her quality, or years, and falling at Charicles his Feet, aid, O Father, no les dear to me, than my natural Parent, take what revenge you pleae upon me, notwithtanding, all the excue that I have of the Gods, Commands for what I did.

Perina alo turning to Hydapes, aid, aure your elf, Sir, that it is o, This young Grecian is your Daughters Husband. The people were overjoy'd at the Dicovery, though they imperfectly, undertood it, or rather were Divinely
inpired, with the knowledge thereof. Contraries were reconcil'd to attend this Wonder; Sorrow being joyn'd with Mirth, and Tears with Smiles: The cruel Slaughter, which was every moment expected, turn'd into a Holy and Bloodles Sacrifice.
O Wiet of Men, aid Hydapes to Syimathres, intruct us what we are to do? to decline the Sacrifice of the Gods, is Sacrilege, and to Kill the Innocent, and uch as they favour, Impious.

Then Syimathres (not in the Grecian Language as before) but in Aethiopian, to be undertood of all, thus expret himelf. O King, aid he, Darknes is ometimes thrown over the mot decerning Undertandings, to produce the greater joy. You ought long ince, to have been enible, That the Gods would not permit this Sacrifice, reolving to make your Daughter Chariclea, happy in all her deires; accordingly they have hither brought her Foter-father, from the midt of Greece: They have likewie ent Frights and Diorder to diturb the Sacrifices, as ignifying, that more agreeable Offerings hould be made: They have latly hewn you, a Bridegroom for your Daughter; this Grecian Youth, whom they have with Miracles deliver'd. Wherefore let us obey their pleaure, and no more offend them with humane Victims, whoe bet Sacrifices, are Prayers and Obedience.

Syimathres having aid this with an audible
voice, Hydapes took Theagenes and Chariclea by the Hand, aying, you who are preent, and ee that thee things are come to pas, by the direction of the Divine Powers, whoe will it is impoible to reit, ince you alo eem to approve their Choice, bear Witnes to the Nuptials, which I here ratiie; which we will farther confirm by Holy Rites, and o let us fall to Worhiping our Gods. The whole Army, with redoubled Shouts and Clapping their Hands, expret their conent to the match.

Hydapes then approach'd the Altars, and ready to begin the Solemnities, aid, O Sun our Lord, and Moon our Patrones: Since Theagenes and Chariclea, are by your good Will, declared Husband and Wife, I doubt not, but you will accept their Offerings, and uffer then to do Sacrifice in our Steads. Having thus aid, he took the Mitres, the Enigns of Priethood, from his own and Perina's Head, placing them on Theagenes and Chariclea. When this was done, Charicles call'd to mind, the Oracle deliver'd to him at Delphi, was now compleated, which foretold concerning this Young Pair, that they hould arrive at a Soil parch'd with Heat;

q.l: Where their prov'd Vertue, jut rewards hould wear,
And Snowy Wreaths from Sun-burnt Temples bear.

div.p:
Being thus Crown'd with Mitres, and veted with Priethood by Hydapes, the Ceremonies
being now finih'd with lighted Torches by their ides, they were Born in Chariots, with Conorts of Flutes and other Intruments: Theagenes with Hydapes, Syimathres in another Chariot with Charicles, Perina in another with Chariclea: With Muick and Congratulations towards the City: Where the more retir'd Ceremonies appertaining to the Nuptials were to be perform'd.
